HEADLINE: The News Faces a Deadline, but the 2 Sides Aren't Even Negotiating

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
The Daily News and leaders of its nine striking unions are locked in a new dispute that has stopped all negotiations, even though the clock is ticking on a management threat to close the paper unless the strike is settled or the paper is sold.
The News announced 10 days ago that it had filed formal notice as required by Federal law that it intended to close the paper in 60 days. Citing mounting losses from the strike, The News said that only a prompt settlement or a sale could prevent the paper's closing. 
 Union leaders say they have not scheduled negotiating sessions because The News's management has refused to delay the time-consuming discovery process on a lawsuit against the unions charging illegal secondary boycott and intimidation of advertisers. The unions have said their actions, like distributing leaflets at stores of advertisers, have been legal.
James Hoge, publisher of The News, said he would not delay the discovery process because union violence and intimidation against the paper's advertisers had not stopped.
The resulting deadlock has raised concern among some union members that their leadership might not be moving fast enough toward serious negotiations, regardless of the burden imposed by the discovery process.
"We feel like this is the moment of truth, and we want to make sure we don't miss any opportunity to prevent the closing of the paper," said Tom Robbins, a striking investigative reporter who is a member of the Newspaper Guild strike committee.
George E. McDonald, president of the Allied Printing Trades Council, the umbrella union organization, said that he was not ruling out negotiating but that doing so while trying to satisfy the voluminous demands for information that were part of the discovery process "makes it harder for us."
As of yesterday, no striking unions hadscheduled negotiating sessions with The News.
Mr. Hoge said the paper had put all the unions on notice yesterday that they must act soon or risk having no role in what will happen. He said unions must contact News management by the close of business next Tuesday "if you intend to bargain over the decision of closure or sale."
The maneuvering by The News and the unions as the final deadline nears is heavily influenced by a desire both share not to be blamed if The News is closed.
The News is liable for an estimated $100 million in lifetime job guarantees that could be nullified if the paper is closed for legitimate economic reasons but not if closing the paper is unnecessary or artificially spurred by News management. Legal action would probably be needed to resolve the issue.
In addition, a host of lawsuits filed by both sides remain outstanding, and it is in the interests of both sides to portray the other as unreasonable and unwilling to do what is required in a good-faith effort to save the paper.
For instance, while Mr. Hoge has been unwilling to suspend the discovery process, he has said he is willing to negotiate "any time, any day, any night, week or weekends, without advance notice."
On the union side, Jay Mazur, president of the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union, said yesterday that more than a dozen unions were mounting a $75,000 advertising campaign aimed at the Chicago-based Tribune Company, which owns The News.
In announcing the campaign, Mr. Mazur said The News was "part of the soul of the city" that the Tribune Company seemed determined to kill by refusing to bargain in earnest. The campaign's headline: "Save New York's Hometown Paper -- Settle or Sell."
Individuals on both sides say on a not-for-quotation basis that they think prospects of a negotiated settlement are small.
But Mr. McDonald, the allied unions' leader, said yesterday that Mr. Hoge had told him The News intended to present unions with a revised proposal. Mr. Hoge declined to discuss any aspect of negotiations.
Barry F. Lipton, president of the Newspaper Guild, said The News had sent him a proposed change in the language of the management rights portion of the contract. He characterized the change as a basis for further negotiations but not a significant change in itself.
 
Possible Shift on Clause
 From the beginning of negotiations, The News has demanded a contractual "management rights" clause that would give the Tribune Company the power to determine staffing, overtime and many other items that have previously been negotiated item by item. News management has said such authority is essential to making the paper profitable, but union leaders have said such blanket control would break the unions.
An article in yesterday's Guild Strike News said the new language proposed by The News would grant blanket management rights "unless expressly prohibited elsewhere in the contract."
The new language raises the prospect that The News might be willing to agree to a management rights clause tempered and limited elsewhere in the contract in ways that would make the concept more acceptable to unions.
A person who spoke on condition of anoynmity and who is associated with Robert Maxwell, the British communications magnate, said that Mr. Maxwell's interest in buying The News remains "very deep."
"He won't do it at any price, but it's important to him," said the person.

HEADLINE: $6 BILLION DEFICIT IS SEEN BY CUOMO FOR NEXT BUDGET

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 24

 BODY:
 Gov. Mario M. Cuomo announced today that he expected New York State's budget gap to balloon to $6 billion, or one-fifth of the state budget, in the next fiscal year and that the state would have to borrow $900 million to close this year's budget deficit.
Mr. Cuomo warned that it would take Draconian measures like reducing the welfare grant and laying off hundreds of state troopers to close the gap purely with spending cuts. He said he had ruled out many of those options, thus suggesting that he was trying to pave the way for possible tax increases. 
 The widening budget gap resulted from "a precipitous decline" in state tax revenues, caused by the national recession, Mr. Cuomo said. He said this and other factors would cause the state to finish the current fiscal year, which ends on March 31, with a $900 million deficit in its $29.2 billion budget.
For the third consecutive year, Mr. Cuomo said, the state will have to eliminate a deficit at the end of the year through short-term borrowing, a step he had hoped to avoid.
 
'A Lot of Complaining'
 That $900 million will be added to a $5 billion deficit that the Governor said today that he envisioned for the new fiscal year, starting April 1.
Although Mr. Cuomo used his news conference today to prepare the state for excruciating fiscal pain, he vowed that his mission of protecting the defenseless and promoting free enterprise would not be eviscerated.
"There will be a lot of complaining and a lot of screaming, from the judiciary, from the workers and everybody else, but still the strength of this state will be evident," the Governor said.
He is not required to disclose his budget proposal for the 1991-92 fiscal year until Feb. 1, and he revealed few details today. But people in his administration, while stressing that many decisions had yet to be made, said tax increases might be used to close about one-fourth of the $6 billion gap.
The measures being considered, they said, include creating a statewide value tax on motor vehicles, increasing the gasoline tax and continuing to delay a scheduled reduction in personal income tax rates.
Mr. Cuomo said today that he hoped to avoid rate increases in broad-based taxes like the personal income tax and sales tax, which he said would put New York at a competitive disadvantage with neighboring states. But he said he had not ruled out expanding the base of the sales tax, as was done this year.
In announcing his projections of this year's deficit and next year's shortfall, Mr. Cuomo added his voice to the cries of fiscal anguish that are resounding through state capitols and city halls across the Northeast.
The Governors of New Jersey and Connecticut have announced sizable gaps in their budgets for this year and next year. And Mayor David N. Dinkins presented a budget plan last week for New York City that would close a $2.2 billion gap by reducing the city's work force by 25,000 employees and imposing $580 million in new or higher taxes.
 
Inextricably Connected
 The city and state budgets are inextricably connected, and Mr. Dinkins said today that he was "very, very concerned" about the impact that the state budget gap would have on the city.
Although Mr. Cuomo and the Legislature trimmed this year's state budget by $1 billion just last month, the Governor said the sharp decline in state revenues would make it necessary to borrow about $900 million. That would exceed the $775 million borrowed in the 1989-90 fiscal year and the $460 million borrowed in the 1988-89 fiscal year.
With just over two months remaining in the fiscal year, Mr. Cuomo said that the state budget was virtually depleted and that the budget could not be balanced through spending cuts.
When the Governor proposed to eliminate the $1 billion shortfall late last year, he pledged to do so without borrowing. "Deficit notes would simply add to next year's substantial budget problems," he said in November.
He said today that he had kept that pledge but asserted that he never promised not to borrow if an additional budget gap emerged. "I did it and then you got a new deficit," he said. "I didn't say, 'Even if on the day before the end of the year, there's another $900 million, I'll do it again.' "
This year's borrowing will have to be repaid with interest in the next fiscal year, thus deepening next year's budget gap. A budget gap is the difference between a government's anticipated revenues and the cost of maintaining its existing programs.
 
'Unwelcome News'
 State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, a frequent critic of past state borrowing practices, called the announcement of the deficit "unwelcome news." But he said, "It is apparent to everyone concerned with the state's fiscal condition that the use of deficit notes, rather than rolling liabilities over into the next fiscal year, is the most prudent course of the choices available."
Several fiscal analysts who monitor the state's finances said Mr. Cuomo had little choice but to borrow at such a late date. But they expressed concern that the deficit had not been avoided through larger reductions in spending last year. Signs that the budget gap was growing emerged almost immediately after the Legislature finished cutting the budget in December.
"They could have leapfrogged the problem for a change instead of being in the position once again where they have to chase their tail at the end of the year," said Cynthia Green, an analyst for the Citizens Budget Commission, a watchdog group financed by businesses.
A significant factor in the size of next year's gap was the state's reliance in this year's budget on $1.9 billion in nonrecurring revenue measures, like sales of state property and raids on reserve funds. Mr. Cuomo said there would be few of the so-called one shots in this year's budget. "I'm looking for them," he said. "There aren't many around."
 
To Be Fairly Distributed
 The Democratic Governor pledged that the budget cuts he would announce next week would be fairly distributed. He has said no program will be spared, although he has exempted financing for AIDS programs.
But Mr. Cuomo also has said he plans this year to establish special funds, with dedicated revenue sources, for environmental and transportation projects. And he will come under heavy pressure to maintain two programs, Liberty scholarships and a child health insurance plan, that he considers centerpieces of his social agenda. Both are scheduled to begin this year.
A countervailing pressure may come from the Republican-led State Senate. "I don't think we'll have any problem accepting the Governor's estimate of the size of the gap," said John E. McArdle, a spokesman for the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino. "But it may be predicated on a level of spending that we have concern with."

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: IRAQ;
Iraq Closes Border With Jordan, Cutting Off Escape for Foreigners

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Iraq was reported today to have barred war refugees from entering Jordan, blocking the major escape route for hundreds of thousands of foreigners trapped behind the lines and prey to deprivation and allied bombardment.
Because of deteriorating conditions in Baghdad, where water, food and fuel are said to be scarce, the Iraqi move could lead to a "large-scale human tragedy if people do not get out," a Western diplomat said. 
 Travelers from the border area also said they had seen little evidence of the tanker trucks carrying crude oil from Iraq to Jordan that provide this economically crippled country with the only petroleum supplies available to it.
Jordan has told the United States and its allies that while it is trying to enforce the international trade embargo on Iraq, it cannot do without Iraqi supplies of crude oil. Until today, scores of Jordanian tanker trucks plied the pot-holed blacktop connecting Jordan and Iraq.
A lone trucker at the Ruweishid border post said today that he had been told by the Iraqi authorities that his safety could not be guaranteed, travelers reported. Iraq has suspended the sale of gasoline to civilians as it seeks to marshal its resources for the war with the United States and its allies.
International relief agencies had been expecting a flow of hundreds of thousands of fugitives, most of them from other third world countries, as the allied bombardment intensified. Several hundred have already arrived, but many more were reported today to be stranded on the Iraqi side of the frontier after the border was closed to traffic bound for Jordan.
 
Iran Is the Only Exit Route
 Jordanian officials and diplomats here said Iraq had not explained its decision, and it was not clear how long the border closing would be enforced. The move leaves Iran as the only exit route from Iraq.
Arab diplomats said the Iraqi action could reflect a concern that the images and accounts of refugees arriving from Baghdad would leave the impression that Iraq is being beaten.
In its official pronouncements, the Baghdad radio continued to rebut allied and Israeli assertions that American missiles had foiled the latest Iraqi missile attacks and saying targets in Israel and Saudi Arabia had been hit.
The Iraqi press agency also reported that President Saddam Hussein toured front-line positions on Wednesday, despite heavy allied bombing. "After giving him a report on the condition of the mother of battles, the commanders said that because of cowardice and fear of combat, the enemy tried to avoid establishing any serious contact by only bombing from high altitudes," the agency said.
The Baghdad radio also accused American airmen of causing a huge oil slick in the Persian Gulf by attacking two Iraqi oil tankers.
 The United States Navy reported Wednesday that American carrier-borne aircraft had badly damaged an Iraqi tanker and destroyed three armed Hovercraft in the gulf.
The Baghdad radio said, "the aggression led to the leak of a huge quantity of oil in the gulf water." It was quoting from a military statement that said Iraq had shot down four allied aircraft or missiles, while the "enemy aircraft carried out 15 raids on our country until 0700 this morning."
In Washington, Bush Administration officials said today that although Baghdad radio and television were still functioning, they were faltering under continued attack from allied jets and missiles.
Asked whether Baghdad television was still broadcasting, one Administration official said: "Yes, with much difficulty. It's a weak signal. It appears they've found a way to continue to broadcast for the time being."
A Congressional official who has been briefed on the conflict said broadcasting was especially difficult to disrupt because radio and television antennae, as well as broadcasting equipment, are mobile and can be operated with relatively little electric power.
 
Economic Woes May Deepen
 Iraq's apparent decision to close the border with Jordan could presage deeper economic woes here.
Jordan has only limited supplies of petroleum products, and is considering rationing, economists here say. Its foreign exchange reserves, enough for two months' worth of oil imports, are not being replenished despite the $400 million in Western aid to those countries suffering from the embargo on trade with Iraq.
The country's other sources of income have all but evaporated. No tourists come to Jordan any more, ships will not pick up its phosphates at Aqaba because of high insurance rates, and remittances from Jordanians in the oil-producing gulf countries and Iraq have virtually disappeared.
Additionally, economists say, the gulf fighting and political tensions between Saudi Arabia and Jordan have cut off the kingdom from the traditional markets for its fresh produce. At the same time, Jordan has forfeited aid from the gulf oil-producers by tilting toward Iraq.

HEADLINE: Bank of Boston Posts Loss

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
In another reflection of the dismal New England economy, the Bank of Boston Corporation, the region's biggest banking company, yesterday reported a net loss of $395 million for 1990, including $187 million in the fourth quarter.
For the quarter, the bank company's loss compared with profit of $9 million, or 8 cents a share, in the comparable 1989 quarter. For all of 1990, the loss compared with a profit of $70 million, or 80 cents a share, in 1989.
To reduce costs the bank company cut 1,100 jobs in the fourth quarter and said it planned to eliminate another 1,000 positions this year. The bank, which employs about 18,000, said it would accomplish this through attrition.
As a result of nonperforming or questionable loans, many of them stemming from sour real estate deals, the bank added $170 million to its reserves against possible losses in the fourth quarter and $620 million for the year.
Bank of Boston's share price closed unchanged today, at $4.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: THE TROOPS;
Blacks Wary of Their Big Role as Troops

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Wesley Hatch, a black teen-ager from Chicago's impoverished West Side, graduated from high school with few choices two years ago. He dreamed of going to college to study architecture, but his mother did not have the money. That left dead-end jobs, the streets and the military. He chose the military.
"He didn't want to go," said his mother, Rhoda Hatch. "But he thought by joining the Army he'd be able to do better, help me out and go to school."
 
104,000 in the Gulf
 Now he is a foot soldier on the Kuwaiti border, one of about 104,000 black men and women who, Defense Department statistics show, account for nearly 25 percent of the American troops in the Persian Gulf and almost 30 percent of Army troops there. 
 Despite their numbers in the armed forces, blacks make up 12 percent of the nation's civilian population. And as the gulf conflict moves closer to ground combat, a painful debate has divided many blacks about young blacks' role in the war and in the military.
The statistics documenting the number of blacks in the gulf have stirred a deep well of resentment and anger in some blacks who fear that their community will pay disproportionately for a war that many of them do not support.
The most recent New York Times/ CBS News Poll, conducted Jan. 17-20, asked 3,002 adults whether they favored starting military action or continuing the use of economic sanctions. The 250 blacks in the poll split about evenly on the question, and whites favored military action by a 4-to-1 ratio. And in a vote four days before the war started, all the black Democrats in Congress were against the measure authorizing force in the gulf.
Some black critics of the war say they are bitter that their sons and daughters are being sent to war by an Administration that they see as being insensitive to members of minority groups. Others say problems like drugs and crime in this country are more important than Kuwait but will not receive attention because of the preoccupation with the war. And with a fervor reminiscent of the civil rights movement, some are forming antiwar groups to discourage more blacks from joining the military.
Still other blacks express pride and comfort in Gen. Colin L. Powell, the nation's first black Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, as well as a loyal, if resigned, sense of duty to the war effort. Others fully support President Bush's use of force against a man many view as a threat to the entire Middle East and say that other concerns have to take a back seat for now.
Pentagon officials acknowledge the dispproportionate number of blacks in the armed forces, but say it is the random outcome of having an all-volunteer force. "Nobody's making them enlist," said Christopher Jehn, Assistant Secretary of Defense for force management and personnel. "They're not victims; they're willing, patriotic Americans."
 
Critics Point to Inequities
 Black critics of the war argue that blacks have defended the country its wars and still face inequities at home. "Once and for all, black women are saying, we're not sending our sons anymore," said Jamillah Muhammad, a Muslim who heads a black women's group in Chicago that is opposed to the war. "Until things change for our children," she said, the military is not going to getthem.
But those who support the war say that this is a time when blacks and whites should be pulling together in the face of a larger threat.
Bertha Bailey, a high school teacher in McKinney, Tex., whose grandson is among the blacks serving in the gulf, says she accepts the inevitabilities of war. "Sometimes, some things can't get corrected without someone getting hurt," Mrs. Bailey said. "We don't need a fight within a fight. Why worry about who is overrepresented when they're all at danger points?"
But the Rev. Jesse Jackson and many black Congressmen have said the disproportionate number of blacks in the gulf was evidence of the bleak economic opportunities they have.
 "This nation ought to be ashamed that the best and brightest of our youth don't volunteer because they love it so well, but because this nation can't provide them jobs," said Dr. Benjamin L. Hooks, president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
And during a week of commemorations marking the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., his son urged blacks not to participate in the war. In a speech in Chicago last week for Operation PUSH, Martin Luther King 3d said: "Every black soldier ought to say: "You all do what you want to. I'm not going to fight. This is not my war.' "
The debate underscores an agonizing irony for blacks. Blacks have faced discrimination and harassment as they fought for important war posts to prove their worth and citizenship. In the last 20 years, since the easing of racial strictures, large numbers of them volunteered for the armed forces as a way out of poverty and now must face the war as a consequence of that decision.
At the core of the problem, said Martin Binkin, a military analyst with the Brookings Institution, are the mixed perceptions of the military and perhaps the conflicting motivations of those who join. "The military is seen as a benefit in peacetime," Mr. Binkin said, "and a burden during war."
In the years of peace since the Vietnam War and the end of the draft, which had tended to equalize the number of blacks and whites in the armed forces, blacks have joined the military at a rate up to three times that for whites. In 1980, 42 percent of black men between the ages of 19 and 24 who could potentially qualify for the armed forces had served in the military, as against 14 percent of all potentially qualified white men in the same age group, according to research conducted by Mr. Binkin. He estimated that today 33 to 35 percent of all qualified young black men have served in the military, as against 16 or 17 percent for young white men.
Military analysts and many blacks agree that the armed forces, while not a racial utopia, offer a more egalitarian and welcoming environment for blacks than perhaps any place in the civilian world. That assessment stems in large part from a military system of promotion and pay based mainly on seniority and skill rather than on race and intangibles.
"The military is the only major institution in America with something like a level playing field," said Prof. Charles Moskos, a sociologist at Northwestern University. "It is the only place where a white will be bossed around by a black on a regular basis at the local level. There is probably a better racial climate in the military than on a college campus."
General Powell has said, "The armed forces have always provided opportunities for blacks, which blacks have found attractive and have gone after, and I see no reason to change that now."
 
A Poverty Draft Is Seen
 But critics say the military is taking advantage of economic conditions in which the armed forces are the only chance for steady work that some black people have. They say that such enlistment amounts to a kind of poverty draft. "We join because we don't have anyplace else to go," Mrs. Muhammad said.
Now that troops have been sent and a war has started, there is scarcely a black church or inner-city school where someone does not know at least one person, if not a lot of people, in the gulf. "There is a sense of impending disaster," said the Rev. George H. Clements, pastor of Holy Angels Roman Catholic Church in Chicago, a predominantly black church with 104 members or relatives of members in the gulf.
Critics of the war fear that the black communities that have already lost great numbers of men to drugs and crime will now lose "the good ones" to war. Military analysts say, that unlike white enlistees who tend to be poorer and less educated than their civilian counterparts, most black men and women in the military are high school graduates or better from working- and middle-class families.
"The stabilizing forces in our community are being drawn out," said Kathy Flewellen, a leader of the National African-Americans Against United States Intervention in the Gulf, a network with affiliated groups in six cities that was formed in Washington, to protest the war.
The feelings of loss and dispair are mixed with a sense of satisfaction about General Powell. "Everytime he's on TV I feel proud," said James Exum, a Vietnam War veteran living in Chicago. "I feel confident with him there. I don't think he'll rush into ground action knowing that there are black men on the front lines. I feel a sense of comfort knowing that there's a black man calling the shots."
Like so many black servicemen, Mr. Exum, a former army captain and Green Beret, enlisted right out of high school to escape the housing projects of Washington. "I didn't see that I had any options," he said. "I got many benefits, but I could have gotten killed."
He survived commando raids that he led into North Vietnam and said he experienced a kind of multiracial fraternity he has not seen since the war. "When somebody got shot down, none of us asked if they were black or white or what religion they were," Mr. Exum said. "All we needed to know was, is the person American. It was the only time we lived up to what this country is all about."
The recent debate over racial disparities in the military has stirred several efforts on Capitol Hill, and hearings on the topic in the coming weeks are being considered.
And black antiwar groups across the country are pushing for improvements in vocational education to give black youths an alternative to the military.
But many say that the demographics of a volunteer force, will not change, until the economic climate does. "Until the problems of society are solved where blacks have more opportunities, you almost by definition will have a disproportionate number of blacks in the military," said Mr. Binkins of the Brookings Institution. "Until then, we have to live with what's over there now."

HEADLINE: Abused Wife Found Guilty Of Murder

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN

 BODY:
Sarah Smith, a 43-year-old Bronx social worker who said she shot her abusive husband to death to save her own life, was convicted of his murder yesterday.
She faces a maximum sentence of 25 years to life in prison. She had earlier declined to plead guilty to manslaughter in return for a recommended prison term of 4 to 12 years. 
 The jurors in State Supreme Court in the Bronx announced a guilty verdict on the charge of second-degree murder at 5:45 P.M. on their third day of deliberations. The verdict left Ms. Smith, her lawyer, his assistants and her family stunned.
"I am astounded," said Ms. Smith's lawyer, Michael G. Dowd, who has successfully defended a half-dozen battered women who killed their husbands or lovers. "I have never in 24 years been so shocked by a verdict."
 
'We Didn't Believe Her'
 Neither the jurors nor the chief prosecutor in the case, Assistant District Attorney Elisa Koenderman, would discuss the outcome. As the jury of seven women and five men hurried from the white granite courthouse into the cold night, most said nothing to reporters asking for comment. One man said simply, "We didn't believe her."
The verdict came as a striking exception to a series of prominent cases in which battered women seemed to gain greater acceptance for the claim of having killed in self-defense.
Last month, Gov. Richard F. Celeste of Ohio granted clemency to 25 women who killed men they said had abused them.
Ms. Smith's case also brought a rare defeat for Mr. Dowd, whose clients included Karen Straw, a 29-year-old Queens woman who came to symbolize the anguish of women seeking protection from violent men. Ms. Straw, who had pressed assault charges against her estranged husband and obtained court orders of protection against him, stabbed him to death during a violent argument one night after she said he had beaten and raped her.
By contrast, Ms. Smith testified that she mistrusted protection orders after reading about the killings of three Long Island women, apparently by husbands ordered to stay away.
Neither side in her case disputed that on May 23, 1989, Ms. Smith shot Owen Smith, 31, once in the head with his .25-caliber pistol as he lay resting on the bed of their South Bronx apartment, then drove his body to Yonkers and dumped it in an abandoned schoolyard.
Ms. Smith said she killed him in self-defense, fearing that he would he would make good on that evening's drunken threat to kill her soon.
The jurors seemed to focus on just what she meant by "soon." In explaining the charge and re-explaining it several times during the deliberations, Justice John P. Collins told them that Ms. Smith would have been justified in using deadly force against her husband if she believed it necessary to prevent his "imminent" use of deadly force.
 
Read From a Dictionary
 Three times, the jurors asked the judge to define the word "imminent." Finally, he read from a dictionary: "immediately or soon."
From the moment she surrendered to the police, Ms. Smith had insisted that the killing had been motivated by the abuse of her husband, who was unemployed. For the last three years of their marriage, she said, he had harassed and threatened her, at times choking her or firing at her with one of his three handguns. One morning, she testified, she woke up staring into a pistol barrel.
For the most part, the prosecution did not challenge testimony that Ms. Smith had been abused. Instead, Ms. Koenderman stressed that Owen Smith had never seriously injured his wife or made good on the threats she said he had made in the past. Had Ms. Smith wanted to, Ms. Koenderman insisted, she could have fled the apartment.
"You could have left him when he was lying down, couldn't you?" the prosecutor asked Ms. Smith.
 
'Blow My Brains Out'
 "Not without chancing that he would catch me at the door and blow my brains out, no," she answered.
In April, 1989, the month before the shooting, Mr. Smith was arrested on drug charges on three successive Sundays. Twice in the months before that he had been arrested for assaulting police officers. On May 19, four days before the killing, Ms. Smith requested a transfer from her job as a caseworker for the Department of Social Services, saying she feared bodily harm and wanted a new job where her husband could not find her.
After the killing, Ms. Smith said, she wrapped her husband's 6-foot-3-inch, 175-pound body in two blankets, wheeled it into her parking lot on a borrowed dolly and put the bundle in the trunk of her car with the help of two passing strangers. She said she gave the men $20 and never saw them again.
She said she dumped the body and did not call the police for a week so that she could spend a last few days with her two daughters.
 
Fear of Retaliation
 Mr. Dowd said Ms. Smith had feared that her husband, who boasted of beating up police officers and selling drugs and getting away with both, would retaliate against her, her mother, daughters or five grandchildren.
"If society couldn't control his lawlessness," Mr. Dowd asked, "how could she expect it to control his violence against her?"
Ms. Koenderman argued that she did not try.
Mr. Dowd had hoped that Ms. Smith's defense would be well-served by his portrait of a woman who, despite hardships, struggled to better herself.
Born in the Bronx, abused by an alcoholic father, Ms. Smith graduated from high school the same day she had her first child. Before her first marriage broke up, she took in the daughter of friends when she found out the girl was being beaten by her father. She earned a college degree at night.
 Later she met Owen Smith, who was then an illegal immigrant from Jamaica. She said their first years together were happy, but ager Mr. Smith obtained legal residency in late 1985, she said, the marriage turned into a nightmare.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: EGYPT;
Mubarak Cites Accords To Help Rescue Kuwait

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Facing growing hesitation here about the extent of Cairo's military and political involvement in the Persian Gulf crisis, President Hosni Mubarak said today that Egypt was obligated by its commitments to the United Nations and the Arab League to go to the rescue of Iraqi-occupied Kuwait.
Speaking to a special joint session of the elected Egyptian Parliament and the appointed Consultative Council, a body of distinguished citizens, he said that even a week after the war had started, "I say in the name of the Egyptian people: Even in these moments we will not slow our efforts to end this tragedy, if Iraq commits itself to withdraw from Kuwait and restore legitimacy and sovereignty there." 
 In a two-hour speech, Mr. Mubarak seemed to go out of his way to detail the many efforts Egypt had undertaken to pacify President Saddam Hussein. He said he had made 26 appeals to the Iraqi leader, including a 44-page letter in which Mr. Mubarak detailed Egypt's views about the crisis.
The Egyptian President tried to draw a line between Egypt's continued commitment to the welfare of the Iraqi people and its view of the future of the Iraqi President. He said that at this point "what happens to Saddam is not Egypt's business, but the Iraqi people are very dear to us."
 
Palestinian Issue Addressed
 Addressing a sore issue often raised by Egyptian opposition parties -- that the United States, while showing great resolve in dealing with the occupation of Kuwait, has not shown the same resolve in addressing the grievances of Palestinians under Israeli occupation -- Mr. Mubarak strongly implied that Egypt and Saudi Arabia had pledges from President Bush to look into the Palestinian issue once the gulf crisis is settled.
In a response later tonight, Rifaat el-Saeed, a spokesman for eight opposition parties and a senior official of the Progressive Alignment party, said the opposition parties rejected Mr. Mubarak's propositions and would circulate a petition calling for an end to the war, which he described as "a savage American attack on the Iraqi people."
Mr. Saeed said the opposition parties would try to meet with Mr. Mubarak to present their petition and would also seek meetings with the ambassadors of the United States, Britain, Turkey and France and the Secretary General of the Arab League.
In his speech, Mr. Mubarak harshly criticized Mr. Hussein's use of Scud missiles against Israel, describing these weapons in terms of their military value as no more than "firecrackers," similar to what Egyptian children use on holidays.
 
Called Political Missiles
 But he said that while the military value of these missiles was nil, they were potent "political missiles" that harmed the Palestinian cause by drawing much sympathy to Israel from around the world and enabling Israel to ask for substantial increases in military and economic aid from the West.
Mr. Mubarak refrained from making any specific comments about the military role of Egypt's estimated 45,000 soldiers stationed in the Eastern Province of Saudi Arabia as part of the allied force.
But he stressed that sending Egyptian troops to Saudi Arabia "was undoubtedly an unavoidable decision in light of our specific contractual obligations, which we view with the utmost seriousness and rigor." This was a reference to Egypt's participation in Arab League mutual defense accords.
He said the purpose of those accords was to prevent relations between nations from reverting to "the law of the jungle," and he strongly saluted the Egyptian armed forces, to rousing applause by the legislators. He described his decision to send troops as "a brave decision."
 
Meeting With Hussein Described
 Leaders of virtually all the opposition parties in Egypt, except for the social democratic Wafd party, have strongly opposed the participation of Egyptian troops in a conflict with Iraqis and asked that the Egyptian troops be moved to western Saudi Arabia to protect the Muslim shrines of Mecca and Medina instead.
Mr. Mubarak said that in his last private meeting with Mr. Hussein immediately before the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, the Iraqi leader told him that Baghdad had so badly shaken Arab gulf governments with its repeated threats against Kuwait that the time was ripe for Egypt to present them with any financial or economic demands for aid it wanted, in the expectation that they would immediately respond.
Quoting the Iraqi President, Mr. Mubarak said he had advised, "This is a good opportunity to ask the gulf rulers what you like and get it."
Speaking about what is likely to happen in the next few days, Mr. Mubarak said the Iraqi Army would suffer the gravest losses once the land battles to liberate Kuwait begin. "We must realize this," he said, addressing the Iraqi leader. "What logic is there in causing the death of thousands of these people. What will you achieve?"

HEADLINE: American Express Net Drops 46%

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The American Express Company reported yesterday that its net income had dropped 46.4 percent in the fourth quarter and 84.6 percent for all of 1990, because of a loss of nearly $1 billion on the year at its troubled Wall Street brokerage house, Shearson Lehman Brothers.
American Express said it had earned $137.9 million, or 28 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, compared with $257.2 million, or 61 cents a share, a year earlier. Fourth-quarter revenue declined less than 1 percent, to $6.3 billion, compared with $6.32 billion a year earlier. 
 For the full year, the company reported earnings of $181.5 million, or 34 cents a share, compared with last year's $1.16 billion, or $2.70 a share. Full-year revenue declined nearly 3 percent, to $24.3 billion, from $25 billion a year earlier.
 
Problems at Shearson
 While its main business units, including Travel Related Services and IDS Financial Services, reported record profits, American Express saw its earnings dragged down by Shearson's poor performance.
American Express disclosed the earnings shortly before 6 P.M., well past the close of the stock market. Its stock rose 25 cents yesterday, to $20, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Analysts expressed surprise at the magnitude of Shearson's losses. Many had been predicting fourth-quarter losses of $50 million to $75 million. Instead, Shearson reported a loss of $115 million for the quarter, compared with earnings of $4 million a year earlier. For the full year, Shearson reported a loss of $966 million, compared with 1989 profit of $110 million.
"The area of continuing surprise has to be Shearson," said Alison A. Deans, an analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. "No one was expecting another round of severance charges of this magnitude."
The 1990 figures include $787 million in charges for layoffs and office closings at Shearson, as well as $50 million in the fourth quarter for severances and more charges related to dismissals and closings.
Fourth-quarter results at Shearson also reflected a reserve of $35 million that the company said was related to shares in the troubled Polly Peck International P.L.C., which were bought on behalf of Polly Peck's chairman, Asil Nadir. Polly Peck's stock collapsed late last year. American Express did not elaborate on the statement.
Shearson's annual revenues totaled $10.2 billion in 1990, down more than 18 percent from $12.5 billion in 1989, primarily because of decreased interest and dividend revenues.
American Express attributed Shearson's poor performance to "a continued and worsening industrywide slowdown in a difficult economic environment."
 
Commissions Are Down
 Brokerage commission revenues were down 18 percent, to $1.6 billion. Revenue from market-making and principal transactions were down 5.5 percent, to $1.2 billion. Investment banking revenues dropped 41.5 percent, to $563 million. And investment advisory revenues fell 7.5 percent, to $633 million.
American Express said its management had met its targets for reducing expenses. Shearson's fixed expenses were cut 9 percent, or $266 million, from 1989 levels. What American Express described as "fourth-quarter, ongoing fixed expenses" were reduced by $86 million from fourth quarter 1989, or $344 million on an annualized basis.
Ms. Dean noted that Shearson had made some progress in cutting staff costs, but she said it still had a long way to go. Last year, the number of stockbrokers declined 16 percent, to 8,711, and the overall Shearson work force fell 12 percent, to 31,300.
 
Gains at Charge-Card Unit
 Meanwhile, American Express's mainstay business, the charge-card and travel division known as Travel Related Services, reported an annual profit of $956 million, up 15 percent from $830 million a year earlier. Full-year revenue increased 16 percent, to $9.7 billion.
In the fourth quarter, net income for Travel Related Services rose 13 percent, to $215 million. Charge volume during the quarter, which occurs during the Christmas buying season, rose 10 percent, to $30 billion.
American Express also said its IDS Financial Services, which provides financial planning and other services, posted net income of $207 million during the year, up 18 percent from the 1989 level. Revenue rose 14 percent, to $2.2 billion, from $1.9 billion in 1989. In the fourth quarter, IDS's net income rose 16 percent, to $56 million.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: EUROPE;
Gulf Fighting Shatters Europeans' Fragile Unity

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
The war in the Persian Gulf has abruptly halted momentum toward political unity in Europe, breathed new life into the "special relationship" between the United States and Britain and raised widespread concern about pacifism in Germany, diplomats, Government officials and strategic experts here say.
Partisans of European unity have been deeply dismayed by the European Community's virtual irrelevance in the crisis since President Saddam Hussein of Iraq spurned the 12 nations' last-ditch attempts to avert war by diplomacy. Since he refused to comply with the Jan. 15 United Nations deadline to pull his troops out of Kuwait, Britain, France and Germany have all gone separate ways. 
 Because the European Community has a six-month rotating presidency, Luxembourg now coordinates foreign and defense policy for the community's 336 million people. Jacques Poos, Luxembourg's Foreign Minister, complained on Wednesday that the war had shown up "the political insignificance of Europe."
 
'A Military Worm'
 "Europe is an economic giant, a political dwarf, and a military worm," the Belgian Foreign Minister, Mark Eyskens, conceded a few days before the war started.
Britain's 35,000 troops in the gulf are committed to battle under United States command, and France's 10,000 will fight but only to get Iraqi forces out of Kuwait, according to the Government of President Francois Mitterrand. Some smaller countries have sent ships and equipment to the gulf, but Belgium turned Britain down when it requested ammunition for its forces there, according to British and Belgian officials.
Germany, with the most powerful and vigorous economy in Europe and one of its biggest armies, has refused to send any troops into battle and hesitated before sending 18 planes to Turkey, a member of the NATO alliance, for protection against possible Iraqi attack.
 
'Lost Its Fighting Spirit'
 It eventually went ahead last month but has pointedly not declared that it will automatically come to Turkey's aid militarily if Saddam Hussein attacks it, prompting President Turgut Ozal of Turkey today to charge that "Germany has become so rich that it has completely lost its fighting spirit."
Germany's contributions to the gulf war have otherwise been limited to logistical support and money, and on Wednesday Chancellor Helmut Kohl said Germany would go beyond the $2.2 billion it had earlier pledged -- up to $6.7 billion more, according to German officials.
Mr. Kohl was critical of the anti-American undertone to the antiwar demonstrations that have erupted in Germany since the war broke out, but Joachim Fest, a commentator for the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, said today that the Chancellor's policy was partly to blame. "What is lacking is a notion of where we belong and what we are willing to stand up for when push comes to shove," Mr. Fest wrote. Another huge demonstration is planned in Bonn on Saturday.
"I thought I understood German pacificism," said Francois Heisbourg, director of the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London. "But here Germany is not a target for attack, the war has been sanctioned by the United Nations, and it's far away. It's not going over well in Paris or London," he said. "How can there be a common European policy when the British and French take ground losses in Kuwait and the Germans keep themselves deliberately aloof?"
 
Bush-Major Relationship
 Because of the crisis, the new British Prime Minister, John Major, has suddenly found himself in the kind of warm special relationship with President Bush that his predecessor, Margaret Thatcher, enjoyed with President Ronald Reagan. British officials say that he and Mr. Bush have been conferring frequently by telephone since the war started, and that the President told Mr. Major when the war would start about 24 hours before he called most of the other NATO allies.
Until the gulf crisis broke last August, Mr. Bush had seemed to be leaning more toward Germany and Mr. Kohl as the principal American ally in Europe, but all that has changed. Senior NATO diplomats said that officials in Washington had been seriously disappointed by the skittish German response to the gulf crisis, and worried about its implications for the future in other crises.
"Now I hope you know who your friends really are," said John Gilbert, a Labor Party Member of Parliament who said that if his party came to power here in the next elections, the trans-Atlantic partnership would remain just as vital.
 
'Complicating Factor'
 In Paris today, Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said Britain would welcome a strengthening of European effort in the gulf, to keep American public resentment over lack of support from Europe from developing into an "important complicating factor" in trans-Atlantic relations.
Britain would like to see Germany and Japan provide more help, officials at 10 Downing Street say. "We think what we're doing in the gulf is worth doing even if nobody gives us money," said one aide, "but it's obviously basic fairness that there should be some burden-sharing here."
Nor is the end of the war likely to bring the Europeans closer together.
British war aims appear to be identical with those of the United States, but very different from those of France or Germany. Citing United Nations resolutions calling for a restoration of peace and stability in the region, British officials and legislators of the two major political parties say that Britain would support sending ground forces into Iraq even after driving Saddam Hussein's armies out of Kuwait, if the Iraqis were still fighting at that point.
In Germany, where the Social Democratic opposition is already calling for withdrawal of the 18 planes from Turkey, Mr. Kohl and Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher want an end to hostilities as soon as possible. Until today, France had refused to authorize air strikes against targets in Iraq, saying it was bound only to come to the assistance of Kuwait. French planes made their first attacks inside Iraq today.

HEADLINE: FOOTBALL;
Ismail Enters N.F.L. Draft; Patriots Consider Options

BYLINE: By SAMANTHA STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PALO ALTO, Calif., Jan. 24

 BODY:
A short time after Raghib (Rocket) Ismail officially declared his intention to forsake his senior season at Notre Dame and enter this spring's National Football League draft, Dick MacPherson, the new head coach of the New England Patriots, was wishing aloud today that this time the Rocket would not get away from him.
MacPherson, who is here preparing to coach the East team in the annual East-West Shrine game on Saturday, failed in an effort to recruit Ismail at Syracuse, where MacPherson coached until hired by the Patriots on Dec. 31. Now his new team, coming off a 1-15 season, has the first pick in the N.F.L. draft, which could very well be Ismail. 
 In making his announcement at a news conference in South Bend, Ind., Ismail reversed his field a bit. He had said often during the season that he would return for his final season at Notre Dame, where he gained 4,187 all-purpose yards in three years. But today he said that the recent death of the mother of his teammate, Chris Zorich, had helped change his mind.
"It made me feel that I wanted to do something for my mother and my family," Ismail said. He added that his decision was supported by Coach Lou Holtz, who thanked him for his contributions to Notre Dame and wished him well.
"I'm positive he's going to be a very, very viable choice," said MacPherson, speaking of the triple-threat player who returns kickoffs, carries the ball and catches it well enough to have been the runner-up for the Heisman Trophy this past season.
But MacPherson cautioned that the Patriots had not made a decision about what they would do with the pick.
"I have no idea what the personnel director has in mind," MacPherson said. "I'm just going on board. The people in New England know the New England Patriots better than I do now. This is going to be a lot of fun. The price of poker went up, hey?
"I think that anybody would want Rocket. I'm sure there will be a lot of offers out there and we'll have to weigh them and see what's best for the Patriots. The nice thing about it, is the worst thing you can do is end up with Raghib Ismail. Nobody can lose with that one."
Sam Jankovich, the Patriots' chief executive and owners' representative, said in a statement: "The Patriots, like other N.F.L. teams, are in an evaluation process at this particular time and it is far too early to make decisions. Anytime a quality person and player like Rocket Ismail enters the draft, it surely adds to the value of the Patriots and other N.F.L. teams."
MacPherson said he had been in touch with Ismail's brother, Qadry, a defensive back, who played for him at Syracuse last season.
MacPherson said Ismail had made the only sound economic move.
"I'm sad for college football," MacPherson said. "I'm sad for Notre Dame and the team. But I think that when anyone has a guaranteed income that he has, by making this option, I'm all for it. He's done his duty and he's paid his dues and he's on to the next level.
"I tried to recruit him. He got away from me once. But it's going to be hard to get away from me again."

HEADLINE: Review/Photography;
Without Sentimentality, The Work of 6 Germans

BYLINE: By ANDY GRUNDBERG

 BODY:
The influence of Bernd and Hilla Becher on contemporary German photography is not exactly a secret. The dryly observant, seemingly neutral style of their detailed pictures of industrial structures has been adopted by Andreas Gursky, Thomas Ruff, Thomas Struth and other artist photographers who studied with Mr. Becher at the Art Academy of Dusseldorf. These younger artists' pictures have frequently been shown in Manhattan in the last two years, creating the impression that German photography is particularly vigorous these days and that the Bechers are largely responsible for it.
This impression is enhanced by a show of six lesser known but equally talented young German photographers at the Sonnabend Gallery in SoHo. All are about 30 years old, are recent graduates of the Dusseldorf school where Mr. Becher teaches and are showing their work in the United States for the first time. Surprisingly, considering how obviously they are indebted to the Bechers, their photographs have fresh and distinctive charms. 
 How interesting the images are is largely proportional to how far they stray from the precedents of their teacher and his wife. Boris Becker (the photographer, not the tennis player) takes black-and-white pictures of stone and concrete structures that appear to be falling down or under construction, but they are such mirror images of the Bechers' work that Mr. Becker's own contribution seems minimal. On the other hand, Simone Nieweg's views of backyard gardens and Ulrich Gambke's landscapes dominated by farm machinery introduce an agrarian theme that lies outside the Bechers' domain.
 Mr. Gambke's combination of wheat fields and the implements that shape them is especially potent, since it links a 19th-century romantic notion of the landscape with 20th-century technology. The plows, harrows and rakes that appear in the foreground of his pictures are as curious and fascinating as the water towers and blast furnaces the Bechers have documented for nearly 30 years; in addition, they serve as symbols of the mechanization of agricultural production.
While Ms. Nieweg's and Mr. Gambke's photographs may reach beyond the Bechers in subject matter, they remain linked to the tradition from which the Bechers draw strength. They bring to mind the New Objectivity movement in Germany in the 1920's and, in particular, August Sander's landscapes of the rural regions around Cologne. Sander's enduring influence is also felt in Andi Brenner's portraits of athletes and laborers, which seem to revive the notion of a distinct Aryan physiognomy, although with the disconcerting addition of loud patterned backgrounds.
 The largest pictures in this otherwise modestly sized exhibition belong to Manfred Jade, who photographs headstones in Jewish cemeteries as if they were living presences lining up to tell the stories of their lives. The most individual images, however, are the work of Jorg Sasse, who fashions disarming color prints of small, seemingly insignificant interior objects like a pink toilet-brush holder and a radiator covered by a board. Much like the Swiss collaborative artists Peter Fischli and David Weiss and the American Tim Maul, Mr. Sasse records a world of small but peculiar events and nonevents.
In one image, an inverted drinking glass sits on a saucer, as if a feat of magic or sleight of hand was about to take place. Mr. Sasse's photographs are uneven, and he sometimes seems distracted by their affinities with geometric abstraction, but they probe a part of the world that is rarely scrutinized. And like the rest of the pictures in this invigorating show, they are intensely meditative works devoid of the slightest traces of sentimentality or artistic inflation. All this is further evidence that the Bechers, who are represented by the Sonnabend Gallery, have tapped into a deep and rich vein of photography.
The show of photographs by six German artists remains at the Sonnabend Gallery, 420 West Broadway, near Spring Street, through tomorrow.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Detail of an untitled portrait by Andi Brenner, one of six artists with works at Sonnabend Gallery. (Sonnabend Gallery)

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
The Musical Returns To America

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH

 BODY:
WHEN the 1980's departed, it was not only the Trump yacht and Drexel Burnham Lambert that sailed into the sunset. Somewhat less conspicuously, the theater's own symbol of a money-crazed decade -- the over-produced English musical -- began its inexorable retreat to the wings. Built on opulent stage effects, London's theatrical spectaculars were as symptomatic of the money-mad 80's as a Malcolm Forbes birthday bash, and in the 1990's, their party, too, seems to be over.
In the nearly two years since "Aspects of Love" opened in the West End, no new Andrew Lloyd Webber project has gone much past the press-release stage in New York, London or Hollywood. The only smash hit "English" musical still in the pipeline to New York, "Miss Saigon," is in fact the work of French and American authors. And whatever that production's merits prove to be in its New York incarnation, doesn't it already feel like old news?
 
 All of which brings hope to those diehard chauvinists who dream of the resurgence of the American musical. That dream has been fueled of late not just by the pricking of the English-musical bubble, but by the steady rise in American musical-theater output. "Assassins," Stephen Sondheim's new show, opens at Playwrights Horizons on Sunday night, the third prominent musical, following "Falsettoland" and "Once on This Island," to originate at that company since last spring. Despite a recession that has otherwise flattened Broadway production, at least two major new American musicals are promised to follow "Miss Saigon" onto Broadway this spring: "The Secret Garden" and "Ziegfeld Presents Will Rogers."
 Until then, the front line for the American musical remains the two current flagship American musicals on Broadway, "City of Angels" and "Grand Hotel." Both recently entered the second year of their runs, and that in itself represents a comeback for the form. Not since the 1983-84 Broadway season produced both "La Cage aux Folles" and "Sunday in the Park With George" have two new American musicals opening in the same season had such staying power on Broadway.
 "City of Angels" and "Grand Hotel" deserve their longevity, without question. But revisiting the two shows this month to see how they were faring after substantial cast turnovers, I was struck by how transitional they both look. These musicals seem to be taking place on two different planets, esthetically at least, and each seems incomplete, as if it were lacking what the other had. If the American musical is now poised to rally for another era of international glory, it can make good on that promise only by transcending the sum of both these shows' better theatrical parts.
 Those parts are still in splendid working order. "Grand Hotel" never depended on the quality of its cast -- which was largely mediocre when the show opened -- and it still doesn't. It's hard to believe that the director Tommy Tune could find an actress as inappropriately cast as a fading ballerina (the old Garbo role) as that tough French cabaret chanteuse Liliane Montevecchi. But in Rene Ceballos, a gawky exemplar of Broadway brashness, he has found an equally far-fetched replacement. As the ballerina's lesbian aide-de-camp, the not untalented Caitlin Brown tailors her voice, makeup and hair so exactly to the image of her distinctive predecessor, Karen Akers, that it's hard to know whether her performance is meant to flatter Ms. Akers or give her the creeps. At least the one major cast holdover, David Carroll as the Baron, acts with more elegant command now than he did before, but what really matters at "Grand Hotel" is Mr. Tune's staging. It remains pristine, and thrilling.
 At "City of Angels," Tom Wopat's rumpled, battered masculinity proves ideal for Stone, the fictional hard-boiled 1940's private eye first played by James Naughton. As Stine, the jaundiced novelist turned screenwriter who created Stone, Michael Rupert is more plausibly cast than his boyish predecessor, Gregg Edelman, but is taking the character's Hollywood humiliations so much to heart that Stine threatens to become as glum as Willy Loman. The gifted Mr. Rupert needs to move a bit further away from the anguish of his last musical role (in "Falsettoland") to retrieve the buoyant charm he brought to his last role in a Cy Coleman musical (opposite Debbie Allen in "Sweet Charity").
 "City of Angels" and "Grand Hotel" have lost the respective supporting players, Randy Graff and Michael Jeter, who won Tony Awards for late-evening show stoppers, and in both cases the replacements (Chip Zien as the dying bookkeeper in "Grand Hotel," Susan Terry as the long-suffering secretary in "City of Angels") rekindle the spirit if not the spark of their predecessors. Even so, the experience of seeing either of these musicals is not markedly different today than it was at the end of 1989. But a repeat visitor may find, as I did, that seeing a second cast does bring the strengths and failings of the musicals themselves into sharper relief.
 Given its reviews, its Tony Award for best musical and its consistently higher attendance, "City of Angels" has been judged by most audiences to be the superior of the two shows, and I concur with that sentiment. The mirror-image double narrative of Larry Gelbart's script is a farcical wonder, as one would expect from the co-author of "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum," and his Hollywood-phobic dialogue is a volley of detonating punch lines worthy of the man who also co-wrote "Tootsie" and the television series "M*A*S*H." Mr. Coleman's exuberant mock-period jazz score, which has been rousingly arranged in the Billy May-Nelson Riddle tradition by Billy Byers, can be faulted only because it imitates the past (sometimes Mr. Coleman's own past) rather than attempting something fresh.
 Vastly entertaining as this musical is, however, there are times when I wish it might check into Mr. Tune's "Grand Hotel." To be sure, the "City of Angels" director, Michael Blakemore, and his designer, Robin Wagner, have done an ingenious job of piggy-backing the show's on-screen and off-screen Hollywood tales by depicting them, respectively, in black-and-white and color. At its best, the ricocheting between the show's two realities is as hilarious as was Mr. Blakemore's similar juggling of on- and offstage shenanigans in his classic production of Michael Frayn's backstage farce, "Noises Off." But "City of Angels" has virtually no musical staging, despite the listing of someone charged with that responsibility (Walter Painter) in the Playbill.
 By musical staging, I do not mean dancing per se -- though "City of Angels" has none of that, either -- so much as a sense of show-biz authority in the presentation of musical numbers. Too many songs are statically set forth, dead center stage, and most of them trail off rather than come to a punctuated, exhilarating finish. For all the sophistication of its content, "City of Angels" is, in theatrical terms, a throwback to George Abbott musicals of the 1950's and early 60's, minus the contributions of Jerome Robbins and Bob Fosse: Nearly every scene is a separate blackout sketch, bordered by a set change (often occurring behind a drop).
 "Grand Hotel," though also short of dancing, is a celebration of the modern musical-theater stagecraft that "City of Angels" avoids. Often several stories are told simultaneously during Mr. Tune's intricately designed two hours of swirling, nonstop movement, and nothing that happens is hidden from the audience behind drops or within blackouts. Mr. Tune needs only an evocative, two-level skeletal set (by Tony Walton), movable stiff-backed chairs, a portable revolving door and waltzing bodies to evoke every dark cranny of a seething, doom-laden Berlin hotel of 1928. When a curtain finally does fall late in "Grand Hotel" -- the only curtain to fall all evening -- the effect is shocking. Mr. Tune uses the curtain's slow descent in the most showy way imaginable: to demonstrate that only the lowering of a figurative wall could possibly still the churning panorama of life that he has unfurled onstage before.
 This director is some kind of genius, with an impeccable theatrical eye and an ability to take subconscious charge of an audience's vision. As the change in performers accentuates, the real reason why the dying bookkeeper's number ("We'll Take a Glass Together") stops the show has less to do with character, plot or performance than with a visual twist in the staging: Mr. Tune heightens the celebratory excitement of the oppressed bookkeeper's belated leap to freedom by making him the only character in the evening who literally leaps out of the grid-like frame that encases the show.
 The blot on "Grand Hotel," aside from its occasional rehashes of directorial ideas from Harold Prince's "Cabaret" and from Mr. Prince and Michael Bennett's "Follies," is that the whole show is fairly meaningless except as a predictable mood piece about Weimar Germany. "Forbidden Broadway" rightly parodied this musical as "Grim Hotel," for its grimness is ludicrously unearned, despite the periodic attempts to drag in class conflict by having scullery servants harangue the audience with the lyrics "Some have/Some have not." Does anyone really believe that Mr. Tune gives a hoot about Marxism? Worse, the director seems to invest little passion in the pulpy aspects of "Grand Hotel" as well. The show never delivers the romance, sexiness and tear-jerking soap operatics of the M-G-M movie that shares its title.
 In part this shortfall is due to the casting and the score, both of which are far too lackluster to convey grand emotions. ("Grand Hotel" must be the first musical in Broadway history to run more than a year without anyone lifting a finger to record it.) But surely Mr. Tune has the power to recruit better performers and to insist upon stronger material; is it possible he does not want any other strong creative personality to upstage him? This has been and continues to be the principal impediment to his career. Unlike Mr. Bennett, Mr. Prince, Mr. Robbins, Gower Champion and Agnes de Mille, Mr. Tune has never worked on a musical in which the other principal collaborators, off- and onstage, were all of his artistic stature. Would those directors be considered giants today if their reputations rested on musicals of the caliber of "Nine" and "Grand Hotel"?
 A triumph of showmanship over substance, "Grand Hotel" has the sensual kick and clammy aftertaste of high camp. A triumph of witty literary intellect over musicality, "City of Angels" is the funniest musical in years but hardly among the most theatrical. Neither show whips up one genuine emotion -- both are far more at home with the put-on -- and neither has a song that will make it to Broadway's all-time hit parade. Yet both have unmistakable, idiosyncratic personalities that linger in the imagination long after the assembly-line English spectaculars have blurred together, and they remain essential viewing for anyone who really cares about where the American musical goes from here.
 
The Shows

HEADLINE: SUPER BOWL XXV;
It's First-and-10 for Buffalo's Zooming Civic Pride

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUFFALO, Jan. 24

 BODY:
When Carletta Rock was a girl, Buffalo was bigger than Los Angeles, and everybody really did call the place the Queen City of the Lakes. She grew up on stories about the days when this terminus of the Erie Canal was one of the busiest ports in the world, the meeting place, residents boasted, of Western supply and Eastern demand.
All this has something to do with why the 74-year-old woman, who confesses to not liking football and not really understanding the rules, was browsing through the racks of the AM & A Department Store here, looking for an official Buffalo Bills Super Bowl XXV T-shirt. 
 "This could put us back on the map," she said. Then, ever so slightly raising a fist, she added: "They'll respect us now. They've got to respect us."
For Buffalo, which more recently has found recognition in Johnny Carson jokes about its snow, the Bills' appearance in the Super Bowl has taken on an air of civic significance out of all proportion to what will unfold on the playing field. The city that produced two Presidents is once again at the pinnacle of something, and nobody seems to mind that it's only a game.
 
Gung-Ho Fans
 That the nation is at war has hardly dimmed the fervor: in a way, fans here seem to have fused the two events, so that in Buffalo the ardor for the home team has become an extra dimension of patriotism.
Many of the 80,000 fans at Sunday's victory over the Los Angeles Raiders waved both American flags and Bills pennants. In suburban Cheektowaga, a large sign in front of a gas station says, "Pray for Peace," and then right below, "Go Bills Go."
Buffalo, in any event, has long been a sports-crazy town. Bills quarterbacks, winning ones anyway, have become local heroes: Jack F. Kemp parlayed his career on the field into a Congressional seat; Edward J. Rutkowski was elected county leader.
The city of about 325,000 is engaged in an almost manic quest to attract a major league baseball team, and even its minor league squad, the Bisons, has attracted more fans in recent years than some major league teams.
 
Rodney Dangerfield Syndrome

But while people are clearly excited about the chance to win a championship, they seem equally motivated by the desire to get some respect.
"Buffalo has had a chip on its shoulder for a long time about how it was perceived by the rest of the world," said Verlyn Klinkenborg, who chronicles a changing Buffalo in his book, "The Last Fine Time," the story of a family tavern on the city's Polish East Side.
Having once been known as a bustling, even glorious place, Buffalo, Klinkenborg said in an interview, "somehow became part of a vaudeville act. You'd say the name and you'd get a laugh. I think a lot of people have been hungering for quite some time for an outward symbol of continuing excellence."
If not always spelled out in historical context, many people here seem to have a profound appreciation for the fact that Buffalo was once more important.
 
A Bad Image to Overcome
 "Buffalo used to be a big stop on the nightclub circuit," said Karen Orosco, the manager of J. J. Mugg's, a sports bar in Lackawanna, just south of Buffalo. "There used to be a saying: 'If you can make it in Buffalo, you can make it anywhere.' I'm not making that up."
The city -- once 8th-largest in the country, now around the 50th -- has yet to overcome its Rust Belt image of decay, although in many ways it deserves to. Thanks in large part to the Canadian free-trade agreement and to $2.5 billion in investment in its downtown and lakefront areas, it has weathered the Northeast's economic downturn better than any other area of the state.
The Bills, some municipal leaders hope, could help highlight an ascent that might otherwise be ignored. "Fortune magazine ranked us one of the top five growth communities in the country," said Dennis Gorski, the Erie County Executive. "That's not sensational; that's not sexy. But if football is what lets you shine in the international spotlight, you seize the moment."
 
A Long Wait
 Many fans are simply reveling in the Super Bowl moment, some perhaps exaggerating the forbearance it took them to reach this point.
"Twenty-five years we've been waiting for this," said Mike Zgoda, who despite 19-degree weather was tossing a football the other day with some friends on Whitehall Avenue in South Buffalo. Mike, a third-grader at St. Ambrose School, is 9 years old.
The enthusiasm is visible throughout the city. At some of the entrances, signs calling Buffalo the home of the "Future World Champion Bills" have been posted.
There have been a few difficulties. Two weeks ago, during the playoff game with Miami, so many of the Erie County Water Authority's 500,000 customers waited until commercials to use the toilet that five water mains broke.
 
Engineers Are Ready
 "We got those fixed, and fortunately the L.A. game was such a romp that not everybody waited until the ads," said George Markle, the authority's supervising production engineer.
He is taking no chances for the Super Bowl: engineers will be "assigned" to watch the game, he said, so that as commercials come on they can adjust pressure valves.
"The last M*A*S*H* show was a headache too," he said, "but this could be the greatest challenge of all."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Carletta Rock, shopping for an official Buffalo Bills Super Bowl shirt, thinks that the team will help bring the city deserved recognition. (Phil Matt for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Borrow a Few Billion, Not Trouble

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, warned Congress this week not to raise taxes to pay for the war against Iraq. It's very good advice.
The war is now costing the U.S. about $500 million a day, $15 billion a month. The allies are paying probably half that, what with Japan's new contribution of $9 billion. That leaves the U.S. with an amount that's surely manageable in a $6 trillion economy. The question is whether to raise the money with higher taxes or more borrowing. 
 Mr. Greenspan's answer is to borrow, at least for the next few months as the country sorts out the costs and figures out what's happening to the economy. The gathering recession is no time to pile on a stiff tax hike. Besides, deficits are less worrisome during recessions because corporations borrow less and don't compete as much with the Government for capital.
To protect the economy, Congress needs to control structural deficits: the imbalance between continuing expenditures and costs. These deficits siphon money away from private capital formation and were the target of last fall's Congressional budget compromise. Deficits due to war and recession are nonrecurring and, therefore, less troubling.
In time, Congress will have a firmer estimate of the war's costs and can determine the mix of taxes and borrowing that best meets long-term needs. In the meantime, Mr. Greenspan is right to advise a safe course: Borrow to fight the war and thus spare the now-fragile economy any unnecessary trauma.

HEADLINE: Mr. Skinner Aids the Traveler

 BODY:
Eastern Airlines stopped flying last week. Pan Am and Continental are bankrupt, though still operating for now. Gone too are a number of former regional carriers -- like Ozark, PSA, Air California and Republic. Deregulation of the airline industry has spurred numerous mergers and failures, leaving only a half dozen major U.S. carriers.
Such consolidation raises concern that declining competition could allow fares on some routes to rise, harming the traveler. One way to inject competition and desperately needed financing into the industry is to lure foreign investment into struggling U.S. airlines. That's why Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner wisely announced this week new rules to ease restrictions on foreign ownership of U.S. carriers. Under the ruling, a foreign investor may purchase up to 49 percent of a U.S. airline, as long as foreign ownership of voting stock is limited to no more than 25 percent. 
 Mr. Skinner's ruling allows KLM Royal Dutch Airlines to keep its nearly 50 percent ownership share of Northwest Airlines. That allows Northwest to hold onto $250 million of desperately needed capital and the wherewithal to stay competitive.
Despite the wave of consolidations that accompanied deregulation, travelers have not suffered -- yet. Competition on typical routes has actually risen, and fares, after adjusting for inflation, have fallen. But if the wave of mergers and failures continues unabated, travelers will be left to the mercy of monopolistic carriers.
Mr. Skinner's ruling alone won't solve the problem. Few foreign investors will bid on U.S. carriers because severe legal barriers -- such as the 25 percent limit on voting shares -- remain. But he has taken an important first step to turning around an overly protectionist U.S. policy. The next step would be for Congress to permit foreign airlines to fly U.S. passengers from one American city to another.
The immediate beneficiary of Mr. Skinner's ruling is Northwest Airlines. And if he pushes Congress to loosen further, the ultimate victors will be every U.S. traveler who wants quality service at affordable fares.
