HEADLINE: Harcourt Accepts Bid From General Cinema

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, the publishing and insurance company that has been struggling under a heavy debt load, yesterday accepted a $1.4 billion takeover bid from General Cinema, the movie theater company that controls the Neiman Marcus retail chain.
The deal would give holders of Harcourt's stock, both common and preferred, $1.30 a share, 5 cents above yesterday's common stock closing price, and will also include tender offers to the company's debt holders. If approved by the holders of Harcourt's stock and debt, the deal is expected to be completed this spring. 
 "It's an extraordinary deal, a near miracle, considering the state of the company, the economy and publishing companies," said Ivan Obolensky, vice president of the brokerage firm Shields & Company. Until yesterday, Mr. Obolensky had consistently expressed pessimism about Harcourt's future as an independent corporation after it borrowed nearly $3 billion to fend off a 1987 takeover attempt by Robert Maxwell, the British publisher. Harcourt stock traded as high as $63.75 a share during the takeover struggle with Mr. Maxwell.
 
Assets Sold
 Harcourt, whose current long-term debt is close to $2 billion, was forced to sell parts of the company to meet interest payments. Had the company been able to survive until 1993, Mr. Obolensky said, it would have faced accrued interest payments on two bond issues in excess of $500 million -- plus regular annual interest payments of at least $160 million.
General Cinema's offer surprised book industry executives because the company was not known to have bid for other publishing houses that were offered for sale in recent years. The company did not explain why it was willing to assume Harcourt's heavy debt load, but said it had looked at book publishing for several years and found it an attractive area.
Publishing executives speculated that General Cinema was willing to pay a premium for Harcourt, by assuming the debt, as the price of admission into the industry.
Richard A. Smith, chairman and chief executive of General Cinema, said in an statement: "HBJ is a fine company with a rich heritage and prestigious franchises in the publishing field. We look forward to bringing HBJ into the General Cinema group of companies and providing it with the financial resources to further strengthen its operating businesses."
The General Cinema Corporation, based in Chestnut Hill, Mass., operates 315 movie theater complexes in the United States and owns 60 percent of the Neiman Marcus group. It had revenues of $2.1 billion in its fiscal year ended Oct. 31, and net earnings of $111.3 million, or $1.51 a share.
Harcourt Brace Jovanovich had a loss of $26.3 million in its fiscal year ended Sept. 30, on revenues of $1.4 billion. Its assets at that time were valued at about $3 billion, but liabilities totaled $4.5 billion. Its principal business is book publishing, but it is also an underwriter of life, health and accident insurance.
 
Several Offers
 "The debt has been like the bad weather over Iraq," said Peter Jovanovich, Harcourt's chief executive. "It wasn't always possible to assess what was going on at this company, but underneath the fog we have wonderful publishing units -- some that took a hundred years to build. Thankfully, General Cinema had their fog lights on."
Mr. Jovanovich said several companies had bid for Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, but he declined to name them. It is known that one was K-III Holdings, the partnership controlled by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the investment banker.
Harcourt's trade book unit is medium sized but often publishes distinguished lists. This spring, for example, it will publish books by Mark Helprin, Alice Walker and Georges Simenon, and it also publishes Octavio Paz, who won the 1990 Nobel Prize in Literature, and Umberto Eco.
Much of the strength of the company, which was founded in 1919, is in its balance. Academic and professional book publishing accounts for almost half its revenues, while elementary and secondary school publishing accounts for much of the rest. But so many units publish such different books that even in hard economic times one or more units are likely to have a good year.
The company, based in Orlando, Fla., has lost share in recent years in the increasingly competitive market for elementary and secondary school texts. And when Harcourt sold its theme parks, including several Sea World parks, for $1.1 billion last year to meet its debt payments, the sale netted $400,000 less than the company had said it hoped for.
But John S. Herrington, who last May succeeded William I. Jovanovich as chairman of the company, said yesterday that the theme parks' sale looks better every day. "In retrospect the falling attendance rates at theme parks and the gas crisis have proved that was an excellent sale," he said.
General Cinema also has an option to buy a separate part of the company, Academic Press, a profitable publisher of medical and scientific books, for $390 million.
Harcourt officials said they had received assurances that the current management would remain in place.
General Cinema will soon begin preparing tender offers for each series of Harcourt's outstanding public debt securities, and will solicit the consent of their holders to amend certain provisions of the related indentures. The cash amounts to be offered range from $930 per $1,000 principal amount for 13 percent senior notes, to $400 for 14 3/4 subordinated pay-in-kind debentures. Tendering debt holders will also receive, as part of their tender consideration, accrued and unpaid interest until March 15, 1991.

 CORRECTION:
A chart on the front page of Business Day yesterday titled "A Link Between Movies and Books," with an article about a takeover bid by the General Cinema Corporation for Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, misstatedthe full-year revenue figures for Harcourt, as well as the stock prices and fiscal years of Harcourt and General Cinema. Harcourt's revenues were $1.11 billion in 1987; $1.27 billion in 1988, and $1.34 billion in 1989. Harcourt's stock closed Thursday at $1.25 a share, unchanged; its fiscal year ended Dec. 31. General Cinema stock closed Thursday at $20.50, up 12.5 cents; its fiscal year ended Oct. 31.
In addition, the article misstated the year in which Harcourt completed the sale of its theme parks. It was 1989, not 1990.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Dime Savings Bank Raises Its President to Chairman

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
The Dime Savings Bank of New York yesterday elevated its president and chief executive, Richard D. Parsons, to be chairman and chief executive and hired a new president and chief operating officer, Lawrence J. Toal, a former Chase Manhattan banker.
The Dime said Mr. Parsons, 42, succeeded Harry W. Albright Jr., who retired and was named chairman emeritus. Mr. Albright has been chairman since 1981. 
 Mr. Toal, 53, was recruited for the Dime from the Philadelphia Savings Fund Society, a subsidiary of the Meritor Financial Group, where he had been president. He had left the Chase Manhattan Bank in 1987 after a 26-year career there to follow Frederick S. Hammer, another Chase executive, who had gone to Meritor as its president.
The Philadelphia bank is "very profitable," Mr. Toal said. The Meritor holding company, however, ran into trouble when it expanded nationally, realized it could not sustain the growth and cut back on its operations.
The Dime, Mr. Toal said, "has what it takes to weather the storm over the next 12 to 18 months and be a major player."
"It has a good name, good capital position, and a good customer base," he said.
The Dime, which is the largest savings institution in New York, has not been without problems, however. In the third quarter last year, it posted a loss of $153.6 million, citing rising losses on real estate lending, and suspended its common stock dividend. Mr. Parsons said at the time that he was pessimistic about the near-term prospects for the New York economy.
Mr. Toal, born in Queens, is a graduate of Dartmouth and holds an M.B.A. in finance from New York University.
He worked in an assortment of banking jobs at Chase, running its credit card operation, its branch networks and its national expansion program, among other assignments. For three years, he was assigned to Hong Kong to run Chase's operations there, followed in 1984 by an assignment in London to start up Chase's international consumer business.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Transamerica Gives President a New Title

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER

 BODY:
The Transamerica Corporation said yesterday that its president, Frank C. Herringer, would assume the additional post of chief executive.
Mr. Herringer, who is 48 years old, will succeed James R. Harvey, 56, on April 25.
Mr. Harvey, who was named chief executive in 1981, will continue as Transamerica's chairman. He previously served as Transamerica's president from 1979 to 1986 and has been chairman since 1983. 
 Over the last 10 years, Transamerica has restructured itself from a highly diversified company to one focused on insurance and financial services.
"While we have made great progress in developing and implementing a new set of strategies for Transamerica, there is still much that needs to be done," Mr. Harvey said. "I think it's very advantageous to our shareholders to have a younger leader who can enthusiastically carry out our strategic plans and who will also bring a fresh perspective."
Mr. Herringer said he would continue to work closely with Mr. Harvey. Over the last decade, "there is no significant decision that I haven't been fully a part of," Mr. Herringer said. "We have had our differences of opinion, but in the end we always agreed."
Mr. Herringer was elected president of Transamerica in 1986. He joined the company in 1979 as vice president and assistant to the chairman. In 1980, he was named senior vice president with responsibility for corporate strategic planning, including mergers and acquisitions. In 1982, he was elected group vice president for Transamerica's insurance brokerage, manufacturing and transportation operations. In 1984 he was named executive vice president, with responsbility for all of the corporation's insurance activities.
Before joining Transamerica, Mr. Herringer served as general manager of the San Francisco Bay Area Rapid Transit District, known as BART, administrator of the Federal Urban Mass Transportation Administration and a principal with the management consulting firm of Cresap, McCormick & Paget Inc.
Mr. Herringer serves on the boards of the Unocal Corporation, the Pacific Presbyterian Medical Center, the Amos Tuck School of Business Administration at Dartmouth College and at Mills College in Oakland, Calif.
A native of New York City, Mr. Herringer received a bachelor's degree in mathematics and economics from Dartmouth College and an M.B.A. from the Amos Tuck School of Business Administration at Dartmouth. He and his wife, Maryellen, have two children.

HEADLINE: AS A NEW WAR IS RAGING, OPPOSING VOICES FROM THE PAST SOUND OUT AGAIN;
McGovern: 'I Am Ready' to Run

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DURHAM, N.H., Jan. 24

 BODY:
The year is 1991 and America is at war in the Persian Gulf. But for a moment today it seemed as if it was the early 1970's and a different war, for here was George S. McGovern on a college stage talking about running for President.
"I have not yet made the decision, but I am seriously considering it," former Senator McGovern told an overflow audience of 850 students and faculty members at the University of New Hampshire. His suggestion drew cheers and prolonged applause on a campus not noted for political activism. 
 Donna Melillo, a 42-year-old psychologist with the school's counseling service, said, "It's great to hear him talk again." Dr. Melillo said she had voted for Mr. McGovern when he was the Democratic nominee in 1972 and, running on a platform of opposition to the Vietnam War, lost badly to President Richard M. Nixon. He carried only Massachusetts and the District of Columbia.
"It sounds like a lot of hookey, but he appeals to what is best in us, to honor, and not to the greed of the 80's," Dr. Melillo said.
 
A New Set of Issues
 The three-term Senator of South Dakota said that if he did decide to run again, "I would not plan to base my campaign primarily on opposition to the war in the Persian Gulf." He said that while he would have preferred that the United States continued with economic sanctions against Iraq and not gone to war in the gulf, "as an American, I want our forces to prevail."
Mr. McGovern, now 68 years old, said that for the next election he was primarily concerned with America's deteriorating economy and the erosion of the nation's political system. Borrowing a catch phrase from the Republicans, Mr. McGovern said that what America now needs is "a new definition of patriotism" that gets beyond symbolic flag waving.
Under this new patriotism, he said, it would no longer be patriotic to accept huge national debts, to spend hundreds of billions of dollars for defense against the Soviet Union with the cold war over, to tolerate pollution or to go along with "the philosophy of greed and breakdown of Federal supervision that produced the savings and loan scandal."
"It is not patriotic to commit young Americans to war unless our national security clearly requires it," Mr. McGovern added. "It is certainly not patriotic to wink and nod as race relations come under new strains."
 
Into the Vacuum
 Looking tanned and relaxed, Mr. McGovern said, "I would prefer that a younger, less battle-scarred candidate would now come forward" to provide a strong new voice for the Democrats. "But if that is not to be, I believe that I am ready in heart, mind and body to raise the Democratic standard."
He noted that so far, no Democrat has seriously begun a campaign for the Presidency, and in particular that not a single Democrat has opened a campaign operation here in New Hampshire, with its influential first-in-the-nation primary.
It was Senator McGovern's strong second-place finish in the New Hampshire primary in 1972, after Senator Edmund Muskie of Maine, the favorite, that helped propel him to a surprise capture of the Democratic nomination that year.
In 1984 Mr. McGovern, with a poorly financed organization, tried again, narrowly missing a second-place finish in the Iowa caucuses to Walter Mondale and Gary Hart, his former campaign manager.
 
Third Time the Charm?
 Four years later Mr. McGovern bought an inn in Stratford, Conn., but it has been struggling to survive. Asked in an interview about a new Presidential bid, he said: "I'm not under any illusions. I'd like to get something other than pure ridicule if I did it."
In particular, friends say, Mr. McGovern does not relish being labeled another Harold Stassen, the perennial Republican candidate of the 1940's, 50's and 60's.
But Mr. McGovern, who frequently lectures at colleges, said that he had been contacted "by a number of people around the country over the past year about running again." As a result, a group of these people met at his inn on Dec. 28 and decided to form an exploratory committee.
"I haven't told them I would do it, but I said I would give them an answer in a couple of months," he said in the interview.
His visit to New Hampshire today is part of an effort to see whether it makes any sense to run, Mr. McGovern said. The keys are whether he can get enough contributions to qualify for Federal matching funds and whether he can put together a strong campaign organization, he said. In his 1972 campaign, it was his army of zealous volunteers, many of them strongly opposed to the Vietnam war, that helped propel him to the Democratic nomination.
 
Mixed Feelings From Supporters
 Encouraging him to run again is Woody Woodland, a minister in New Boston, N.H., who was Mr. McGovern's state coordinator in 1984. "McGovern people who know the Senator personally have mixed feelings," Mr. Woodland said. "We are excited, but we know it will be rough with comparisons to Stassen."
In his appearance today, Mr. McGovern was careful to differentiate his all-out opposition to the Vietnam War from his reservations about American involvement in the gulf. "One obvious difference is that there was clear aggression in the gulf, with Saddam Hussein invading Kuwait," he said.
He pointed out that Dale Nitzschke, the president of the University of New Hampshire, has a son who is a Marine fighter pilot in Saudi Arabia. And he asked for a moment of prayer for all those caught in the war.
Paradoxically, it was Mr. Nitzschke who invited Senator McGovern to speak here. "I have great respect for George," Mr. Nitzschke said. "The invitation was extended some time ago, before the war, but I know George has a little gleam in his eye. He's sampling things."

HEADLINE: Dinkins to Lead Contingent in Trip to Israel

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins, who has repeatedly criticized the American effort in the Persian Gulf, said yesterday that he would travel to Israel next week in a symbolic gesture of support for Israelis and for American troops.
In the tender world of the city's ethnic politics, the visit could prove awkward. It would appeal to Jewish supporters and strengthen his pro-Israel stance, but it might appear too hawkish to some of his anti-war constituents, including many blacks, who still form the base of his support. 
Mr. Dinkins announced at a news conference that he would travel to Israel on Feb. 2 and return on Feb. 4. During his stay, the Mayor plans to meet with President Chaim Herzog, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, Mayor Teddy Kollek of Jerusalem and Mayor Shlomo Lahat of Tel Aviv. Mr. Dinkins will be accompanied by Representative Charles B. Rangel; the Israeli Consul General, Uriel Savir, and representatives of the Jewish Community Relations Council and the United Jewish Appeal Federation of Jewish Philanthropies.
The Mayor also plans to greet Ethiopian and Soviet Jews who have recently arrived in Israel and to visit victims of Iraqi missile attacks.
"As the Mayor of the city with the largest Jewish community anywhere in the world," Mr. Dinkins said yesterday, "I hope our visit will serve to reaffirm our historic solidarity with the State of Israel, our concern for the safety of the people of the Middle East who are caught up in this conflict, and of course, our support for the men and women in uniform who are risking their lives for freedom."
Albert Scardino, the Mayor's press secretary, said security would be tight and gas masks would be provided for the contingent. City officials are still working on the details, but the trip will be financed by one or two private, nonprofit Jewish organizations that do not do business with the city. Although Mr. Dinkins has said he is opposed to the war, he has expressed continued support for American troops and for Israel's safety as it comes under attack from Iraq.
Many blacks, based on both anecdotal evidence and a recent New York Times/CBS News Poll, are opposed to the gulf conflict. The poll asked 3,002 adults whether they favored starting military action or continuing the use of economic sanctions. The 250 blacks polled were about evenly split on the question, while whites favored military action by a 4-to-1 ratio.
In the vote four days before war started, all black Democrats in Congress opposed the measure authorizing force in the gulf.
During a Jan. 21 rally near City Hall to celebrate the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., some in the predominantly black crowd heckled Mr. Dinkins as being pro-war for appearing the previous day at a rally in support of Israel.
 
'Political Fallout'
 "I don't make decisions based on what the political fallout will be," Mr. Dinkins insisted yesterday when asked about the political ramifications of his visit. "It seems to me that one has to do is make a judgment on what one feels."
The Mayor said yesterday that he and Mr. Rangel, a longtime friend and political ally, conceived the idea of visiting Israel on Thursday night, the same day that Mr. Dinkins and a contingent of mayors attending a United States Conference of Mayors in Washington made a similar overture of support by visiting the Israeli Embassy.
Although Mr. Dinkins said yesterday that he planned the trip without considering political ramifications, he acknowledged that various meanings will inevitably be attached. When asked what he hoped to accomplish beyond an expression of support of Israel and American troops, Mr. Dinkins said that was the simple intent.
Michael Miller, executive director of the Jewish Community Relations Council, praised the Mayor's visit by saying: "Most Israelis know who David Dinkins is. Those in New York see this as a symbolic link between Jews in Israel and people in New York."
Mr. Rangel, who will speak at an anti-war protest in Washington today, said opposition from blacks and from those opposed to the war is a non-issue in regard to his visit to Israel with Mr. Dinkins. He said the visit is a show of solidarity and respect for the State of Israel.
"If you're going to be in Washington tomorrow you'll be privileged to hear me speak against the war," Mr. Rangel told a reporter. "What the heck has that got to do with me going to some people who have been the victims of the war?"

HEADLINE: Florio Budget Is Said to Cut 8,000 Jobs

BYLINE: By PETER KERR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
The Florio administration is planning to eliminate up to 8,000 state jobs -- about 9 percent of the state work force -- in the next fiscal year as part of budget plans that include more than 4,000 layoffs and the reduction of the number of departments to 16, from 19, administration officials said today.
Officials say Gov. Jim Florio plans to present a $14 billion budget that includes severe cuts in state government. They said the proposal, to be presented to the Legislature on Tuesday, reflects an attempt to cope with weak state revenues in a political environment that makes it impossible for the Governor to raise anything resembling a tax. 
 The administration will rely heavily on layoffs, they say, and the consolidation of government departments. State agencies employ about 85,000 people. New Jersey's next fiscal year, when the budget would go into effect, starts on Aug. 1.
 
Decline in Revenues
 "What we've tried to do is make it all more manageable," said an administration official who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "We have gone back to check the mission of every agency when it was established and see if it should still have the same mission. We've tried to get rid of duplication."
Like New York, New Jersey suffered a sharp decline in revenues in the last 12 months as the region's economy slowed.
But as a result of sales, income and other taxes raised here last year, administration officials say New Jersey's problem is not as serious as in nearby states. New Jersey's gap is $800 million, compared with $6 billion in New York and $1.5 billion in Connecticut. The Florio administration said reducing the size of government would save the state $400 million.
 
Cutbacks Are Less Severe
 The $800 million gap represents about one-twentieth of New Jersey's budget, while $6 billion represents about one-fifth of New York's and $1.5 billion is about one-fifth of Connecticut's.
New Jerseyans will see cutbacks in a wide range of services, officials say, but they say there will not be the extreme cuts or the borrowing expected elsewhere.
The consolidation plans for state agencies include the merging of the state's Banking, Insurance and Commerce Departments into a new Department of Regulated Commerce. The Department of Environmental Protection would be merged with parts of the Board of Public Utilities to form a Depart ment of Environmental Protection and Energy.
In preparation for those moves, Mr. Florio today announced the resignation of the Environmental Protection Commissioner, Judith Yaskin and her replacement by Scott Weiner, the president of the Board of Public Utilities. Administration officials said this week that Mr. Florio planned to announce job reductions of between 5,000 and 6,000 in his speech next week. But the administration's ultimate goal, one official said, was to reduce the size of state government by up to 8,000 jobs,The administration's targets for reductions include:
*The layoff of 3,000 workers as a result of 8 percent reductions in the budgets of state departments that Mr. Florio asked his commissioners to make plans for last year.
*The dismissal of up to 1,000 middle-management state workers who are paid an average of $45,000 a year.
*The elimination 300 to 500 state employees as a result of the consolidation of the training and vehicle maintenance programs.
*The early retirement of 2,500 employees under an incentive program for workers who are at least 50 years old.
*The elimination of an additional 2,000 jobs through attrition, replacing only two of three workers who leave the state payroll.
The administration is fairly certain it can eliminate 4,000 jobs through the 8 percent budget reduction and the dismissal of middle-management workers. The jobs to be eliminated through consolidation, retirement and attrition are projections.
 
Workers' Rally
 "The 4,000 layoffs are firm," the official said. "But plans call for 8,000 as a goal."
In response to expected layoffs and demands for givebacks by unionized workers, several thousand state workers who are union members demonstrated outside the State House today, chanting "Hell No, Florio," and "They say pay back. We say give back." The Communications Workers of America and other unions said the Florio administration had asked them to accept $400 million in salary and health concessions on current contracts or to face 10,000 layoffs. The administration denies having threatened 10,000 layoffs.
"We are not going to stand idly by while elected officials attempt to make political points by slam-dunking state workers," said Jan Pierce, a Communications Workers district vice president. "We will be heard."
 
Tax Increases Last Year
 The $14 billion proposal represents a substantial rise in spending. The budget for the current fiscal year is more than $12 billion. The increase includes a jump of $1.1 billion in aid to education, money raised from an income tax increase that Mr. Florio urged last year. That money went to finance Mr. Florio's controversial program to aid poor and lower-middle-income school districts.
About half of Mr. Florio's $2.8 billion in tax increases last year came from a sales tax used to fill a budget shortfall. The other half was an increase in income taxes used to finance his education plan and to provide rebates for middle- and lower-income property taxpayers.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Florio administration plans to eliminate up to 8,000 New Jersey state jobs to ease budget problems. Several thousand demonstrators, members of the Communications Workers of America, protested proposed layoffs yesterday outside the State House in Trenton. (Associated Press) (pg. 28)

HEADLINE: Review/Fashion;
Bohan: A Gallic Revolution in London

BYLINE: By BERNADINE MORRIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
Marc Bohan gave the stolid British couture a lively injection of Gallic style with his first collection for Norman Hartnell , dressmaker to the Queen and her mother. Mr. Bohan, 63 years old, was for almost 30 years the designer for Christian Dior in Paris. His new clothes were graceful, colorful and stunningly simple.
British fashion buffs hope that Mr. Bohan can raise the status of the couture houses here to offer a serious challenge to Paris. 
 The main advantage today is in prices. Several designers claim that a customer could receive change from a 1,000-pound note (the pound is worth about $2) when ordering a relatively simple made-to-order suit or dress. Typical French prices are two to four times as much.
 
Visitors From Paris
 The houses here operate without much fanfare or elaborate promotional efforts, and the workrooms are less sophisticated, one of the reasons Mr. Bohan says he kept his styling simple. Still, the results were particularly appropriate for a time of almost worldwide recession and war in the Persian Gulf. Both situations cut the number of Americans, both clients and press, at his show Thursday, but friends from Paris did cross the channel. They included Alistair Blair and Jean-Louis Scherrer, the designers, and Anne Arnault, the wife of Bernard Arnault, the head of Financiere Agache, which owns Dior.
Mr. Bohan's presence has already spurred five other couture houses here to form a loose federation that coordinated showing dates, scheduling them the week before Paris. Each show consisted of about 50 pieces, half the usual number in Paris.
The Bohan opening capped the week and brought a standing ovation from the usually restrained, mostly British audience. The clothes avoided the frivolities of typical British style as well as the exaggerations of French fashion. They were in cheerful, but not strident, colors, and the neat, clean lines were easy to comprehend and to wear. They expressed a feeling of restrained elegance, comforting in a world in turmoil.
The key to daytime dressing was a fingertip-length jacket that slid gently over the body and often topped a matching short skirt or dress with a flurry of pleats near the hemline. For evening, he offered floor-length dresses that opened at the front to show a shorter skirt underneath. They were occasionally brightened with mirror embroidery, silver nailheads or sequined patches. The clothes were clearly the work of a seasoned designer not interested in making raucous fashion statements.
Anouska Hempel , the trendiest designer showing in London, drew Twiggy and Princess Margaret to her relatively restrained presentation. Mid-thigh hemlines that curved up even higher at the sides, pompons everywhere and touches of color brightened her collection, which usually focuses on black. Twiggy was impressed by the dark green and purple styles.
"Gimmicks are passe," said Franka Stael von Holstein, a designer born in Yugoslavia whose husband is Swedish. Franka , as she known professionally, makes wearable, easy-fitting black dresses with white collars and cuffs and party dresses in interesting shades of chiffon like copper with burnt orange or gold. Her knitwear has been successful at Saks Fifth Avenue and she plans to introduce ready to wear in March.
While the two women staged modest shows in their salons, Victor Edelstein , like Mr. Bohan, introduced his collection at Claridge's and Hardy Amies chose the rotunda of the Coutts & Company's bank headquarters in the West End. Amid reports that French designers were nervously canceling entertainments after their shows, both Mr. Edelstein and Sir Hardy gave cocktail parties or dinners.
Both showed respectable clothes that brought comments like "lovely" or "charming" from their neatly dressed clients.
 
Satin Nehrus
 The Hardy Amies collection combined Bermuda shorts with tailored jackets in bright colors like aqua and yellow in what he called "couture sportswear." It seemed adventure enough. A green chiffon tent was the best of his cocktail dresses and a black silk column decorated with a trio of black ribbons the best of the long dresses.
The most original design for evening was seen in his men's clothes, which included satin Nehru suits, quilted velvet vests and topcoats with cut-velvet shawl collars. Women loved them, for themselves.
The silk tweed fitted suits and a coat in purple, green and orange that opened Victor Edelstein's show were expressed in soft, clean tailoring with a bit of dash. His evening dresses had big, rounded skirts and snug jeweled bodices, except for a white crepe style with controlled fullness. Many thought it would be great for the Princess of Wales.
The best exponent of typical British style is Lachasse , a company that has been around since the early part of this century. Hardy Amies trained there.
"Clients come through recommendations -- women bring their granddaughters," said Peter Lewis-Crown, the owner and designer since 1949. He added that business was up 50 percent for the month of January over the same period last year.
Traditional tweed suits and printed silk ball gowns are specialties; godets and pin tucks were prominent details. A hand-woven Irish tweed suit looked cheerful and indestructible, and showed that fashion can be immutable.

(Jonathan Player for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The program that insures bank deposits will show a deficit sometime next year, the White House has estimated, raising the specter of another huge taxpayer bailout. And after 1992, Government officials said, the hole will only grow deeper. [Page 1.]
The economy contracted at a 2.1 percent annual rate in the final three months of 1990, the biggest quarterly drop in more than eight years and the most definitive proof yet that the nation's longest peacetime business expansion has ended. [1.]
In Richmond, war has put a sizable, though hard-to-measure, dent in a local economy already in recession. [31.]
President Bush nominated as Agricuture Secretary an Illinois Republican, Representative Edward R. Madigan, one of the most influential farm policy experts in Congress. [11.]
Packaging is becoming more of an issue in the battle to win consumers concerned about the environment. Consumer's World. [50.]
 
Companies
Columbia Savings and Loan was taken over by the Government, paying the final price for its risky investment strategy of buying more "junk bonds" than any other savings institution. [31.]
Ratings on Citicorp and Citibank were reduced by Moody's, which cited deterioration in loan portfolios, particularly commercial real estate. [31.]
USAir said it was pulling out of six markets in California and one each in Oregon and Washington State, thus abandoning its hopes to become a major force on the West Coast. [31.]
Morgan Stanley reported sharply lower earnings, citing a sharp drop in investment banking revenues. But the drop was offset by healthy trading revenues and lower pay to employees. [31.]
S.A.S. said it would cut 3,500 jobs, 16 percent of its work force, and slash costs by $540 million. [32.]
After a bizarre marketing mishap, Pepsico executives scrambled to re-edit TV commercials for the Super Bowl to remove references to a phone-in contest that has been canceled. [31.]
Saying its earnings soared 69 percent, Shell Oil joined the ranks of large oil companies reporting strong profits because of oil prices pushed higher by the Persian Gulf crisis. [32.]
Texas Instruments said it lost $56 million in the fourth quarter, as demand for computer chips remained depressed. [33.]
Interco filed for bankruptcy protection. The footwear and furniture maker is struggling with heavy "junk bond" debt. [33.]
Pan Am has refused to carry Iraqi passengers since war broke out. Two years ago it lost a jet with 250 aboard to a bomb. [9.]
 
International
The harmonious facade of corporate Japan cracked in an extraordinary board room attack, as Itoman's directors ousted the president, Yoshihiko Kawamura. [32.]
 
 Markets
Stock prices took wide swings in hectic trading on the heavy flow of war news but managed to end the day higher. The Dow advanced 16.34, to 2,659.41. [34.]
The Treasury securities market was unsettled by a smaller-than-expected G.N.P. decline and the erratic behavior of the interbank lending rates. [34.]
Oil prices slipped further as traders found no reason to act because of war news. Crude settled at $21.35, down 36 cents. [41.] The dollar edged up in cautious trading, and gold was higher. [41.]
 
 Today's Columns
Trusts, a favorite planning tool of the rich, can be used advantageously by middle-income people. Your Money. [32.]
A toothpaste formula said to clear away plaque and tartar without endangering tooth enamel was patented. Patents. [32.]

HEADLINE: One City's Merchants Sense an Eerie Quiet

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RICHMOND, Jan. 22

 BODY:
To Hugh Cline, owner of a two-store appliance business in the suburbs of Richmond, big news is usually good news. Whatever happens, he figures on doing a brisk business in television sets.
Not this time. The outbreak of war in the Persian Gulf has hit hard at Cline Appliance and other local merchants like Hyman Brothers Pontiac and the Adventures Unlimited travel agency. War has put a sizable, though hard-to-measure, dent in a local economy already in recession. 
 "I'd say traffic is off at least 50 to 60 percent" since the shooting started, said Mr. Cline, whose stores sell refrigerators, ranges and other kitchen appliances as well as televisions. "It was just like somebody turned the faucet off."
Other merchants have suffered less. Some, including those who provide shortwave and portable radios, flags, maps, military gear, pizza and snack food, model planes and religious publications, have enjoyed some benefit. Others have already experienced big gyrations.
"The first couple of days it was real scary," said Carl Rosen, general manager of Alan Furs on East Grace Street. "But this week we've been blowing merchandise out of here." With the aid of colder weather, he said, the sales pace has nearly reached the "phenomenal" level generated by post-holiday price cuts and promotions this year, he said.
And at Radio Shack, Gloria Holley, the assistant manager, said, "It was crazy in here for a while." She said customers had swarmed in to buy radios at prices from $24.95 to $199.95 until supplies ran out.
 
Much to Be Lost

Interviews with dozens of Richmond-area businesses and consumers indicate that while the economic impact of the first week of war is mixed, there is relatively little to cheer and potentially much to be lost, even from levels diminished by months of recession.
Consider, for example, the situation at Hyman Brothers, which calls itself Virginia's No. 1 dealer in Pontiacs, a make especially popular among military-age and blue-collar drivers. "It's been very slow for us," since shortly after the shooting started, said Ernie Simopoulos, the worried general manager. He said his competitors, which he has taken to checking frequently, were similarly suffering. 
 
Shattered Confidence
 Richmond, with a population of just over 200,000, is typical of many smaller East Coast cities, with a diverse economy of manufacturing, government and service industries, including medical and educational institutions.
Consumer confidence was shattered when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, an event that many contend pushed a teetering economy over the brink. But confidence will not be easily restored even by a quick victory for the United States-led coalition, said Prof. Richard T. Curtin, who supervises the consumer attitude surveys of the University of Michigan. And should the war be prolonged, as seems increasingly likely, consumers' expectations would probably be further tempered.
"The upside potential is rather shallow," Professor Curtin said, "while the downside risk is much greater."
Consumers rarely shift buying patterns enough to cause the economy to change direction. But because they account for two-thirds of the nation's economic activity, their mood and their ability to buy are crucial to sustaining trends, and if those don't soon improve the recession will likely be longer and more severe than the mild, short-lived slump still projected by most analysts.
At most stores, shops and service establishments in Richmond, consumers are scarce and skittish.
 
A Fear of Terrorism
 "Last Wednesday, it died," said Cathy Madison, a vice president of Adventures Unlimited, of new bookings, especially those to overseas destinations. "It was just like a curtain fell." She said people were not even requesting brochures from the travel agency, much less planning trips. Ms. Madison said she feared that if a terrorist attack occurred in the next week or two it would keep customers away indefinitely.
At the Sixth Street Marketplace, a downtown mall, David Elyea was in a particularly somber mood. A partner in Nicholas & Alexandra, a shop selling Soviet-made gifts, Mr. Elyea, who is in his 20's, was thinking of canceling a trip to the Soviet Union next month because of the risk that he said is "on everybody's mind." He had returned home from Europe on Pan Am only a few days before the December 1988 bombing of Flight 103.
Over on Church Hill, a block from where Patrick Henry made his "liberty or death" speech in old St. John's Church, Jim and Lynn News fretted about business at their inn, called Mr. Patrick Henry's.
"It's going to hurt us," Mr. News said of the war, adding that the couple had added possible furloughs of employees to a list of previously adopted cost-control measures. He noted that restaurants were a luxury that many people could do without. "Nobody needs to go out to eat," he said.
 
Even Dance Classes Affectred
 And except for the items they particularly wanted right away -- from radios to yellow ribbon -- consumers here seem inclined to pull back in ways small as well as big.
At the Shops at Willow Lawn, for example, Carole Lodel said fresh economic uncertainty involving gasoline prices and the war had prompted her to cancel a dance class for her daughter, Elisabeth.
On the other hand, Sue Haase, a single parent who works in the computer department of the James River Corporation, said while buying two $1 flags at a downtown variety store that her outlook was already gloomy because she had been unable to sell her house.
Mr. Cline attributes his failure to sell televisions of late to the fact that people were glued to those they already had. He assumes this situation will not last for long but has little hope of recovering lost sales.
"The last week is pretty much gone forever," he said.
Professor Curtin observed that Americans do not have a recent memory of wartime shortages, unlike the situation at the outbreak of the Korean War. In the absence of indications of shortages, he said, people are unlikely to make precautionary purchases that would spur the economy. Moreover, even a protracted war is unlikely to deplete military stocks enough to generate a big increase in weapons production, which would also stimulate the economy.

HEADLINE: USAir Pulling Back on West Coast

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
USAir, abandoning its hopes to become a force on the West Coast as it is in the East, said yesterday that it was pulling out of six markets in California and one each in Oregon and Washington state.
The carrier also reported a loss of $221.1 million in the fourth quarter of 1990 on revenue of $1.66 billion, compared with a loss of $101.7 million on revenue of $1.5 billion in the fourth quarter of 1989. 
 As part of its pullback in the West, USAir said it would retire 18 BAe-146 aircraft, an 81-seat jet made by British Aerospace. The jet became a favorite of large commuter airlines for carrying passengers to the large hubs of major airlines.
 
Cuts in the East, Too
 USAir also said it would reduce service by 20 daily flights at Cleveland and by 25 daily flights at the Baltimore-Washington International Airport, one of its larger hubs.
The carrier had already been struggling with service problems before the Persian Gulf crisis sharply raised jet fuel costs and induced many travelers to stay home.
USAir was just making progress in solving problems stemming from its merger with Piedmont Airlines. Among the difficulties were a disruption of flights because of a shortage of crews, long delays at airports and misrouted baggage.
Edwin I. Colodny, the chairman and president of USAir Group, the airline's parent company, said a downturn in traffic, a huge increase in fuel costs and the competitive need to offer discount fares put great pressure on the entire airline industry in the fourth quarter.
"Most of these factors continue to be present," he added. "It is unrealistic to think the airline industry's economic environment, which is adversely impacted by the gulf war, will change significantly in 1991."
The cutback will mean that some workers will be dismissed, the company said. But it added that the number had not been determined.
Most of the cutbacks come at what used to be PSA Airlines, which USAir took over in 1986 for $400 million to stay in the race to build a nationwide route system.
USAir will no longer fly from the Burbank, Oakland, Ontario. Orange County, Palm Springs and San Jose airports in California, or from Portland, Ore., and Bellingham, Wash.
USAir said there would be no change in its hourly service between Los Angeles International Airport and San Francisco International Airport.
Over all, the steps will reduce USAir's capacity by 4 or 5 percent.
"It shows that rationality is coming into the airline industry," said Kevin Murphy, an airline analyst for Morgan Stanley. "The West Coast got top-heavy with capacity, and now it's the domain of those that have hubs at Los Angeles and San Francisco."
He said that United Airlines, with its San Francisco hub, and Delta, with a hub in Los Angeles, had survived a grueling battle for the lucrative West Coast markets.
 
 A Series of Cutbacks
 The plans announced today are the latest in a series of steps that USAir, based in Arlington, Va., has taken to stem losses since 1989.
In August the airline furloughed 3,600 workers, including 500 managers, in one of the largest recent cuts in the industry.
The loss that USAir reported for the fourth quarter included a one- time pretax charge of $90 million. The charge consisted of $44 million for lease obligations for the 18 aircraft that will be gradually retired and $46 million for the costs of laying off and relocating employees.
Its losses for the full year of 1990 totaled $454.5 million on revenues of $6.56 billion, compared with a 1989 loss of $63.2 million on revenues of $6.25 billion.
USAir announced this week that Seth E. Schofield would succeed Mr. Colodny as chief executive in June, when Mr. Colodny reaches retirment age. Mr. Colodny, who guided the carrier through the more competitive times of deregulation, will continue as chairman of both USAir and the USAir Group.

HEADLINE: Ouster of Realty Leader Jolts Corporate Japan

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 25

 BODY:
The harmonious facade of corporate Japan cracked today in an extraordinary board room attack, as the directors of Itoman & Company, an ailing trading and real estate concern, rose up and voted to oust the company's president, Yoshihiko Kawamura.
Not since 1982, when the domineering president of Mitsukoshi, a large department store, was dismissed after a scandal has the sometimes harsh warfare inside Japanese companies broken into the open so unceremoniously. 
 The board room battle was just the latest in a series of blows to hit Itoman and the financial institution that effectively controls it, the Sumitomo Bank, Japan's and the world's third-largest bank. And it appears that it was Sumitomo that orchestrated Mr. Kawamura's ouster.
 
 Prices Soared
 Itoman, which is based in Osaka, is one of several big real estate companies that have fallen victim to a Government-ordered credit squeeze. The Finance Ministry stood aside during the last five years as extremely low interest rates and an economic boom sent the prices of various assets, particularly stocks and property, rocketing to unprecedented levels.
Having decided that speculation had gotten out of hand, ministry officials said it was time to wring some of these excesses out of the system.
Itoman is a textile trading company that in the speculative boom of the 1980's went on a real estate buying binge. That has left it smothered by nearly $10 billion in debt, and a cutoff by some lenders.
The Sumitomo Bank rescued Itoman once before, after the oil crisis in 1974 sent Itoman's textile trading business into a tailspin. Mr. Kawamura, in fact, was a Sumitomo executive sent by the bank in 1975 to lead Itoman's overhaul and rehabilitation.
Although Sumitomo owns just under 5 percent of Itoman, in traditional Japanese fashion it exercises effective control through cross-holdings with other affiliated companies and informal ties that have involved sending a number of executives to help manage Itoman.
 
Rates Raised Sharply
 Itoman's recent problems appeared several months ago when it was disclosed that it was suffering from the staggering debt load. Banks here were being forced by the Finance Ministry to curb their lending to speculative real estate companies. The Government also raised interest rates sharply, putting even more pressure on companies that had borrowed heavily to buy property in Japan and in the United States and Europe.
As a result, a number of big real estate concerns have run into problems, among them the Shuwa Corporation, which owns ARCO Plaza in Los Angeles, and EIE International, which is developing the Regent of New York Hotel on 57th Street in Manhattan.
But in most instances, a bank has stepped in to support the ailing real estate companies and provide credit until debt could be reduced, properties sold and the company rebuilt. The Sumitomo Bank has had to sharply increase its lending to Itoman to make up for other forms of credit that were drying up.
Itoman's debt to Sumitomo has jumped to about $3.6 billion, from a little more than $2 billion last September, according to recent reports, as investors stopped buying Itoman's commercial paper and Sumitomo had to replace it with new loans.
 
Scandal Over Art Works
 News reports said Mr. Kawamura had refused repeated suggestions that he resign, saying he wanted to complete the debt reduction and restructuring.
Even worse for both companies' images was a scandal late last year when it was disclosed that Itoman had spent hundreds of millions of dollars on art works. According to news reports, the paintings were bought at inflated values as part of a scheme to avoid direct payments for real estate transactions. In effect, the transactions involving the paintings were used, according to these reports, as a circuitous means of providing payments in land transactions and avoiding the scrutiny of regulators.
Shortly after newspapers reported the scheme, a top Itoman executive, who had come from Sumitomo, committed suicide.
Sotoo Tatsumi, Sumitomo's president, said after the startling announcement of Mr. Kawamura's ouster that Sumitomo would increase its control over Itoman.

HEADLINE: Economy Falls at 2.1% Rate; Decline Is Biggest in 8 Years

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
The economy contracted at a 2.1 percent annual rate in the final three months of 1990, the biggest quarterly drop in more than eight years and the most definitive proof yet that the nation's longest peacetime business expansion has ended.
But the fall was not as sharp as most Government and private economists had predicted. And the report released today was seen as supporting a widely shared view that the recession now gripping the nation, as best as can be judged in the early stages of the Persian Gulf war, would be less severe than most and would end by midyear. 
 "The current economic downturn is likely to be relatively brief and mild," Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher said. "Inflation is subsiding, overall inventories are relatively lean in relation to sales, and the Federal Reserve continues to take steps to support economic growth. In addition, U.S. exports are expanding at a solid pace."
Others took considerably less comfort in the department's report on gross national product. They contended that the fourth-quarter decline would have been far worse without the stimulus of the military buildup and that improvement in exports could not be sustained. The economies of various trade partners are also floundering, they noted, making it unlikely that these countries will buy more American goods.
"The worst isn't over yet," contended Bruce Steinberg, a senior economist at Merrill Lynch & Company, noting that private domestic demand fell more than 4 percent in the latest quarter, with weakness in nearly every sector.
For all of 1990, G.N.P. rose by nine-tenths of 1 percent, compared with 2.5 percent in 1989 and 4.5 percent in 1988. It was the worst annual performance since a 2.5 percent decline for 1982.
The report unsettled the Treasury securities market, which thrives on negative economic news. Investors in debt issues had been expecting a larger drop in the G.N.P., which is the value of all goods and services the economy turns out.
Projected declines for the fourth quarter had ranged from about 2 percent to as much as 5 percent. The Bush Administration was in the mainstream with an estimate of 3.4 percent, while the Congressional Budget Office, with an estimate of 2.6 percent, was in the unusual position of being more optimistic than the White House. Both predicted a smaller contraction for the current quarter, implying that the worst was already over, followed by the beginnings of recovery.
The fourth-quarter decline of about $22.4 billion, or 2.1 percent, followed a 1.4 percent rate of economic growth in the third quarter, a gain that some still find somewhat puzzling, since the recession is thought by many economists to have begun in the summer months.
 
 Expecting 'Clear-Cut' Gains
 The third quarter ended worse than it started, as did the fourth. Speaking today after the G.N.P. figures were released, Michael R. Darby, the Commerce Under Secretary, said, "This trajectory suggests continued softness in the first quarter's output, most likely another outright drop in real G.N.P., but less severe than the fourth-quarter setback."
He said he hoped to see "clear-cut signs of recovery" in three months.
Two straight quarterly declines in G.N.P. are popularly regarded as a sign of recession. But the arbiters at the National Bureau of Economic Research, a private group, consider the depth and breadth of a downturn as well as its persistence, and they have already issued a preliminary ruling that the recession probably started in the summer.
The latest decline was the first since a drop of 1.8 percent in the second quarter of 1986. That decline was unrecognized at the time, emerging later only after many statistical revisions. Last quarter's decline was the largest since one of 3.2 percent in the third quarter of 1982, toward the end of what until now was the most recent American recession and the deepest downturn since the Great Depression.
 
 Inventories Were Slashed
 The fourth-quarter decline was concentrated in motor vehicles, with lower output reflecting weak sales to businesses and consumers and the fact that much of the existing demand was met by drawing down inventories rather than raising production.
Sparse inventories, however, means that when car buying and other demand picks up, "there's going to be instantaneous throttle response" at factories, said Thomas F. Carpenter, chief economist at ASB Capital Management, a Washington money management firm. G.N.P. rises when goods are produced, even if they pile up in the hands of manufacturers or dealers.
Businesses slashed inventories at a rate of $16.3 billion in the quarter, a $21 billion swing from the third quarter, when stocks climbed $4.7 billion.
The fourth quarter was also marked by very strong foreign trade, without which the 2.1 percent decline in G.N.P. would have been almost twice as great, observed C. Fred Bergsten, head of the Institute for International Economics.
He called this a "stunning performance" and said it must be sustained if the economy was to rebound. Mr. Bergsten said he was optimistic that foreign growth would be sufficient to raise imports of American goods and that United States companies, facing weak demand at home and benefiting from a low dollar, would be driven to exploit markets overseas.
Government purchases also helped to minimize the decline in G.N.P. in the last quarter, but this was partly offset by increased military purchases overseas, which raised imports. Thus, the deployment in the Persian Gulf "had little impact" on G.N.P., the Commerce Department said.
When asked about the economic effect of the war, Mr. Darby ventured that while new uncertainty was causing a "holding back" among consumers, this would be countered by higher military spending. "How these balance out is not clear," he said.
 
 Personal Consumption Down
 Real personal consumption fell at a rate of 3.1 percent, today's report also showed, with durable goods down 8.6 percent, nondurables down 5.8 percent and services up seven-tenths of 1 percent.
Housing fell at a 15.4 percent rate, nonresidential fixed investment at 4.6 percent and imports at 6.3 percent. Exports, however, rose at a 7.8 percent rate for the quarter and Government purchases rose 4.9 percent.
Real final sales edged down one-tenth of 1 percent, the report said.
Inflation, as measured by the fixed-weight price index that assumes no change in the composition of output, ran at a moderate 4.1 percent rate in the quarter, slightly below the 4.2 percent of the third quarter. The implicit price deflator, which takes account of changed production patterns, fell to 2.8 percent, from 3.7 percent.
In current dollars, rather than in constant 1982 dollars, G.N.P. rose three-tenths of 1 percent, compared with 5.3 percent in the third quarter.
The savings rate -- personal savings as a percentage of disposable personal income -- was essentially unchanged at 4.1 percent last quarter.

HEADLINE: $56 Million Loss at Texas Instruments

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Jan. 25

 BODY:
Texas Instruments Inc. said today that it had lost $56 million in the fourth quarter, as demand for computer chips remained depressed and prices continued to fall. The company's chairman, Jerry R. Junkins, indicated the loss would widen in the current quarter.
"We expect the pressure on financial results to become more intense in the near term," he said. Revenues in the fourth quarter were up 2.3 percent, to $1.76 billion from $1.72 billion. In the 1989 quarter, earnings were $36 million, or 33 cents a share. 
 The loss for 1990 was $39 million, and it was the first unprofitable year for the company since 1985, when the loss was $140.9 million. Earnings in 1989 were $292 million, or $3.04 a share. For the year the company had revenues of $6.57 billion, up less than 1 percent from 1989's $6.52 billion. Share Price Off $3
The size of the fourth-quarter loss and Mr. Junkins's comment disappointed Wall Street, where Texas Instruments' share price fell $3, to $34.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Prices for high-volume chips made by Texas Instruments and several of its Asian rivals plummeted as the American economy weakened in the second half of the year.
For example, chips with a million characters of memory -- used in increasingly huge quantities in computers, cars and electronics -- fell in price to $3.50 each in early December, from $6 early in the year, according to In-Stat Inc., a research firm in Scottsdale, Ariz.
Texas Instruments continued its heavy spending to complete new chip-making plants and to finance research, but it slashed 1,600 jobs from slowing military operations. Mr. Junkins said military orders could increase in the months ahead because of the gulf war but that the trend in military sales was downward. The company makes a laser-guided bomb, the Paveway, and a high-speed anti-radiation missile, called the HARM, used by the American-led coalition against Iraq.
 
Japanese License Deal
 Texas Instruments also said today that it had completed a patent-licensing pact with the Oki Electric Industry Company, a Japanese concern. As in earlier deals with the Toshiba Corporation and Samsung Electronics, Texas Instruments did not disclose the terms. It did say that it expected that royalty payments with the three companies would "greatly exceed" yearly amounts from past agreements. Royalty income in 1990 was $172 million, compared with $165 million in 1989.
Some analysts had estimated that the licensing pacts Texas Instruments has completed or negotiated since 1987 with Asian chip makers could bring more than $4 billion in royalty income through 2001. Mr. Junkins's warning of larger losses ahead was a hint that those estimates were too high, said James L. Barlage, a semiconductor analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.
Sales could improve quickly if the economy picked up, Mr. Junkins said, because inventory levels among computer chip customers were low. Demand should rebound later in the year and into 1992, but for now, demand from electronics manufacturers, especially computer companies, was sluggish, he said.

HEADLINE: Administration Foresees a Deficit In Bank Insurance Fund by 1992

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
Raising the specter of another huge taxpayer bailout, the White House has estimated that the program that insures bank deposits will show a deficit sometime next year, Government officials said today. And after that, they said, the hole will only grow deeper.
The projection by the Office of Management and Budget, made in the budget request the White House will send to Congress on Feb. 4, is the first official estimate to become public that suggests that the bank insurance fund could be insolvent as early as 1992. The White House projection is that by the end of next year, the fund will have a deficit of $4 billion and that by 1995 the shortfall will be $23 billion. 
 A taxpayer rescue could be averted through increased industry contributions, but the insurance fund's troubles would still be felt by bank depositors and other customers through increased fees and lower rates paid on deposits.
The fund has posted three consecutive years of losses, and is now at its lowest ratio of insurance to deposits since its creation in 1934. Because of the growing number of failures of large banks, the fund is expected to show record losses for both last year and this year, totaling $9 billion. That would leave it with about $4 billion by the end of this year.
 
Fears of Another Bailout
 Administration officials have struggled in recent months to distinguish the plight of the fund and the commercial banking industry from that of the nation's savings and loans. The bailout of that industry could cost taxpayers as much as $500 billion over 40 years. But the latest estimates on the bank fund and the failure of the banking industry to agree on a solution provide the strongest indication so far that a bailout to protect bank deposits may also be needed.
"The Treasury is looking at a budget that has a black hole and saying our first job is to fill that black hole," a bank lobbyist said. "If the economy and the real estate markets do not turn around soon, then it is clear we will not be able to make up the difference."
Industry representatives have been meeting with regulators and Treasury officials this week to try to find a way to rebuild the insurance fund through industry contributions in a way that would not cripple banks, many of which have been posting anemic profits.
"They are still far from any agreement," said L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. He added that within the next month, the F.D.I.C. would probably be considering another increase in the premiums that banks pay to the insurance fund.
 
 Rising Premiums
 On Jan. 1, the premium paid by banks to the fund rose to 19.5 cents for every $100 in deposits, from 12 cents. Lobbyists are predicting that it could soon be increased again, to at least 23 cents. For the first nine months of 1990, the industry earned about 60 cents for each $100 in deposits.
The White House estimate is based on the expectation that the premium will increase to 23 cents, an 18 percent jump over the current payments and a 92 percent rise over the 12 cents paid last year. Its projections for losses are based upon an economic model that compares the capital and quality of assets of banks with the trends shown by similar institutions that failed.
A similar method has been used by the Congressional Budget Office, which will present its latest forecasts on the health of the insurance fund at a Congressional hearing on Tuesday. The budget office projection is also expected to show a deficit, even assuming an increase in industry contributions.
Mr. Seidman said the F.D.I.C. was in the process of calculating how it would fare in 1992, and he questioned the reliability of long-range forecasts. Within the last year, the F.D.I.C. has been forced several times to increase its estimates of the amount it expected to lose.
The Administration is preparing to release its proposals for overhauling the banking industry next week, shortly after the President's State of the Union address on Tuesday.
 
 Activities Are Restricted
 The proposals will call for the elimination of barriers that have prevented the merger of commercial and investment banks, have sharply limited interstate banking and have prohibited industrial enterprises from owning commercial banks. The Administration will also recommend a significant reorganization of the regulatory structure that oversees banks and savings associations.
But officials said today that the package might not include specific details on reorganizing the bank insurance fund because bank trade groups in Washington had been unable to agree among themselves on how to proceed.
A senior official at the Treasury Department said that despite the disagreements, the Administration would support some significant principles in next week's report.
"We think our plan ought to take care of the future and rely on the industry," said the official, who insisted on anonymity. "But it ought not break the backs of the banks."
"It ought to have the industry's leadership behind it, but that is complicated to achieve," the official continued. "To bring together an industry as diverse as banking is a very, very tough job."
 
 Sizing Up the Contributions
 The official said the Treasury Department did not know how much the industry would be able to contribute without damaging some banks and leading to sizable failures.
One proposal under discussion is for banks that are more secure to set up a fund to invest in weaker institutions. But officials and industry representatives said there were substantial disagreements over the size of such a fund and its structure. Of particular concern to some banks, especially the smaller ones, is whether the fund would be used only to prop up the larger institutions.
Another proposal being discussed is the issuing of zero-coupon bonds backed by bank assets to raise $25 billion.

HEADLINE: Carter Hawley Cuts Nearly 100

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25

 BODY:
Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. said it had dismissed nearly 100 workers after failing to achieve enough job cuts through attrition. In October, the Los Angeles-based retailer cut 350 workers and said it would eliminate another 650 jobs by leaving openings unfilled. But the level of attrition was low because of the uncertainties of recession and the Persian Gulf crisis, forcing this week's action, a company spokesman, Bill Dombrowski, said.
The department store operator suffered a loss of $14.9 million in its first quarter, which ended on Nov. 3, after losing $9.5 million in the previous fiscal year. The company, which operates Broadway, Weinstocks and Emporium stores in California and the West, recently sold its Thalhimer division for $325 million.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Avery Charge Of $85 Million

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25

 BODY:
The Avery Dennison Corporation, an office and industrial products company formed three months ago through the merger of Avery International and Dennison Manufacturing, said today that it would take an $85 million charge against fourth-quarter earnings to cover the cost of job cutbacks and other changes.
The changes, which include eliminating 700 to 900 jobs in the next 18 months, will result in a loss for the quarter. 
 Avery Dennison, which is based in Pasadena, Calif., said it had been hurt by the slowing economy and had unexpectedly weak profits from its Dennison operations.
The company said it was realigning several businesses and would sell off some small operations besides eliminating jobs. The $85 million charge comes in addition to a $14 million charge covering merger expenses.
The restructuring charge will reduce net income by about $52 million, resulting in a quarterly loss. The company predicted full-year earnings will be about 10 cents a share.
Avery Dennison's stock slipped 25 cents today, to $20, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Treasuries Unsettled by G.N.P. Data

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
The Treasury securities market was unsettled yesterday by a smaller-than-expected decline in the nation's gross national product and the erratic behavior of the interbank lending rates in recent days, which suggested that banks have become reluctant to lend reserves to other banks, or even to dealers.
At the opening, the Treasury debt market reacted negatively to the Government's report of a 2.1 percent decline in the total output of goods and services in the last quarter of 1990. This was much less of a decline than most estimates had suggested. 
 Because the market in fixed-income debt thrives on negative economic news, the G.N.P. report caused selling of Treasury debt issues. Also weighing on the bond market, which always fears any development that could stimulate inflation and higher interest rates, was the persistent high level of the rate that banks charge one another for temporary loans.
 
Fed Intervened at Midday
 Despite another move by the Federal Reserve to add reserves to the banking system, the interbank lending rate soared as high as 9 percent just before the close. The funds rate was at 7 percent, or a quarter-point above the Fed's perceived target, when the central bank intervened at midday to reduced this bedrock cost of credit.
Philip Braverman, senior vice president and chief economist at the DKB Securities Corporation, the domestic arm of the Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank of Tokyo, said some banks had become reluctant to lend reserves to other banks and even to Treasury securities dealers who normally tap the funds market to finance inventory.
What may also be causing banks to hold back their reserves, he continued, is the belief that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation may at some point limit its coverage of bank deposits to $100,000 for each individual Social Security number.
"When this happens, we can expect a massive outflow of funds from banks by individuals and all kinds of other depositors with more than one account," Mr. Braverman said. "We can also expect a huge inflow of funds into Treasury securities, which may be one of the few safe investment places left for savings and deposits over $100,000."
 
Quarterly Treasury Refunding
 Government securities dealers were loath to discuss their inventory financing practices or how they plan to finance their purchases at the coming quarterly Treasury refunding, the terms of which are to be announced on Wednesday. The Treasury is expected to auction a record $34 billion of 3- and 10-year notes and 30-year bonds the following week.
In late trading, the Treasury's benchmark long bonds, the 8.75 percent issue maturing in August 2020, had recovered a bit to close down 28/ 32, at 105 26/32. This caused its yield to climb to 8.22 percent, from 8.15 percent the day before and 8.17 percent a week ago.
Because of the confusion over the funds rate, dealers said it had a minimal, if any, influence on Treasury bill rates, which are most sensitive to any change in the funds rate. The discount rate on 90-day bills rose five basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 6.18 percent. Six-month bills gained three basis points, at 6.20 perent, and the one-year bills advanced four basis points, to 6.20 percent.
Among other representative Treasury issues traded in the secondary market, the new 7 percent notes of 1993 and 7.5 percent notes of 1996 that were auctioned this week showed little change from the average sales prices.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises on G.N.P. Data; Gold Prices Also Advance

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar edged up in cautious trading yesterday after pessimism about the economy was tempered by a Government report that was better than expected.
Gold was slightly higher, with the price up in New York by $2.70 an ounce, to $375.70 on the Commodity Exchange. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid for gold of $375.50, up $2.75 from late Thursday. 
 Traders said the dollar staged a small early rally when the Commerce Department reported that the United States economy declined at an annual rate of 2.1 percent in the final three months of 1990.
The Government said the gross national product -- the country's total output of goods and services -- dropped at the sharpest rate since a 3.2 percent decline in the third quarter of 1982. Many economists took the report as verification that the nation is in a recession.
But currency analysts said the number was better than the 3 to 4 percent decline that the market had been expecting. "It was a startling bit of news," said Robert Ryan, corporate foreign exchange manager for the Bank of New York. "It dampened the pessimism that was out there."
 
Dealers Wary
 The dollar moved narrowly, a reflection of reluctance among dealers to take major positions without knowing what might happen in the Persian Gulf over the weekend.
"People are playing close to their chest," said Bob Morrissey, senior trader at the Bank of Boston. "If they are running positions over the weekend, they are running much smaller than they usually are.
The dollar rose marginally in New York against the Japanese yen, to 132.55 yen from late Thursday's 132.35. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.73 yen, to 132.38 yen. Later in London, it was quoted at 132.25 yen.
The dollar also rose slightly against the British pound in New York, where sterling fetched $1.9564, compared with $1.9565 late Thursday. In London, the pound fell to $1.9580, from $1.9600 late Thursday.
And the dollar was up against the German currency, to 1.4910 marks from 1.4868.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday, were: 1.2628 Swiss francs, up from 1.2575; 5.0685 French francs, up from 5.0550; 1,120.50 Italian lire, up from 1,117.75, and 1.1643 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1600.
