HEADLINE: For Collection Agencies, These Are Busy Times

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
In the current recession, promptly paying bills -- or not paying bills -- is perhaps the best indicator of an individual's financial health. And the people who best know when and whether bills are being paid these days are the nation's 6,000 collection agencies, the companies that collect debts owed to others. As they tell it, there's been a slowdown in paying bills, which makes them busier than they've ever been before. What's more, today there are more collectors in the field.
"If you have increasing unemployment, folks are going to have less discretionary dollars for bills they have accumulated," said William Mark Edwards, vice president of Credit Bureau Systems, a debt collection agency in Paducah, Ky. "It's going to make it a tougher dollar to collect." Mr. Edwards is also the chairman of the collection service division of Associated Credit Bureaus, a trade association. 
 Larry D. Wages, the president of the Merchants Association of Fresno, Calif., which handles collections among its other activities, said: "As things slow down, merchants and other creditors start looking at their outstandings. They are turning stuff to collection agencies a little bit sooner."
The American Collectors Association, the major trade group for collection agencies, with about 3,500 members, estimates that three million companies in such fields as retailing, banking and health care grant credit to consumers each year. But less than 1 percent of all outstanding debts are turned over collection agencies, the group said.
Mr. Edwards noted that companies that have extended credit now typically call in a commercial collection agency when payments are three to four months past due and an outside agency seems to be their only hope of getting any money at all.
"In tough times, most collection agencies will have more listings, but we will not recover as much as in better times," said George Goodyear, the president of Goodyear & Associates, a collection agency in Charlotte, N.C., and the president of the American Collectors Association.
Last year, $72.4 billion worth of debts was listed with collection agencies in the United States, compared with $51.5 billion the previous year, according to the collectors asssocation. But the actual collection rate fell to 18.4 percent of the total amount, compared with 21 percent the previous year..
Collection agencies work on commission, now 25 to 34 percent of the amount collected. Richard W. Gilbert, a senior vice president of Equifax, Inc., the giant Atlanta financial company whose services include bill collection, said that the commission depends on many factors, including the balance due, the length of time the account has been overdue and the type of account.
Since collectors derive income only from the amount they collect, their appetite has been growing as the economy weakened.
"The most common consumer complaint is oral harassment," said Jean Noonan, the associate director for credit practices of the Federal Trade Commission. "Consumers have a right to tell the debt collector to stop contacting them."
Another common complaint, Ms. Noonan said, is so-called third-party contacts, which are illegal. "They can call a relative, neighbor or employer for location information," she said, "but they cannot discuss the debt."
The usual first step taken by collection agencies is to send a form requesting payment, This gives the name of the creditor and the amount owed, and it must advise you of your rights and inform you what to do if you believe that you do not owe the money.
The actions that debt collectors can and cannot take are governed by the Federal Debt Collection Practices Act, which is administered by the F.T.C. But collection agencies do not have to be licensed by the Federal Government.
Among the outlawed collection tactics: calling you at inconvenient or unusual times. That means before 8 A.M. or after 9 P.M., but if you have a good reason -- say, you work at night and sleep during the day -- you can ask to be called at another time.
In addition, collectors are not permitted to threaten, intimidate or make false statements. They cannot, for example, say directly or imply that they are government representatives or that you have committed a crime. They may not send you any material that looks like an official document from a court or government agency. And they may not obtain information under false pretenses, collect more money than is legally due, deposit a postdated check before the date on the checkor hold the debtor up to public ridicule.
If you think that a collector has broken the law, you can, of course, sue the collection agency. If you win, you can receive up to $1,000 in damages plus your legal costs, Ms. Noonan said. And you can complain to your local Better Business Bureau, state Attorney General or to the F.T.C.
You can also sue the collection agency. If you win, you can receive up to $1,000 in damages plus your legal costs, Ms. Noonan said.

 
WHERE TO GET INFORMATION
 A free brochure on debt collection is available from the Federal Trade Commission, Sixth Street and Pennsylvania Avenue NW, Washington, D.C. 20580. Attention: Ed Bush.
Another brochure, "Consumers, Collectors and the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act," is available for 25 cents from Consumer Pamphlets, Associated Credit Bureaus, P.O. Box 218300, Houston, Tex. 77218.

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Called Set to Urge Summit Delay

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
Administration officials said today that the United States intended to inform the Soviet Union on Saturday that because of the crackdown in the Baltics, Washington wants to "postpone" the next summit meeting indefinitly.
The Soviet Foreign Minister, Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, is to meet here on Saturday with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. 
 A senior Administration official said that unless Mr. Bessmertnykh brings some startling and convincing new message about a changed Soviet policy for the Baltics, or possibly concessions that will allow the still uncompleted negotiations for a treaty limiting long-range nuclear weapons to be concluded, he will be told that the Administration wants to postpone the summit meeting, planned for Feb. 11 to 13.
"Unless Bessmerthnykh pulls a rabbit out of a hat, the plan is to postpone," a senior Administration official said.
 
Hoping to Break Deadlock
 One reason American officials in recent days have indicated that they are inclined to postpone the summit may be the hope that this signal would induce the Soviets to break the deadlock in the negotiations for a strategic arms reduction treaty, known as Start.
President Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, had hoped to sign a strategic arms reduction treaty at the February summit. But the two sides have not been able to resolve some highly technical disputes over how to verify certain aspects of the treaty. If Mr. Bush could say he was going to Moscow to sign a treaty that would slash long-range nuclear arsenals by 30 percent, it would be much easier for him to justify the meeting, despite the violence in the Baltics.
But even if such a treaty is possible, the summit meeting would still be jeopardy, officials said.
"It's not only the Baltics that's a problem," an Administration policymaker said. "It is also the idea of the President being in Moscow for three days in the middle of a war."
 
Meeting With Bush on Monday
 A formal announcement about the fate of the summit will be made only on Monday, after Mr. Bessmertnykh meets the President at the White House. A cancellation would almost certainly be presented as a "mutual decision," in hopes of lessening the embarrassment and domestic political damage to Mr. Gorbachev.
In a brief news conference Friday, Mr. Bush declined to commit himself, but he gave the most downbeat public assessment yet about the prospects for a summit meeting, in the wake of the recent killing of 19 pro-independence demonstrators by Soviet troops in Latvia andLithuania.
"I am looking forward to the consultations that Secretary Baker will have with Mr. Bessmertnykh," Mr. Bush said. "Mr. Bessmertnykh knows the United States very well, and he knows the difficulties that we have with any use of force in the Baltics. We're going to see how this plays out, and we have an arms control agenda that I want to see fulfilled. But whether it would be ready in time for the meeting as now scheduled, I don't know. We're having some difficulties there, frankly."
Asked whether he now felt it was less important for American-Soviet relations if Mr. Gorbachev survived in office, or if Washington intended to cancel the summit anyway simply because of American outrage over the Baltics, Mr. Bush said:
"I'm disappointed in the Soviet actions in the Baltics because use of force is not the way to resolve that problem. And I've had an opportunity to discuss that with the President, and I know the difficulties that he faces. And I have not lost sight of the fact that Mr. Gorbachev was the catalyst, really, for much of the change that has taken place in Eastern Europe; had a lot to do with the reunification of Germany, a lot to do with common ground in the Persian Gulf."
 
'Great Difficulty' on Baltics
 He then added: "But the problems in the Baltic states, the use of force there, causes us great difficulty. And so the Bessmertnykh-Baker talks will touch on a wide array of issues, some where we have very much common ground, some where we have common objectives that are not fulfilled, and some where we might have clear differences. And at that point, I will take a look again at the whole problem and see what must be done, and I'm sure the Soviets will be doing the same thing."
Mr. Bessmertnykh, a former Ambassador to Washington, will be on his inaugural visit to the United States as Foreign Minister, since he replaced Eduard A. Shevardnadze two weeks ago.
Both the Senate and the House have passed nonbinding resolutions calling on Mr. Gorbachev to halt immediately his use of force in the Baltics, and at a meeting Thursday at the White House between Mr. Bush and Republican Congressional leaders, the President was bluntly warned about the rising sentiment in Congress against his going to Moscow at this time.
The Senate resolution, passed Thursday, appealed to the President to suspend all technical exchanges with the Soviet Union, review all economic aid to Moscow and consider withdrawing Washington's support for Soviet membership in the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The Soviets have already begun drawing the $1 billion in food credits that Mr. Bush extended last month in order to help the country through the winter.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: North Africa;
Pro-Iraq Sentiment Is Increasing in North Africa

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TUNIS, Jan. 23

 BODY:
All along this city's main boulevard, clusters of young men, many of them unemployed, form in front of newsstands and grow angry as they read the latest news from the Persian Gulf war.
"Storm Over a Few Prisoners of War, Silence Over a Genocide," declared the two-inch-tall headline in La Presse, while the front page of Le Temps announced, "Saddam Hussein Proclaims That Iraq Has Not Yet Used All Its Arms." 
 "We're all for Saddam," said Chadli Braham, one of the angry young men hanging out on the boulevard. "I'm absolutely sure that Saddam is going to win. America isn't fighting just 17 million Iraqis; it's fighting hundreds of millions of Arabs. We have God on our side."
Although Tunisia has long been Washington's best friend in the Arab world, it has been hard to detect much good will here -- or in much of North Africa -- toward the United States since the American-led coalition began bombing Iraq last week. Through protest marches, officials' statements and harsh newspaper commentaries, Tunisia has joined other North African countries, including Algeria and Mauritania, in lashing out against the United States and its military partners.
 
Government Condemns Bombing
 North Africa's people, poor and long angry about the plight of the Palestinians, overwhelmingly support the Iraqi leader's defiance of the West. Tunisia's Government, like Algeria's, has condemned the bombing of Iraq, both in deference to the passions so evident on the street and in part to keep the fundamentalist opposition from stealing the issue.
"If the people are with Saddam, it is because he is challenging the Western world," a senior Tunisian official said. "He is a symbol of pride. Arab people feel humiliated, especially regarding Israel and the lack of progress of the intifada. The Arabs are hoping that through Saddam they will regain a sense of dignity."
The Tunisian Government has begun a campaign to collect blood for its "Iraqi brothers." In Morocco, opposition leaders are calling on King Hassan II to withdraw the nation's 1,500 troops in Saudi Arabia, saying they are not defending Arabs, but carrying out a "Zionist plan" against Iraq.
In Mauritania, the police fired tear gas to break up a rally of 20,000 demonstrators who marched on the American and French Embassies after Friday prayers. Heeding the advice of the Government, almost 1,000 Westerners, most of them French, have left their homes to camp out at the heavily protected French Embassy.
 
Many Seek to Enlist for Iraq
 As war fever is sweeping Algeria, hundreds of young men have sought to enlist to fight on Iraq's side. The Government, after speaking softly and trying to mediate in the gulf crisis, has begun competing with the fundamentalist opposition for the most fiery pro-Iraqi, anti-American polemics.
While the Algerian opposition, the Front for Islamic Salvation, called for a trade embargo against Egypt and Saudi Arabia, the Government's newspaper said, "The battle that has begun in the gulf is not Iraq's, but that of all the Arab and Muslim countries, against the great Western powers: the United States, Britain, France and the West's creature, Israel."
Since the State Department warned of possible danger in North Africa last week after the war began, thousands of Americans and other Westerners have left the region. For the last week, the Tunisian Government has protected the American Embassy with tanks, machine gun-armed soldiers and five-foot-tall spirals of barbed wire.
"It's wrong for a heavyweight like the United States to hammer on a lightweight like Iraq," said Abbes Agha, who owns a men's wear shop. "America has dropped more bomb tonnage on Iraq than was dropped on Hiroshima. The Americans are proud of that, but I'd say that's nothing to be proud of."
 
Hypocrisy Is Seen
 Mr. Agha added that he thought Washington was hypocritical to go to war to end Iraq's occupation of Kuwait while doing little about Israel's occcupation of Palestinian lands. "Whatever warm feelings Tunisians had toward America are fast dissipating," he said.
From the start, the Tunisian Government, unlike many of its people, criticized Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. But the Government now says the bombing campaign against Iraq goes beyond what the United Nations Security Council approved.
"We're witnessing the total destruction of Iraq's industrial and economic potential and not the liberation of Kuwait," the Tunisian Foreign Minister, Habib Boulares, said in a radio interview. This "won't fail to have grave consequences for the security and interests of the entire Arab nation."
"Tunisians are very angry inside about the war, but things are relatively quiet because the Government has made it clear that it will clamp down," a teacher said.
 
Fighting Against the Rich
 A major reason most Tunisians, Algerians and Moroccans back Mr. Hussein is they see him as their brother in fighting against the rich. The masses of people have few kind words for Kuwait and were not sad that Iraq gobbled it up.
"It's not fair that the Kuwaitis were building million-dollar castles and investing billions of dollars abroad when most of the Arab world has to eat crumbs," said Fathi Bouguerra, a taxi driver.
The people here also have little sympathy for the Saudi monarchy, seeing it as a plutocratic elite that cares little for the Arab poor. In their view, the monarchy betrayed the Arab world by inviting in Westerners to help defend it, rather than finding an Arab solution to the crisis.
The region has also embraced the Iraqi leader because he has struck out against Israel and spoken out for the Palestinians.
"You can't imagine how great our happiness was when Scuds landed in Israel," a Tunisian official said. "The fact that he showed Israel could be struck put pride in our hearts. It showed the Arab world could strike a blow against Israel."

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Religious Leaders;
Cardinal Says Iraqi's Acts Prove Bush Right

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS

 BODY:
Saying that prompt military action in the Persian Gulf now appears to have been necessary, Bernard Cardinal Law of Boston has become the highest-ranking Roman Catholic prelate in the nation to offer support for President Bush's position.
In a column published yesterday in the weekly newspaper of the Boston Archdiocese, Cardinal Law said President Saddam Hussein's conduct since Jan. 15, the United Nations-imposed deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, showed that postponing military action "could have played to his advantage." 
 "The allies were faced with a regrettable dilemma," the Cardinal wrote. "Even as we echo the prayer of Pope Paul VI, 'No more war, war never again,' with heavy hearts we realize that such a prayer is not fulfilled at the price of granting tyrants and aggressors an open field to achieve unjust ends."
Although the nation's Roman Catholic hierarchy had urged continued reliance on economic sanctions, since the outbreak of fighting individual bishops have taken positions ranging from outright condemnation of the war to stances similar to that of Cardinal Law.
On Jan. 17, the president of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, Archbishop Daniel E. Pilarczyk of Cincinnati, said, "History will judge whether or when this war should have been launched." The Archbishop emphasized that moral limits had to be respected in combat.
And last Sunday, James Cardinal Hickey of Washington said Catholic "moral tradition clearly does not sustain peace at any price." He cited the conclusion of "many well-informed persons" that "armed intervention has become a necessity to resist aggression."
But unlike Cardinal Law, Cardinal Hickey did not quite say he had personally reached the conclusion that American military action had been necessary now.
Within the spectrum of Catholic bishops' opinion, two trends are becoming discernible. Some bishops are insisting that because, in their judgment, economic and diplomatic means for obtaining a settlement had not been exhausted the Persian Gulf war did not meet the requirement in Catholic teaching that a war can be just only if undertaken as a last resort.
"I am not convinced that this is a war of last resort," Archbishop Francis T. Hurley of Anchorage said Jan. 17. "It is a war without glory."
Prelates like Archbishop Raymond Hunthausen of Seattle and Bishop Walter Sullivan of Richmond have also continued to challenge any need for war.
 
Moral Scrutiny of Fight
 But many other bishops, following Archbishop Pilarczyk's lead, are taking the fact of the war as a starting point and concentrating on moral scrutiny of the way it is fought. John Cardinal O'Connor of New York and Archbishop John R. Quinn of San Francisco, for example, have warned against direct attacks on civilian populations.
At an antiwar demonstration at the White House last Wednesday, Auxiliary Bishop Thomas Gumbleton of Detroit, president of Pax Christi U.S.A., a Catholic antiwar group, expressed disappointment with the recent statements of many fellow bishops.
Since the war began, he said, their attitude has been "to get behind the President and be careful not to divide the Catholic community." Bishop Gumbleton has said he hopes to encourage conscientious objection among military people.

HEADLINE: State Capitals Show Population Gains

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
Expanding employment in state government and higher education in the 1980's fueled population gains in college towns and state capitals, according to 1990 census figures released today.
The population of cities like Lawrence, Kan., home of the University of Kansas; Columbus, Ohio, home of the state government and of Ohio State University, and West Lafayette, Ind., home of Purdue University, gained 20 percent or more even as the states around them stagnated. The new census figures show that North Dakota, for example, lost 1.7 percent of its population, but its capital, Bismarck, gained 10.7 percent. 
 This trend did not hold true in older cities in the East that are state capitals, like Boston or Atlanta. But generally, said John Connally, an assistant director of the Census Bureau, "You get one star if you have a state capital, two if you have a college or university, and three if there's a major medical center there."
In their overall depiction of the country, the new numbers reflected trends long tracked by demographers, most dramatically the population gain of 6 million in population registered by California, much of that on the immigrant- and industry-rich southern coast.
 
Decline of Northern Cities
 The new numbers also demonstrated anew the decline of many Northern urban centers, a decline now spreading to the inner suburbs of cities like New York, Washington and Detroit. And they reflected the continued decline of old industrial cities like Gary, Ind., which lost 26 percent of its population in the 1980's, and the quick expansion of suburban and satellite communities on the edges of metropolitan areas from Frederick County in Maryland to Orange County in California.
But, while the new figures provide a thorough confirmation of some of the population trends of the decade, particularly the impact that an influx of 7 to 9 million Latin American, Asian and European immigrants has had on the United States in the 1980's, demographers combing through the numbers today found other trends that have gone relatively unnoticed. Among them are these:
*Older industrial cities in the South are joining their Northern counterparts in the cycle of decline. Atlanta, Birmingham, Ala., Macon, Ga., Chattanooga and Knoxville, Tenn., were among the Southern cities losing population. "About 25 percent of all the big cities lost, and half of those that lost were in the South," said William O'Hare, director of policy studies for the Population Reference Bureau, a Washington-based research organization.
*Immigration has been a bulwark against decline in other major cities, he said, including Miami, New York and New Jersey communities like Elizabeth and Jersey City, both of which registered modest population gains of 2 to 4 percent. In the more suburban areas of New Jersey like Gloucester, Hunterdon and Middlesex counties, a combination of expanding suburbs and thousands of immigrants from India, China, the Philippines and the Dominican Republic pushed growth rates to near 15 percent, triple the state's growth rate.
*California's growth, while the best-told story of the 1990 census, continued to generate astonishing statistics: of the 29 cities that surpassed the population mark of 100,000 for the first time, 18 were in California. Seven of the 10 fastest growing cities in the 100,000-plus group were in Southern California, including Chula Vista, Bakersfield, Irvine, Oceanside and Escondido. One American in eight now lives in California.
*In other states with big gains, like Texas and Florida, there was a mixture of growth and decline, although growth predominated. Texas, whose population swings tracked the roller-coaster fortunes of the oil industry, still had two cities among the 10 fastest population gainers -- Plano and Arlington, both suburbs of Dallas. Austin, the state capital, gained 35 percent, a rate double that of the state as a whole.
*The changes in rural America were more dramatic than earlier indications had shown. Half of all rural counties lost population in an exodus of more than two million people from dwindling mining communities in Wyoming and Kentucky, from cotton and catfish farms of the Mississippi Delta and from parched farms on the Great Plains, according to Calvin Beale, a demographer for the Department of Agriculture.
 
Move to Rural Areas
 But while these areas, which encompass more than a million square miles, emptied out, one-third of the nation's rural counties were growing quickly. Ocean-view communities, mountain resorts and farm land an hour's commute from urban areas were booming with long-distance commuters, vacationers and retired people.
In an article awaiting publication, Mr. Beale says the movement of retired people to rural areas is so pronounced that 20 percent of all rural counties may now be retirement areas. These counties grew by 15 percent in the 1980's, compared with a national growth rate of 10.2 percent.
About two-thirds of all state capitals gained population. Those that lost were largely in the East, including Albany, Harrisburg, Pa., Columbia, S.C., Augusta, Me., Trenton, Charleston, W.Va., and Richmond. Capitals that were both the seat of government and of a state university, like Madison, Wis., and Columbus, Ohio, which each grew 12 percent, far outstripped their states' growth.
State government experts and private statisticians say the population growth in state capitals parallels the 16.3 percent growth in state employment over the decade. And they say it may be a fragile trend, as many states wrestle with intractable budget deficits because of the current recession.
 
Heyday in State Capitals
 The 1990 census may be a picture of a heyday in state capitals that is now over, said Edward J. Spar, president of Market Statistics, a New York marketing and demographic analysis firm.
"The figures are a wonderful reflection of the Federal Government pushing more and more down to the states, which have to increase staff to handle the burden," said Mr. Spar. "But you can't project this data into the future with the current recession."
The similar, though less dramatic, boom in college communities may be tempered by declining numbers of college-age students as well as by shrinking budgets in the next few years. But in the 1980's, college towns in many states were population meccas. The population of Norman, Okla., seat of the University of Oklahoma, grew by nearly 18 percent, while the state as a whole grew by 4.2 percent.
Austin, Tex., benefited both by the presence of the state capital and the state university, but its 35 percent population growth rate was also attributable to the annexation of new land. Immigration was apparently an important factor pushing up the population rate in South Texas -- four counties bordering the Rio Grande showed gains of 34 percent to 48 percent.
Occasionally, a single company turned a city around. Although South Dakota had the same problems as its neighbors on the Great Plains, Sioux Falls, now home to the billing operation of Citibank MasterCard, went from a population of 81,000 to 101,000, a 24 percent increase.

HEADLINE: Entire Staff Is Laid Off From Operation PUSH

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 25

 BODY:
Operation PUSH, the grassroots firebrand of civil rights organizations and brainchild of the Rev. Jesse Jackson, has been searching for an identity since its charismatic founder left Chicago for Washington more than a year ago. Now the group is in such deep financial trouble that this week laid off its entire staff of 12.
The action came six months after the organization began a boycott of Nike Inc., the athletic shoe and apparel company, a protest that never appeared to catch on and had little apparent effect on the company's sales. The company did hire more minority managers after PUSH's action. 
 Political observers here say that, despite the efforts of the organization's energetic new leader, the Rev. Tyrone Crider, PUSH has not been able to gain momentum without Mr. Jackson, whose image still appears in posters and photographs thoughout the organization's South Side offices. They say the 20-year-old organization's financial troubles reflect a loss of enthusiasm that might be expected during a major transition.
 
'Natural Pangs of Transition'
 "The organization is changing, but it hasn't died," said Robert Starks, an associate professor of politcal science at Northeastern Illinois University. "It has maintained its tradition of fighting injustice. These are the natural pangs of transition."
But the current leaders at PUSH say that the nation's recession has hurt its poor and working-class membership and thus dues and donations, its major sources of revenue, were down.
"Sears just laid off 21,000 people, T.W.A. just laid off however many thousands, and Eastern closed down completely," said the Rev. Willie Barrow, vice chairman at PUSH. "We're not immune. When America catches a cold, black people catch pneumonia."
PUSH staff members did not receive a paycheck this week and were laid off temporarily until the group's financial situation improves, PUSH officials said. Most of the employees are now working on a volunteer basis.
 
A Modest Operation
 "They've been coming in everyday," Ms. Barrow said. "Some of them are single mothers and we've told them, 'We'll help you find something else.' We may be financially handicapped but not morally bankrupt."
PUSH has always been a loosely run organization of mostly volunteers and a small staff that works out of a modest complex. On the whole, the group is meagerly run. "We pay just enough people to open the doors and make sure the telephones get answered," Ms. Barrow said.
But the group fell into fiscal chaos in the mid-1980's, when it ran so deeply into debt that its auditor warned it might not be able to continue operating. In 1987, the Justice Department accused the group of misspending or improperly accounting for about $1.4 million in Federal grants for its education and job-training program. The dispute was settled, with PUSH agreeing to pay back about half the money.
 
Fund Raising Is Planned
 PUSH is preparing for a major fundraising drive. The announcement of the layoffs prompted an outpouring of support and offers for money from people who themselves have turned to PUSH. For years many of them have come for inspiration during its Saturday morning services and for help in getting things from job referrals to voter registration cards.
Members are expected to address the organization's finances at its meeting on Saturday.
What is unclear is the role that Mr. Jackson may play in financially rehabilitating his longtime bailiwick. He has been officially removed from the day-to-day operations since he began his Presidential campaign in 1984. But did not appear to cut the umbilical cord until he moved to Washington in 1989.
Frank Watkins, Mr. Jackson's spokesman, said that Mr. Jackson was traveling and unavailable for comment, but was aware of the layoffs.
Mr. Watkins said that the group had never been in such financial trouble. "There may have been a time or two when we cut back a staff member or two, but I'm sure there wasn't anything like this," Mr. Watkins said.
Ms. Barrow hinted that she hoped Mr. Jackson would help out. "If you're a real good parent, you never deny your child," she said.

HEADLINE: E.P.A. Moves to Change Environment Priorities

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
The Environmental Protection Agency took to Congress today its campaign to reassess national environmental priorities that the agency's leader says are sometimes misplaced.
The campaign won the support of Senators from both parties on its broad objectives but also evoked misgivings and skepticism about whether scientists know enough to rank environmental risks accurately. 
 William K. Reilly, the Administrator of the agency, told the Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works that what scientists regarded as the most serious environmental threats were often different from those that excited the public and stimulated Congressional action.
For example, he said, a study by a board of scientists who advise the agency has determined that global warming caused by gases from human activity is among the highest environmental risks, while hazardous waste is among the lowest. But he said people rated them the other way around in public opinion surveys, placing hazardous waste as a top threat and relegating global warming to a spot far down the list of concerns.
 
Push for National Debate
 Mr. Reilly has said he is seeking to prompt a national debate on the subject. It is part of an effort by his agency to take a central role in shaping a coherent, long-term environmental policy based on scientific assessments of risk. In the past, he has acknowledged, the agency has mostly reacted to public and Congressional environmental concerns on a case-by-case basis. Those concerns can differ from scientists' long-term view because they are often a reaction to a crisis, for example, when there is a big oil spill or release of toxic chemicals.
Until recently, Mr. Reilly told the Senate committee, "questions of relative seriousness have not been asked."
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who is chairman of the committee, said that he was "enormously heartened" by the direction the agency was taking and that its attempt to get the nation to re-examine priorities could "define the next stage in this whole area of public policy."
But Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, said the establishment of environmental priorities "certainly sounds good" but it "might be easier said than done." The scientists who advised the E.P.A. acknowledged that much information was lacking about some environmental risks, Mr. Metzenbaum said, adding, "Frankly, I don't find that very reassuring."
And Senator Dave Durenberger, Republican of Minnesota, said, "I don't think we know enough to make risk judgments with any confidence."
 
Panel's High-Risk List
 At the center of the debate is a report issued last fall by the E.P.A. Science Advisory Board, a group of independent scientists who advise the agency. In addition to destruction of habitats and global warming, the group's list of high-risk ecological threats includes depletion of the ozone layer that protects the earth from harmful solar radiation, the extinction of species and loss of biological diversity.
Medium-risk threats on the list included herbicides and pesticides, acid rain, pollution of surface water and airborne toxic substances. Relatively low-risk problems included oil spills, the escape of radioactive materials into the environment and groundwater pollution, which can be caused by hazardous wastes and leaking underground storage tanks.
The group also identified these high-ranking environmental risks to human health: indoor and outdoor air pollution, the exposure of workers to chemicals and pollution of drinking water. Citing inadequate data, the group declined to go any further in ranking environmental health risks.
The panel also urged that the E.P.A. concentrate more than it has on the protection of natural ecosystems. "The E.P.A. and the nation should attach as much importance to reducing ecological risk as to reducing human health risks," Dr. Raymond C. Loehr of the University of Texas, co-chairman of the science advisory panel, told the Senate committee. He said there was a vital long-term interaction between a healthy environment, sustainable economies and human health.
 
The Big Picture
 He said the panel judged and ranked environmental risks on the basis of how severe their effects could be, how many people and how broad a geographical area they could affect and how long it might take to reverse their ill effects.
Mr. Reilly said in a statement to the committee that he did not "want to minimize the importance of other problems that were not ranked high, like oil spills," adding, "These problems can cause real damage." But he emphasized, "They are typically in a different league compared to some of our other problems, such as stratospheric ozone depletion and climate change, which have the potential to affect life everywhere, and for many years to come."
In describing what he considers his agency's more active role in shaping policy rather than just responding to episodic environmental crises and concerns, he cited its role in working toward treaties on global warming and reforestation and its work on the phasing out of chemicals that destroy the ozone layer, on the planting of trees, the protection of the African elephant and debt-for-nature swaps.

HEADLINE: Germany's Ostrich-Politik

 BODY:
The new world order begins with a huge hole in the center of Europe. Germany, now Europe's most important state, is trying to minimize its involvement in the gulf war, citing the country's militarist legacy. It would be more constructive to redeem past errors by making collective security more truly collective, providing a real alternative to superpower policing of global crises.
Germany has not stayed entirely aloof from the gulf conflict. It joined the diplomatic coalition condemning Iraq's aggression. It pledged $2.2 billion to support allied efforts last fall, and now, under pressure, weighs a substantial increase. This week it offered Israel Patriot missiles and $165 million in emergency aid. But all this falls short of what might be expected from Europe's richest economy. 
 Germany's postwar Constitution prohibits offensive use of the country's military forces, but also provides for participation in "a system of mutual collective security." That includes NATO and, arguably, the United Nations-sponsored action in the gulf. Yet Chancellor Helmut Kohl has refused to acknowledge Germany's obligation, under Article 5 of the NATO treaty, to treat any attack on Turkey as an attack on NATO as a whole. And the Kohl Government interprets the Constitution as barring any direct German military role in the gulf.
Mr. Kohl's reticence is easy to understand. Polls show 75 percent of Germans opposed to military participation in the war. Peace demonstrations have drawn wide support. The peace issue helped left-wing parties win a key state election this week.
Many demonstrators act as if allied military action against Iraq is a replay of the Vietnam War. It's not. For one, Saddam Hussein bears direct responsibility for triggering this crisis with his invasion and sack of Kuwait. More to the point, the allied coalition, though assembled and commanded by Americans, is remarkably broad, and would be broader still if Germany played a larger part.
Further, German businessmen, like other Europeans, have some responsibility for helping Saddam Hussein build his war machine. German companies sold biological and chemical weapons components to Iraq, helped increase the range of its Scud missiles and built a luxurious Presidential bunker designed to survive aerial attack.
Recent history has left Germans skeptical of military solutions and involvements far from their fatherland. Germans worry more about instability in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union than about who will sell them oil in the Persian Gulf. And reunification costs leave little budgetary slack.
Yet history is the strongest reason for Germany to become more actively involved. Before 1945, Germany's inability to find a constructive international role commensurate with its economic strength brought terrible grief. In the postwar years, West Germany, through integration with NATO and the European Community, became a valued and respected partner.
A united Germany can now build on that legacy of cooperation. It can add its hard-won sense of perspective and caution to coalition debates and draw strength from its partners to face uncertainties in the east.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Why Library Funds Shouldn't Be Cut

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Thus far this fiscal year, the Queens Borough Public Library has absorbed a cut of $2.4 million in New York City funds. Now, the library is faced with an additional cut of $2.1 million -- bringing the total to about $4.5 million, or 12.15 percent of its city budget. We are mindful of the city's problems. But we must cite two reasons why City Hall must reconsider.
One is the high illiteracy rate in New York and across the country, a matter of deep concern for many businesses in their search for qualified personnel. Another is that less than half the city's public school students read at or above grade level.
The Queens Borough Public Library and its counterparts in Manhattan and Brooklyn address these problems through adult literacy programs that serve many thousands and services that encourage reading by students of all ages.
Libraries, then, are making a tremendous contribution to the economic as well as to the educational and cultural life of the city. Any further cuts in funds could cause irreparable damage to our efforts to improve the quality of life for vast numbers of citizens.
 
CONSTANCE B. COOKE
Director, Queens Borough Public Library
Jamaica, Queens, Jan. 11, 1991

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Oil Prices and Profits: What Goes Up . . .

BYLINE: By Mark Green; Mark Green is New York City's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs.

 BODY:
Next to blood and water, gasoline is the most important liquid for Americans. So they wonder why the combination of plunging crude oil prices and ballooning petroleum industry profits isn't leading to a rollback of gasoline prices, which could help jump-start the stalled economy.
And that's why Congress should insist on restoring a windfall profits tax if the industry, which is announcing record profits this week, doesn't immediately start cutting prices. With Americans sacrificing in the Persian Gulf, the public won't tolerate Big Oil unpatriotically profiteering from the crisis.
 That was quickly evident when consumers became outraged by the price spike that began after Aug. 2, when Iraq seized Kuwait. In New York City, the average pump price rose from $1.19 per gallon of regular gasoline in July to $1.54 in December (this week it is $1.39). The cost of filling up a 15-gallon tank rose from $17.85 to $23.10. Put another way, the extra outlay for gasoline and home heating oil for consumers, business and government in the five boroughs would be $1 billion over a year -- enough to fund the "Safe Streets, Safe City" police plan for three years. 
 The American Petroleum Institute argues that the "free market," not oil firms, set the price, and that oil companies had to keep pump prices high to compensate for the months they lagged behind higher crude oil prices. Besides being mutually exclusive, these alibis lag behind reality.
As for the "free market," Daniel Yergin's "The Prize" explains how cartels -- Big Oil, from 1928 to 1973; OPEC, since 1973 -- created anticompetitive habits that led to nonmarket prices. Nor is it persuasive to say the industry is passing on the "replacement costs" of the next barrel of crude, as set by the commodities market. Only 1 percent of all crude used in the U.S. is traded on the crude oil futures market. Besides, oil firms hold more than two-thirds of the contracts traded there: An infant is more independent of its parents than this market is from oil companies.
Second, there was no "lag." While crude oil prices fell 27 percent fromJanuary through June ($20.64 to $14.98 per barrel), the average price of regular unleaded gasoline rose 4 percent ($1.04 to $1.08). Since the industry raises pump prices when crude prices go both down and up, this pricing theory appears to be heads-we-win-tails-you-lose.
While nearly 100 percent of the crude oil and wholesale gasoline price increases since August have evaporated, retail price increases have fallen back by only half. Why? Profiteering by procrastination. Firms quick to increase pump prices are slower to lower them because delay means huge profits by exploiting the difference between low crude oil costs and high consumer prices.
The proof? This week, the top oil companies are reporting fourth-quarter profits nearly double those of 1989. As profit shoots up, it shoots down the argument for high consumer prices.
A truly free market based on old-fashioned criteria of supply and demand should lead to a retail rollback to pre-August prices. Since supplies are ample because of Saudi overproduction, since there seems to be no plausible Iraqi threat to Saudi oil facilities, since President Bush has begun tapping the 600 million barrel Strategic Petroleum Reserve and since consumer demand is down and wholesale gasoline prices are now below pre-invasion levels (even counting December's nickel-a-gallon gasoline tax), oil firms have run out of excuses just as consumers have run out of patience.
Lower prices could help restore consumer confidence, spur more home building and retail buying, lower overall business costs and hasten the recovery by adding a half point of growth to the gross national product. Is Houston listening to America?

HEADLINE: Your Money;
2 Trusts Suitable For Middle Class

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
Trusts, long a favorite financial planning tool of the rich, can also be used advantageously by middle-income people. In recent interviews, two advisers offered trust plans that are particularly appropriate in a sluggish economy.
Douglas S. Brown, a certified public accountant who is president of Sherwood Trust Consultants in Springfield, Mass., described a trust he set up for a client who wanted to supplement the modest retirement benefits provided by his employer. The same approach could be used by many owners or employees of small businesses that have minimal retirement plans, he said, or by people who fear they may lose their jobs before they are vested in a corporate pension plan. 
 And Samuel J. Friedman, senior tax partner in the New York law firm of Hall, Dickler, Lawler, Kent & Friedman, describes how a couple with sizable assets could transfer their vacation house to a trust, enabling them to continue using it and eventually to pass it on to their children without burdensome estate taxes on its appreciated value.
Mr. Brown's client, a 30-year-old man, could have used an individual retirement account to save for his retirement, but at his income level his contributions would not have been tax deductible and would have been limited to $2,000 a year.
By setting up a charitable remainder trust, he can make contributions of any amount he wants, Mr. Brown said. If he contributes $2,500 a year until age 60 -- $75,000 total over 30 years -- and his trustee invested in zero-coupon bonds, assuming a 9 percent annual compounded return, he would have about $350,000 in the trust at retirement age. He can then switch to an income-producing investment, and that income could be used to supplement his company pension plan.Each year he contributes to the trust, he will get a charitable income tax deduction for part of the contribution, Mr. Brown noted, and when he dies, the charity that is to benefit from the trust will receive the principal. Thus he will have financed a sizable charitable gift.
"It is still a novelty idea," Mr. Brown said. But its use may grow "either as a replacement or a supplement to the traditional qualified pension plans," he predicted, because small businesses, in particular, are cutting back on traditional pension plans. One reason is to save money; another is because of tough Federal regulations intended to make sure that benefit plans do not discriminate against lower-paid employees.
Another client, a doctor, told Mr. Brown that he liked the idea because of the flexibility it afforded in contributions from year to year.
"People who do not need the income flow until retirement should structure the investments in the trust so they are not income-producing," he said, suggesting zero-coupon bonds or growth stocks.
Mr. Friedman's plan for the vacation home applies to people whose estates would exceed $600,000 -- the level at which estate taxes start.People with a primary home, an investment portfolio, possibly an interest in a business and a vacation home can easily reach that level.
No estate taxes are due on property left by one spouse to another. But when the surviving spouse dies, leaving the property to children or other heirs, the estate is subject to taxes, which are as high as 55 percent at the Federal level.
A grantor retained interest trust can be created and property transferred to it, though a principal residence is excluded. The grantor retains the right to use the property, and eventually his or her children, as beneficiaries, get the property.
"A house that was worth $400,000 a few years ago might be worth $300,000" in today's market, Mr. Friedman said, making it a good time for the transfer. "Say they retained the right to use it for 10 years," he continued. That might mean the gift to the trust would be worth $100,000 to $120,000, using up that much of the $600,000 that is not subject to gift or estate taxes. But over the long term, houses can be expected to appreciate, and this strategy will shift the appreciation out of the taxable estate.
"It doesn't work with mortgaged property," Mr. Friedman continued, "or where there is equity financing, because payment of the mortgage benefits everyone and could be viewed as additional gifts."
Also, he added, this is not the sort of maneuver to do in isolation. Rather, it should be part of an overall estate plan.
One of the simplest estate planning strategies is giving money away. Individuals are allowed to give up to $10,000 apiece -- $20,000 for couples -- to as many people as they want each year, free of gift and estate taxes. Mr. Friedman said he always advised affluent clients to make such gifts as early in the year as possible, because Congress could restrict it at any time and each year's opportunity expires on Dec. 31.
"You get an idea of how your children will look at money," he said, "a preview of an inheritance."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 31, 1991, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, the Your Money column in Business Day on Saturday misstated the type of property that can be placed in grantor retained interest trusts. It includes principal residences, in addition to vacation homes.

HEADLINE: Where Has Progress Got Us?

BYLINE: By William Julius Wilson; William Julius Wilson, the Lucy Flower University Professor of Sociology and Public Policy at the University of Chicago, is completing a new book on race, poverty and social isolation.

 BODY:

THE TRUE AND ONLY HEAVEN
Progress and Its Critics.
By Christopher Lasch.
591 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Company. $25. 
 Sometimes a scholarly work is more important for the questions it raises than the answers it provides. In this provocative, and certain to be controversial, book, Christopher Lasch, a professor of history at the University of Rochester, pursues a fundamental question: "How does it happen that serious people continue to believe in progress, in the face of massive evidence that might have been expected to refute the idea of progress once and for all?" According to Mr. Lasch, despite the shrill and acrimonious conflicts between the left and the right, they share a common belief in the inevitability and desirability of economic and technical development.
However, in "The True and Only Heaven" he maintains that the idea of progress rests on several untenable propositions: that material expectations can be constantly revised, that luxuries can be ceaselessly redefined as necessities, that new groups can be continually incorporated into the culture of consumption and that a global market embracing impoverished populations around the world can be ultimately created. Neither the right nor the left has yet come to grips with an increasingly obvious problem: "the earth's finite resources will not support an indefinite expansion of industrial civilization." Given the present rate of population growth, he argues, an environmental disaster would be created if the Western standard of living were successfully exported to the poorer nations of the world. Moreover, the advanced countries have neither the will today nor the resources to assume such an immense program of development. They cannot even address their own problems of poverty. "In the United States, the richest country in the world," Mr. Lasch writes, "a growing proletariat faces a grim future, and even the middle class has seen its standard of living begin to decline."
Mr. Lasch's critique of the idea of progress has a one-sided focus, however. Except for a brief, vague discussion of the deleterious social and environmental effects that would result from the program of economic growth and unregulated business enterprise advocated by the right, it is the liberal supporters of progressive ideology who are under attack in "The True and Only Heaven." To fully understand Mr. Lasch's concentrated criticism of the left, one has to recognize that his recommended alternative to the idea of progress would be anathema to supporters of liberal ideology -- a return to the moral conservatism of "petty-bourgeois" culture.
Lower-middle-class culture, Mr. Lasch argues, reflects an emphasis on the family, the church and the neighborhood. A community's continuity is valued more highly than individual advancement, social solidarity is favored over social mobility and the maintenance of existing ways takes precedent over mainstream ideals of success. Parents want their children to succeed in life, but they also want them to be considerate of their elders, to willingly bear their responsibilities and to show courage under adversity. "More concerned with honor than with worldly ambition, they have less interest in the future than do upper-middle-class parents, who try to equip their children with the qualities required for competitive advancement."
Mr. Lasch acknowledges the provincialism and narrowness of lower-middle-class culture, and he does not deny that "it has produced racism, nativism, anti-intellectualism, and all the other evils so often cited by liberal critics." But, he maintains, in their zeal to condemn such objectionable traits, liberals have failed to see the valuable features of petty-bourgeois culture -- what he calls moral realism, skepticism about progress, respect for limits and understanding that everything has its price.
Mr. Lasch's clear discussion of petty-bourgeois culture provides an important context for a more sophisticated understanding of the lower middle class's discontent with liberalism. Indeed, no book has done a better job of capturing the perspective of the lower middle class on the abortion debate, family values, the politics of race (particularly the politics of busing and affirmative action) and other issues that dominate liberal discussions of white backlash. "Whatever can be said against them," Mr. Lasch states, "small proprietors, artisans, tradesmen, and farmers -- more often victims of 'improvement' than beneficiaries -- are unlikely to mistake the promised land of progress for the true and only heaven."
In pursuit of the question of why people continue to believe in progress in the face of recurrent calamities, Mr. Lasch interprets the writings of great thinkers who both supported and criticized the notion of progress. Among their works he claims to find ideas that resonate with key aspects of petty-bourgeois culture.
From the writings of earlier supporters of the idea of progress such as John Maynard Keynes and the 18th-century moralists Adam Smith and David Hume, Mr. Lasch derives the postulates of progressive ideology -- an indefinite expansion of wants, a steady rise in the general standard of living and the incorporation of the masses into the culture of affluence. "It is only in this form that the idea of progress has survived the rigors of the twentieth century," he argues. More extreme versions of the progressive faith, grounded in assumptions about the perfectibility of human nature or the potential of love and reason, foundered ages ago.
The critique of the surviving idea of progress that Mr. Lasch highlights should not be equated with nostalgia, which "freezes the past in images of timeless, childlike innocence," or with the idea of community, with its historical and confining discourse of intimate versus larger social groups, Gemeinschaft and Gesellschaft. Nor should the argument be reduced to one between tradition and modernity. Rather, the opposition to progressive ideology that Mr. Lasch finds definitive is embodied in historical writings on the idea of limits.
Such work includes that of the 19th-century philosophers and social critics Thomas Carlyle and Ralph Waldo Emerson (who discussed human limitations and argued that control of destiny could be accomplished only by gratefully acknowledging that the world was not made solely for human enjoyment, and that unrestrained wants invite retribution); William James (who emphasized, among other things, the value of self-sacrifice, loyalty, devotion and civic honor); and, in the early 20th century, Georges Sorel (whose attack on progress focused on the importance of proprietorship and pride of workmanship formerly embodied in small-scale private ownership).
The idea of limits is also found in G. D. H. Cole's arguments for guild socialism, the American philosopher Josiah Royce's philosophy of loyalty, the theologian Reinhold Niebuhr's discussion of the "spiritual discipline against resentment" and the thinking of Martin Luther King Jr. on nonviolent resistance. All of these wise men, Mr. Lasch argues, speak to the distinctive concerns of the lower middle class. This is difficult to recognize in the works of major thinkers, he argues, "only because we expect major thinkers to participate in the general revulsion against the petty-bourgeois way of life."
Mr. Lasch, whose other books include "The Culture of Narcissism" (1979) and "The Minimal Self" (1984), does not hesitate to express strong views on sensitive topics, and therefore "The True and Only Heaven" will provoke considerable controversy. Because of the sheer force of his critique of the idea of progress and of liberalism, however, the book is required reading for any student of social criticism and cultural history. Although many will object to his arguments purely on ideological grounds, many others will find much in this book that is objectionable on scholarly grounds.
"The True and Only Heaven" is marred by a number of assertions that lack firm empirical foundation. And Mr. Lasch's central arguments are shaped more by informed opinion than by systematic theory. Moreover, the connection between material progress and cultural (including moral) progress is only vaguely discussed in the book. Thus the reader is left unsure about the extent to which the evolution of such issues as minority rights, women's rights, gay rights and abortion rights is actually linked in progressive ideology to the growing material expectations and the redefinition of luxuries into necessities. Since the book is not sharply focused, issues rising out of liberal ideology are often confounded with issues of progress.
Furthermore, scholars of cultural and intellectual history will find little that is new in the hundreds of pages on the works of the critics of the idea of progress. And the summary themes Mr. Lasch derives from these pages are so vague that the connection he sees between the ideas expressed by the critics of progress and important features of lower-middle-class culture is not clearly or convincingly demonstrated. Finally, despite Mr. Lasch's elaborate discussion of the history of the struggle between the idea of progress and the idea of limits, he fails to provide an explicit answer to the central question of the book -- why the idea of progress has survived the challenges of the 20th century.
However, this book is a major and challenging work because of the questions it raises. Despite its contentiousness and polemics, "The True and Only Heaven" will add an important new dimension to the continuing debate on the decline of liberalism.
 
STANDING UP FOR THE LOWER MIDDLE CLASS
 Christopher Lasch, in "The True and Only Heaven," takes care to refine, and often reject, labels. And he pretty much rejects any label for himself.
"Populist, I guess," Mr. Lasch responded during a recent telephone conversation from his home in Rochester when asked how he would label himself if he did. "But that is widely misunderstood. My intention was to show why the labels that are used commonly to describe political positions are no longer valid. One of the things I pursued is how the lower-middle-class culture, sometimes referred to contemptuously as the petty bourgeoisie, is the source of the most persuasive arguments against the theory of unlimited abundance."
Mr. Lasch, who is 58 years old, is the Watson Professor of History at the University of Rochester, and he reads a lot. He knits together the finiteness of the earth, the social ambiance of 19th-century artisans and farmers, Thomas Carlyle, Martin Luther King Jr., abortion, school busing and Reaganomics. The last stitch -- a reprise on finitude -- comes on the last few pages.
John Bunyan's complaint in "Prilgrim's Progress," about the superficiality of the town of Vanity, and especially of its fair, is echoed in Mr. Lasch's epigraph, taken from "The Celestial Railroad" by Nathaniel Hawthorne: a lament that Americans have come to think that Vanity Fair -- "the true and only heaven" -- is real.
"The culture of unlimited material progress now has the blessing of highest moral authority: the press, the educational establishment," Mr. Lasch says. "And, yes, politicians." Why the hesitancy? "Well, Americans are still not completely sold on the dream of progress and abundance without limits. All the evidence seems to contradict this, and now those whose beliefs are bound up with the promise of luxury speak with diminished authority. Today's culture has ceased to stand for the values that many people continue to believe in: families, continuity, self-discipline." -- BARTH HEALEY

LENGTH: 1101 words

HEADLINE: The Specter of Capitalism

BYLINE: By Nicholas Eberstadt; Nicholas Eberstadt, a researcher at Harvard's Center for Population Studies and the American Enterprise Institute in Washington, is the author of "The Poverty of Communism."

 BODY:

THE ANTI-COMMUNIST MANIFESTO
Whom to Help in Russia.
Edited by Lev Timofeyev.
Translated by Vitaly Kisin and Oleg Glebov.
Foreword by Richard Pipes.
96 pp. Bellevue, Wash.:
Free Enterprise Press. Paper, $7.95. 
 Not quite three-quarters of a century after the revolution that ushered it in, the Soviet Union -- the greatest and most costly of this century's political experiments -- appears to be heading into its final phase. Although the tale is not yet concluded, the rise and decline of Soviet power already abounds with ironic parallels.
Consider: in the early 1920's, with famine looming, the Soviet Union accepted enormous quantities of foreign food aid to keep the socialist revolution alive. Seventy years and twelve five-year plans later, hunger is again a menacing presence, and Moscow is accepting emergency relief from such unlikely benefactors as India.
By the same token, only months before the coup through which they gained power, the Bolsheviks passed a resolution affirming that "every nation forming a part of Russia must be recognized as having the right to secede freely and to form an independent state." Today the central authority of the Soviet Government is being challenged by a multiplicity of nationalist movements, all of them agitating for the self-determination that the Communist Party had earlier promised.
A newly published collection of essays, ably translated for a Western audience by Vitaly Kisin and Oleg Glebov, adds yet another parallel to the list. Years before the ultimate collapse of the czarist order, but in anticipation of it, Lenin wrote the influential pamphlet "What Is to Be Done?" Nearly nine decades later, six citizens of the ailing order Lenin helped to found have answered his question with a pamphlet of their own, entitled "The Anti-Communist Manifesto: Whom to Help in Russia."
The authors of this important document include Vasily Selyunin, Larisa Piyasheva and Boris Pinsker, newly prominent economists who have already provided powerful critiques of Soviet performance, as well as the scientist Maksim Frank-Kamenetsky and the journalist Anatoly Strelyany. The manifesto's editor, Lev Timofeyev, who himself has contributed a piece on the black market, spent two years in the Gulag for his criticisms of Soviet economics -- after Mikhail S. Gorbachev had come to power. The group is representative of an emerging body of thinkers who prefer to remain on Russian soil, but who refuse absolutely to acknowledge the legitimacy of Communist rule or to collaborate in its continuation.
As perhaps befits a polemic against Leninism and its worldly works, the authors of "The Anti-Communist Manifesto" do not speak with a single, disciplined voice. Their visions of a post-Communist Russia differ in a variety of particulars. They are unanimous, however, in their reading of the current Soviet crisis, and they are united by their apprehension that the West's impending aid programs may forestall rather than promote liberal reforms and renewal in the Soviet Union.
"The empire of evil," Mr. Timofeyev writes, "is being destroyed." "It is already clear," he says, "that the Communists have been utterly defeated politically" but "it is only privatization that can ensure the irreversibility of democratic reforms."
These writers do not view Mr. Gorbachev as their ally. Mr. Pinsker dismisses the current leadership as "reformers terrified of reforms." To be sure, he notes: "This is indeed the best government the Soviet state has yet had. Still, 'best' is far from being equivalent to 'good.' When the Communist government talks of reforms, it never wants to yield any property to private ownership."
The current system, says Mr. Selyunin, "combines the irremovable vices of command planning with an absence of any responsibility on the part of producers. The result is economic chaos." He recommends a "rapid and decisive transition to a market economy" characterized by private property, free enterprise, currency convertibility and free prices. "Privatization of property," he pointedly insists, "does not present any special technical problems." Participation in the world economy figures centrally in Mr. Selyunin's program, and he views the creation of an attractive climate for foreign business as essential, for "the grim reality is that the USSR needs the foreigners more than they need it."
Today's "increasingly hysterical reports of urgent conferences, extraordinary measures and emergency mobilizations," observes Ms. Piyasheva, "may be highly instructive for a prospective foreign investor." She warns against private loans to the Soviet Government: "Under Soviet conditions renovation programs tend to take a long time . . . products are typically noncompetitive . . . and thus there will simply be no earnings to pay off such loans. They will be written off as happens with loans to the dictatorships in Latin America, Africa and Asia." Outright aid, for its part, is said to risk "prolonging the agony" engendered by the existing system. She advocates "stringent economic and political conditions" on aid to Moscow: "Substantial loans . . . must be accompanied [by] elimination of central planning of the economy and . . . guarantees of access to the Soviet economy by foreign investors, international trade in Soviet securities and so on." "Unless it gives appropriate guarantees and makes real steps toward privatization and free enterprise," she writes, "no loans or most-favored nation status in trade must be given to the USSR."
It may be, as Richard Pipes suggests in his foreword, that "The Anti-Communist Manifesto" underestimates the difficulties of adjusting back to a market order after three generations of enforced socialism. Moreover, if the authors of this manifesto consider themselves "disciples of Friedrich Hayek," as one writer intimates, their tutelage would appear to be as yet incomplete: a program of private ownership that envisioned Government spending of up to 50 percent of national output, like Mr. Selyunin's, would surely be unobjectionable to a Swedish Social Democrat, but is unlikely to be embraced by Mr. Hayek, Milton Friedman or other exponents of a more classical liberalism. Such qualifications notwithstanding, this bold, thoughtful and passionately honest salvo poses a genuine and indigenous alternative to the temporizing of Mr. Gorbachev's crippled regime. This manifesto is sure to be followed by others, but its arguments and points of view are likely to have a continuing influence on the struggle for liberty and prosperity in the Soviet Union.

PUB-DATE: January 27, 1991

SECTION: Section 7; Page 32; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 924 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy

BYLINE: By GEORGE JOHNSON

 BODY:
A TENURED PROFESSOR, by John Kenneth Galbraith. (Houghton Mifflin, $7.95.) After a Harvard economist discovers how to quantify the irrational side of economic behavior, he and his wife reap a fortune, devoting their sudden millions to making the world a nicer place. Last year our reviewer, Barbara Ehrenreich, called the novel "a liberal wish-fulfillment fantasy, transmuting greed to good with rollicking zeal. Along the way, Mr. Galbraith has great fun at the expense of the powerful and their all-too-numerous admirers."
JAZZ CLEOPATRA: Josephine Baker in Her Time, by Phyllis Rose. (Vintage, $12.95.) The daughter of a St. Louis laundrywoman, the dancer Josephine Baker caused a sensation in the clubs of Paris when she appeared onstage wearing little more than a skirt of bananas. Later she became known for her work as a spy in the French Resistance, as a campaigner for civil rights in the United States and as the matriarch of a multiracial family of adopted children she called the Rainbow Tribe. In 1989 The Times's Michiko Kakutani said Phyllis Rose "has a gift for combining biography with literary, social and psychological analysis, and there are passages in 'Jazz Cleopatra' where this talent shines."
FOR THE SAKE OF ALL LIVING THINGS, by John M. Del Vecchio. (Bantam, $5.95.) While her brother is working as a leader of the Khmer Rouge, a Cambodian woman falls in love with an American adviser to the Government in Phnom Penh. Last year our reviewer, David Murray, said the novel succeeds because of "the power of Mr. Del Vecchio's prose and the enormous amount of information he submits to his readers. He has added another memorable book to the literature of the Southeast Asian conflict, a tragic, bloody saga that seems to be with us forever."
ISARA: A Voyage Around "Essay," by Wole Soyinka. (Vintage International, $9.95.) In a book that is part imagination, part fact, Wole Soyinka, who won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1986, tells about his father, a teacher named Essay, and his life in colonial Nigeria. The book "goes far beyond a homage," Rita Dove said here in 1989. "It supplies the essential ingredient missing from history books -- not only the Zeitgeist, but the heart that propels the spirit."
ADVANCE, RETREAT: Selected Short Stories, by Richard Rive. (St. Martin's, $10.95.) Written by a South African who was found murdered in his home in 1989, these short stories tell what it is like to be of mixed race in the land of apartheid. "Richard Rive's historical place in the development of South African literature is assured," Tony Eprile said here last year. "This humane, sharply observant collection of stories shows that his is a voice to be discovered by each new reader, a voice that lingers long after one has read the stories."
THE COMING GLOBAL BOOM: How to Benefit Now From Tomorrow's Dynamic World Economy, by Charles R. Morris. (Bantam, $12.95.) Despite the prevailing view of the doomsayers, an economist argues, the world is on the verge of an unprecedented boom. "Charles R. Morris is not afraid of optimism," Adam Smith said here last year. "In 'The Coming Global Boom' he has once again set himself up as contrarian critic, and has published a bullish argument in lively form."
TIME'S WITNESS, by Michael Malone. (Pocket Books, $5.95.) The police chief of a small town in North Carolina uncovers a web of corruption when he investigates the murder of a local black political leader. In 1989 our reviewer, Valerie Sayers, said the novel offers "a complex and satisfying plot, a rich panorama of a class-stratified Southern town and dense portraits of even minor characters."
DOWN THE RIVER, by Edward Abbey. (Plume, $9.95.) When these essays by Edward Abbey, the patron saint of environmental guerrillas and nature-loving misanthropes, were published in 1982, our reviewer, Tim Cahill, said, "He can write movingly about the most simple outdoor pleasures: planting a tree, seeing a bear, watching hawks in flight, getting drunk." THE JOURNEY HOME: Some Words in Defense of the American West (Plume, $9.95) shows Abbey as an "American artifact, part maverick, part pastoral extremist, part semi-hermit, part latter-day Jeremiah Johnson," Ted Morgan said here in 1977. The publisher has also reissued two other books by the author, who died in 1989: ABBEY'S ROAD ($9.95), a 1979 collection of wilderness essays, and GOOD NEWS ($10.95), a 1980 novel set in a future time when American civilization has fallen apart, replaced by a preindustrial economy of whites and Indians living off the bounty of the West.
ANY WOMAN'S BLUES, by Erica Jong. (Harper Paperbacks, $5.95.) As she approaches middle age, the liberated heroine of "Fear of Flying" finds herself grounded by an addiction to sex, drugs and an abusive young boyfriend named Darton Venable Donegal 4th. Last year our reviewer, Benjamin DeMott, said he liked "Fear of Flying" better but that "an occasional idiom or patch of comic invention elsewhere calls up Ms. Jong's earlier achievements."
EAST OF CHOSIN: Entrapment and Breakout in Korea, 1950, by Roy E. Appleman. (Texas A&M University, $14.95.) Through interviews with survivors and other sources, a historian of the Korean War tells what happened when American forces at Chosin Reservoir were surprised by a regiment of the Chinese Army. "For most Americans, knowledge of the Korean War is both scant and vague," Bernard E. Trainor said here in 1987. This book "deals at once sympathetically and analytically with one of the painful episodes of that struggle."
