PUB-DATE: January 27, 1991

SECTION: Section 6; Page 36; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 3290 words

HEADLINE: ARE THINGS AS BAD AS THEY LOOK

BYLINE: By Charles R. Morris; Charles R. Morris is a partner in Devonshire Partners, an investment advisory firm. His last book was "The Coming Global Boom."

 BODY:
Yertle the Turtle, Dr. Seuss assures us, came a cropper when his hastily rigged empire turned out to be just another shell game. Yertle was the ruler of a small turtle pond, who had the brilliant insight that his kingdom extended as far as he could see. His subjects were ordered to pile up in a higher and higher stack while Yertle, perched on top, exulted in his new glory. Alas, the underpinnings of his kingdom proved structurally unsound when a little turtle at the bottom of the pile had the bad manners to burp. The whole stack came crashing down and a thoroughly humbled Yertle ended up stuck deep in the turtle pond mud.
It's clear that the American economy has been splashing about in the mud since Saddam Hussein's tanks rolled into Kuwait, knocking both oil prices and financial forecasts for a loop. The questions are: How deep will the plunge be? And how long will it take to climb out again? The answers, in large measure, turn on an assessment of how rickety the economy's financial underpinnings really are. Will another hiccup, on top of an oil crisis, the fighting in the gulf, the continuing catastrophe in the savings and loan industry, serious problems in the banking system and heavily indebted consumers and businesses, be enough to bring down the whole structure? 
 ALTHOUGH MOST ECONOMISTS expect that the present recession will be relatively brief and mild, there is pervasive worry about what one analyst calls "the nightmare scenario." At least two of Wall Street's inveterate pessimists, A. Gary Shilling, of the economic consulting firm that bears his name, and Stanley D. Salvigsen, of the money management firm Comstock Partners, talk about a stomach-churning financial plunge of a severity not seen since the 1930's. Shilling sees a deep recession that may last "a couple of years," while Salvigsen says "the word 'depression' rings a little closer to our theme."
The nightmare scenario goes something as follows: As sales slow and unemployment rises during a recession, consumers and businesses start to default on the heavy debts they built up during the 1980's. Banks take big losses on their mortgage portfolios and their credit-card and business loans; under pressure from regulators, they sharply curtail their lending, even to healthy businesses. Unemployment shoots up, mortgage defaults become widespread, home prices drop like a stone and, in growing panic, consumers watch their primary savings, their home equity, disappear. As the banks get into deeper trouble, money-market funds, which hold a lot of bank paper and are not Federally guaranteed, begin to default, and the run for the ratlines starts in earnest.
But it gets even worse. In a normal recession, interest rates would drop as the economy slows, easing debt pressures, and the Government would kick in with increased social spending to cushion the decline. But now, since the Federal deficit is already so high, a surge of Federal borrowing, on top of the borrowing to bail out banks and savings and loans, could make the credit crunch worse -- interest rates, that is, might actually rise, causing new waves of debt defaults to ripple through the country. And we can no longer count on the world's deep-pocket savers, Germany and Japan, to supply the missing credit. Germany's bailout of the crippled East German economy dwarfs America's savings and loan problems, while in Japan, unbridled speculation has driven the market value of real estate to ridiculous levels. If that bubble bursts, and Japanese money goes squirreling into mattresses, the whole world economy could collapse at the same time.
No one is discounting the nightmare scenario out of hand. Even Edward Yardeni, chief economist at Prudential-Bache Securities, who has been resolutely upbeat through a series of recession false alarms, says that this time a really serious crash "is not outside the realm of reality." But Yardeni and a number of other economists, like Peter Canelo, the chief strategist at the investment banking firm Bear Stearns, still foresee only a mild recession.
All economists look at the same data. Economics is more metaphor than science, a way of imposing interpretive order on the buzz of transactions that make up a modern economy. Forecasting, in particular, is a narrative art form; there's no black box to grind up the numbers and produce a reliable prediction. Here are some program notes for watching the evolving drama.

THE GOOD NEWS IS THAT MOST OF THE EIGHT recessions in the postwar era started with inventory buildups. As good times rolled, companies would stockpile more and more goods to stay ahead of demand. When consumer spending slowed even a little, businesses choked on their unsold inventories, factories shut down, workers were laid off, consumer spending screeched to a halt and there would be a full-scale recession. Inventory ups and downs have been the prime driver of the boom-and-bust "business cycle" that has dominated the economy from time immemorial.
The difference today is that companies worked very hard through the 1980's to keep inventories lean. A typical example is a foundry in Virginia that makes cast-iron parts for Chrysler. Not many years ago, the foundry stockpiled parts until there were enough to fill a freight car. Now trucks leave each night carrying just enough parts for Chrysler's production run one day later, cutting the parts pipeline from about three months to just a few days. Nationwide, total inventories stand at less than six weeks' worth of sales, the lowest level ever. "If you look at just the traditional business-cycle factors," says David Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services, "they point to a short recession, because the manufacturing sector has maintained such good control."
The other bright spot is that prices have behaved relatively well. "Strip away the volatile sectors, like food and energy, and inflation looks under control," says Peter Canelo. "Producer price inflation is down from an annual rate of 5 percent a year ago to about 3 1/2 percent now, and it's probably going lower." On the eve of the fighting in the gulf, most analysts felt that, unless the conflict was prolonged, energy prices would stay under control. Even without production from Iraq and Kuwait, world oil supplies are bigger than they were a year ago. Once the gulf crisis is resolved, one way or the other, oil prices could fall quite sharply.
With inventories and inflation in good shape, why all the nightmares? A number of analysts fear that the risks in the present slowdown may be quite unlike any we have seen in the recent past. They are worried that American assets, the things that businesses and consumers own, may be worth a lot less than we thought they were. So much wealth is tied up in assets like office buildings and housing that a widespread crash in asset values could bring down the whole economy, much as happened in the 1930's.

THE REASON ASSET VALUES ARE such a worry is that during the 1980's we all borrowed against our assets as never before. Business borrowing rose about 40 percent a year faster than in the previous 30 years, much of it fueled by the late and much-lamented revolution in junk bonds, the high-interest securities sold by companies with shakier credit than America's industrial blue-chips. Each day's headlines bring news of another company either in the tank or hanging on by its fingernails because heavy debt service payments have gobbled up cash flows -- Donald Trump's casinos, Eastern Air Lines, Robert Campeau's department store chains (Bloomingdale's, Abraham & Straus) and William Farley's textile empire (Fruit of the Loom, West Point-Pepperell).
Consumer borrowing tells the same story. For a number of years, consumer debt has been growing some 5 to 8 percent faster than paychecks. Sooner or later, as Stanley Salvigsen puts it, "you hit the wall." Home mortgages have grown at a similar clip. In 1980, homeowners had borrowed about 37 percent of the current value of their homes; by 1990, the ratio was over 50 percent, despite the fact that home values had increased substantially. Now that house prices are falling on both coasts, homeowners worry that they may never get their money back. If they decide to walk -- mortgage delinquency rates are rising around the country -- banks may have to write off a large portion of the debt when they try to sell the foreclosed property.
The collapse of the junk-bond market and a depressed residential real-estate market have drawn most of the publicity, but the true disaster is commercial real estate. As George A. Puskar, the head of Equitable Real Estate Investment Management, puts it, "an undisciplined flow of capital fueled rampant overbuilding without regard to supply and demand." Warning signals, especially rising office-vacancy rates, were flying as early as 1985; but banks, savings and loans, insurance companies and pension funds kept on lending anyway -- mostly, it seems, because it was a business they were familiar with. Almost 45 percent of the office space ever built in America was constructed during the 1980's. Real-estate loans accounted for 87 percent of the growth in commercial-bank lending from 1986 through 1989. Richard Kateley, the president of Real Estate Research Corporation in Chicago, says "commercial vacancy rates are so high in most of the country that it will take until mid-decade to work off the glut."
All of these excesses add up to a strained financial system. Investment banks like Merrill Lynch and Credit Suisse/First Boston have a lot of their capital tied up in junk bonds. Insurance companies like Equitable have invested heavily in real estate and junk bonds, and the commercial banks are exposed across the board, at a time when their capital is still draining into third world quicksands like Brazil and Argentina. Digging out from under all these commitments, David Hale says, "creates the danger of a serious financial accident." And that's why so many analysts, even the more optimistic ones, wake up and stare at the ceiling in the middle of the night.

THERE ARE OTHER THINGS TO worry about. During much of the 1980's, profligacy in the United States was supported by frugality abroad. High savings rates and trade surpluses in countries like Germany and Japan created a big pool of capital that financed American trade and budget deficits and kept the investment machine humming. But those pools of capital may be drying up. To end the political division of Germany, a major cause of the cold war, West Germans agreed to pay for the economic damage wreaked by their Communist cousins to the East. The total bill, including the cost of repairing the dilapidated East German infrastructure and supporting a lot of laid-off East German workers, may be as much as a trillion dollars over the next decade. In the near term, the German budget deficit will balloon to about 5 percent of its gross national product, or double the level in the United States.
On the other side of the world, the portents in the Japanese tea leaves are every bit as dire. Lurking beneath the smoothly running exterior of "Japan Inc." may be the world's biggest savings-and-loan-type scandal. The long economic boom in Japan was fueled by very rapid credit creation. In most countries, turbocharged money growth quickly spills over into price inflation. But in Japan, docile consumers just plunked their new money into low-interest bank accounts, where it financed a huge increase in business investment.
But the inflationary pressures bubbled over into stock prices and real estate. The Nikkei index, Japan's version of the Dow Jones average, shot up to 60 times company earnings -- American investors get nervous if stock prices exceed 15 times earnings. The run-up in real-estate prices was even more absurd: The value of real estate in Japan is four times higher than all the real estate in America (which is 25 times larger). Stock prices finally cracked last year, and the Nikkei index fell almost 50 percent in 1990. (By way of comparison, during the "Black Monday" stock market crash in October 1987, the Dow Jones fell only half as much, a loss it recouped by the end of the year.)
Japanese real-estate prices are still holding firm, at least for the time being. But the banks and the government are watching nervously. Unlike American banks, those in Japan can include part of the market appreciation of stocks and real estate in their official capital. Banks can lend up to something like 12 times their capital. So if real-estate values suddenly break, the banks will have to call in 12 yen worth of loans for every yen their capital base falls. That is almost too nasty to contemplate. To avoid suddenly pitching headlong off the treadmill, the Japanese Government is easing back on credit growth by raising interest rates -- Japanese rates are now actually higher than in America. The problem is being addressed, that is, but a misstep could be disastrous.

WITH SO MANY ACCIDENTS waiting to happen, why is it that so many economists still foresee a relatively mild recession? The answer, once again, depends on the spin you choose to put on the data. If you are inclined toward pessimism, you see an economy that was unusually weak even before the technical recession got under way, which suggests that the recession will be unusually severe. If you are inclined toward optimism, you see an economy that had managed to handle more than a year of very bad news and still avoid a recession until the oil-price shock following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait last August, which suggests substantial underlying strengths. And the available data can easily be made to support either interpretation.
Take the problem of corporate debt. On the one hand, the rate of debt growth was high during the 1980's, and corporate debt service now consumes a bit over 20 percent of corporate cash flows, which is historically high. But at the same time, a 20 percent debt service ratio, up from about 16 percent in 1980, doesn't seem too frightening. Stephen S. Roach, a senior economist at Morgan Stanley, points out, moreover, that companies whose cash flows are squeezed hardest during recessions, like heavy manufacturers, have actually been reducing debt quite sharply for several years. Debt growth has been concentrated in industries whose sales hold up best during downturns, like food and tobacco manufacturing. "We have a tendency to base a lot of analysis on headlines, the Campeaus or Macy's," Roach says. "But if you look at the data in the aggregate, and sort out the debt based on companies' ability to carry it, the risks are a lot less than is commonly appreciated."
There is no gainsaying the problems in commercial real estate, which, far more than junk bonds, are at the heart of the problems in the savings-and-loan and banking industries. But the picture in residential real estate -- about three times as big as the commercial market -- is more mixed. "The residential market is soft," says Richard Kately, "but by no means a disaster area."
Glenn E. Crellin, vice president for economics and research for the National Association of Realtors, makes the point that "residential markets are inherently local." While prices are falling in New England, New York and parts of California -- all areas where there was double-digit appreciation during the 1980's -- they are holding up in the Midwest and most of the West, and a recovery may be under way in Texas. "A lot of the 'losses' we hear about are just sellers getting less than they had hoped," says Crellin. "Most homeowners have been in their houses for more than six years, and they've enjoyed a lot of price appreciation."
James J. McDermott Jr., president of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, an investment-research firm, suspects that the banks' problems may also have bottomed out. "Banks have been building up their reserves for some time now," he says, "and actually are in much better shape than they were before the last recession. If the downturn is only moderate, they should come through quite well. What really worries me is how the regulators will behave. Bankers are spending so much time introspecting that they may forget how to make loans."
Finally, according to some analysts, developments in Germany and Japan may offer as many opportunities as dangers. "We're already running a trade surplus with Europe, and that should increase as Germany reconstructs," says Steven Nagourney, chief international strategist at Lehman Brothers. Nagourney also expects that Japan will solve its real-estate problems and reach a better economic balance with the rest of the world as it completes "a critical transition from a third world type of export-driven economy to a more balanced first-world economy."

DESPITE THE radically different scenarios of the most optimistic and the most pessimistic of the forecasters, there is substantial agreement on the main issues. Widely divergent predictions result from very small differences in emphasis. Just as Edward Yardeni of Prudential-Bache, a defiant optimist, concedes that a serious crash is within the realm of reality, Gary Shilling, one of the most confirmed pessimists, concedes that we might skate through. "This is a bailout era," he says. "The S.& L. industry is being ripped apart, but things just go on their merry way, with maybe a little grumbling about higher taxes. Conceivably, we could bail out the banks, then the insurance companies, and people will say, 'Well, just one more bailout' and ignore it -- although you have to believe all the risks are on the downside."
With the economy poised on a knife edge, much may turn on psychology. Consumers and businesses maintained remarkably stiff upper lips in the face of cascades of bad news through most of 1990, although confidence was clearly cracking by late fall. One reason for the relative cheeriness was that much of the country -- the Midwest, and parts of the Southwest and West -- chugged through the year at a respectable, if unspectacular rate; the recession has been felt most acutely in the Northeast. The Wall Street establishments, the banks and the insurance companies that rode the crest of last decade's boom now must streamline and consolidate, just as Rust Bowl manufacturing businesses were forced to do in the 1980's. (Since the financial-services industry also happens to house a lot of economic forecasters, the lamentations accompanying this round of restructuring may be more heartfelt than in the past.)
There is no way to know for sure how long the recession will last. It has been anticipated for so long, and so intently, that all the bad news may be out on the table. With the Federal Reserve easing up on interest rates and pushing banks back into the lending business, a turnaround could come quite quickly -- assuming, of course, that the crisis in the gulf is successfully resolved.
However long it takes, the restructuring of the financial-services industry is long overdue. Strikingly, the optimists, Yardeni and Canelo, and the pessimistic Shilling all agree that the 1990's could be a period of very strong growth for the United States, as the average age of the work force rises and investment capital shifts away from real estate into factories and technology.
But the burning question for most Americans is not what will happen over the long term, but what will happen over the next 6 to 18 months. Will the recession be very severe or will it blow over quickly and relatively painlessly? And the frustrating reality is that economic forecasting tools are much too crude to answer that question with any confidence. What happens next is anybody's guess.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 14; Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 2156 words

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN: Montreal

BYLINE: By NANCY LYON; NANCY LYON, who lives in Montreal, is at work on a travel book about Quebec for Passport Books.

 BODY:
Montreal in summer bares its Latin soul in cafe terraces, street fairs, and festivals of fireworks, jazz, theater and stand-up comedy. But when the snow piles up to the windows and hockey sticks fly, Montreal's jovial French-Canadian camaraderie and cosmopolitan flair combine to give this city its winter spirit. Yes, everyone complains about the length of the season and the ritual of brush, scrape, chisel, shovel and push to park and unpark cars. But who does not thrill at the sights of the city in winter -- snow falling through a neon pink sky from a cafe window on Rue St.-Denis, ice-skaters gliding by moonlight on the lagoon in Parc LaFontaine, toboggans zipping down Mount Royal.
Winter is a time for conversation, the favorite pastime of Montrealers, bilingual quibbles aside. Quebec's bilingual tensions get played out in Montreal in a tussle of commercial and street signs proclaiming chiens chauds and hot dogs, Arrets and Stops. But the citizens of the second-largest French-speaking city in the world can sling a bilingual joke as deftly as a snowball. Social interchanges here are verbal salads, tossed with sentences that begin in good radio French, but quickly get salted and peppered with Canadian or American English and end up with joual -- Quebecois slang. 
 Skates and snowshoes and cross-country skis and poles and hockey sticks are toted in Metro cars as if they were Alpine trams. Right now they're playing baseball in snowshoes and racing canoes, dog sleds and beds on the ice for the ninth annual Fete des Neiges, or Winter Festival, which began yesterday and runs through Sunday.
 
The Winter Festival
 Ile St.-Helene and Ile Notre Dame, islands across the St. Lawrence from the Old City, are the main sites for the festival. A quick Metro hop from downtown, Ile St.-Helene became a public park in 1874, but since the island was tripled in size (to 336 acres) for Expo '67, it has become a year-round family playground, with race track, museums, ice rinks, toboggan runs and, in summer, pools, beach amusement park and waterslides. In winter these hilly, wooded islets in the river's rapids become a wonderland for skating, cross-country skiing, tobogganing and snowshoeing.
At the Ile Notre Dame's Jardin de Neige, tons of snow have been transformed into a three-and-a-half-story chateau, a setting for friendly snow skirmishes. (Open daily 8 A.M. to 7:30 P.M.) Winter festival activities at the Olympic Basin include ice sculpturing and speed skating next Saturday from 9 A.M. to 1 P.M., and a bed race and a dog-sled promenade next Sunday from 9 A.M. to 1 P.M. To get to Ile Ste.-Helene and Ile Notre Dame during the festival take the Metro to Ile Ste-Helene station where buses depart daily for the site. Although there is generous parking on the islands, traffic jams are inevitable.
The other center for the winter festival is Old Montreal, where the cobbled Place Jacques Cartier has been turned into a downhill ski slope, complete with ski lift, snow cannons and terrain for snowboarding, as well as an area for snow and ice sculpture (Feb. 2, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.). At the old port at the foot of Place Jacques Cartier, there's a traditional cabane a sucre, or maple sugar shack. Syrups and candies are on sale, and visitors can try tire des neiges, hot maple syrup dripped onto fresh snow and eaten like taffy. Information on the festival: (514) 397-9190.
Montreal's other big winter passion is ice hockey. The screams and whistles, brightly lighted ice, melodramatic organ music and gravelly cries of vendors all contribute to the fervor. The Montreal Canadiens play from September to May at the Montreal Forum (2313 Ste.-Catherine West, at Atwater; (514) 932-2582. If you can't get a ticket inside the Forum, you can buy one outside from scalpers from $20 to $40. Official prices range from about $9.25 for standing room to $20 for seats. (Prices in U.S. currency, based on 87 Canadian cents to the U. S. dollar.) Depending on availability of tickets, reservations can be made up to a month in advance.
 
Mont Royal
 For those who prefer a quieter winter scene, there are dozens of charming places to ice skate free, including the parks of LaFontaine, Maisonneuve (with the Botanical Gardens) and Angrignon, with its children's zoo and Winter Fairyland with ornate ice palace. But traditionalists go to Beaver Lake on the Mountain.
Montrealers always call Mount Royal (designed by Frederick Law Olmsted) "the Mountain," even though its peak is only 764 feet above sea level. The park, a dense woodland habitat threaded with steep fir-crested paths, twisting through stands of maple and oak. The base is about a 20-minute walk from downtown. All paths around the mountain lead to Beaver Lake and the Grand Chalet, site of an interpretive nature center. On a sunny Sunday, Beaver Lake takes on the atmosphere of a snow circus, with skaters waltzing, and children with toboggans and sleds flying down the sloping lawn. Two cross-country ski trails start at the lake. Rather than walk to the mountain, you can also drive along the Camillien Houde Parkway, hire a horse-drawn caleche, or hop the No. 11 bus (from Rue Mont Royal) to Beaver Lake.
 
The Old City
 In summer everyone goes to Old Montreal and the old port to stroll, bicycle along Lachine Canal, sip a cappuccino and gawk at the big ships. In winter, when snow in the rest of the city may look thin or brown around the edges, the narrow, cobbled streets of the old town recall the 19th century. Until the Quebec Government declared Old Montreal a historic zone in 1962, the fieldstone walls and steeply-pitched roofs of its old stone buildings had been left to deteriorate in the shadows of rusty warehouses and grain elevators marring the skyline of the port. Now the French Regime residences and buildings, which date to 1685, have been restored and are occupied by residences, offices and boutiques.
The old city has two hearts, Place Jacques Cartier, the historic political center, and Place d'Armes, the economic and religious center. In close proximity to the Place Jacques Cartier are the Hotel de Ville, or City Hall (1874-1878), with its mansard pavilions, green copper covered dormer windows, and the splendid Chateau de Ramezay, at 280 Notre Dame Street East. Today it is a museum reflecting the middle class life of 18th-century settlers in New France. (Open Tuesday to Sunday, 10 A.M. to 4:30 P.M.; admission is $1.75, students and seniors, 85 cents. (514) 861-7182.)
Along the Place d'Armes dignified banks and businesses line the square. One place to visit is the foyer of the Bank of Montreal and its Numismatist's Museum; 129 Rue St.-Jacques West, Monday to Friday 10 A.M.-4 P.M. Another is the interior of the Basilica of Notre Dame, for many years the second most popular tourist attraction in Canada after Niagara Falls. This neo-Gothic limestone giant 260 feet long, with a luminous gold and blue interior, was begun in 1823 and stands where 60 French settlersfounded Montreal's original settlement, Ville-Marie, in 1642. The 12-ton bell can be heard for miles around, and the 6,800-pipe organ, a century old this year, has an astonishing voice. The basilica is a popular venue for concerts by the Montreal Symphony Orchestra. Informal tours are offered regularly, and the small museum has a valuable collection of sacred vestments and ornaments, bishops' thrones and croziers. (Open Saturday and Sunday, 9:30 A.M. to 4 P.M.; admission 87 cents, children 40 cents.)
 
Underground City
 They say that Montrealers, some 200,000 a day, swear by their Metro, not at it. The subway is a gigantic museum, each of its stations designed by a different architect. The Montreal University station, for example, at the base of Mount Royal, evokes a feeling for nature, with wooden benches and earth colors. The Metro started out in 1966 with 22 stations and 14 miles of track and now has 65 stations and 40 miles of tracks. More than 30 percent of Montreal's developed downtown space is connected -- via pedestrian passageways and the Metro. The statistics keep growing but at last count the underground city comprised six hotels, 1,400 boutiques, 150 bars and restaurants and 30 cinemas and theaters.
Buy your Metro tickets six at a time ($6); bought individually they cost $1.50. The subway opens at 6 A.M. and closes at 1 A.M., and trains run every 3 to 10 minutes, and a bit slower on Sundays.
 
Night Life
 Montrealers are indefatigable night owls. In the Latin Quarter on Rue St.-Denis, the bars and cafes are in colorful old Victorian homes with peaked roofs and dormer windows. St.-Laurent Street, "the Main," divides Montreal East (French) from Montreal West (English). The long strip between Sherbrooke and Fairmount is a fascinating mix of ethnic shops and imaginative cafes and bistros, including Le Bar Business (at No. 3510), Cafe Melies-Le Cinema Parallel (3682), Zoo Bar ( 3556), and Cafe Lux Complex (5220), a converted textile mill. Crescent Street, the English answer to Rue St.-Denis, boasts its own strip of bars and cafes between Rues Ste.-Catherine and Sherbrooke. Nearby Biddles (2060 Aylmer) is popular for jazz.
For a sense of Quebecois tradition, one can attend a square dance. The rollicking Quebecois jigs and reels are a hybrid of lilting Celtic sounds mixed with French, sung and played on violins, melodeons, harmonicas and backed by pianos and spoons. For the uninitiated, a sense of humor and the words main droit and main gauche (right hand, left hand) are probably enough to bluff one's way through the evening. Dances are monthly at 2275 Boulevard St.-Joseph East (Metro Laurier) at 8:30 P.M., admission $6. The next two are Feb. 16 and March 16. Information: Societe Pour la Promotion de la Danse Traditionnelle Quebecoise; (514) 598-8295.
Call or visit Place des Arts (1501 Rue Jeanne-Mance) to see what concerts, operas, ballet and theater are available. Call (514) 285-4200 for information, and (514) 842-2112 to order tickets.
 
 Where to Eat
 There are hundreds of fine restaurants, bistros, patisseries and cafes. But beware the sign "Mets Canadiens" or "Mets Quebecois" -- Quebec dishes. Quebec food, at least in its old-fashioned neighborhood restaurant form, is based on sugar and fat. The touch is somewhat lighter at Le Festin du Gouverneur (Ile Notre Dame), Les Filles du Roy (415 Bonsecours) and Le Blanc Bec (5091 de Lanaudiere).
The wealth of Continental French restaurants is concentrated mostly on Rue St.-Denis and in old Montreal. The Old Fort on Ile Notre Dame provides the jovial setting for "Nouvelle France," eat-with-your-knife banquets and dinner shows at the Festin des Gouverneurs (514-879-1141). A set price of $35.30 buys a four-course dinner featuring pate de foie gras and oven-roasted honey-glazed chicken with carafe of wine, and a bilingual dinner show from 7 to 9 P.M. Reservations are needed at the Festin and for the elegant castle-like Helene-de-Champlain on Ile Ste.-Helene, 200 Tour de l'Ile; (514) 395-2424). The Continental French cuisine menu is $26.50 for table d'hote and runs from $50 to $80 a la carte.
Other Continental French restaurants, all in the old city, include: Les Filles du Roy, 415 Bonsecours; (514) 849-3535 (Sunday brunch with French songs and accordion music, about $13; table d'hote, $18); La Mare (404 Place Jacques-Cartier; (514) 861-9794), about $43; Restaurant des Gouverneurs, 458 Place Jacques-Cartier; (514) 861-0188); Le Fripon, 436 Place Jacques-Cartier; (514) 861-1386, $17.50; and A la Catalogne, 311 St.-Paul East; (514) 866-6254, also $17.50. Prices do not include wine. At the historic Maison Pierre du Calvet (400 St.-Paul East), you can sip cappuccino beside a roaring fireplace and eat pastries baked on the spot.
In addition, there is a thriving Chinatown, and good Belgian, Cajun, Indian, Italian, Vietnamese and kosher food.
 
Where to Stay
 It's still as fashionable as ever to stay at the Ritz-Carlton, a Montreal institution since 1912, and Le Quatre Saisons. The Ritz-Carlton, with 230 rooms, is at 1228 Sherbrooke West, (514) 842-4212 or (800) 363-0366. Room rates for two in winter range from about $110, the lowest weekend rate, to $235. Le Quatre Saisons has 300 rooms; 1050 Sherbrooke West; (514) 284-1110 or (800) 332-3442. Rates for two in winter range from $195; there are weekend packages from about $110 a night, with breakfast.
But for meeting Montrealers and saving your dollars for more tangible splurges, try the bed and breakfast networks. They offer rooms in charming houses or condominiums from $25-$50 for a single and $50-$75 for a double. Among them are: : Bed & Breakfast Montreal, (514) 738-9410; A Bed & Breakfast -- A Downtown Network (514) 289-9749; Bed & Breakfast de Chez-Nous, (514) 485-1252; Residences Interim, (514) 845-7711; Relais Montreal Hospitalite, (514) 287-9635.

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Airline and Tour Packager Liable in Nile Cruise Fire

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
TRAVEL law in New York State took a further step in the consumers' direction in November when a jury found an airline responsible for negligence in a 1983 fire that sank a Nile cruise boat used by the airline's packager. Two women who swam ashore holding a deck chair sued Trans World Airlines and the tour packager for personal injuries, charging negligence because the T.W.A. brochure said the airline had inspected the vessel. The airline's defense cited the brochure's small type, which, as is usual in tours combining more than one element, disclaimed any responsibility for actions of independent contractors.
The crux of the case was the assertion by the two passengers that the boat, the Pharaoh, had no life preservers available to the passengers, that there were no fire extinguishers or evacuation plans and only one lifeboat, which the plaintiffs said was used by employees of the vessel. An inspection by the airline or its tour operator, as claimed in the brochure, would have shown these fundamental safety defects, the lawsuit said. 
 The State Supreme Court jury awarded $420,000 to the two women and their husbands on Nov. 15, but T.W.A. and the tour packager, Travelers Intenational, said they would appeal, a process that could take a year. The Nile cruise boat burned in the early morning of Oct. 11, 1983. On Dec. 20, 1990, the couples agreed to accept an immediate settlement of $245,000. The two women, Lillian Elsis of New Jersey and Theresa Weinstein of Long Island, each received $112,500 instead of the $200,000 the jury awarded, and their husbands, who were not on the trip, got $10,000 each. The husbands had been awarded $20,000 each on the ground that the marital relationship was impaired after the wives returned from their trip. The maximum legal fee in such a case is limited to a third of the settlement, according to lawyers in the case.
A number of the 76 other Pharoah passsengers -- no one died in the fire and sinking -- sued in California but Travelers International was excluded as a defendant on technical grounds and a settlement of $7,000 a passenger was reached at an early stage, so no new ground was broken there.
The Judge's Ruling
In New York, because the jury ultimately supported the passengers' case, the pro-consumer language that will set precedent for future travel lawsuits was set down by the judge who presided, Justice Elliott Wilk. In a preliminary ruling a year ago sending the case forward for trial while rebuffing T.W.A.'s effort to have it halted by seeking a summary judgment, Justice Wilk reviewed the arguments.
He wrote that the two women booked a tour to Egypt, selecting from a brochure, "T.W.A. Getaway & the Middle East 1983," which included a 14-day tour with air travel to Cairo, four days at hotels and a seven-day cruise on the Pharoah. Justice Wilk quoted from the big type in the brochure, adding emphasis:
"T.W.A. has a proven track record as one of the most successful operators of tour programs to this part of the world . . . Every one is custom-designed by T.W.A. and Travelers . . . Travelers maintains full-service offices in Cairo and Athens. They're staffed by travel experts who examine every hotel, every sightseeing attraction, every cruise ship on site."
After discussing the small type in which T.W.A. as a tour operator disclaimed responsibility for "injury, damage, loss, accident, delay or irregularity," Justice Wilk wrote:
"It seems clear that having explicitly undertaken to 'examine . . . every cruise ship on site,' defendants may be held liable in negligence for their failure to detect obvious defects in safety equipment aboard the M/S Pharaoh. Moreover, having created the image of 'T.W.A. Getaway' and implored passengers to 'sit back and relax with the peace of mind that only T.W.A. Getaway Egypt vacations can offer,' defendants undertook to provide a cruise ship with expected safety features such as lifeboats and preservers."
The plaintiffs, Justice Wilk wrote, "do not seek to hold defendants liable for the acts of another, but rather for their own negligence in booking passage on an unsafe vessel." The jury supported the plaintiffs.
David L. Ganz of Ganz, Hollinger & Towe in New York, which handled the case for the Elsis and Weinstein families, was satisfied with the result of the three-week trial. "I think it's good for the consumer," Mr. Ganz said. "Every packager will look over what they are putting out, and it will give a boost to truth in advertising. If the operator says it looks over the cruise boat to check on alarms, extinguishers and lifeboats, they better do it."
Frederick A. Nicoll of Shanley & Fisher, the chief lawyer for T.W.A. and Travelers International, said neither he nor his clients wanted to comment on the outcome. Asked if he would recommend that his clients take a closer look at the wording of any brochures they published, he said he would not comment.
 
Frequent Flier Cases
 The endless procession of frequent flier court cases resulted in one decision in favor of an airline, one in favor of consumers.
The airline won in Utah, where a Federal court issued what seems to be the first decision declaring the brokering of frequent flier coupons illegal. The court ruled in favor of American Airlines, which sued in 1988 to stop three coupon brokers from buying passengers' frequent flier coupons and reselling them. All airlines say their frequent flier mileage coupons, which are exchangeable for tickets, may not be sold, although many airlines allow them to be given away to family members and sometimes others. The airline accused the brokers of interfering improperly with its contractual relations with the passengers holding the coupons, and of unfair competition.
On Oct. 16, 1990, District Judge David K. Winder agreed with American, issuing a partial summary judgment declaring that the brokers, Platinum World Travel and Coupon Connection of Salt Lake City and Texas Budget Flights of Dallas, were engaging in illegal acts. The judge did not issue an injunction requiring the brokers to stop, but both sides said he was expected to do so.
American Airlines said it was the first decision that selling coupons was illegal and would set a precedent for further efforts to halt the activities of brokers, of whom there are 50 in the United States. Michael W. Gunnn, a senior vice president for marketing for American, said the decision "will greatly support" the line's legal fight.
A lawyer for American, Richard A. Rothman of Weil, Gotshal & Manges in New York, noted that there had been settlements in 1990 in three other cases against four brokers in Dallas, New York and Los Angeles. He said those brokers agreed to stop selling American coupons and paid the line settlements in "six figures," which he said he could not further explain under the agreement.
Scott Wangsgard of Conder & Wangsgard in West Valley City, Utah, the lawyer for the brokers in the Utah case, said the decision would be appealed in the 10th Circuit Court of Appeals and that his clients would ask the judge to stay the effect of his expected injunction until the appeal was heard. Mr. Wangsgard noted that the Federal Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit in California had just overturned an injunction preventing a broker there from trading in T.W.A. coupons.
In the appeal, Mr. Wangsgard said, the brokers would ask the court to balance the public interest in doing what it wishes with its coupons against the airline's need to restrain the public.
Con Hitchcock, a lawyer at the Aviation Consumer Action Project in Washington, said of the ruling, "I understand the economics of the airlines but if you can give a ticket to Aunt Shirley and Uncle Ed, why can't you sell it to them?"
The other frequent flier decision came in the Illinois appellate court on Dec. 12, when the judge opened the way for a lawsuit by holders of American Airline coupons who said the coupons' value had been eroded when the line began to limit the number of seats available to award-holders in 1988. The plaintiffs plan a class-action suit on behalf of all who joined the plan before 1988. American Airlines is asking the highest Illinois court, the Supreme Court, to hear an appeal, but the request might be rejected. The class action suit cannot begin in the 60 days that the appeal request is pending.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 1; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: Postings: Symposium;
A Car-Free New York?

 BODY:
Put tolls on the East River Bridges to discourage drivers from coming into the city. No, build more parking garages so they have places to park. No, reduce the number of parking spaces and plant grass and trees in their place, and raise taxes on cab rides. No, leave medallion cabs alone but control private car services. No, put tolls on the East River bridges.
New York's cocktail of competing economic and environmental interests will get a stirring Friday at a Municipal Art Society symposium called "Auto-free New York: Is It Possible?" at which panelists will argue about whose car should be gored in the interests of a less congested, less polluted, more congenial city.
The burden of proof will probably land on one of the panelists, George Haikalis, a transportation consultant who heads the Auto-free New York Committee. He and Arthur Rosenblatt, an officer of the Grand Central Partnership, the business improvement district, want to try mid-town pedestrian malls. Mac Victor, head of the Metropolitan Parking Association, will argue for more parking. Mark Simon will talk on his work as director of the Alternate Fuels Program in the city Department of Environmental Protection and Jack Lusk, head of the Taxi and Limousine Commission, will moderate.
"When New Yorkers visit other cities -- London, Berlin, Paris -- they see large commercial central zones that are indeed auto-free," said Mr. Rosenblatt. "They make a case that large pedestrian zones can be accommodated in New York without inhibiting business and the free flow of commerce."
The discussion runs from 6 to 8 P.M. at the Society's offices, 457 Madison Avenue, at 51st Street, and is open, free, to the public.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1978 words

HEADLINE: New-Home Deals Are Getting Sweeter

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
DOMINICK AND MARIE PANZERA wanted to retire near their daughter on the Jersey shore, and a developer's offer of a premium, very private lot in his new development at no extra cost clinched their decision to buy a new house in Bayville, N.J..
Connie and Vito Valvano are newlyweds who will be neighbors of the Panzeras when their new home is completed. They picked the development because they liked the social life centered on the project's clubhouse. 
 Paul and Katie Lakin already had a friend living at Chesterfield Farms in Chester, N.J., and the view from the hillside lot was spectacular. Since the builder also offered a deeply discounted fixed-rate mortgage, they found the deal too good to refuse.
These buyers of new homes in the New York metropolitan region bought in different areas for different prices and for different reasons, but they share one or two traits that distinguish today's new-home buyers from those of recent years. They bought because they really needed a new place to live -- not for speculative reasons -- and because they liked the sweetened deals they were able to work out in bargaining with builders.
None of the buyers could point to a single factor that decided a deal for them, but all of them were moved to buy by the readiness of developers to offer much more than they would in a better market to make a sale.
"Builders are giving up lots of incentives out there," said Patrick J. O'Keefe, head of the New Jersey Builders Association, a trade group. "Financing, price reductions, amenities, upgrades -- they are offering all kinds of things they would never think of offering when the market was red hot."
A year or so ago, as the housing recession was just getting its teeth into the market, many developers turned to frivolous come-ons to make sales, such as trips to Disney World, health club memberships or savings bonds for future college tuition bills. Today's incentives or more likely to focus directly on the value of the property and can be worth tens of thousands of dollars in savings.
An important difference in today's new-house market is the general scarcity of already built speculative houses. During the boom mid-80's years, most new houses were built before they were sold. Now, after two years of slow sales, most speculative houses have been sold off at heavy discounts, or, in the case of town-house condominiums, turned into rentals.
"Spec houses are off the market -- they just aren't being built anymore," said Edwin Schwenk, head of the Long Island Builders Institute, a developers' group. "First of all, there isn't much to spec for in this market, and banks have just closed the door on financing them."
An exception to this may be in New York City, where a strong rental market gives home builders an option that is far more difficult for their suburban colleagues to follow. Herb Roleke Jr., a Queens developer, is working on only one house so far this year, compared to half a dozen a year during the mid-80's, and he is resigned to the idea that he may have to keep it.
"I'd love to sell it, but I'm not optimistic," he said of the three-family detached house nearing completion at 142-32 84th Avenue in the Briarwood section. He is asking $575,000 for it but has had only two phone calls on the property so far.
"If someone comes along and wants to deal, I'm prepared to be flexible," he said, "but I think I'll end up keeping it for a while as a rental."
EVEN with build-to-order housing, however, builders have vacant land to pay off and construction or management staffs they want to keep on the payroll for the next economic upturn.
Robert H. Karen's Sonata Bay Club, opened in October 1989 in Bayville, N.J., has 312 lots, of which 20 have been built on and sold, including the one to the Panzeras. Thirty more are under contract and are being built on -- one for the Valvanos -- and buyers for 20 more are waiting to sell their current homes, a constant stumbling block to sales, Mr. Karen said.
Buyers are offered four basic two-bedroom models, ranging from the $139,000 Schubert,through the Ellington and the Strauss, to the $152,000 Gershwin. The builder said his profits come from the extras the buyers order, including premiums for lots on dead-end streets or those backing on woods. But nowadays those extras are being heavily discounted too, Mr. Karen said.
Mr. and Mrs. Panzera wanted a sunroom addition for their two-bedroom retirement home at Sonata Bay Club, along with a bigger family room and different tile work. Mr. Karen agreed to make the changes for them at a reduced price.
Most of all, Mr. Panzera wanted a better yard.
"He happened to offer me a very choice lot at no extra cost, no houses behind it, just woods," Mr. Panzera said. "For me, that made the difference." He paid $180,000 for his two-bedroom retirement home, which was completed in May, and believes he got a good deal.
"I bought in a soft market," he said, "and I feel Bob Karen could have got a lot more money for these houses if his business were going better."
Mr. Karen would rather not have to make deals like that, but he considers the concessions he makes the a price of keeping busy.
"In a real hot market I don't know if I would do it," he said, "because every change requires a great deal of administrative work, going back to the architect, amending the town plans. But you have to be willing to play 'Let's Make a Deal.' "
Of course, the Panzeras had to sell their one-family home in Sheepshead Bay in Brooklyn. But having paid $50,000 for it 15 years ago, the $200,000 they got was enough.
"I did all right," Mr. Panzera said. "I feel that if I had waited to sell in a high market I would have had to buy in a higher market. It all balances out."
He does not think he drove a very hard bargain, however squeezed the builders seem to feel -- an idea many buyers repeated.
"I don't consider myself a very hard bargainer, and I'll tell you why," said Mr. Lakin, a computer specialist with A.T. & T. "I've built several houses and I know that builders will accept almost anything you're willing to pay, but they'll take it out of the construction. He's in the business to make some money and I just want to make sure I get the quality I want."
Arthur Welles, whose company is building Mr. Lakin's $750,000 home in the Chesterfield Farms development, makes no bones about the pressure he is under from less understanding customers. His homes are already selling for about $100,000 less than last year, not only because he is cutting prices, but also because people are buying less expensive models, he said.
Last year he even bought a customer's old house to get rid of a spec home, he said, selling the old home at a loss.
One of the most sought-after incentives is the so-called end loan, or builder mortgage financing at below market interest rates, usually written by lenders of the construction funding on new developments. They have become scarce as banks have pulled back from development lending, but Mr. Welles's partner in the development, the Harmonia Savings and Loan Association of Elizabeth, N.J., offers buyers 30-year mortgages at a fixed rate of 7 percent, or almost three percentage points below the market for fixed-rate mortgages, and for only a $300 application fee.
The lower rate is worth about $1,000 a month in payments compared to his current Maryland mortgage, Mr. Lakin said. When Mr. Welles also gave up the $100,000 surcharge he had placed on the two-and-a-half-acre hillside lot, Mr. Lakin agreed to buy.
"I think it's very creative of them to bring down their prices through the financing," Mr. Lakin said. "That and the $100,000 drop he took on the lot."
Mr. Lakin believes buyers who squeeze the builder only set themselves up for disappointment. "Working with the builder is much more important than focusing on the contract," he said. "I think contracts are set up as excuses to fail, and I'm interested in dealing with someone who is not going to fail me."
THE Valvanos -- Gloria is a travel agent, Vito a public school consultant -- will move into Sonata Bay later this spring when Mr. Karen finishes putting up their house, bought after their marriage last year when she pressed for a new home in which to start their new life together.
"I said to my husband, either we do it now or forget it," Mrs. Valvano declared. "We both wanted a little more room than we have now, and we wanted a social life."
A visit to the Sonata Bay clubhouse sold them on the community, she said.
"We went to look, and we saw the men were playing pool, and I could be in the whirlpool or the exercise room, and it just clicked for us."
Of course, they still had to settle on the house with Mr. Karen.
In the end, they rearranged the location of some windows, got a bigger, two-tub kitchen sink, an ice-maker, different cabinets and better tilework in their bathrooms, at no charge. Mr. Karen made them pay for upgraded light switches.
"We ended up getting a lot of things that he's not charging us for because they're trying to establish the homes there," Mr. Valvano said. "Later on, they won't have to give so much. So this is a perfect time to purchase a home, even if you have to sacrifice when you sell your present home, because you won't be able to get deals like this when the market gets better."
If most of today's buyers move because of a change in personal circumstance, such as a job transfer, marriage or retirement, Meyer Lang chose his $350,000 town house in the Apple Ridge development of Mahwah, N.J., for more direct reasons.
"To be honest with you," Mr. Lang, a pet supply wholesaler, said with a little chuckle, "I moved to New Jersey to get away from New York taxes. It looks like I jumped right into New Jersey taxes."
His choice of the house had more to do with the development's landscaping and the design of the properties than with the price, he went on. "I just liked it and that's why I bought it," he said, echoing Mr. Lakin's advice against pushing a builder too hard.
Mr. Land eschewed hard bargaining with Brian Stolar, head of East Crescent Developers, the builders. "I've been in business practically all my life and I don't see any point in doing to others any different from the way I want them to do to me," he said. "So he gave me a little, and I gave him a little. and now all I have to worry about is how much my decorator is charging."
According to builders, it is the customers in today's chilled housing market who sometimes fail to bargain in good faith, more and more frequently by using a kind of sudden-death bargaining tactic, by threatening to pull out of a signed contract at the last minute. This leaves the builder with the choice of meeting onerous new demands or giving up on a sale that seemed to be in the bag.
"IT is a troubling trend," said Mr. O'Keefe of the New Jersey builders' group. "It means that the builder is at a real risk even with an executed contract, and financial institutions will become even more reluctant to lend construction money than they already are if it becomes no longer clear that the buyers will be at the table at the time of closing."
Mr. Welles, the builder of Chesterfield Farms, said that in the decade before the slump, only one of his buyers had tried to break a contract. But it has happened at least three times in the last 11 months. So far, he said, the buyers have backed down in all but one case.
"My position is that I try to squelch that immediately," he said.
"I have not done it, but I could think of scenarios where I might," he added, speaking of giving in to new demands to avoid a broken contract.
The one case where the contract did not go through was out of his hands, he said; the buyer responded to a divine message against the purchase and gave up $50,000 of a $70,000 deposit to break the deal.

HEADLINE: Perspectives: The Cooper Square Plan;
Smoothing the Path to Redevelopment

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
NO love was lost between former Mayor Edward I. Koch and the Cooper Square Community Development Committee and Businessmen's Association. For that matter, the association has had its differences with mayors and housing commissioners for 31 years.
The committee was formed by Frances Goldin and the late Thelma Burdick to oppose the urban-renewal efforts of Robert Moses, who wanted to "tear everything down from Ninth Street to Delancey Street," as Ms. Goldin put it. "We are the oldest anti-displacement organization in the United States," she said. 
 Adjustments were made to the urban renewal plan in 1971, providing for more rehabilitation. But in the 80's, as the market began to improve, the city's attention turned to the possibility of encouraging 80 percent market-rate housing on two large sites where relocation and demolition were far advanced, and using proceeds of land sales to assist low-income production and rehabilitation. The committee opposed that as an encouragement of gentrificiation.
Last month the administration of Mayor David N. Dinkins, in one of its first achievements in advancing city-assisted housing, reached an agreement with the committee that both sides consider a compromise. The committee agreed to support new mixed-income housing on the two redevelopment sites, although with a higher proportion of low- and moderate-income apartments than the Koch administration had planned.
In addition, the city will rehabilitate 430 units in dilapidated city-owned buildings that were taken long ago for urban-renewal redevelopment. The apartments will then be put under the ownership and management of a mutual housing association that the committee will organize. They will become permanent low-income housing.
"We are thrilled by this agreement," said Maria Torres Bird, the chairwoman of the committee.
The reconciliation underscores the shift in approach from the Koch to the Dinkins administration, as well as the shift in market conditions. With the slump in the market, the city has probably lost the chance to underwrite all or most of the cost of the rehabilitation from the value of vacant urban renewal land. Instead, Mayor Dinkins is prepared to use capital funds to create gut-rehabilitated low-income housing, at least in the Cooper Square urban renewal area.
The area runs from East Fourth Street south through Houston Street to Stanton Street one block farther on. The other boundaries are the Bowery (lower Third Avenue) on the west and Second Avenue and Chrystie Street on the east.
THERE are two development sites with scattered occupied structures at the southern end of the area, on each side of Houston Street. But on East Fourth and East Third Streets the old buildings still stand, with tenants paying rent to the city. Among the tenants is the Cooper Square committee itself. It runs a housing and social services operation at 59 East Fourth Street.
Under the agreement, 31 occupied and six vacant city-owned buildings are to be renovated and turned over to the mutual housing association. This rehabilitation phase, already under way, means major improvements to 390 occupied apartments and 40 vacant apartments at a cost of $17 million.
Several theater and dance companies, including La Mama Experimental Theatre, currently lease space in some of the buildings on East Fourth Street. That space, too, will be renovated and then offered on favorable terms to their occupants.
The new-construction plan calls for one rental and one for-sale project. On Site 1A, 59,500 square feet of land just south of Houston Street, developer proposals will be sought for 200 units of rental housing, with a maximum of 80 percent for moderate- to middle-income households and a minimum of 20 percent for low-income households. The Cooper Square committee will participate in tenant selection. Eight loft buildings on the site will be rehabilitated and may become part of the mutual housing association's inventory.
The other development site, known as Site 2, lies between Houston and East SecondStreet. It would become a 360-unit co-op or condominium, with 80 percent of the apartments sold at market rate. The rest would be low-income units reserved for the mutual housing association.
The Site 2 plan also involves the rehabilitation of certain existing residential buildings and the provision of a community facility to replace the existing annex of the Church of All Nations. The design plan will preserve a community garden on Houston Street. The agreement clears the way for choosing a developer and the public review that follows. The rehabilitation work near Cooper Square itself is already under way, however.
One of the ironies of the long period of dispute over a redevelopment plan for the area is that what is going to be achieved in the 90's could have been achieved in the mid-80's, at less cost to the city, if there had been less friction over housing ideology. The Department of Housing Preservation and Development has long had in place the mechanisms for mixed-income rentals and condominiums and for the rehabilitation of existing buildings for low-income occupancy, with or without the Cooper Square committee as sponsor.
The decline in land values in the late 80's has served not only to narrow the city's redevelopment options but also to blur the distinctions between market-rate and assisted housing. The gap in income between those who can afford market-rate vacant apartments on the Lower East Side and those who can afford new middle-income units is narrow or nonexistent. Buildings are being "gentrified" by households that fall within the city's definition of middle-income, that is, with incomes up to 180 percent of the New York City median.
Renovated one-bedrooms can be found in well-kept railroad-flat walk-ups for around $700 a month, down about $100 a from two years ago, brokers report. Two-bedrooms rent for $850 to $1,200. An apartment renting for $1,000 a month is affordable to a tenant earning $42,800 a year, using a 28 percent rent-to-income ratio.
Similarly, co-ops have become more affordable. The sponsor of Village Court, a converted 66-unit building at 99 East Fourth Street, is asking $89,000 to $110,000 for his six vacant one-bedrooms and $165,000 to $169,000 for three vacant two-bedrooms. "It's a slow market, there's no getting around it," said Douglas White, who represents the sponsor, the G.L.M. Companies, based in Washington. The conversion plan became effective in June. The last sale was made in July. No insiders have bought.
In the end, the compromise agreement has proved an expensive solution for the city, however gratifying it is to both sides. It is desirable mainly because it is a practical way of achieving compromise on an issue that looks more ideological than real. And it could lead to a Cooper Square committee of greater stature as a contributor to community welfare.

HEADLINE: Cost-Cutting Plan Inspires Question: Is Cheaper Better?

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
FROM the very beginning, in 1989, when the General Assembly appropriated $4 million for an independent report on improving the efficiency of state government while reducing state spending, the question nagged: would the report tell lawmakers and agency heads how to do things better, or simply how to operate on the cheap?
Last week, the study was completed and filed, but the question remains. The study group, dubbed the Thomas Commission for its chairman, DeRoy C. Thomas, president of the I.T.T. Corporation, reported to the Governor that $578 million could be saved by making a series of large and small changes in the way the state manages and spends its money. 
 The commission said that Connecticut treats its employees too generously, that grants to towns and cities have outstripped demographic trends and should be capped, and that every agency from the Department of Public Works to the Bureau of Purchases should be tightened, tucked and trimmed.
 
Two Members Dissent
 Legislative leaders hailed the report and said it would be thrown into combat immediately against the huge shortfall in state tax revenues caused by the recession. Connecticut faces a gap of more than $600 million in the year than ends on June 30, in a budget of just over $7 billion. The projected shortfall for the following year is $1.5 billion.
But the murmurs of doubt have not entirely subsided. Two of the 23 commission members refused to endorse the final report. State budget officials said the commission was sometimes wildly optimistic in how much money could be saved by making specific changes. The Speaker of the House, Richard J. Balducci, a Democrat from Newington, said he thought the real saving could be closer to $300 million than the $578 million crowed over in the report.
And Mr. Thomas himself, while defending the commission, said in an interview that if all the proposals became law, residents would certainly experience greater inconvenience in their contacts with the state, if only by being required to wait longer or drive farther to get their driver's licenses renewed.
The report suggests that the General Assembly explore the idea of consolidating the number of offices of the Department of Motor Vehicles from the current 18 down to 8, but it does not formally recommend such a change for the immediate future.
"They lost sight of the question, how can we do this more effectively and efficiently?" said John W. Olsen, president of the Connecticut State A.F.L.-C.I.O. and one of the commission members who dissented from the final recommendations. "The only thing they were looking for was cuts and savings."
Mr. Olsen said that his strongest objections arose over the proposal to cut back state employee benefits, a measure that would directly affect some 40,000 workers affiliated with Mr. Olsen's union. But he said he also disagreed with what the commission began defining as spending cuts.
He noted, for instance, that the report said that capping grants to cities and towns could save the state $70 million to $170 million. "There's a lot of cost shifting to the cities and to the public at large," Mr. Olsen said. "Cost shifting is not savings."
But the report's defenders, including Mr. Thomas, said that the final saving figures are not the point, and that if the commission's work encourages Connecticut's elected officials to re-examine the premises of government, the panel will have succeeded in its mission.
 
Receptive Climate
 Those proponents say that the timing of the report -- begun 19 months ago but filed now, coincidentally, in the midst of a crushing budget crisis -- has created an opportunity that should be seized.
"With a potential shortfall of $2.2 billion, I think that the climate of the legislature will be changed and will be very receptive to suggestions to do things differently," said the State Senate majority leader, Cornelius O'Leary, a Democrat from Windsor Locks. "Nobody likes to see this kind of a deficit situation, but there is opportunity in it as well. The Thomas Commission represents some of that opportunity."
The final report, which distilled 18 separate consultants' studies into one book, includes hundreds of separate suggestions by the panel, whose formal name is the Commission to Study the Management of State Government. Some of the suggestions, if passed into law by the legislature, would clearly be felt by state residents. The report urges the closing of the Mansfield Training School, operated by the Department of Mental Retardation, to save $2.5 million a year, as well as the closing of two satellite vocational schools, in Enfield and Essex, for a saving of $1.2 million annually.
Other measures might be undertaken with little pain. The commission estimates, for instance that more than $27 million worth of underutilized state buildings and land could be sold to the public.
But many of the measures are expected to fall into the middle ground between efficiency and economy, which will make their passage through the General Assembly uncertain. The report recommends reducing the state's contribution to the state employee medical plan from 100 percent to 80 percent, a move that would affect most of the state's 52,500 employees while saving the state $9 million a year.
Another measure approved by the commission that could become a point of controversy in the legislature concerns inmate detention by the Department of Correction. The commission said the state could save $14.5 million next year by maintaining the present term of 9.1 months as the average time served by state prisoners.
 
Outcry About Prisoners
 The average time takes into consideration the thousands of inmates who served only fractions of their sentences before being freed on "supervised home release," a program that the legislature voted to terminate last year after an outcry from the public about people who were committing new crimes only weeks or even days after their sentencing. Keeping the average detention period as low as 9.1 months would almost certainly mean reversing at least part of the course that the legislature charted last year.
State Representative Linda N. Emmons, a Republican from Madison who was the only commission member to join Mr. Olsen in dissenting from the final report, said the debates that loom in the General Assembly over the commission's work were a major consideration in keeping her name off the final document. Getting the Thomas Commission's suggestions into law will not be easy, she said, and she wanted to be prepared to defend herself when the time comes.
"I don't have a whole lot of problems with most of it," Ms. Emmons said. "But I didn't want to be in a debate on the floor of the House and have someone say, 'You didn't dissent on that particular point on the Thomas Commission.' "

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT GUIDE

BYLINE: By Eleanor Charles

 BODY:

 
 
MOZART COMMEMORATION
 Nine musical events will be performed in Waterbury this year in commemoration of the death of Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart on Dec. 5, 1791, at the age of 35. The first is a concert by the Naugatuck Valley Youth Symphony at 2 this afternoon focusing on his early works: the Symphony No. 6 in F and the Serenade in D.
 The music will be preceded by a talk on "Mozart: Prodigy and Genius" by Vincent deLuise, a Waterbury opthalmologist whose avocation is musicology. "We chose to begin the festival today because it is Mozart's birthday," he said. Admission to the Mattatuck Museum at 144 West Main Street, where the concert will take place, is $6.
 An ensemble of 20 musicians from the 140-member Naugatuck Valley Youth Symphony will be playing this afternoon. The organization was founded in 1971 by Edward Bergin, who was the Mayor of Waterbury, and the composer Leroy Anderson who lived in the area. John Pytel, a member of the woodwind section of the Waterbury Symphony Orchestra and a music teacher in the local school system, is the permanent director of the group. For more information call 755-4540.
 
WINTERFEST AT YALE
 This year's crop of Winterfest plays in Yale's annual series of new works continues through Feb. 9, offering an opportunity to sample what could be the Broadway hits of tomorrow. All four plays, which define familial relationships set in diverse ethnic and economic settings.
"Bricklayers," by Elvira J. DiPaolo, an exploration of the Italian-American experience in Pittsburgh, and "Ohio State Murders," by Adrienne Kennedy, about the reverberations of a black author's expulsion from a white-dominated school, will be seen at the University Theater, 222 York Street.
 "Ties That Bind," by Walter Allen Bennett Jr., which concerns a husband's desertion of his family in hard times and his eventual return, and "The Size of the World," by Charles Evered, which focuses on an unusual relationship between an elderly couple and their boarder in Passaic, N. J., will be presented at the Yale Repertory Theater, Chapel and York Streets.
 At the Yale Repertory Theater, performances are scheduled in rotation Monday through Friday at 8 P.M., Saturday at 8:30, and matinees at 2 on Wednesday, Thursday and Saturday. Performances at the University Theater begin 15 minutes later, except for the Saturday matinee, which is scheduled at 5 P.M.
 Tickets are $19 for weeknights and matinees, $26 Friday and Saturday nights. A $52 Winterpass entitles the holder to see all four plays on Friday and Saturday and the following weekend. The box office number is 432-1234.
 
ELLSWORTH HOMESTEAD
 George Washington was not the only president to sleep at the home of Oliver Ellsworth and Abigail Wolcott Ellsworth. John Adams was also an honored guest in the Windsor residence.
 Mr. Ellsworth was Connecticut's first United States Senator after serving as a member of the Continental Congress and a framer of the Constitution. His home and birthplace, built in 1740, is currently undergoing restoration by its owners, the Connecticut Daughters of the American Revolution, and a lecture about the process will be given today at 3 P.M. in the Connecticut Historical Society auditorium, 1 Elizabeth Street, Hartford.
 Rose-Marie Ballard, the site administrator and curator of the historic house, is the speaker, drawing on the wealth of letters, diaries and other written records, which have provided architectural and decorative information as well as insights into the lives and times of the Ellsworth family.
 Admission to the program, titled "Restoration as an Interdisciplinary Approach: The Documentation of the Oliver Ellsworth Homestead," is free. For more information call 247-8996.
 
JOYCEAN CELEBRATION
 James Joyce has been celebrated in South Windsor over the past decade or so at the Paperback Alley bookstore, 984 Sullivan Avenue, where Lila and Marshall Cohen, the proprietors, have been hosts to annual events based on the author's birthday, writings and mystique.
 Feb. 2 is Joyce's 109th birthday and the catalyst for browsing the shop's Joycean books, posters, paintings and artifacts and to become involved in literary discussions anytime from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. on Saturday and noon to 4 P.M. on Sunday.
 At 7:30 P.M. on Saturday, the 1979 film "A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man," based on Joyce's autobiographical novel, will be shown, and at 6 P.M. on Sunday, a 1967 movie version of his novel "Ulysses" will be presented. Both films were directed by Joseph Strick.
 Irish soda bread and tea will be served both days. And following the films, a traditional cake bearing a reproduction of the first page of "Ulysses" in chocolate and vanilla icing will be cut and distributed to all those present. Everything is free, but reservations are advisable for the films, since seating is limited. Call 644-9979.
 
COMEDY, WITH MUSIC
 Homer's "Odyssey" rendered in rap, a blues "Macbeth" and a dissertation on the intergalactic real estate market are among the numbers in Mikhail Horowitz's comedy performances, backed by a music combo.
 When not onstage, Mr. Horowitz writes poetry that has been published in The Village Voice and The Soho Weekly News, and he serves as arts editor of the Woodstock Times in Woodstock, N. Y.
 At 8 P.M. on Thursday he will perform at the Koeppel Student Center of Trinity College. The program, which is sponsored by the Poetry Center of the college, is open to the public without charge. For more information, call 297-2138.
 
SOLO NAVIGATION
 In 1985, Dodge Morgan took a solitary 150-day sailboat cruise around the world. Mr. Morgan, who lives in Maine, will give a talk at 8 P.M. on Friday about the preparations and the experience, which were recorded in a film, "Around Alone," and a book, "Voyage of the American Promise" -- the name of the sailboat.
 The program will be at the John Winthrop Junior High School in Deep River, and admission is $7.50. Call 767-8269 for reservations.

HEADLINE: DIVIDED LOYALTIES

 BODY:
In his article "Divided Loyalties" (Dec. 16), Joel Brinkley argues that Jordanian society is split over the question of support for Saddam Hussein.
From our reading of both the Western and Arab press and recent visits to Jordan, we are convinced that opinions on the crisis are in fact shared by Jordanians and Palestinians. There was little initial support for the invasion among either populace. Once, however, American troops began pouring into Saudi Arabia, a consensus formed that was as much one of opposition to the actions of the United States as it was support for Saddam Hussein. It was an unlikely consensus at that, crossing as it did lines of gender, socio-economic background, religious commitment and political affiliation. It was a reaction that has also been seen in other Arab countries that permit popular expression, such as Yemen, Tunisia and Algeria.
 
OMAR RAZZAZ, MATTHEW S. GORDON
Cambridge, Mass.

HEADLINE: BETTING THE PLANET

 BODY:
It is not what a decade does to the cost of inanimate copper or tin that matters to the future of humankind but what happens to the nature and value of life. I thought your letters column would straighten the matter out, but not one letter alluded to the central environmental issue.
Why didn't Paul Ehrlich and Julian Simon bet on the decline of living habitat or the increase of extinctions? Is it because Simon knows that no ingenuity is being applied to this problem and that more people make it worse -- or was it because Ehrlich has found that we accord life no measurable value.
It is a poor environmental bet that glosses over the fact that there are things of immense value that cannot be purchased for any price, cannot be manufactured and for which there are no substitutes.
 
WILLIAM CONWAY
General Director, New York Zoological Society
Bronx
