HEADLINE: Potholes, Traffic Jams and Now a New Worry: Bigger Trucks

BYLINE: By States News Service

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
NEW JERSEY drivers who are already plagued by potholes, traffic jams and rising gas taxes may soon have another worry to add to the list: triple trailer trucks.
Fiercely opposed by public safety groups, the triple trailers weigh up to 110,000 pounds, ride on 28 wheels and stretch 110 feet, more than one-third the length of a football playing field. Thirteen states allow such trucks on the highway, and the American Trucking Association wants Congress to clear the way for them nationwide. 
 The trucking industry argues that bigger trucks will increase efficiency, decrease costs for customers and pose little safety hazard. Congress will decide whether to let states permit heavier trucks on the road when it reauthorizes the Surface Transportation Assistance Act this year. And Representative Robert A. Roe, as the new chairman of the House Public Works and Transportation Committee, will play a major role.
But New Jersey public interest groups, police officers and state legislators are gearing up for a major fight against the association's proposal, which they say will make the state's growing highway problems even worse. The opponents say that with an aging infrastructure, narrow bridges and the densest vehicle volume in the nation, New Jersey cannot handle triple trailer trucks.
"It's like taking a 10-story building, laying it on its side and running it down the road," said Dan Capriotti, New Jersey coordinator for Citizens for Reliable and Safe Highways, a national safety coalition created last year in response to the association proposal. Dubbed Crash, the group is lobbying Congress and organizing local opposition.
In New Jersey, the group has mustered support from some 30 organizations, from town councils to health-care organizations and several city councils in Mr. Roe's district, which includes most of Passaic County and parts of Bergen, Essex and Morris Counties. The group has also encouraged opponents to write some 130 letters to Mr. Roe, Democrat of Pompton Lakes, opposing the association's proposal, and it has paid for three billboards in Passaic County.
Now visible near the junction of Route 3 and Route 46 in Clifton, a billboard greets drivers with the sight of a mammoth truck driving straight at them, and the blunt message: "They're Coming."
"Our concern is that doubles and triples are inherently unsafe," said Bill Bronrott, a Washington spokesman for the lobbying group, which is based in California. "And in an environment in which we are losing 45,000 lives a year and hundreds of thousands are injured or crippled for life, we need to be improving highway safety and not worsening it."
Like most spokesmen for the group, Mr. Bronrott is armed with statistics on the hazards caused by oversized trucks. From 4,500 to 5,000 people died last year in truck-related crashes nationwide, and 100,000 people were injured, he said. Car occupants are 49 times more likely to die in such crashes than truck drivers, and polls indicate widespread public opposition to bigger trucks.
The American Trucking Association says that Crash has received close to half of its $1 million budget from the Itel Corporation, a railroad equipment supplier based in San Francisco. The railroad industry strongly opposes the introduction of bigger trucks on the highway, largely for fear of losing business.
"We oppose it on economic grounds, because these trucks would divert traffic to the highways that are now going by rail," said Dan Lang, a spokesman for the Association of American Railroads in Washington. "And all of that could see us losing up to 50 percent of profit."
In contrast with the trucking industry and its $250 billion annual budget, railroads receive some $30 billion in revenues a year. At bottom, the fight over truck size reflects an increasingly bitter battle between the railroad and trucking industries. The battle even prompted Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner to warn in a Dec. 10 speech that healthy competition between the two industries should not become "open warfare."
The American Trucking Association points to higher fuel costs, which have risen 30 to 35 percent for the industry since August, and new gas taxes as evidence of the need to improve efficiency. A study requested by Congress and completed earlier this month by the Transportation Research Board, a branch of the National Academy of Sciences, indicates that trucks heavier than the standard 80,000 pounds will not damage highways, provided the number of axles is increased, said trucking association officials.
"The emotional side is just raising the specter of larger and bigger trucks," said Robert Farris, the trucking association's vice president for policy. "There needs to be safety concern about trucks and motor vehicles and motorcycles on the highway. But trucks now move about 70 percent of everything that's produced in this country."
In the 13 Western and Middle West states that do allow triple trailer trucks, Mr. Farris said, safety has not been a problem. Only experienced drivers with special training are allowed to drive the big rigs, which are permitted only under limited conditions and on certain roads, he said. The trucking group is asking Congress to let states permit larger trucks only on specific routes, and in conjunction with extra fees to pay for associated highway damage.
In 1983, Federal laws allowed double-tandem trailer trucks on highways, at the discretion of each state. New Jersey was one of a handful of states to restrict those trucks tightly; they are generally allowed only on interstate highways and their connecting roads.
Crash officials, who do not like double trucks either, say triple trailer trucks are even more unstable and difficult to maneuver under any conditions. A "crack the whip" effect makes it difficult for drivers to control the third trailer, and impossible for drivers to back up. Longer, heavier trucks have tremendous difficulty braking and stopping, and are more likely to jacknife and roll over, said Mr. Capriotti, of New Jersey's Crash branch.
Crash officials hotly denied that they were influenced by the railroad industry's financing. The group has turned down $10 million from the railroads in an effort to maintain credibility, said Mr. Bronrott, its spokesman. He noted that many groups, including truck drivers themselves, opposed the oversized rigs.
In New Jersey, the American Trucking Association proposal has been criticized by police officers throughout the state, and many have written to Mr. Roe and other legislators in an effort to block the plan. And this month, the North Jersey Transportation Coordinating Council, a local advisory body, approved a resolution calling on Gov. Jim Florio to oppose triple trailer trucks.
"They are making trucks bigger, they are making cars smaller, and we feel that they are making a very dangerous mix on the highway," said Anthony Parenti, president of the New Jersey Traffic Officers Association and a spokesman for the state Association of Chiefs of Police. "It can't help but add to the accident rate, injury and death."
 
23.3 Million Trucks on Turnpike
 A major problem in New Jersey is simple density, said James S. Arena, director of the New Jersey Division of Highway Traffic Safety. In 1990, 23.3 million trucks traveled the New Jersey Turnpike, or 11.9 percent of total vehicle traffic, he said. Yet truck accidents accounted for 34.1 percent of the 4,924 collisions that took place .
The New Jersey Department of Transportation is also not receptive to the idea of increasing truck sizes. But Crash officials fear that states like New Jersey could feel pressure to go along if neighboring states adopt the trucking proposal.
Representative Roe said he needed to hear all the evidence before making a final determination. Nevertheless, he said he resisted the notion of allowing larger, heavier trucks on the highways. New Jersey already faces a transportation crisis, Mr. Roe said, and needs to encourage more cooperation among trains, trucks, cars and planes.
Mr. Roe said he was sympathetic to the trucking industry's financial problems but did not want to solve one problem by creating 10 more.
"We need trucks," Mr. Roe said. "But there has got to be a limit to what the highways will hold."

HEADLINE: WRIGHTSTOWN JOURNAL;
Tough Economic Times for 'Military Town'

BYLINE: By ALBERT J. PARISI

DATELINE: WRIGHTSTOWN

 BODY:
WHEN thundering jets climb into the evening and early morning skies here, residents in this Burlington County community rarely complain. Many who live and work here say the roar of straining engines brings with it a feeling of security, just like a ringing cash register.
With war a reality, more and more aircraft arrived and departed,most of them C-141B Lockheed Starlifters, military air transports assigned to neighboring McGuire Air Force Base. But the sound of cash registers has faded, in part because of a sagging economy and the deployment of service men and women in the Persian Gulf area. 
 "There's no question in my mind, we're hurting all right," said James S. Davis Jr., a past president of the Wrightstown Rotary and owner of the Thunderbird Bowling Lanes on the Wrightstown-Cookstown Road.
"I've seen good times and bad here, but this is different," he said. "We don't know where this crisis is taking us and whether it's short or long term. People around here are feeling the effects in more ways than one."
For decades, this mile-square borough of 3,700 residents has depended on military spending for its economic survival, local merchants and elected officials say. Whether it's off-duty service men and women frequenting taverns and fast-food shops or civilians employed at both McGuire and nearby Fort Dix, an Army training center, the sight of uniforms and military-style haircuts has been as common here as summer vegetable stands along rural roads.
 
'You Have Our Prayers'
 Placards and storefront windows proclaim "We are with you" and "You have our prayers" and far outnumber graffito inscriptions of "No blood for oil." Yellow ribbons adorn many trees on front lawns.
"During Korea, during Vietnam, things were tough, but we thrived because there were a lot of people stationed here," said Mr. Davis, whose family has operated the Thunderbird Lanes for 31 years.
But in recent years, he said, the personnel at Fort Dix have been drastically cut back as part of a national effort to decrease military spending. Currently, the deployment of McGuire active-duty and Reserve air crews in and out of the Saudi Arabian desert "means that there are that many less people spending their money on weekdays and weekends," he said.
All told, Mr. Davis and other merchants said, business is off by as much as 20 percent since United States forces began leaving for overseas duty last August.
"A lot of it has to do with the economy and the state that it's in -- we know that here," Mr. Davis said. "But what's happening in the Persian Gulf is affecting everybody, each in their own way."
While some businesses are hard hit, others are holding ground.
"About the only businesses not affected by what's going on are the beauty parlors," Mr. Davis said. "While most of those who have shipped out are the guys, their wives and girlfriends are still here waiting for them to come home, and making appointments to get their hair done."
While officials at McGuire are reticent about revealing the number of aircraft and crews deployed overseas, they admit that the absence of military personnel has affected a way of life both on and off the base.
"It's been busy here and we've had a lot to do," said Art Covello, a spokesman for the 514th Military Airlift Wing, an Air Force Reserve unit based at McGuire. He said that the economic downturn was not restricted to Wrightstown, but affected other neighboring communities frequented by off-duty service people and their families.
In his unit alone, some 400 reservists are either overseas or manning continual flights to and from the Saudi desert ferrying in troops and supplies as well as providing air medical evacuation for the wounded and ill. In addition, McGuire is a key staging area for the delivery of some 200,000 pounds of mail daily destined for the gulf.
For Margaret Steere, manager of the Goodyear Auto Service Center on Fort Dix Street, a tough economy and regular customers' going overseas mean a significant drop in business.
"Compared to last year, my decline in business from customers on both bases is pretty obvious," she said, "and I'm sure it's going to get worse before it gets better."
While she did not give specific figures on her lost volume, she said it was more than the average 20 percent decline being experienced by the local business community.
But such times have also helped to strengthen ties between shop owners and their military customers and families. The crisis has served to bring out compassion in many besides a sense of business as usual.
"I can feel for what these families are going through because I come from a military family," Mrs. Steere said. "My husband spent 27 years in the Air Force, and I know what it means to live on a limited budget and have someone you love far away. People in business around here go out of their way to help others, but with this crisis we all have to be more accommodating, caring and thoughtful for those living on the edge whose wives and husbands are in the gulf."
Mrs. Steere said she and her employees had gone out of their way to provide transportation back to military housing for spouses needing car repairs and "have helped to change a few diapers" along the way. They have also tried to alleviate the tension and anxiety felt by many families.
Wrightstown's history was agricultural until 1917 and involvement in World War I. Fort Dix's role as an Army recruit training and embarcation center for troops moving overseas "was this town's rebirth" and has helped its economy through the Depression, World War II and United States participation in ensuing conflicts, Mr. Davis said.
 
'We've Come a Long Way'
 As a "military town," the borough has retained some of the seedier aspects of catering to a service community, like raucous bars and a tattoo parlor, but business leaders also point to a 15-store mall built in 1959 designed to cater to service families.
"We've come a long way and we've still a long way to go, depending on what direction the gulf crisis takes us," Mr. Davis said.
Mrs. Steere said, "People are afraid here, and that fear has made this community a stronger family." Her son and daughter are both in the service and awaiting orders to the Persian Gulf.
"I've got a nephew who is a helicopter pilot out there right now and like everybody else, we live from headline to headline," she said. "In the meantime, I wear my Desert Shield heart on my blouse and do what I can do to help."

HEADLINE: Travel Advisory;
Gulf War Leads To a 30% Drop In World Travel

BYLINE: By ERIC WEINER

 BODY:
Fearful of terrorist attacks spawned by the Persian Gulf war, Americans are canceling vacation and business trips, not only in the Middle East but also in Europe, Latin America and the United States, according to travel agents and industry analysts. International travel has declined by at least 30 percent since war broke out Jan. 16, they said.
Virtually all commercial airline service to the gulf region, including most flights to Israel and Egypt have been suspended. Also suspended are some flights to Athens, Istanbul and Ankara, Turkey, and Karachi, Pakistan. 
 Some businesses are now prohibiting employees from traveling overseas, said Roger Ballou, president of the Travel Services Group of American Express, the nation's largest travel agency. Mr. Ballou said the number of tickets sold by American Express had declined about 15 percent between the time Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and the outbreak of hostilities. Higher air fares and the national recession had also contributed to the slump, he said.
"All international travel is off," said David Perelman, president of D.M.S. Travel Group, a travel agency in New York. "It's not just the Middle East. It's not just the Mediterranean. It's a concern about travel outside the United States."
Some international flights are being rerouted around the Middle East, via China, the Soviet Union, Mongolia, Pakistan or Afghanistan. Because of the expense of this additional mileage, some fares could rise, according to industry analysts.
Responding to passengers' concerns, several airlines are waiving their cancellation penalties. For instance, American Airlines said it would allow customers who had purchased a nonrefundable international ticket for travel before Feb. 15 and exchange it for a voucher good for travel at any time. In addition, American will allow customers already traveling abroad to change their return date without incurring a penalty. The offer is valid for any of American's international flights, but most people taking advantage of it had planned to travel to Europe, the airline said.
Some carriers offer the waiver only for international flights, but as of earlier this week, at least two airlines, Northwest and T.W.A., were extending the policy to domestic flights as well. All airlines said they were constantly reviewing their waiver policies and might widen them if the war continued for several months.
Even if the war were to end quickly, industry analysts predict Americans will continue to avoid overseas destinations because of the lingering threat of terrorism. Phil Davidoff, president of the American Society of Travel Agents, said, "When it comes to a vacation, if there is the slightest bit of fear, it is no longer a vacation."

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Brigham Young;
A Helping Hand To Hard-Pressed In Soviet Union

DATELINE: PROVO, Utah

 BODY:
What started as a letter to the editor of Brigham Young University's student newspaper has turned into a small crusade by two professors to send money and food to hard-pressed Soviet citizens.
Early last month Prof. Alan Keele wrote to the paper, The Daily Universe, citing food shortages and other hardships in the Soviet Union and the help that country was receiving from Germany. The letter inspired an editorial applauding the Germans' efforts and calling upon Americans, especially students and faculty and staff members of Brigham Young, to become involved in similar activities. 
 "Let's send food to the Soviet people ourselves and urge our Government representatives to develop a more enlightened national policy to do the same," Professor Keele wrote.
Residents of the Provo area responded by getting in touch with Professor Keele and asking what they could do. Don Jarvis, a fellow professor in the Germanic and Slavic languages department, said: "People kept asking what we can do, who we can donate to. It was silly to stand around and wait for someone to do it."
 
$5,000 Collected>
 The week before Christmas the two professors began collecting donations from the community and started the Russian Relief Fund to handle them. So far they have collected about $5,000.
Professor Jarvis then talked with another colleague, Gary Browning, who is serving as a mission president for the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, based in Helsinki, Finland. Mr. Browning, a professor of German and Slavic languages, is on leave from Brigham Young to direct the activities of missionaries from the Mormon Church who are based in the Soviet Union. The missionaries are distributing the donations.
Last month, Professors Jarvis and Keele wired $4,000 to Professor Browning for food and other needs of Soviet citizens. "You've got one of the most powerful nations in the world facing the enormous task of changing a dictatorship to a market economy," Professor Keele said. "We have to do what we can to say: 'We are your friends. We want to support you.' "
Professors Keele and Jarvis are working with Utah business executives and church and government leaders to increase the donations to the Soviet Union and to coordinate such efforts as transporting food by plane.
Peter Serdiukov, a visiting Soviet professor from Kiev who is teaching Russian, said: "The hardest-hit are senior citizens, children and the handicapped. I'm very thankful for the American people's willingness to help people they don't even know."

HEADLINE: Campus Life:;
Student-City Relations Strained over Taxes

DATELINE: LEXINGTON, Va.

 BODY:
Students from Washington and Lee University and city officials are holding meetings in an attempt to resolve their differences after students threatened to boycott businesses in downtown Lexington to protest a personal property tax the city intends to levy on students' cars.
The dispute is over a state law that enables cities to collect taxes on personal property that is kept in the city for more than half the year. Until recently, the city had never enforced the tax on student-owned cars, but Mayor H. E. Derrick said the city had decided to "get the Commissioner of Revenue to collect all the taxes due." 
 Bills for the 4.25 percent tax on cars' assessed value have not yet been mailed, but Lexington's Commissioner of Revenue, Courtney Baker, said, "As far as I know, we will proceed."
Mayor Derrick contends that the city is not "going after student money" but will only be enforcing a state law that is already on the books. "This isn't a new tax or a city tax or the imposition of a tax," he said.
 
Indefinite Postponement
 Because Washington and Lee and Virginia Military Institute are both in Lexington, more than 60 percent of the city's land cannot be taxed, the Mayor said.
V.M.I. has released to the city the names of students who own automobiles, but Washington and Lee's president, John D. Wilson, has refused to do so, saying that a Federal law that protects student records precludes him from releasing the names.
Last week, the Student Executive Committee, along with other student organizations, endorsed a measure that urged students to boycott local businesses for one week "to remind the City of Lexington of the crucial role students play in the city's economy, as well as students' contributions to city coffers through indirect taxation." The boycott has been postponed, though, pending the outcome of negotiations with the city.
The resolution cites a recent study that claims the university generates at least $18.5 million annually for the city's economy. It says student expenditures account for 55.6 percent of this total.
 
'No Other Recourse'
 "I was surprised to see how scared many of the merchants were of the boycott," said Raymond Welder 3d, a senior in European history and geology from Beeville, Tex., and vice president of the student body. The point of the boycott, he said, would not be to harm merchants, but rather to get the attention of the City Council.
"I don't want to go after the man who owns the bike shop or the family who runs the ice cream store," he said. "A week of no business would hurt them, and that's unfortunate, but I feel we have no other recourse."
Mayor Derrick said he was not so sure that a one-week boycott would hurt businesses. "When students go off on break, do they think the town just folds up?" he asked.
But Jay Melvin, who owns one of only two dry cleaners in town, said he would definitely feel the effects of a boycott. "It probably wouldn't be devastating, but it would definitely affect my business," Mr. Melvin said.
Mr. Derrick said a boycott would poison already tense relations between students and local residents. "The end result would be to destroy student relations with the merchants."
The Virginia State Legislature is considering a bill that may affect Lexington's ability to tax the college. House Bill 514 states that "if the owner is a student attending an institution of higher learning" any taxes and license fees should be paid in the owner's place of permanent residence. However, Mayor Derrick said he did not feel the regulation would apply to Lexington's tax efforts if enacted because the bill would amend a section of the Motor Vehicle Code dealing with the registrations, not with personal property taxes.
Campus organizations, like the Interfraternity Council, the Panhellenic Council and the Student Bar Association, have endorsed the boycott. Mr. Welder said the only group he had heard openly criticize the boycott proposal was the student newspaper. In an editorial last week, the paper called the boycott "a temporary solution to a perennial problem."

HEADLINE: Oil's Inconvenient Bonanza

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
In almost any industry, a batch of quarterly earnings reports heralding huge profit gains would bring on buoyant appraisals from gleeful executives. But not Big Oil. Despite vigorous profit gains in the fourth quarter announced last week by several oil giants, few industry executives were celebrating.
In releasing 1990 results, leaders of the nation's largest, international oil companies took pains to stress that their stunning profits from the last three months of 1990 were a solitary event, a bonanza from high oil prices that was unlikely to be repeated anytime soon. 
 Oil prices have indeed dropped since war broke out in the Persian Gulf and an oversupply of crude is expected to depress prices further when the conflict ends, taking oil industry profits with them.
And oil companies say their earnings from the last quarter were dramatic in large part because the corresponding 1989 period against which they are compared was the worst in a decade for the industry. Analysts expect the fourth-quarter operating profits for the 12 largest oil producers to increase by an average of 70 percent over the same period in 1989.
The oil executives' somber tone is intended in part to blunt populist opposition in Congress. Given the public anger over high prices at the gas pump since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait last August and the anticipated wild increases in oil company earnings, some representatives drafted bills earlier this month proposing that oil companies be taxed on windfall profits made from the high price of crude.
The breathtaking collapse in crude prices immediately after war flared in the Persian Gulf on Jan. 16 -- prices fell by $10.56 a barrel the next day -- may help muffle opposition on Capitol Hill for now. The closing price on Friday for the March contract of domestic light, sweet crude, was about $21.35 per barrel, far below the average crude price of nearly $30 a barrel in the fourth quarter.
But some longstanding adversaries of Big Oil may not back off so readily. "It is very disturbing to conservationists that the oil companies have profited so greatly by the war and the runup in oil prices," said Sharon Newsome, vice president for resources conservation at the National Wildlife Federation, one environmental group urging the oil companies to put profits into alternative energy sources.
The airline industry, which consumes huge quantities of jet fuel to power its 19,000 flights a day in the United States, is also up in arms and has appealed to Washington for help. It suspects that oil companies kept jet fuel prices high in the last months of the year to recapture profits lost when competition stiffened and demand lapsed in gasoline sales after the initial jump in prices this fall.
While the price of jet fuel was 8 cents a gallon below that of wholesale gasoline when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, it has ranged between 9 and 40 cents per gallon above gasoline since mid-August, according to the Energy Department.
"We have borne far more of the crude-oil price increase," said Edward A. Merlis, vice president of policy and planning at the Air Transport Association, the airlines' trade group in Washington.
Expecting newspaper headlines telling of huge, fourth-quarter profit increases that would soon appear, Kenneth T. Derr, Chevron's chairman, two weeks ago told reporters : "I would hope that we don't end up with a major political problem over a quarter that I would refer to as an anomaly. Today, we are earning at a significantly lower rate than the fourth-quarter average."
The quarterly gains reported by Exxon, Mobil, Texaco, Chevron, Amoco and Shell -- the nation's six largest companies ranked by sales -- were nevertheless dramatic. Net income for the world's largest oil company, Exxon, soared more than threefold, to $1.56 billion. Mobil's profit rose 45.6 percent. Texaco was up 35 percent, and Amoco, by 68.6 percent. Chevron earned $633 million, after a loss of $883 million in the period a year ago, which was caused by write-offs and other charges totaling $1.2 billion. Shell Oil's earnings jumped by 68.9 percent.
In fact, these quarterly profits might have been much larger. But each of the top five lowered their reported profits with bookkeeping tactics that oil giants often employ legally to pare taxes in periods when profits -- and public resentment -- are on the rise.
The five companies settled legal and tax disputes, wrote down the values of aging or unwanted oilfields, tallied losses from jettisoned refineries and plants and added millions to reserves for cleaning up oilfields and refineries.
But the oil companies point out that the write-offs were even heftier in last year's final quarter, another reason the final 1990 quarter appeared so prosperous. Exxon, for instance, wrote off $800 million in the last quarter a year ago for costs to clean up the Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaska. With that expense removed, Exxon's profit in the quarter a year ago was $1.29 billion, and its percentage gain in the 1990 fourth quarter was 21 percent, not 221 percent.
In the fourth quarter of 1990, all of the majors reported spectacular profit increases in their exploration units because crude prices in the averaged about $10 a barrel more than in the last three months of 1989. Mobil's profit in its domestic exploration unit rose more than fivefold, to $68 million, and in its larger foreign unit by 72 percent, to $505 million. The average global price for its crude was $27, compared with $17 in the similar period a year ago.
Because the five companies each refine much more crude oil than they produce, they must buy vast supplies on global crude markets. Exxon, for example, refined an average of 3.3 million barrels of crude a day in the fourth quarter, while producing half as much from its own oilfields, or an average of 1.6 million barrels a day.
Because the price of crude was falling for most of the quarter while retail prices remained steady, profit margins rose for refining operations in most companies. Crude costs moved lower through November and much of December, after rising the previous quarter, and that cut refiners' expenses. Profit margins increased because prices for wholesale and retail gasoline prices drifted lower at a slower rate than crude prices. Those condition were ideal for refining units of most big oil companies.
Despite the spectacular final quarter, the profit picture for all of 1990 was mediocre. That is because world oil prices averaged about $20 a barrel in the first three months of 1990, before slipping below $16 a barrel in the spring quarter. Analysts estimate that year-to-year gains were in a range of 10 percent to 12 percent. Exxon's net income, excluding the huge Valdez expense, rose 7.6 percent. Mobil's profit rose 6.7 percent and Amoco's, by 19 percent.
And contrary to a survey by Chevron showing that most Americans believe oil is more profitable than most businesses, the oil industry has been a weak sister. The industry earned an average of about $12.50 on every $100 of capital invested during the last 20 years, compared with $13.40 for the average industry. Several industries like software, beverages, pharmaceuticals, hotels, gaming and publishing did much better during the 80's.
The surge in crude prices in the last half of 1990 pushed Chevron and Exxon to a rate of return on equity above $15 for every $100. In Chevron's case, it was the first time since 1981.
But that kind of return may be short-lived. The world is awash with oil, a result of rising output, mainly from Saudi Arabia since the Persian Gulf flare up, and slumping demand for crude. And Saddam Hussein has not appeared able to disrupt supplies: Tankers have moved safely from Saudi loading ports on the Persian Gulf since war erupted, apparently out of the reach of Iraqi forces.
"The world has ample crude inventories now, and it is going to have more," said Richard J. Kruizenga, Exxon's vice president for corporate planning. He said global crude supplies amounted to 150 million barrels, and that the surplus was rising by 500,000 barrels a day. Consumption outside the Soviet Union is 54.1 million barrels a day.
Analysts agree that if it were not for trader fears about Saddam Hussein's potential for havoc on oilfields in the Middle East, crude would be selling for far less than $20 a barrel. Dillard P. Spriggs, president of Petroleum Analysis Ltd., in New York, said crude prices could easily fall below $15 if the war ends in a few months.
William L. Randol, an oil analyst at the First Boston Corporation, said oil prices should average a little more than $20 a barrel in 1991 if war ends before summer -- a prospect that means the industry's quarterly gains would not be nearly as spectacular as for the last quarter of 1990.
"It is impossible to forecast what conditions we may face," Mr. Derr of Chevron said this week.
 
 
THE OPTIONS IN ENERGY PATHS
 The prospects of bloodshed in distant oilfields vital to the American economy is certain to intensify the call from Washington for reduced reliance on Middle East oil.
Large oil companies say they want new supplies, too, but will be unable to find them without improvements in profitability, which despite impressions to the contrary, have lagged behind other manufacturers.
A Texaco-sponsored survey showed that the public opposes the use of taxes to finance the search for oil and natural gas in places other than the Middle East, as well as other forms of energy like geothermal, synthetic fuels and methanol, according to a William K. Tell Jr., a company executive. "They want to see the money come from industry investments," he said. "But I don't see how they can expect that if they are critical of the earnings of an industry that is looking at such moderate rates of return."
Many environmentalists fault oil companies for devoting most of their capital budgets to extending their search for oil, preferring that they spend more on renewable energy sources like wind and solar power. "Oil companies have resisted those changes," said Sharon Newsome, of the National Wildlife Federation. "Their alternatives to oil, like oil shale, coal gasification and synfuels, are damaging to the environment and have an enormous impact on global warming."
Yet environmentalists and oil executives have found some common ground in recent years by promoting a cleaner-burning fuel: natural gas. The United States is nearly self-sufficient in natural gas, with known reserves much larger than for oil.
The problem is raising billions of dollars needed to shift a gasoline-reliant economy toward using more natural gas.
Some oil companies have formed partnerships with natural-gas distributors. "If they make a profit doing so, so be it and more power to them," said Jeffrey Seisler of the Natural Gas Vehicle Coalition in Washington. "In terms of national security and energy security, this is a very positive move forward."

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
War Plays Bring Their Own Dangers

BYLINE: By Alison Leigh Cowan

 BODY:
As long as there are wars, there will always be a profit-minded few whose fortunes are made by ministering to the needs of war. The 12-day-old war in the Persian Gulf is no exception.
The Raytheon Company, the defense supplier whose Patriot missiles stole the show early on by intercepting several of Iraq's deadly missiles in midair, is only the latest example of a company whose business outlook has fundamentally improved because of the war's progress in the Persian Gulf. 
 But for every Raytheon, whose stock has risen nearly 10 percent since the war's outbreak, there are wartime wannabes, pretenders that would like to latch on to the huge stock-market rewards available to those who are seen contributing to the war effort, or benefiting by it. The opportunists range from the outright swindlers, whom investors should avoid altogether, to the overzealous, who may receive some windfall from the war but whose premature hype investors should greet skeptically.
Take Sunrise Medical Inc., an otherwise attractive stock that closed Friday over-the-counter at $22.75 a share. The Torrance, Calif.-based company makes beds and mattresses for hospitals and nursing homes and custom wheelchairs and crutches for the retail market.
No sooner had war erupted than the company's public relations firm in New York was calling reporters, breathlessly pitching the company as a war play, one whose fortunes could rise dramatically with events in the Middle East. "This company will not be stymied by a recession and also would benefit from any war situation because it's in the wheelchair and crutches business," said Anthony J. Russo, the chief executive of Noonan/Russo Communications Inc., the public relations firm. Of course, he added, that scenario, "is all contingent on how many casualties there are."
Richard H. Chandler, the company's chairman, admitted that he was a little uncomfortable with Mr. Russo's sales pitch. "These are heroes, and we don't like to be connected with profiting from other people's misfortunes," he said.
But he added that to the extent war would increase the number of disabled Americans, his company would do its part to help out. "Our war wounded don't have to experience the haunting images of 'Born on the Fourth of July,' " he said. "Just like high-tech weaponry is different than in Vietnam, you've also got high-tech products for the disabled that can make a difference in the quality of life."
The company's stock has soared 17.4 percent since the war broke, about 7 percentage points more than the Nasdaq Composite Index over the same period. Some of the run-up is probably because second-quarter earnings are expected to be up nearly 50 percent when they are announced on Tuesday.
Nonetheless, investors should be cautious about factoring any war windfall into their calculations about Sunrise's future worth. Military and securities experts point out that there are several reasons why it may be harder for companies and investors to cash in on the crisis in the Gulf than they may realize. For one thing, the war is going fairly well. With inventories flush and few allied planes being shot from the sky, the military may not have to go shopping anytime soon.
In that light, obvious war plays may look less alluring once investors run the numbers. OEA Inc., a Denver company that makes explosive devices, would have been a logical beneficiary of the war. After all, its devices not only go into the air bags found in cars, but also into the ejector seats in fighter planes.
Has it been? "At most, you're talking about a one-time contribution to earnings of a penny a share," said Ronald Glantz at Dean Witter Reynolds in San Francisco.
Even the companies that have landed huge contracts to supply everything from lip baum to Gatorade to the troops may see little, if any, long-term impact on profitability. A spokeswoman for the Defense Personnel Support Center, an arm of the Defense Department, said the military has awarded $1.9 billion worth of contracts since Desert Shield began in August.
Those dollars, earmarked for food, medical supplies and clothing, are spread over some 300 vendors, and have generally not altered the thinking of Wall Street analysts about the earnings potential of any individual companies. The contracts may not be priced as attractively as commercial contracts. And assuming the war ends shortly, they also may turn out to be one-time contributors to income -- not the sort of earnings that the market tends to notice.
"Wall Street pays for earnings that come from a sustainable trend," said John McMillin, a food analyst at Prudential Bache Securities, "and maybe this is going to be a sustainable trend. But one would hope that we'll get the boys back and this will not be the next Vietnam. That's why I, for one, am not jumping up and down about these sales."
Geo A. Hormel & Company is a good example. It won a $44.4 million contract to sell 25 million entrees to the troops. Mr. McMillin figures that the contract might generate $3 million in after-tax profits, given the product's usual margins. That would add 4 cents to the $1.20 a share that the company is already expected to earn. "It might give them a little kick," said Mr. McMillin. "But you've got to question the sustainability of the business. Nobody will pay a big multiple for one-time events."
And investors should pay nothing at all for the dubious wares being hawked by unscrupulous promoters who spring into action anytime market sentiment shifts. The North American Securities Administrators Association warned consumers in August about telephone solicitations pushing phony oil and gas partnerships or precious-metal investments.
"Almost always, they latch on to what's hot," said John Perkins, the president of the Washington group. "It's their form of advertising."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1624 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/January 20-25

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL
 
Now, Almost Everyone Has Become Energy-Dependent
 
Even our modern-day Newcastle has to bring in some fuel. Saudi Arabia, the world's second-largest oil producer, has imported 8 million barrels of diesel and jet fuel to power the attack against Iraq. American forces guzzle gasoline faster than the rush-hour crowd on the Ventura Freeway; some tanks get only about 3,000 feet to the gallon. The shortage comes not in crude oil, but in end products. "The quantities used are enormous and the refinery capacity is elsewhere," said Robert G. Neumann, director of the Middle East program at the Center for Strategic and International Studies and a former Ambassador to Saudi Arabia. The situation is worse in Iraq, which has banned fuel sales to civilians. And in Kuwait, the Iraqis set wellheads and refineries on fire last week. Christopher Flavin, an energy specialist at the Worldwatch Institute, said it might take Kuwait five years to rebuild. In his view, the United States will be as vulnerable to energy shortages as ever in the coming decade. "Future crises are all but inevitable," he said.

 Those Embarrassing Oil Profits
 
They marked down assets likely to be sold. They reduced their earnings to account for environmental costs. But still, the oil companies had to admit that they had a darned good fourth quarter. Exxon's earnings tripled, Amoco's rose by more than two-thirds, Texaco's by more than one-third and Mobil's by nearly half. Their executives did their best to avoid celebrating or even cracking into smiles. Instead, they churned out press releases about how unlikely their strong earnings were to recur. Maybe so, given the volatility of oil prices. Still, what oil company wants to be caught profiting from the belligerence of Saddam Hussein?
 
Who's to Feed the Soviets?
 
Leningrad residents, startled to see chicken legs in the stores, call them nozhki Busha -- literally, legs of Bush -- assuming they came from the United States. But President Bush is under strong pressure from Congress to reduce assistance and postpone a summit meeting planned for next month. The European Parliament held up approval of $1 billion in food aid last week to protest Moscow's attack on independence groups in the Baltic republics. The United States has offered as much as $1 billion in credit guarantees for Soviet purchases of food. President Bush, relying on the Soviets to support his attack on Iraq, has so far shown little inclination to cut Soviet off food supplies at the legs.
 
A Foreign Boost for Airlines
 
Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner has a new foreign aid program for the nation's airlines. On Wednesday, he announced that non-American carriers could buy as much as half the equity in United States airlines, up from 25 percent, as long as they held no more than 25 percent of the voting stock. Mr. Skinner's ruling allows the Dutch airline KLM to keep its 49 percent interest in Northwest Airlines, acquired in a complicated transaction. Several of the nation's airlines, which lost an estimated $2 billion last year, are hungry for foreign capital.
 
Whither the Price of Oil?
 
Iraqi missile attacks on Israel and apparent arson at Kuwaiti oil fields aroused second thoughts last week about whether oil should sell for less than $20 a barrel. After a dramatic fall to $19.25 during the week war broke out, prices stabilized and closed last week at $21.35.
 
Soviet Ruble Recall
 
If wealth in the Soviet Union is almost a crime, then only criminals will have wealth. This, anyway, is one likely outcome of the sudden declaration last week that 50- and 100-ruble notes will become worthless except for the limited amounts that can be exchanged for smaller bills. Aides to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev argue that black marketeers have piled up their earnings in the higher denominations. But state workers, new entrepeneurs and the retired are the ones saving rubles. Most anyone who plays the black market has also found ways to convert rubles into dollars, stereos and jeans. Herbert S. Levine, a Soviet specialist at the University of Pennsylvania, called the ruble recall a bureaucratic mess, unlikely to shore up the currency's value as long as the Government keeps printing more money to paper over its budget deficits. "It's a confiscatory currency reform," he said. Four Soviet republics, including Russia, challenged the plan by allowing more time for the exchange of large bills.
 
THE ECONOMY

 
More Gloomy Numbers
 
The nation's output fell at an annual rate of 2.1 percent during the last quarter of 1990, the worst showing since 1982. The nine-tenths of 1 percent growth rate in the 1990 gross national product was also the worst in eight years. Economists were initially impressed -- many had feared worse, and a weak auto industry accounted for all of the quarter's decline. But then some remembered that Friday's figure is subject to revision. Alan C. Lerner, an economist at the Bankers Trust Company, said that other indicators have reflected "much more widespread weakness."
 
Another Bailout?
 
The fund that insures bank deposits could be insolvent as early as next year and $23 billion in the red by 1995, the White House has said. The projection, in a budget request, raises the prospect of another huge taxpayer bailout. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is also likely to raise the premiums that banks pay to the fund. After three years of losses, the fund is already in its worst shape since it was created in 1934.
 
Points of Light Grow Dim
 
Economists looking over statistics on charitable giving say that Americans have become less inclined to share their wealth. Reduced tax rates in the top brackets account for some of the stinginess, as the potential tax savings from charity diminish. But the gains in giving that were expected as Americans have grown wealthier since the 1950's have never materialized; contributions still represent about 2 percent of G.N.P. Republicans might point to over-reliance on the welfare state, while Democrats decry the other party's faith in enlightened self-interest. Edward O. Wilson, the sociobiologist, has noted that ants share food even when hungry; among Americans, plenty seems to merely create an appetite for more.
 
Columbia Savings' Turn
 
Federal regulators seized the Columbia Savings and Loan Association, the industry's largest buyer of "junk bonds," on Friday. The Beverly Hills institution, closely allied with Drexel Burnham Lambert and Michael Milken, bought more than $4 billion worth, now probably worth less than two-thirds as much.
 
 
COMPANIES

 
General Cinema's Synergies
 
Imagine the synergies that could result if the General Cinema Corporation, which controls Neiman Marcus, completes its acquisition of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich: When designers have a passion for purple, Neiman's could offer their fashions along with Alice Walker's most famous book. On a counter displaying chunky Mexican silver, the store could stack some novels by the Nobel laureate Octavio Paz. Analysts had thought that General Cinema was happier serving up Hollywood mayhem and mirth than the doings of Georges Simenon's Inspector Maigret. The $1.4 billion bid that Harcourt accepted on Thursday would rescue a publisher suffocating in debt. But some Harcourt bondholders might object to a deal giving them far less than full value.
 
G. Heileman and Its Bondholders
 
Used to be that a bankruptcy filing was a company's last exit. But these days, it's more like a highway tollbooth. The G. Heileman Brewing Company asked for bankruptcy protection Thursday in a New York court often regarded as favorable to debtors. The company. based in Chicago, was inundated with debt when Alan Bond of Australia bought it out in 1987. Executives acted as giddy last week as if they had downed several six-packs of their Colt .45 and Carling's Black Label products. They announced plans to continue business as usual, with no layoffs, no production cuts, but the likely slaughter of their bondholders. As a spokesman boasted about the bankruptcy process, "This forces a negotiation with the unsecured bondholders so that a package can be wrapped up."
 
Air Travel and the Free Market
 
Up, up and away: Eastern Air Lines might be permanently grounded, but its competitors' fares are soaring. No more $158 round trips between New York and Florida; for some airlines, the price will go to $279. Other destinations in the South can cost more than a round trip from New York to London. "The loss of one or more airlines will not necessarily mean less competition," Secretary of Transportation Samuel K. Skinner assured travelers last week. He explained that higher fares mean healthier airlines which mean more competition which just might mean better bargains in the long run. But so far, free, deregulated enterprise is working better in the abstract than in the air.
 
Pepsico's Super Bowl Punt
 
After a long huddle with the Federal Communications Commission, Pepsico Inc. decided to punt. The company dropped plans for a Super Bowl commercial that might have tangled the nation's telephone system. Pepsi had planned to flash a toll-free number, then give $1 million to each of three randomly chosen callers. Federal officials and telephone company executives warned that as many as 50 million would try to call. The resulting delays in completing other phone calls could slow the dispatch of fire engines, ambulances and police. "It would have been as if everyone in New York City decided to flush their toilets all at once," said a spokesman for an association of local phone companies.

HEADLINE: Novo-Nordisk Rides the Enzyme Tide

BYLINE: By ISRAEL SHENKER; Israel Shenker is a former reporter for The New York Times who now lives in Scotland.

 BODY:
Copenhagen's Assistens Cemetery is one of the burial sites established after the plague of 1711.
Upon visiting the cemetery -- centuries after that plague -- Otto Andresen surreptitiously scraped samples of soil from the graves of Soren Kierkegaard, Denmark's most illustrious philosopher, and Niels Bohr, the nation's foremost physicist. 
 Hans Christian Andersen, the great storyteller, is buried in the cemetery, but where? Mr. Andresen did not find the grave, but he took a sample from a rotting heap of leaves.
Back in his lab, he got nowhere with the soil from the two graves. But the compost heap yielded a bacillus that produced an enzyme that could break down proteins. Dubbed Esperase, the enzyme is now marketed as a key ingredient for detergents by Denmark's Novo-Nordisk, where Mr. Andresen is a research scientist.
Foraging in places like burial grounds and Malaysian jungles for molds and fungi that might contain enzymes useful to the industrial world is all in a day's work for a world-class enzyme-maker. Today, Novo-Nordisk produces half the world's industrial enzymes -- those that are mass produced in a factory for commercial use. Many of them, used for everything from wine making to breaking down barley so that it is digestible by chickens -- were developed as serendipitously as was Esperase.
On the horizon are enzymes for everything from treating toxic waste to turning undigestible plant cellulose into digestible sugar. There indeed is plenty of room for Novo-Nordisk, which now derives about 30 percent of its revenues from enzymes, to grow. Of the thousands of naturally occurring enzymes, fewer than 50 have been isolated for commercial use.
The company is also an important force in the medical market, making almost half the world's commercial insulin supply and a broad array of enzyme-based pharmaceuticals. In fact, Novo-Nordisk is the result of a merger in 1989 of two world leaders in insulin development production -- Novo Laboratories and Nordisk Gentofte.
"Almost all insulin innovation has come from these two companies," said Mads Ovlisen, the managing director of Novo-Nordisk. "That's the only reason they have managed to stay alive while others fell by the wayside."
The combined company had pretax profits of $121 million on sales of about $845 million in 1989. More than 90 percent of those revenues came from abroad. In the first nine months of 1990, sales were running comfortably ahead of year-earlier results.
With research laboratories in five countries, Novo-Nordisk employs 7,500 people and has four large factories in Denmark and others in Switzerland, France, Japan, Brazil, South Africa, Canada and the United States.
Enzymes -- from the Greek word for "in yeast" -- are catalysts, chemical tools that trigger or accelerate a biochemical reaction and survive unchanged, ready to work their magic again. In the body, enzymes break down starch, protein and fat during digestion so that cells can absorb the nourishment. This degradation also occurs throughout nature. When a tree topples, it decays because of enzymes in microorganisms. A compost heap, like the one at Assistens, is nothing more than a living factory seething with enzymes.
"I'm a chemical engineer," said Mr. Andresen. "What I know about microbiology I've learned since I came to Novo."
In fact, he was able to isolate the microorganism that led to the discovery of Esperase largely because of his orientation. "If I'd trained as a microbiologist, I probably would never have discovered the microorganism," he said. "I performed the screening at high pH [high alkalinity], and microbiologists wouldn't be likely to do that, since they are taught that microorganisms rarely survive at high pH."
Mr. Andresen was instrumental in another finding. He showed his father, Paul Andresen, a physician, how to take soil samples, before the doctor went off to visit a distant relative, the Sultan of Johore, in Malaysia. While in tiger and monkey country, Dr. Andresen used a small wooden tongue depressor to scrape jungle soil into plastic bags.
He eventually delivered the soil samples to his son. "The sample from the tiger area didn't lead anywhere," Dr. Andresen said. But the sample from the monkey reserve yielded an enzyme that Novo-Nordisk now calls Promozyme, used in degrading starch to sugar.
Another Novo adventurer, Knud Aunstrup, returned from summer holiday some years ago and found that his brother-in-law had mowed the lawn for him. That made a heap of clippings, and in the humid weather the microbes inside heated up this compost heap. Mr. Aunstrup took samples from the center of the pile, isolated fungi, and tested for enzymes. When he added milk to one fungus the milk promptly coagulated. Mr. Aunstrup -- and Novo -- now had the microbial source for Rennilase. That is an industrial enzyme that now replaces rennin from the stomachs of lambs and calves in making cheese, including such pedigree products as Camembert, Cheddar, Edam, Emmental and Tilsit.
One primitive, but effective technique to unearth an enzyme for breaking down a particular compound is to pour a bit of the compound on the ground -- and then examine the soil and find the microorganisms that have degraded the chemical. "Some people will know what microorganisms will do just by looking at them," said Mr. Aunstrup.
Looking at microorganisms was crucial for Japan's Lion company, an industrial concern, three years ago. Its competitor's Attack detergent was conquering all rivals. Threatened with defeat in the battle for customers, Lion called for a "counter-Attack."
No one had managed by then to produce an economic commercial enzyme that overpowered fat and grease while withstanding protein-destroying enzymes. Novo had been seeking just such a product for years, but at the urging of Lion, it took an even closer look.
After screening hundreds of fungi at its lab in Japan, Novo produced a white, fibrous fungus. Then, at its headquarters in Bagsvaerd, outside Copenhagen, a genetic engineer transferred one of the genes of the white fungus to a strain of Aspergillus, a fungus adept at reproducing itself and producing proteins. A flask containing the modified organism was then fixed in the embrace of a machine which for five days shook it to a fare-thee-well. On Sept. 10, 1987, a small quantity of olive oil was added to the cloudy, brownish mass. Ten minutes later, chemical analysis confirmed the triumph.
Novo had an enzyme that could be incorporated in detergents to break down stains produced by frying fats, butter, salad oil, sauces, lipstick, shoe polish and body grease, as well as eliminate stubborn dirt on collars and cuffs. Jubilant scientists celebrated with lots of another enzymatically assisted product called beer.
But Danish regulation of genetic engineering is draconian, and Novo would have had to wait months for government approval of industrial production. So Novo flew a tiny vial of about a thousandth of a liter of the wondrous substance -- capable of producing the enzyme called Lipolase -- to its Japanese factory on Hokkaido. The Japanese worked quickly, granting permission to produce that Dec. 13; work began the same day.
The first batches of Lipolase were ready by Christmas, and in January Lion began cleaning up with enriched Hi-Top. Danish production permission for the enzyme eventually came through the next summer.
Enzymes have also been put to work at other nasty tasks. Since ancient days, dog or pigeon dung, for example, had been used to soften leather. The job is now done with trypsin, an enzyme from a pig's pancreas.
Trypsin has worked overtime in the unlikely field of Egyptology. With X-rays, researchers could see -- but not read -- an ancient text written on papyrus covered with plaster. A biochemist used trypsin to separate the plaster from the papyrus and fully reveal a text that goes back to the third millenium before the Christian era.
Copenhagen's National Museum has about 13,000 artifacts of amber, a soft, semiprecious gemstone. To preserve the relics, a conservator at the museum prescribed a coating of glycerin mixed with gelatin -- glycerin for luster, gelatin for binding. But as the gelatin dehydrated, it contracted and cracked the amber. To remove the gelatin and prevent further damage, conservator Dorte Gramtorp used an enzyme called Neutrase.
Starch-bearing crops such as corn, wheat, sorghum and rice produce high-fructose syrup and may free people from dependence on traditional sugar sources. High-fructose syrup provides the sweetness in colas. In baking bread and cake, enzymes increase volume, softness and shelf life. Pizzas and bagels are improved by enzymes.
Industrial enzymes efficiently extract oils, coffee, tea, proteins and starches from seeds, fruits, leaves or roots. Baker's yeast yields the enzyme required to make chocolates with liquid centers. And enzymes can give jeans their fashionable faded look.
Enzymes are playing increasingly vital roles in improving the environment, and in detecting, analyzing and treating disease. More than 125 human diseases stem from enzyme deficiency, and medical scientists are using commercial enzymes to attack these diseases.
The possibilities make for a promising future for Novo-Nordisk. Noted Mr. Ovlisen, its managing director: "We're not going to go out and buy a dance school or an airline because we don't know anything about them. What we will do is stick to what we know and can do best."

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Using Zeros as a Safe Harbor

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
Playing the financial markets these days is like hopping a ride on a rogue freight train: You may reach your destination or your investment may be completely derailed.
Given today's volatility, the idea that investors can know exactly what they will have in hand several years down the road is gaining popularity and "target maturity" funds -- basically, packages of zero-coupon bonds -- have taken off. In 1985, there were five, with $10.5 million in assets. Now there are eight, with assets of $711.2 million, according to Morningstar Inc., a Chicago-based mutual fund consulting firm. Most of the explosive growth came in the last two years. 
 Zero-coupon bonds have been around for years. They are sold at a steep discount to their face value and when held to maturity pay a predictable rate of return. The downside, of course, is that if the market rises sharply, you don't benefit from potential gains. Zeros become more volatile investments if you don't hold them to maturity, and some short-term investors use them as interest rate plays. But their main attraction these days is the rate of return guaranteed at maturity.
Two big fund companies have set up mutual funds to capitalize on their popularity. The biggest forces in the market are the Benham Capital Management Group, based in Mountain View, Calif., and Scudder, Stevens & Clark, based in New York. The Benham and Scudder funds are portfolios of zero-coupon United States Treasury securities that mature in five-year increments.
 Should these funds be in your portfolio? That depends on what you want them for. Benham and Scudder pitch their funds as tools to meet future investment goals, "college tuition, for example, a vacation home or retirement," the Scudder brochure suggests. The lure is powerful: high-quality holdings, predictable returns.
But there is a problem. The price for the convenience may be too high. Benham's expense ratio -- the ratio of fund expenses to average net assets -- is .70. Scudder charges even more; its expense ratio is 1.0 percent. The funds, however, are simply packages of bonds and not actively traded like other types of bond funds. They simply manage the cash flow when investors buy or sell in or out of the funds. As a result, the funds "are not doing a heck of a lot for their money," said Lewis J. Altfest, who runs an investment advisory firm in New York.
Still, the sharp increase in assets under management at these funds shows that investors seem to believe advantages outweigh disadvantages. Funds make sense for small investors because they require only a $1,000 minimum investment. By contrast, to get competitive interest rates, investors buying zeros directly would have to spend at least $4,500 to $5,000; that would buy a zero with a face value of $10,000.
Another advantage of buying zeros through a fund instead of directly is that the volume discount given to large buyers raises returns. Recently, for example, the annualized return for investors who bought $1 million lots of zeros and held them to maturity was 8.3 percent; investors with lots of $10,000 got only 7.94 percent.
But if you buy zeros directly and do not plan to hold them until maturity, the numbers change. Let's say you bought zeros with $10,000 face value directly and sold them after one year. Because of the transaction costs, your return would drop to 4.88 percent, from 7.94 percent. Each year you hold zeros, you lose less as the bond appreciates. After four years, the return is 7.33 percent. That's roughly equal to what you would get from the Scudder funds, which bought $1 million lots for an anticipated one-year return of 8.33 percent, after you subtract the expense ratio.
Mr. Altfest's rule: If you plan to sell before four years or so, buy through a fund. But if you plan to hold zeros until maturity, buy them directly because, over time, the annual expense ratio eats into the return.
Because of the price volatility that comes from selling zeros before maturity, zeros make sense for investors who want to play interest rates. The consensus among market analysts calls for falling rates over the next several months or so. Given an identical drop in rates, a five-year zero will be worth more than a five-year coupon bond. So it can pay to own zeros for a short time -- say, six months to two years -- to reap benefits of falling rates. In this case, it makes sense to buy them through a fund because there are no fees for buying or selling fund shares.
For some investors who want to make interest-rate moves, though, there are better alternatives than target maturity funds, says Kenneth E. Gregory, a partner in Litman/Gregory, San Francisco-based investment advisers. He says the Benham Target Maturities Trust 2000 responds to changes in interest rates in roughly the same way as a 30-year Treasury bond. For interest-rate plays, he likes the Vanguard U.S. Treasury Fund, with an expense ratio of .36 percent compared to Benham's .70 percent. Similarly, the Target 1995 Fund is about as volatile as the Vanguard Bond Market Fund, which costs about one-third of the Benhamfund.

HEADLINE: New Yorkers, etc.

BYLINE: By Enid Nemy

 BODY:
As far as spending is concerned, whoever came up with the phrase "we've gone from an era of swashbuckling to one of belt-buckling," had it down pat, although perhaps belt-tightening might have been more apt. The fact is that even the people who are not worried about money or affected by the economy are cutting down, watching what they spend and thinking several times before they do it. It's not only that untrammeled extravagance is now beyond bad taste; it's a general feeling that restraint is both in and desirable.
For many people, this new climate is almost a relief, freeing the mind from a lot of trivia that once seemed if not important at least expedient and conserving both energy and hours that were often spent on unnecessary and frequently self-indulgent activities. If this is not yet (and, indeed, may never be) an era of complete stripping down, it is at least one of contraction in varying degrees. 
 Perhaps the greatest indication of change in attitude is the willingness of most men and women to talk about the ways they have cut their spending or, from the other point of view, methods they now use to save money.
The smallest in terms of savings, but possibly one of the biggest changes, is the number of people who now clip and use coupons when grocery shopping. It's not that coupons weren't always widely used, but the current economic unease has converted many other people, career fast-trackers who once claimed that the time involved in coupon-clipping outweighed the saving.
It has been documented that many restaurants, particularly the more expensive, are suffering. But in addition to seeking more reasonably priced meals, a considerable number of diners are changing the way they order. Some who once chose three courses have cut out appetizers; others have eliminated dessert and a smaller percentage are settling only for the main course. And as a result of a development that combines money-saving and what appears to be a change in eating patterns, more than a few diners are choosing two appetizers instead of an entree.
Dorothy Leeds is one person who now eliminates at least one course when she eats out and frequently bypasses the main course in favor of two small appetizers. She's also taking a further step. "This is a good time to eat less, to diet," she said. "I'm doing it, but I'm trying to make it fun."
Ms. Leeds, president of Organizational Technologies Inc., a management and sales consulting organization, said her attitude was that economizing should be looked on as a challenge and so far, she hasn't found any of it too difficult or upsetting.
"I walk more," she said. "If I have an appointment within 20 or 25 blocks, I don't take a bus; I stand in the half-price ticket line for the theater; I turn off lights when I leave the room; I let my haircuts go a little longer."
Although she has always bought some of her wardrobe through catalogues, "I used to buy whatever I wanted," she said. Now she marks what she wants, goes over the list a day later and eliminates some of the items, leaves it another day and cuts out some more. By the time she sends off her order, it is usually only 25 percent of what she originally marked.
"I ask myself more questions before buying and ordering," she said.
John Barman, an interior designer, isn't canceling a planned ski trip but, other than that, he said, "I'm postponing all pleasure travel."
Mr. Barman said he has found his clients "really concerned about costs, even if they have a lot of money." He frequently suggests reupholstery, rather than new furniture, cleaning and refinishing instead of discarding, and freshening up a room with new wallpaper, rather than redoing the whole thing.
Janet Odgis buys clothes for her 2-year-old son, Ivan, at end-of-season sample sales and is doing more of the same thing for herself. She is also buying more accessories and fewer larger items and she visits the shoemaker more often rather than buying new shoes. She has found, too, that renting videos is not only cheaper than going to the movies but, she said, "it also saves a baby sitter."
Not too long ago Peter Higgins, an owner of the Hudson River Club, didn't think twice about taking a $13 taxi ride from midtown to his downtown office. "It's out of the question now," he said. "I take the subway."
Mr. Higgins is yet another person getting more repairs and alterations done to his current wardrobe, and although he still belongs to a health club, he doesn't sign up for any extras.
"The whole period of self-indulgence has ended very quickly," he said.

HEADLINE: About Cars;
New Technology Chips Away at Noise

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
There is such a thing as gee-whiz journalism, and I will admit to being a sometime practioner. But how can you not be excited about the likes of Acura's NSX supercar? Or antilock brakes, which prevent skids and save lives?
And how can you not think this latest technology is amazing, not to say magic?
Since the early days, one element of automobiles has been neglected by the inventors. It has been that simple but annoying factor, noise. But now, one man has gone after it, cornering patents and making deals with Fiat and other multinational companies, all in the aid of silence. 
 His name is Thomas H. Hesse. He is a 54-year- old native of New York, a graduate of Brooklyn Tech. He is a former Air Force computer analyst, a 22-year veteran of I.B.M. and the former North American sales director of I.T.T. He loves New York but he lives in Phoenix, Ariz., where he says it is hot but you don't have to shovel it, and he is now the president and major stockholder of a company that has its finger on the world's thumping pulse.
His company is called Active Noise and Vibration Technologies Inc., a properly unmelodic name since it threatens to hush the song of engines everywhere.
"There is not one car manufacturer in the world that is not talking to us or to the people we work with," Hesse said modestly. "We now have acquired about 300 man-years of work and about $30 million worth of research."
See? Is that worth being excited about or what? But you still don't have a handle on what I'm talking about, and that is either major gee-whiz or pretty bad editing. So let's get to it.
What Hesse and company are proposing is an electronic solution to noise. And, put simply, it uses the microchip to break down sound waves and then to produce antiwaves that are exactly the same but 180 degrees out of phase, rendering the original cacophony soundless. In other words, loud from loud is zero.
"As an example," he said, "we have done some things with the military where they didn't want to be able to hear a vehicle. And we can get it so that when a 1,600-horsepower tank is rolling across the desert, you can't hear it."
That has advantages, obviously, not only for stealth in a military sense but for buzzy boats and helicopters and civilian factories. And cars.
"There are four primary automobile applications, and we are focusing on them in a joint venture with Fiat," Hesse said. "They are electronic muffler systems, in-vehicle quieting systems, electronic motor mounts, and electronic headrests which would replace normal headrests to quiet certain zones around the driver."
Hesse likes the term "zone of silence," and he admits to being a fan of the old Maxwell Smart television show, in which Max and the Chief routinely conferred about spy stuff under a Cone of Silence. That, essentially, is what you can have in an automobile's interior with the "in-vehicle quieting system," which uses the radio to counteract unwanted external noise.
"I talked to the head engineer at Porsche," Hesse said. "He said buyers liked to hear the engines in their cars, and I asked him if they wanted to hear the engine when they were trying to listen to the radio. The answer was no, and he asked if I could cancel the noise only when the radio was on. I said 'Why not?' "
In this application, the radio has a built-in microphone which feeds ambient sound to a computer. The computer measures the noise and generates antinoise through the same speakers that are playing the music. Hesse's company is working with a Japanese radio producer to come up with an after-market version.
Even with the radio off, though, the headrest option can make a car fairly silent. In this case, the headrest uses two speakers to emit an antidote and cancel the differing sounds that assault a driver's left and right sides. The headrest is particularly useful in eliminating wind noise, one of the company's more difficult challenges.
"The problem is what to do when you have an open convertible or a boat or a helicopter," Hesse said. "The answer is to cancel sound only where the operator's head is, so you use two electronic cancellors, one on each side of the head because the noises are different, and you transmit independent zones of silence."
Uh huh. But the automotive applications that promise more than just quiet and a lack of driver stress are the electronic exhaust system and motor mounts.
With the computerized muffler (and it's hard to believe such a phrase is possible), a straight- through exhaust system terminates in a microphone that feeds the sound to a chip. The processor reads the tone and sends an out-of-phase image to speakers that cancel all sound. Voila, no burble!
"The result with the straight-through exhaust and lack of back-pressure is that you get an 8 to 10 percent increase in performance and fuel economy along with a cleaner burning engine," Hesse said.
But perhaps even more amazing are the company's engine mounts, which remove vibration and lend a hush to the passenger compartment. In a conventional rubber mount, the material compresses as the engine throbs. In the compressed mode, vibration transmits to the car's structure, and that translates into noise for the occupants.
"We place an electronic device inside the rubber mount, which is then controlled by the computer," Hesse said. "That takes the dynamic vibration out of the mount, cancelling it before it goes into the structure."
At idle, he said, a conventionally mounted engine may turn at 750 r.p.m., which would be its optimum for reasonable smoothness. "And it burns gas at that rate," Hesse said. "But if I put electronic engine mounts on the car, I can get the engine to turn at 200 r.p.m., and that means a big improvement in fuel economy."
He is proving all this, he said, in work with Honda and with test vehicles that include an AMC Jeep, a Ford Thunderbird, a Mercury Sable, a new Chrysler and a large cab-over truck. In Europe, the company is working with Renault, Peugeot and Fiat.
Sure sounds like gee-whiz to me.
