HEADLINE: Newark Arts Center: Other Opinions

 BODY:
Re: "Arts Center's Impact on Newark Debated," Dec. 16: The construction of a cultural center at the cost of $200 million (read $300 million before it is finished) in poor, dirty, old, tired and mismanaged Newark will not aid its 325,000 residents. We must learn from history. Ancient Rome died because the leaders sponsored circuses instead of providing for basic human needs.
Newark decorates its light posts in the downtown area with banners, which are changed four times a year at a cost of $100,000. That amount paid in salaries for in-house management of some of the now abandoned housing, including the old Military Park Hotel, where the arts center is supposed to go, would begin to solve one of the basic needs -- shelter for the low-income and homeless people of the city.
The managers would also be teachers. Basic trades to maintain the buildings, like painting and plumbing, would be the responsibility of the residents.
If performance is to be used to judge a city before an investment is made in it, Newark strikes out. This theme is reinforced in the article by the statement of George Sternlieb of the Center for Urban Policy Research at Rutgers. He believes that people "will still be afraid to go there," and he doubts "whether the people of Newark really want it."
I can go a step beyond this. The Mayor and other leaders of the city do not want guests. Evidence of this is readily visible.
I visit Symphony Hall at the southern end of Broad Street when the New Jersey Symphony is in session. Hundreds of dedicated people, most elderly, are not provided with safe crossing on Broad Street after they park their cars at one of the costly lots. Traffic on the street is fast because it is a wide, open thoroughfare. But police control is sporadic. Surely many subscribers, including me, will think before renewing subscriptions.
From the suburbs, many dedicated attendees use chartered buses to get to concerts. One might think there would be drop-off space at the curb for the safety of these folk -- again, mostly elderly. Not in Newark.
Symphony Hall, owned and operated by the city, does not get the tender loving care so badly needed in this fine old building. I have found fire exits blocked and doors jammed. Lighting and cleanliness are neglected. Newark's citizens and their leaders make little or no effort to entice visitors to the hall. We cannot expect this to change.
A direct indicator of lack of interest by Newark, and the management of the New Jersey Symphony, in cultural affairs lies in the fact that at each concert there are a few hundred vacant seats. These are in the mezzanine area. Why are these seats not provided at a nominal cost (perhaps $3 to cover transportation) to the students in Newark and surrounding communities? With leadership by school officials, especially music teachers, hundreds of music-hungry children could hear and see a fine orchestra.
Newark is an Urban Aid city. All New Jersey taxpayers underwrite funds to keep it afloat. But if my observations are an example, the money is wasted in trying to develop image and in poor managerial performance.
I am willing to allow my taxes go to the city. People need shelter, water, sewers, fire and police protection and health-care facilities. A handful of zealots are attempting to "help" the city via the cultural center plan, saying there will be jobs during the construction and for operation of the project. A few million dollars have already been spent in planning and propagandizing the idea.
It should be stopped immediately. Until such time as Newark displays genuine interest in basic needs for all its residents, all public and private funds should be curtailed.
My roots are in Newark. I want to see it restored to health. I invite all to join all programs to rebuild from the ground up while voicing opposition to wasteful, pie-in-the-sky imagery like the cultural center plan.
 
LOUIS E. SCHINDEL
Chatham

HEADLINE: Lest We Forget the Battles on the Home Front

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Iron Medal" by Tom Wicker (column, Jan. 9) offers some sobering statistics about the social and economic costs of the country's drug-control policies. Since I hold several jobs in fields related to criminal justice, I have several perspectives on the problem. The composite picture they present is not encouraging. 
 Four days a week, I work with at-risk youths in foster care in New York State. None of these teen-agers believe that prison or homelessness is in their future. Unfortunately, their optimism is unrealistic. Many will fail to obtain a high school diploma or general equivalency diploma, and for only a small minority does gainful employment lie ahead.
Three mornings a week, I interview criminal defendants in Westchester County to determine their suitability for pretrial release. Few qualify for consideration, because of previous conflicts with the law and irretrievably broken family ties, typically the result of unchecked drug abuse. While many detainees express a desire to participate in an inpatient drug-treatment program, this must be evaluated in light of their chronic homelessness as well as their wish to get "clean." Often, they have no stable address to return to.
Two evenings a week, I teach word processing to former offenders at the Fortune Society in New York City. These people are the survivors -- the ones who have made the decision to break the cycle of street to prison and back again. They are serious and dedicated students who realize how difficult it is to compete in today's job market and are willing to put forth the effort to learn new skills. Unfortunately, many of their peers will have given up and become the statistics cited by Mr. Wicker.
We need a great deal more public debate on the demographics of incarceration, and the social and legal policies that lead up to imprisonment. Despite the important events taking place elsewhere in the world at this time, we must not lose sight of what amounts to a war on a large segment of our own population right here at home.
 
ALINE BERNSTEIN
Thornwood, N.Y., Jan. 10, 1991

HEADLINE: Norbert Bogdan, 87, An Investment Banker

 BODY:
Norbert A. Bogdan, an investment banking executive, died on Thursday at the Berkshire Medical Center in Pittsfield, Mass. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan and in Tyringham, Mass.
He died of lung disease, his family said. 
 Mr. Bogdan, who was born in Abattsia, Italy, and was raised in Vienna, studied at the London School of Economics before coming to the United States in 1923, where he joined the International Acceptance Bank. From 1937 to 1948 he was a vice president of the J. Henry Schroder Banking Corporation in charge of business in continental Europe, South America and Asia.
From 1948 to 1953 he was vice president and treasurer of Ford International, after which he was with General Dynamics before becoming president of his own investment banking firm, N. A. Bogdan & Company, in Manhattan.
He served in World War II as an Army Air Forces officer and was with the Allied Control Council for Germany and later an adviser to the American Military Government in Japan. He also served in several advisory posts with NATO.
An accomplished musician, Mr. Bogdan was a leader of the Musicians Emergency Fund.
He is survived by his wife, the former Barbara Cates; two stepdaughters, Julia Marks of Buffalo and Barbara Washburn of Santa Monica, Calif.; a stepson, Louis Wilkin of Berkeley, Calif., nine grandchildren, and one great-grandchild.

HEADLINE: Business Groups Urge New Farm Trade Talks

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
Business groups from throughout the world, at an unprecedented meeting here Thursday and Friday, pushed for a resumption of the trade talks that broke down last month in Brussels over the European Community's refusal to negotiate farm policies with the United States and other leading food-exporting nations.
While the war in the Persian Gulf has cut chances for reviving the stalled global trade negotiations in time to meet a March 1 deadline for presenting a completed package to Congress, lawmakers say the outbreak of the fighting may have improved the prospects for the extension that President Bush is expected to seek in a few weeks. 
 "Congress would tend to be more sympathetic on grounds of war solidarity, and if members can be convinced that gains are substantial enough, then I think it reasonable to assume that extension is appropriate and achievable," said Senator Frank H. Murkowski of Alaska, a senior Republican on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
The impasse on the farm issue has blocked broader efforts to liberalize world trade under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
"Business in the U.S., Europe and Japan is just not satisfied to see governments say we tried, but we didn't succeed. That's not good enough," said R. K. Morris, director of international trade for the National Association of Manufacturers.
The 13,500-member association is the chief sponsor of the meeting, which included the Keidanren, the No. 1 Japanese business group; the Union of Industrial and Employers Conferations of Europe, the business federation of the 12-nation European Community, and a number of national organizations like the Bundesverband der DeutschenIndustrie, the Confederation of British Industry, the Conseil National du Patronat Francais and others.
The organizations at the meeting represent companies doing 75 to 80 percent of world trade and employ nearly 300 million workers.
 
Wider Benefits Are Seen
 The business organizations say they are trying to convince political leaders that a compromise on agriculture could bring about the wider benefits of liberalization in manufacturing and services, which provide most of the industrialized world's jobs and income.
A joint statement issued at the end of the two-day meeting said the need for a positive outcome of the farm trade negotiations was more urgent in light of the war in the gulf, the serious difficulties besetting the movement towardpolitical and economic liberalization in Eastern Europe, and the economic downturn in the United States and other large economies.
The statement warned that if the negotiations failed, international business relationships and prospects for world growth could be endangered.
While the European Community has yet to present any concrete offers, it is strongly signaling that wants to break the deadlock and is preparing for radical and highly controversial changes in its farm policy.
American and European officials believe the changes, which have been forced by the expensive rebuilding of food stocks in Europe, could be the basis for a compromise in the trade talks over coming months.
"It's the beginning of a process, and is likely to take some time," said theDeputy United States Trade Representative, Julius L. Katz.
"Realistically, we couldn't finish the negotiations by March 1," Mr. Katz said in an interview. "But we're still hoping to be able to report enough progress to justify an extension of time."
Andreas Van Agt, the European Community's Ambassador to Washington, also waved an olive branch by speaking of the "bold policy review" now under way in Brussels "to realign the community's agricultural policy and bring it in line with its responsibility as the world's largest food importer."

HEADLINE: ECUADOR FIGHTING TO AVOID DRUG LINK

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Sandwiched between Colombia, the world's largest cocaine refiner, and Peru, the world's largest coca leaf grower, tiny Ecuador is fighting to keep out of South America's drug trade.
For the moment, the tranquillity of this Pacific Coast country contrasts sharply with the violence of its big neighbors. 
 Well-heeled American tourists clog hotels here on their way to nature tours of the Galapagos Islands. Without bodyguards, businessmen and politicians travel freely around this city, the nation's economic capital.
But reminders are frequent that the multi-billion-dollar drug business is at Ecuador's door.
 
500 Pounds of Cocaine Seized
 Acting on a tip last month, policemen descended on the docks of this sweltering port and seized 500 pounds of cocaine hidden in a shipment of wooden doors bound for the United States. A busy container port, Guayaquil was cited as the port of origin for about 20 cocaine shipments seized last year in ships around the world.
"Ecuador's ports are second in importance in Latin America to those of Colombia," said a recent Interpol report on cocaine trafficking.
A Guayaquil Congressman conducted an inquiry last month that concluded that the amount of drug money laundered in Ecuador virtually doubled last year to $700 million, a huge sum for a $12 billion economy.
Farmers complain that cash-rich Colombian investors are bidding up farmland in border areas, sometimes paying three times going values. One town, Santo Domingo de los Colorados, has received so much Colombian investment that locals jokingly call it "Santo Domingo de los Colombianos."
"The drug business is coming to Ecuador, almost though osmosis because of its geographical position," said Jose Ulloa Vernimmen, an editor of Guayaquil's largest newspaper, El Universo. "There is a sudden growth of people in this city, who previously were unknown but who are buying mansions and driving around in Mercedes."
 
Too Strong for Governments
 Many Ecuadoreans are worried that by the experiences of their neighbors where drug trafficking apparently has grown too large for governments to confront directly. Colombia's Government, tired of the drug war, is negotiating a truce with the traffickers. Peru's Government is unwilling to confront coca leaf growers for fear of feeding an ongoing guerrilla war.
"We need a strong hand to cut out the problem at the start, otherwise it could get as big as in Peru, where the Government can't handle it," Jaime Nebot, a center-right presidential candidate, said in an interview here.
Ecuadoreans have in the past moved decisively on the drug problem. In the mid-1980's, when coca leaf plantations started to proliferate, the Government started an eradication program, cutting the harvest from 4,000 metric tons in 1984 to about 300 tons today.
As trafficking increased, the police stepped up surveillance, using for coastal and river patrols eight boats provided by the United States.
Last year, policemen at Ecuador's international airports arrested smugglers almost daily. About one metric ton of cocaine was seized nationwide from the traffickers, including 15 Americans. But the United States State Department estimates that 30 to 50 tons of cocaine annually slips through Ecuador to consumer countries.
 
New Law Stiffens Penalties
 In September, a new drug law stiffened penalties for people who smuggle cocaine or the chemicals used to produce cocaine. In 1989 Ecuador's economy grew by 2 percent, but chemical imports jumped 30 percent.
"There are coca leaf plantations on the Colombian sides of our border rivers," Col. Gustavo Gallegos, executive director of the Ecuador's anti-drug police, said, referring to the destination of the chemicals.
A Government crackdown on the sale of chemicals to Colombia has slowed the trade, but at a price. On Oct. 10, the day after Ecuador Army soldiers seized 70 barrels of acetone and 20 sacks of caustic soda, guerrillas of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia ambushed a river patrol, killing four soldiers and wounding six. In the area of the attack -- the Colombian sides of the San Miguel and Putumayo rivers -- the guerrillas control coca leaf plantations and refining laboratories.
In a new effort, Ecuador's Congress is seeking to control money laundering -- the conversion of illegitimate cash assets earned by traffickers into seemingly legitimate bank accounts.

HEADLINE: Hickel Wants New Alaska Gold Rush

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JUNEAU, Alaska, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Flush with oil money gained since the start of the Persian Gulf crisis, Alaskans are once again dreaming aloud of grand schemes to extract riches from the nation's largest and least developed state.
Leading the charge is Alaska's new Governor, 71-year-old Walter J. Hickel, who was elected in November as an independent representing a party whose platform called for seceding from the Union. 
 Mr. Hickel disavows that particular plank of the Alaskan Independence Party. But Alaska's revived oil wealth has given him new impetus to pursue old dreams.
This week, in his State of the State Message before the Alaska Legislature, Mr. Hickel called for oil drilling in North America's biggest wildlife preserve, urged construction of an $11 billion natural gas pipeline down the length of the state and proposed laying railroad tracks across the tundra in central Alaska and building roads into towns that are currently unreachable by cars and trucks.
 
Water Pipeline to California
 He also envisions exporting fresh water, through an ocean pipeline, from Alaskan rivers to drought-plagued Southern California. The Governor's proposals have attracted so much attention that people here are referring to the grand design as "Wally World."
Some of these ideas were first promoted by Mr. Hickel more than 20 years ago, when he was Governor for two years until President Richard M. Nixon named him Secretary of the Interior in 1969. But even though Mr. Hickel began his second term after winning only 39 percent of the vote in a three-way race, he says he represents the larger-than-life temperament that has long epitomized Alaska.
While critics deride Mr. Hickel as one of the last of the "boomers," as the pro-development forces in Alaska are known, the idea of using billions of dollars in oil money for big projects is welcomed by many in this land, which came of age in an epic gold rush and has been enriched by the continent's biggest known oil field.
"Sure, I'm a dreamer; that's what Wally Hickel is all about," the Governor said in an interview. "Our goose that laid the golden egg, the North Slope oil, is running out, so we've got to build more geese."
 
Some Significant Opposition
 Mr. Hickel's ideas have run into significant opposition from Alaskan Eskimos, Aleuts and Indians, environmentalists and legislative leaders in both the Democratic and the Republican parties.
The Federal Government, which owns about 60 percent of Alaska's land, would have to approve many of the projects, particularly any oil development in the 19-million-acre Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. In recent years Congress has passed Alaska land legislation over the objections of the state's pro-development political leaders, a pattern that fuels secessionist talk, most of it in jest.
But with projections of a $2 billion surplus in the state budget this year, Mr. Hickel's enthusiasm is contagious here in Alaska's capital, even though he was elected with the support of neither major party.
"We don't want to spend money on pyramids," said Ben Grussendorf, a Democrat from Sitka who is Speaker of the State House of Representatives. "But when Governor Hickel says civilization needs big projects to grow on, everybody around here is interested. We just have to make sure we don't end up with something that's only good for looking at."
 
Annual Dividend Checks
 Alaskans pay no state taxes. Instead, every resident receives an annual dividend check from the Permanent Fund, an $11 billion trust made up of royalties earned by oil pumped from the North Slope region of northern Alaska. Last year the checks were nearly $1,000 for each of the 512,000 men, women and children who had lived in the state for at least a year.
As oil prices fell in the 1980's and the volume of crude pumped through the Trans-Alaska Pipeline started to decline, state revenue dried up. With 85 percent of its budget dependent on oil money, Alaska was facing a $300 million deficit last summer, and looking at cutbacks in services, dividend checks and dreams spawned by the price of oil.
For the first time in years, Alaska politicians were talking seriously about trying to reduce the state's dependence on oil. Such talk became even more urgent in March 1989, when the tanker Exxon Valdez struck a reef in Prince William Sound and spilled nearly 11 million gallons of oil, the largest spill in the nation's history.
But last August, when Iraq invaded Kuwait, oil prices shot up and Alaskans found themselves in the position of benefiting enormously from the crisis.
"I think we are all very sensitive to the fact that the state is getting rich off what's going on in the Persian Gulf," said Chuck Logsdon, a state petroleum economist.
 
Increase in Oil Output
 In response to President Bush's call on oil suppliers to increase production, the Alaska pipeline, which provides 25 percent of the nation's domestic oil, raised its daily output by more than 100,000 barrels, to 2.1 million barrels. As long as oil remains above $15 a barrel, a price that has not been seen since before the gulf crisis, the state surplus rises by millions of dollars a day.
Mr. Hickel says most of the surplus should be used on his plan to "let Alaska recapture its glory." With the Federal Government controlling vast tracts of national park land and wilderness, he said, "the state has been on the brink of colony status once again."
In his state of the state speech, the first major public statement of his administration's intentions, the new Governor said, "We will not tolerate further insults born of ignorance in Congress, the national media or national interest groups." He was referring to statements in Congress and the press implying that Alaskans have not always been the best stewards of their natural resources.
Mr. Hickel moved to Alaska from Kansas in 1940 -- arriving, he said, with 37 cents in his pocket. After taking odd jobs ranging from bartending to logging, he became a developer and builder in World War II, and was so successful that he spent $750,000 of his own money getting elected last year.
 
Themes From the Old West
 In keeping with his self-made status, Mr. Hickel evokes the themes and heroes of the 19th-century American West. He favors railroad development, even at a construction cost estimated at $3 million a mile, because that was how the West was developed. He says the state's Eskimos, Aleuts and Indians, which make up 15 percent of the population, should have no special hunting or fishing rights. And he loathes having vast tracts of land designated as official wilderness, because of the restrictions that go with it.
"When Lewis and Clark went across the country, they didn't do it on a National Scenic Road," he said. "We Alaskans must be allowed to catch up. We're young."
Environmentalists are counting on a change in attitude, brought on in part by the Exxon Valdez spill, to generate opposition to many of Mr. Hickel's plans.
 
An Unpredictable Politician
 "Walter is stuck in the past, giving us these Gilded Age pronouncements as the last great leader of the boomer school," said Jack Hession, the Alaska representative of the Sierra Club. "I think he'll find there has been a great change here. People see Federal protection as a good thing. They protect some of the most valuable areas in the world."
Mr. Hickel is unpredictable. As Interior Secretary he fought oil companies over their environmental records, and was dismissed in 1970 after disagreeing with Mr. Nixon on the Vietnam War. Since then, Mr. Hickel has built an empire of hotels and shopping malls, run from his headquarters in the Captain Cook Hotel in Anchorage.
Congress is not likely to approve oil drilling in the wildlife refuge any time soon, leaders of the House Interior Committee say. The natural gas pipeline, an 820-mile project that was first proposed by Mr. Hickel as an investment for his company, the Yukon Pacific Corporation, is not feasible in current market conditions, economists say.
The proposed railroad, an extension that would open up some of the state's harshest terrain, is opposed by wildlife advocates. They note that trains on the Alaska Railroad, which runs 525 miles from Fairbanks to Seward, are one of the biggest killers of moose in the winter.
And, because many Alaskans delight in their isolation, the new roads proposed by the Governor are getting a cool reception by some people in the very towns that would be connected to the outside world by them.
Despite the odds, Mr. Hickel says all his dreams will eventually become part of Alaska's landscape. "These are not idle visions," he said. "They are the keys to our independence."

HEADLINE: U.S. Plan on Child Care Is Reported to Be Stalled

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: COLUMBUS, Ohio

 BODY:
For almost a year, Nicole McDaniel has worked nights and weekends as a registration clerk at St. Anthony Medical Center here. With the help of a state subsidy for child care, she can leave her daughter, Stacie, at Northside Child Development Center, one of a handful of such centers in the nation that are open seven days a week, 24 hours a day.
In addition to working unusual hours and days, Mrs. McDaniel, 23 years old, recently separated from her husband. Without the subsidy, she might easily slip out of the work force and onto the welfare rolls. "I don't know what I'd do if I couldn't leave her here," she said. 
 It was to help families like hers that Congress passed and President Bush signed a two-part child care measure last year that is the Federal Government's largest commitment ever to child care programs. The promise was to help low- and middle-income families find decent child care they could afford. One part of the plan committed the Federal Government to $2.5 billion in block grants to states over the next three years and the second to $1.5 billion in matching funds over the next five years.
 
Dispute Over Running the Plan
 But now advocates say the Bush Administration is dragging its feet in writing the regulations for the block grant program that will be needed to put it into effect by its scheduled starting date of Sept. 7. They also say the Administration is already off to a bad start, having designated a welfare agency rather than a child development agency to run the program.
The Administration replies that the regulatory process is on schedule and that the Family Support Administration, which operates programs like Aid to Families with Dependent Children, is the appropriate agency to administer the child care program. "The law was only passed recently," said David H. Siegel, a spokesman for the Family Support Administration.
Still, state social service officials say they need Federal regulations soon if they are to coordinate the program with their existing services. Most states have a dozen agencies that handle child care programs, from education to social services and welfare departments, and their administrators say they need time and flexibility to put the money to work.
 
Eligibility a Major Factor
 "We're hopeful that people can light a fire under the Federal Government and they'll promulgate these regulations quickly and release the funds," said Michael Werner, senior legislative analyst for Gov. William Donald Schaefer of Maryland. And Henry Jenkins, an official with the Ohio State Human Services Department, said that unless care was taken in the flow of funds from Washington, families who are now eligible for child care assistance might find themselves ineligible under the Federal regulations.
Some child care advocates also fear that state governments desperate for cash may try to use the new Federal funds to pay for state child care programs already in existence, which is prohibited by the legislation, or to cover shortages in other programs.
"Child care is really an economic development issue, but many states see it as a social service, one of the first things to go in hard times," said Barbara Riceman, executive director of Child Care Action Campaign. "Child care is as essential for getting people to work as public transportation."
 
Plan Reflects Compromises
 The child care program involves a variety of approaches, reflecting political compromises reached after a four-year fight in Congress and a decade of discussion about the wisdom of involving the Federal Government in the issue. The $2.5 billion program will supply grants to the states to provide child care services for families of different incomes and eligibility requirements, with some money set aside for things like early childhood education and after-school child care. Its supporters say it will serve 750,000 children.
Preliminary regulations have already been issued for the second part of the child care package, which will provide $300 million a year in matching funds over the next five years. This money will be available for child care programs that would help families get off welfare as well as help families stay off the welfare rolls.
Here in Columbus, Tom and Vivian Rice, who are in school to improve their job skills, hope the new money will provide after-school care for their three children. "We tried to separate our classes," said Mrs. Rice. "That way, one of us would be home to be with the children. But this quarter, we're both going to be in school when the children get home, and we haven't figured out what to do."
Child care advocates and administrators say they fear the Bush Administration may interpret the law so narrowly as to thwart the intent of Congress. They had hoped that the program would be administered by the Administration for Children, Youth and Families, the agency in the Health and Human Services Department that handles Head Start and other child development programs. Instead, the Administration has designated another agency, the Family Support Administration, which handles welfare programs.
Mr. Siegel, of the Family Support Administration, said his agency had the necessary experience in licensing and child care to "effectively operate the child care and development block grant program."
 
Will Program Be Stigmatized?
 But state officials say administering the legislation as a welfare program could lower the child care standards, limit beneficiaries and stigmatize the program in the eyes of potential recipients and providers.
For example, the officials say, the family support agency reimburses child care services at such a low rate or so slowly that many centers are discouraged from participating. Health and safety standards of child care centers in the agency's programs are not as strict as those outlined in the child care legislation. And the child care program is not a welfare program, advocates say. Under the child care law, families are eligible for assistance if their children are younger than 13 years old and their family income is less than 75 percent of the state median income, which includes families well above the poverty level.
Debates over the program may take on new urgency from the war in the Persian Gulf as reservists pour into states where military bases are concentrated. Karen Thelin, a member of the Iowa Child Care Alliance, put it this way: "We're sending middle-income guys to Kuwait, so the women have to work. That means they have to find child care."

She is able to leave her daughter, Stacie, at Northside Child Development Center, which is open seven days a week, 24 hours a day. (Photographs by Kevin Fitzsimmons for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Eastern Workers Line Up at Unemployment Office

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
For Robert Fanfauzzi, who had been a ramp worker at La Guardia Airport for Eastern Airlines for $6.75 an hour, the shutdown of the carrier over a week ago was not a big deal.
Since being hired last July he had few illusions about Eastern's chances of surviving. "I was looking for other jobs while I was there; I knew it would probably go bankrupt," he said as he waited with about 100 other people to fill out unemployment insurance forms at a New York State Department of Labor office near the Queensboro Plaza station on the Flushing line. 
 But for Ruby Stocker, who had been a flight attendant for Eastern for 30 years, the shutdown was a blow that still hurts. "I just don't know what I'm going to do," said said, covering her feelings with a smile.
 
'Going Back to Training School'
 Miss Stocker said she would like to get another flight attendant job because she enjoyed her work. "It means going back to training school and starting at the bottom," she said, and that would mean sitting through classes to learn things she already knows, to receive a salary that would probably be half of what she had earned at Eastern.
All week long, some of the 1,350 Eastern employees at La Guardia who lost their jobs in the shutdown on Jan. 18 have been going to the unemployment office near Queensboro Plaza, as well as to offices in Jamaica and Flushing. There they have sat in metal chairs waiting to hear their names called to receive their forms and booklets.
Most of the workers live within easy commuting distance of the airport, where Eastern was once a dominant carrier.
Another 350 workers lost their jobs at Newark International Airport, part of the 18,000 people nationwide who will be out of work because of the shutdown. Other businesses have been affected, too. One is Chelsea Catering, a kitchen owned by Continental Airlines that had the contract to supply meals on Eastern flights at La Guardia. Art Kent, a spokesman for Continental, said 95 new probationary workers for Chelsea and 50 regular workers had lost their jobs.
 
Bitterness All Around
 Behind the lines at the unemployment offices lay the 22-month strike that tore Eastern apart, and the bitter feelings on all sides over the fact that the jobs the workers lost were jobs they had taken from the mechanics, flight attendants and pilots who had struck and stayed on strike.
The strike by the International Assocation of Machinists and Aerospace workers, which began on March 4, 1989 and quickly gained the support of the pilots' union, crippled Eastern's operations. Most machinists' union members and pilots honored the picket lines. Five days after the strike began, Eastern filed for protection under the bankruptcy laws. In the summer of 1989, Frank Lorenzo, then the chairman of Texas Air, Eastern's parent company, began to rebuild Eastern by hiring new pilots, mechanics and flight attendants at much lower wages.
By that fall about 60 percent of the airline was operating, staffed mostly by new workers, many of whom were heckled by pickets. Many pilots and flight attendants who had supported the strike also went back.
During this period Miss Stocker decided to go back herself, she said, because the union's cause seemed hopeless.
 
Machinists' Union Fought On
 By November the Air Line Pilots Association and the Transport Workers Union, representing flight attendants, decided to call off its strike. The only union to fight on was the I.A.M. -- the machinists and aerospace union -- which once had about 12,000 members at Eastern.
And only last Thursday, almost a week after the shutdown, did the I.A.M. leaders call a halt to the strike. Most of its members had already been forced to find other jobs. Others, unable to find enough work, have suffered severely, losing savings and even houses.
The hostility toward workers like Mr. Fanfauzzi who were hired during the strike still runs deep among some I.A.M. members. There were cheers among I.A.M. pickets when Eastern announced it was shutting down after operating since 1928.
In interviews after the shutdown, some former pickets said that the workers who had helped break the strike would also be on the street.
One replacement who felt the hostility was a young mechanic who had been hired in December 1989. He spoke on the condition of anonymity, saying he still feared that other I.A.M. members might harass him as he looked for work at another airline. "The I.A.M. is a pretty strong union," he said.
The worker said that even though some airlines are cutting back to cope with the higher fuel costs and the drop in traffic caused by the gulf war, he believes the training that he received at Eastern will help him get another job as a mechanic.
 
Lower Salaries Are Likely
 The outlook for others, however, is not as promising.
Phil Stroh, the manager of the Queensboro Plaza unemployment office, said an "airline career center" had been set up at Kennedy Airport to help workers at Eastern and other airlines, like Trans World Airlines, which recently furloughed 2,500 employees.
But the pay for new airline workers is very low, since most carriers have adopted two-tier pay scales, in which senior workers can keep their usual salaries.
Eastern's baggage handlers, for example, were paid $15 to $16 an hour under the old scale. Mr. Stroh said that the starting wage for that kind of work now is $6.50 an hour, lower than before, and that new workers would probably never receive $15 to $16. He said the job center had openings for reservation agents at $4.40 an hour and for flight attendants at $9.40 an hour.
"It's a very tough time for someone in the airline industry," he said.

HEADLINE: The Daily News Strike Tests The Will of Weakened Labor

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN

 BODY:
Though small and in some ways parochial, the strike at The Daily News has become an important trial for an American labor movement that has been losing ground for decades.
Because of the attention that the paper attracts, being in the nation's media capital and in a city with strong labor traditions, the strike at The Daily News has galvanized organized labor's drive to stop management's use of a weapon -- the permanent replacement worker. Unions maintain that it blunts their mightiest weapon: the strike. They say the use of permanent replacements, to whom strikebound employers promise permanent jobs, underlies much of labor's waning influence. 
 "As long as workers can be replaced when they go on strike, the right to strike is taken away," said Juan Gonzalez, a Daily News columnist and strike leader for one of the unions, the New York Newspaper Guild. "The strike cannot be resolved until that's resolved."
 
Special A.F.L.-C.I.O. Aid
 Unions represent only one in six of the nation's workers today, but in New York City the figure is at least 40 percent. This fact, combined with the replacement worker issue and the newspaper's fame, has focused unusual labor attention on a strike involving only 2,300 workers.
"We're dealing with one of the world's most visible newspapers," said Thomas Donahue, secretary-treasurer of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. "The Daily News has made a high art of using replacements. We think the issue has matured to the point where we believe Congress will do something about it this year."
Mr. Donahue said the federation had singled out the strike for special assistance, including the full-time support of three staff members, outside legal and public relations help and $300,000 to underwrite strike activities.
Mr. Donahue and other leaders have met in New York to help organize the strike. Unions like the United Mine Workers and the Steelworkers have offered financial and organizational help. They have also helped set up a nationwide campaign against the Tribune Company, urging people in Florida, for instance, not to subscribe to the company's papers there.
In November, members of 25 unions in New York canvassed neighborhoods in Queens to ask Daily News subscribers to cancel home delivery.
And the labor federation has mounted a lobbying offensive in Washinton. Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, and Representative William L. Clay, Democrat of Missouri, have reintroduced legislation to ban employers' use of replacement workers. Despite wide support among Democrats, their bills were crowded out of Congress's agenda last year. "This is the single most important issue before us now," said the chief lobbyist for the United Steelworkers, Jack Sheehan.
A senior Labor Department official said the Bush Administration had yet to take a position on the legislation. But the Administration has opposed most other labor objectives, and he implied the Administration would oppose a replacement-worker law because "we might get more strikes and more labor strife."
 
 Reagan's Action In '81 Sets Precedent
 Employers have always been free to try to keep their businesses going in strikes with temporary workers, or scabs, as unions call them. And since a Supreme Court ruling in 1938, they have been free to hire nonunion workers during strikes over wages, benefits and working conditions and keep them on the job, often leaving the strikers and their unions permanently on the street.
But until 1981, when President Ronald Reagan used permanent replacements to break the illegal strike of 12,000 air traffic controllers, employers hardly ever resorted to them, perhaps for fear of public rebuke for union busting. "But any businessman could then say, 'The President did it so it must be O.K.,' " said Richard L. Trumka, president of the United Mine Workers.
When permanent replacement workers are used, strikers regain their jobs and accrued pay only if courts find that employers engaged in unfair labor practices. Otherwise the strikers' sole right is first claim on the jobs after the replacements retire or move to other jobs. The nine unions representing The Daily News's 2,300 strikers have filed unfair labor practice complaints with the National Labor Relations Board, but rulings typically take several years, and by then the paper may have collapsed.
Labor experts say the air traffic controllers' strike coincided with the slow decline in union membership, from 24 percent of all workers in the early 1950's to 16 percent today, and waning public support of unions. "It was a sign that the American public was not going to look at labor relations as it did in the heyday of organized labor -- that a person is entitled to a job almost as a property right," an official of the National Labor Relations Board said.
 
Managements Shift To Replacements
 Since the air traffic controllers' strike, several major companies have permanently replaced strikers. They include Greyhound Lines, which last year replaced nearly all 6,000 striking drivers; Continental Airlines; the International Paper Company; Boise Cascade, another paper company, and six years ago The Chicago Tribune, flagship of the Tribune Company, owner of The Daily News.
Many other employers, including the Pittston coal company in Appalachia and Delta Pride Catfish Inc. in Mississippi, the nation's largest catfish processor, threatened to replace workers during their recent strikes but dismissed the replacements upon settling with their unions. The Ravenswood Aluminum Corporation in West Virginia says it has given permanent jobs to 400 replacements for 1,800 members of the United Steelworkers of America now on strike there.
No one keeps a tally of all the strikes that unions wage, much less the numbers involving permanent replacements. But industry's willingness to hire them seems to be spreading. In a poll of 132 companies that experienced strikes in 1985, the General Accounting Office, Congress's auditing agency, found that 15 percent said they would use permanent replacements. Four years later, 23 percent said they would. In each year, 15 percent actually did so.
Their use would be far greater, unions assume, were it not for a sharp decline in the number of strikes, which unions attribute in part to the threat of permanent replacement. In strikes involving 1,000 or more workers since World War II, the Bureau of Labor Statistics recorded the most strikes ever -- 470 -- in 1952 and almost as many -- 424 -- in 1974. But the number fell precipitously in the 1980's, to 40 in 1988, to 51 in 1989 and to 44 last year.
 
Added Pressure In Time of Recession
 The recession lends some urgency to organized labor's campaign to ban use of the replacements. Companies normally pay the replacements less than unionized workers. And with unemployment rising, employers have access to a growing pool of willing workers.
At The Daily News, management maintains that rather than tip the balance of power in a strike its way, the use of replacements merely rights the balance. James Hoge, the publisher, argues that the paper lost $160 million from 1979 through the first nine months of last year, before incurring large additional strike-related losses, because of the costs in excessive overtime and overstaffing that management accepted "with knives at their throats" in settling earlier strikes.
Mr. Hoge has threatened to close or sell the paper unless the newspaper obtains $70 million in annual savings. "The only real thing that strikes have produced in New York," Mr. Hoge said, "is the death of one newspaper after another." With permanent replacements of strikers, he said, "we have the hope of rectifying a major imbalance."
Mr. Hoge is deliberately ambiguous about his commitment to the 800 replacements he has brought aboard. Unlike Greyhound, for example, which has been unequivocal in assuring permanent jobs for its replacements, Mr. Hoge said, "By law we're open to discussions and negotiations." He has required the replacements to sign a release giving management the right to dismiss them at will, and in bargaining sessions with the unions his negotiators have said only that the replacements are secure in their jobs "at this time."
 
Epithets Shouted Across Picket Lines
 By using replacements, The Daily News is the first New York newspaper to continue printing during a strike, and the use has turned the company's normally hostile labor relations white hot. At the entrance to the main printing plant off Atlantic and Flatbush Avenues in Brooklyn one night, six big, graying white men stood encaged within a fence of police barricades.
The men worked in the plant until 60 of them walked out on Oct. 25, precipitating the strike. This night, like others, the men in the cage hurl epithets, including racial slurs, at the workers, many of them black, hurrying through the door.
Many of the replacements themselves believe they are safe in their jobs. Inside the printing plant, the company's production manager, Richard Malone, said he is printing the paper and printing it better with 5 or 6 replacement workers for each of the 12 presses, compared with 13 to 15 regular workers.
The plant is a 70-year-old industrial artifact with rows of heavy, dark-metal Goss presses, dark floors and windowless dark walls that soak up the fluorescent light, creating expanses of Dickensian gloom. Mr. Malone said the company planned to abandon the plant eventually and build a new one on Long Island. For the first time ever, the company is painting the presses, bright blue with yellow trim.
 
Theme of Unions: Settle, Sell or Sink
 A replacement pressman who declined to give his name for fear of attack by strikers said he is paid $12 an hour, more than he made in his last job as a security guard but about half the pay of the unionized pressmen. "I have been hired for good," he said. "That's what I was told when I was hired. I believe them."
Another pressman is Cedric Noah, 30 years old. He applied for the job last February, when The Daily News was advertising for replacements in anticipation of a strike, and was given four weeks' training at a smaller plant in Kearny, N.J. His pay, about $40,000 a year, is close to a regular pressman's pay and $12,000 more than he said he had earned as a restaurant manager. "I expect this to be a permanent job," he said, "but they still have the right to release me."
Both sides in the strike seem to be flirting with suicide. In retaining replacement workers, management has alienated union members to the point that they have no stake in the company and no alternative to driving away advertisers and intimidating newsstand operators. The paper's 1.1 million circulation has been cut in half and all the major advertisers have disappeared.
For many of the unionized workers, who have made "settle or sell" the theme of the strike, closing the paper is becoming a strong third option, even though that spells the end of their jobs.
They say hundreds would lose their jobs anyway as part of a settlement to drive down production costs, and far more would be lost if management insists on retaining the replacements in a settlement to keep the paper open. Settling, they say, would send a message to employers that even in a big union city like New York management can ignore its unions.
"You have to draw the line," said Nicholas Bianca, 45 years old and a driver who started working for the paper when he was in his teens. "I would want the paper to close, absolutely." Mr. Trumka, head of the mine workers' union, said, "You've made it in the strikers' interest to say The Daily News should fold."
In sacrificing their jobs by forcing the paper to close, the Daily News unions would send other employers a message. "The lesson is that the strike weapon can still be effective," said Robert M. Baptiste, a lawyer in Washington who represents unions. "Workers who stick together, no matter how tough it gets, can force employers to negotiate -- or go out of business."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Unions contend that management's use of permanent replacement workers at The Daily News blunts the strength of their strongest weapon, the strike. Outside the newspaper's plant in Brooklyn, a replacement worker passed a group of picketing strikers last week on his way to work. (G. Paul Burnett/The New York Times) (pg. 23)

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: Suffering in the Cities Persists As U.S. Fights Other Battles

SERIES: Missing Agenda: Poverty and Policy/First of three articles.

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
Nearly three decades after the Great Society, and after eight years of record economic growth, urban poverty remains an entrenched force in American life and an increasingly destructive one.
Homelessness, underclass, crack, AIDS -- the past decade has challenged dictionaries to keep pace as it redefined city suffering. Some wonder whether such words spell a permanent change in the definition of America itself. 
 Programs and policies have failed to halt this sinking spiral even in a decade of relative prosperity like the 1980's. Some Administration officials have been urging President Bush to use his State of the Union Message on Tuesday to announce a sweeping new policy to tackle the problem. But as the country wages war and sags into recession, there is even less reason to believe it can summon the will or the wallet to fight this internal enemy.
 
'Not on the Agenda'

"Very few people in a responsible position are dealing with, or even debating, what to do," said Representative John Lewis, the Georgia Democrat who was an early leader of the civil rights movement.
"It's not just this Administration," he said. "In the Congress or in the private sector, the problems of the poor are just not on the agenda. They're becoming more visible and yet invisible."
And just as Vietnam stalled the war on poverty of the 1960's, Mr. Lewis said, the Persian Gulf war will leave even more domestic problems unattended. "You cannot spend $1 billion a day to fight a war and still deal with the problem at home," he said.
The explanations for America's policy failures are complex, numerous and hotly contested. Some say the nation has spent too little; others say it has spent too much. Some argue that ideas are lacking; others say commitment is what the country needs most.
 
A Worsening Problem
 Race, too, is a complicating factor, as the problems of the inner city fall disproportionately on minorities.
Whatever the causes, an overwhelming majority of the American public says that urban poverty is growing worse and that President Bush has done little to improve the situation.
Seventy-two percent of those interviewed in a New York Times Poll said poverty and its related problems were worse today than 10 years ago, while only 4 percent said the problem had become less pressing. And when asked to choose from description of Mr. Bush's attempts to address the problem, 77 percent answered "not much" or "nothing at all."
The poll of 1,028 adults, including 93 blacks, was conducted Dec. 12 to 14 and had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3 percentage points over all, and 10 points for blacks.
Over the past two years, there have been some signs that poverty has been inching up the nation's list of priorities. Despite the climate of austerity, Congress last year voted to expand tax benefits for the working poor by $18 billion over five years, and added several billion for Medicaid and Head Start.
Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp, the Administration's chief antipoverty strategist, has written Mr. Bush, urging him to use the State of the Union speech to offer "audacious" solutions to the problems of the poor. Six months ago there was even talk of a "peace dividend" that might make money available for social spending.
But now, with the recession and the war dominating the nation's attention, many believe that this modest momentum will produce little.
"We will lunge at these international problems, but we have stopped trying to solve domestic issues," said H. Ross Perot, the Texas entrepreneur who was a force in that state's efforts to improve its educational system several years ago. "Let's say you're President and you're concerned about rape, plunder, and pillage. You don't have to go to Iraq; you can find it in New York, Detroit and Chicago."
Mr. Perot added, "The thing we lack in this country more than anything is Churchill's dictum: 'Action this day.' "
 
The Effects
All of Society Pays a Price
 In the past decade, two words have become central to discussion of American cities: homeless and underclass. They can be hard to define and the groups they describe harder to count.
But both have implications beyond their size. They suggest a second, separate America, a nation within a nation whose health, welfare, and social mobility evoke the Third World. Indeed, visitors startled by the rows of homeless lying in Grand Central Terminal in New York strain for analogies and produce the word "Calcutta."
When speaking of an underclass, researchers are not simply talking about poor people, which America has always had in abundance. They are talking about a development more alarming, something many regard as a new and hardened population of poor people, disproportionately black, who live in subcultures where unemployment, female-headed families, welfare dependency, violence and drug abuse flourish.
Part of the reason the very concept has been so controversial is that its implication of permanent classes rubs raw the notion of equal opportunity.
 
Deep Change in Cities
 Estimates put the number of the underclass at less than 10 percent of the 31.5 million Americans whose incomes are below the Government's poverty line, $12,675 a year for a family of four. And some argue that the problems are most apparent in New York and a few other large cities in the Northeast and Midwest.
But Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who is Congress's foremost expert on urban poverty, says such figures underestimate the depth of change in cities.
From the seas of available statistics, Senator Moynihan fetches one to announce his dismay. In a study by the University of Michigan, researchers found that 72 percent of the blacks born in 1967 spent at least a year on welfare before their 18th birthday. The figure for whites was 25 percent.
"When three-quarters of your children are on welfare, do you have any idea what that means?" he said. "It's almost a complete collapse."
He added: "When you're on welfare, you're a pauper. Your whole life is broken up. You're dealing with brain-dead, artery-clogged bureaucracies that hate you."
 
Effects are Widespread
 No one suffers more for the decline of the inner city than the people who live there, but the rest of society pays a price as well, in ways both obvious and subtle. Among the tasks facing modern urban parents is explaining to innocent young minds why so many men and women sleep in American streets.
Moreover, urban disintegration brings economic consequences for all: in laborers removed from the work force and the government costs of prisons and programs.
Beyond economics, the poverty and disorder of the inner cities lacerate a larger civic fabric, driving people from shared institutions like subways, buses, parks, schools and even cities themselves. For example, in 1960, families within New York City had 93 percent of the median income of families in the suburbs. But according to the Census Bureau, by the mid-1980s, that figure had fallen to 55 percent, a trend that could also be seen in city after city.
The increasing concentration of urban poverty undermines faith in Government as the instrument of the popular will, producing an epic tale of governmental breakdown told in terms of crowded clinics, failing foster care, ineffective law enforcement and burdened or neglected social services.
Perhaps most damaging of all is the effect that urban poverty has on race relations. It is like a poison in the national ground water that is producing a thousand deformed fruits, from race-based campaigns for public office to taxicabs that do not stop for black men at night.
White politicians like David Duke, the Louisiana State Representative and former Ku Klux Klan leader, seize on the inner city to conduct entire campaigns denouncing welfare and street crime. Black newspapers look at the same neighborhoods and ask whether whites are plotting to kill them. Last year, when the Black Entertainment Network inaugurated a public affairs program on cable television, producers said they built their first show around a topic on black viewers' minds. They titled it: "Black Genocide: Myth or Reality?"
In The Times's poll, 52 percent of blacks said it was harder today than 10 years ago for a black person to get out of poverty by starting poor and working hard, and 40 percent said it was easier. Among whites, only 29 percent thought that a black person would have a harder time now than 10 years ago and 57 percent thought it was easier.
"The nation pays a huge price for the existence of the underclass," said Nicholas Lemann, author of "The Promised Land," a book on black ghettos to be published by Alfred A. Knopf in March. "It makes the whole atmosphere of the country more sour."
 
The Policy Failures
Promises Yield Limited Results
 How did America get this way?
Discussion of future offensives against urban poverty inevitably turn to the lessons of efforts past.
In effect, the deepening of poverty has defied the promises of two Presidents. The most famous was Lyndon B. Johnson's 1964 announcement of a war on poverty, which Ronald Reagan answered with a frequent quip: "poverty won." Mr. Reagan made his own antipoverty promise when he promoted his economic policies by saying that "a rising tide lifts all boats" -- and saw the inner cities continue to sink.
But the fault was shared among ideologies, said Theda Skocpol, a Harvard University sociologist who is writing a history of American social policy. "Neither liberals nor conservatives, as they battled from the 60's to the 80's, adequately conceptualized the problems of the ghetto poor," she said.
Some experts argue that past policies accomplished more than current discussions typically acknowledge, and offer a base of encouragement.
"If Johnson had said, 'We're going to cut poverty in half within 10 years,' then he would have been wildly successful," said Sheldon Danziger, a professor of public policy at the University of Michigan. Noting that the percentage of Americans below the poverty line dropped from 22.2 percent in 1960 to a low of 11.1 percent in 1973, he added, "But he overstated it; he said we're going to eliminate it."
The poverty rate then rose to its recent high, 15.2 percent, in 1983 and has been slowly declining since, to 12.8 percent in 1989, the latest year for which figures are available. The Government's poverty line arises from a crude measure established in the 1960's that simply multiplies a family's minimum food budget by three, adjusting it for inflation each year.
Social spending in the past 25 years has gone disproportionately to programs for the elderly, most prominently Social Security and Medicare.
In 1990, for instance, the Government spent $353 billion on Medicare and Social Security, but only $100 billion on things like food stamps, school lunches, tax credits, Medicaid and welfare that help the non-elderly poor.
For the elderly, the spending has made a difference. The poverty rate for the elderly dropped from 35.2 percent in 1959 to 11.4 percent by 1989. As it fell, it crossed the poverty rate for children, which has risen from 15.1 percent in 1970 to 19.6 percent in 1989.
"The war we did fight, we won," said Senator Moynihan, "and the war that wasn't won, we didn't fight."
Professor Christopher Jencks, a sociologist at Northwestern University, carries the observation further. Not only does most social spending go to the elderly, he said, but most of the remainder goes to programs like food stamps or Medicaid that aim only to smooth poverty's rough edges, rather than to programs like job training that aim to end it.
But many conservatives argue that billions have been spent on inner-city problems, with results that have been limited at best.
Where liberals and conservatives increasingly agree is that earlier antipoverty efforts failed to envision the complex problems of behavior and motivation. "They both assumed the poor were straining on the leash, striving to get ahead," said Lawrence Mead, a political scientist at New York University.
Eleanor Holmes Norton, just elected to represent the District of Columbia in Congress, noted, "These are the discouraged poor who have sometimes lost the incentive to rise out of poverty in traditional ways, and therefore sometimes take ways that are most available -- the drug culture, the underground economy."
 
The Political Failures
Lack of Direction And Lack of Will
 The problem is not just one of policy but also one of politics. A minority of members of Congress come from districts directly affected by urban disintegration. The poor have few PAC's.
And sweeping initiatives like Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal and Johnson's Great Society are the exception in American life. "We always have an incremental, do-some-of-this, some-of-that approach," said Richard P. Nathan, a domestic policy expert at the State University of New York in Albany.
Moreover, the public image of the disadvantaged has changed in ways that cost much American sympathy.
The civil rights movement had provided a barrage of sympathetic images: young men in ties sitting at segregated lunch counters, children willing to face fire hoses. But in the decades that followed, argues Douglas Besharov of the American Enterprise Institute, the dominant image of America's social problems turned more toward idleness: young men standing around empty oil barrels, welfare mothers whiling away their days in front of televisions.
"I think the public draws a clear line between the deserving poor and the undeserving poor, between adults who work and those who don't," he said.
 
A Delicate Balance
 What many experts think has been missing from the poverty debate for many years is a language that is frank while also being empathetic.
"Liberals have been terrified that if you're saying there's a behavioral problem, you're saying it's the poor's fault and the hell with them," said Mickey Kaus, an editor at The New Republic who is writing a book on poverty. Republicans, he said, "have been unwilling to spend the money."
Would the country know how to spend more antipoverty money, even if it wanted to? The question is complex, and produces qualified answers.
Certainly some antipoverty programs produce consistently good results. And the country spends large sums on many other programs, like fighting drugs or building weapons, whose success is no more guaranteed. Today's urban poverty has indeed proved more vexing than that of the past, yet a wealth of research has produced many proposals that experts say are promising. And despite budget deficits and past disappointments, there is considerable public support for new efforts and confidence that they could succeed.
The Times poll found that twice as many people believed that the nation's fight against urban poverty was limited more by lack of concern than by lack of money, with 42 percent saying lack of concern was the problem and only 21 percent saying lack of money. Thirty-two percent said the country most lacked know-how.
Almost two-thirds of those surveyed said a major Government effort to fight poverty was likely to have some success, with 13 percent saying success was very likely and 51 percent saying it was somewhat likely. Twenty-two percent said success was not too likely and 11 percent said it was not likely at all.
 
The Lessons of History
New Complications To an Old Problem
 Today's alarm over the inner city may be widespread, but it is not without precedent. American history contains many examples of middle class fears about an urban population whose poverty was seen as intractable and whose values and behavior were considered at odds with the norms. Yet the country has repeatedly innovated to accommodate those who seemed destined to be permanent outsiders.
At the turn of the century, for instance, New York City slums were filled with European immigrants whose presence inspired fears. "There were plenty of people at the turn of the century who thought the problem of poor people in urban neighborhoods was intractable," said Roy Rosenzweig, a historian at George Mason University who is completing a history of Central Park.
Mr. Rosenzweig said he sees similarities in attitudes toward the inner city today. "People saw it as a moral failing on the part of the poor," he said. "They drink; they're not responsible; they're morally lax."
Among historians, opinion is divided on whether today's urban problems pose a more daunting challenge than those of the past. Most agree there is less actual physical need: less hunger and malnutrition, more government support in the form of various safety nets, however imperfect.
On the other hand, many argue that today's economy is less accommodating to the unskilled, that the drug economy is more captivating and violent and that today's poor are more physically and culturally isolated from the rest of the city.
In addition, many analysts say the racial composition of today's inner cities is cause for further pessimism. They argue that blacks have traditionally faced fiercer barriers to advancement than other ethnic groups.
"It's helpful to know that in the past we've felt so terribly low about minorities entering cities and being impoverished," said Prof. David Ward, a historian at the University of Wisconsin. "But I think the conditions today are very different. I don't think past comparisons offer much hope."
One person undaunted by the look back is Mr. Perot in Texas. "Would you want the challenge of solving this problem or of getting the United States out of the Depression?" he said. "This is a piece of cake."

HEADLINE: The World;
The Tough New Leaders in Moscow Have Kremlinologists Up and Guessing

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
THE classic Kremlinologist, a veteran practitioner of the trade once noted, divides knowledge about Moscow roughly into two categories: secrets and mysteries.
For a few golden years, perhaps it was not so, or at least it didn't seem that way. Glasnost lifted the shrouds of secrecy a notch and real information flowed forth. Mikhail S. Gorbachev's closest advisers actually dipped into the cocktail circuit, politics could be discussed in the streets, the United States ambassador actually paid a courtesy call on the director of the K.G.B. 
 But the sharp turn to an older, chillier agenda that the last three months have seen has restored much of the mystery and secrecy, prompting old Kremlinologists to blow the dust off their binoculars and once again to pore over the tidbits floating down from the Kremlin ramparts.
That the direction has changed is obvious. In recent days alone, the Government has followed the bloody crackdown in the Baltic republics with the chilling announcement that armed soldiers will patrol the streets with the police and with a decree authorizing the K.G.B. to search any business, ostensibly to uncover economic crimes that deprive the citizenry of goods.
Even before that, Eduard A. Shevardnadze's dramatic warning that a dictatorship is coming, the shelving of the "500-day plan" of radical economic reform, the tough speeches by the K.G.B. and defense chiefs, the departure of virtually all the old advisers -- these and many other developments over the past four months seemed to plot an inexorable shift toward a tough and often crude reimposition of central authority.
The change, however, poses some intriguing questions: Did Mr. Gorbachev personally decide to change course, acting out of determination to maintain the unity of the Soviet state, or was he coerced by the military, the K.G.B. and the Communist Party? Who then is really in charge, Mr. Gorbachev, or the rough chiefs of the military, the K.G.B., the police and the Communist Party?
There is ample evidence for both versions. If it was the former, it can be argued that the lovable "Gorby" of Western magazine covers was really a Western concoction born of a keen desire to believe; that the real Mikhail Sergeyevich is pragmatic, intelligent, urbane and politically brilliant -- but still a Soviet Communist, for whom the basic principles, including the integrity of the Soviet Union and state control, are sacred.
Under this scenario, Mr. Gorbachev returned from summer vacation and sometime in September concluded that the "500-day" plan was untenable until order was restored to the streets and to the country, and until the renegade republics quit trying to break up the union. So he turned loose the traditional forces of security.
Alternatively, it may have been the security forces who came to Mr. Gorbachev and said, in effect, either let us restore order or be gone. A mysterious movement of troops around Moscow in September might have been a warning to the President.
In any case the rollback quickly gathered speed. Arms-control negotiations slowed. Defense Minister Dmitri T. Yazov and the K.G.B. chief, Vladimir A. Kryuchkov, issued tough public statements. A new breed of people began filling key offices: Gennadi I. Yanayev, a colorless party functionary, became vice president; Boris K. Pugo, hard-line party chief in Latvia, became Minister of the Interior; Valentin S. Pavlov, an economic apparatchik, became prime minister. With the crackdown in Latvia, the state television moved distinctly backward to the Kremlin.
At the same time, Mr. Gorbachev's liberal guard began to abandon him. The most dramatic exodus, of course, was Mr. Shevardnadze, who left Dec. 20 warning that a dictatorship was coming.
One intriguing side question now is whether the order to put armed soldiers in the streets, announced last Friday but dated Dec. 29, may not have been the last straw for Mr. Shevardnadze, who surely knew about the order before he resigned.
The brain trust of perestroika -- Aleksandr N. Yakovlev, Stanislav S. Shatalin, Nikolai Y. Petrakov, Vadim V. Bakatin -- all walked off. About the only liberal left is Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, Mr. Gorbachev's new Foreign Minister.
Who then runs the country? "In principle," as Russians say when the obvious answer is not the whole story, it is Mr. Gorbachev, who has assumed huge powers as President. In principle, he can rule by ukaz -- by decree -- much as the czars used to. Also in principle, the Supreme Soviet, or parliament, can veto his decisions.
In fact, nobody really knows how decisions are being made now in the Kremlin or who is really calling the shots, just as nobody knows who really ordered the troops to move in Lithuania or in Latvia.
Mr. Gorbachev denied he knew anything about it in advance, but he made no effort to chastise the troops or to denounce the shadowy and blatantly illegal "Committees of National Salvation" that purportedly called for help.
That sort of mystery is perfect grist for the de-mothballed Kremlinologists. The crackdown in the Baltics, they would argue, did not have Mr. Gorbachev's stamp to it -- the phony pretexts, the hasty appeals from the anonymous committees, the brazen challenge to public opinion abroad -- all these were far too crude for a man who has demonstrated considerable political finesse.
Does that mean then that Mr. Gorbachev, by choice or coercion, agreed to give the security chiefs a free hand, and that these crude apparatchiks reverted to form, reviving the brutally simple methods used to subjugate Eastern Europe and the Baltics after World War II?
Or is Mr. Gorbachev deliberately trying to look crude to drive home his warning?
Such questions could become increasingly critical as the new line takes shape. So far, Mr. Gorbachev and his tough new advisers seem in agreement at least on their readiness to use force to prevent the breakup of the Soviet Union and to restore order.
What is still unclear is how many of the achievements of the years of glasnost the new team is prepared to keep. Mr. Gorbachev insisted in a statement that he personally read to the foreign press last week -- questions were not allowed -- that his basic goals remain unchanged.
But the men around him are not known for their infatuation with free markets or free speech, and neither the military crackdown nor the forceful currency reform, with its open hostility to anyone who has amassed capital, were likely to encourage entrepreneurs at home or abroad.
Perhaps Mr. Gorbachev wants to believe that once stability is restored he can resume the road to perestroika. But having tied himself to the old institutions, would he be able to break free once again? For the answers, unleash the Kremlinologists.
