SECTION: Section 4; Page 2; Column 3; Week In Review Desk

LENGTH: 964 words

HEADLINE: The World;
For Some, a U.S. Victory Would Be the Third World's Loss

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

DATELINE: NEW DELHI

 BODY:
IF the war against Saddam Hussein has closed a gap between East and West, it has opened a chasm between North and South -- the developed nations and the third world.
On this side of the international poverty line, there is not much rejoicing that an American-led war machine is hammering a tyrannical aggressor. There is, instead, apprehension that an unambiguous victory for the United States would usher in an age of unbridled American power in which Washington would enforce its economic and strategic policies worldwide. 
 A generation raised on 35 years of rhetoric from a nonaligned movement that more often than not hewed to Moscow's cold war interpretation of international affairs finds it hard to shake the instinctive fear of "American imperialism." There is a widespread though vaguely defined assumption that from now on the rich will call the shots and the poor can only get poorer.
"We are very uncomfortable with the thought of a Pax Americana," a scholar in the Indian city of Hyderabad said last week. He admitted that he had no logical explanation for this, only the sense that the least developed nations would probably be exploited or overlooked in a "unipolar world," a phrase that is heard everywhere here.
Feeling abandoned, third-world Communists are criticizing Moscow for siding with the United States in the Persian Gulf. There is also widespread frustration that no nation or group of nations among the remnants of the nonaligned movement has been able to forge a countervailing consensus on the use of force. Ad hoc efforts at peace plans, too vague and too late, are merely brushed aside at the United Nations, even now that India, a leader of the nonaligned, holds a Security Council seat. Also going unheard are other Asian voices asking why Americans fight for the rights of Kuwaitis but reject calls for self determination in Tibet or Kashmir.
Many South Asians are already suffering from higher energy prices and lost jobs because of the war. They are threatened with environmental devastation if Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil wells, not far away on the prevailing winds, continue to burn or if crude oil, already being dumped into the gulf, drifts to their shores, further fouling an environment that cannot now support its populations. And they blame the Americans, not the Iraqis, for economic dislocation.
Officials here say that Washington has failed to make the point to the third world that the defeat of Iraq would in fact lead to falling oil prices. Preoccupied with the war, a NATO diplomat said, the United States has apparently not had time for public relations south and east of Suez.
"Among the alienated masses, the whole argument about this war has turned on the poor versus the rich," an Asian ambassador said. "Saddam Hussein is supported by and large by the poor people, and the intellectuals who thrived on a nonalignment that was in reality guided by the Soviet Union. Kuwait is the rich neighbor, supported by rich friends."
 
How to Respond?
 "To many people now, Saddam is a courageous man standing up to the wrath of 28 nations," said Cho Ramaswami, editor of the political magazine Thuglak in Madras. But he added that he believed there was a sharp difference of opinion in India on the issue of how to respond to the gulf war.
Some of this may be regional. Myron Weiner, a political scientist from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a writer on India who has been traveling in the southern part of the country, found more grassroots support for the resistance to Mr. Hussein than is evident in the north. Many southerners, better educated than northerners, were employed in Kuwait in professional jobs.
Moreover, in the richer nations of Southeast Asia, there is less spontaneous, emotional support for Iraq, according to Hadi Soesastro, a political economist who is executive director of the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Jakarta. In both Indonesia and Malaysia, countries with Muslim majorities, he said there is general backing for the United Nations resolutions that set the stage for attacks on Iraq -- although there are also demonstrations backing Mr. Hussein.
 
The Price of Oil Prices
 Mr. Soesastro, an energy analyst, said that Indonesia believed oil prices would fall with an American victory in the gulf -- not a positive factor in a country heavily dependent on income from petroleum. But he said the country was prepared to cope with this, and that the prospect of Iraqi-supported higher prices was not a reason to support Baghdad. This measured view is not often articulated among South Asian intellectuals.
Perhaps most astonishing to American audiences operating on the assumption that Iraq is the transgressor in the gulf would be the growing public opinion in India and Pakistan that morality and principle are not on Washington's side.
"Morally, the war waged against Iraq and its people is impossible to defend," wrote N. Ram, a leading Indian investigative journalist who is associate editor of The Hindu newspaper and editor of Frontline, a news magazine. Arguing that sanctions were beginning to bite, and that the United States ignored this and moved to an assault out of all proportion to the problem it faced, Mr. Ram wrote in The Hindu that President Bush had exceeded the definitions of a "just war."
"It should not be difficult to see how this principle stands in relation to the war that Mr. Bush has unleashed in order to punish Mr. Saddam Hussein's aggression and defiance," he said. "Nasty rounds of surprises and enormous suffering and cruelty seem guaranteed."
He added: "The idea of a just war against Iraq on Kuwait is a fraudulent construct which will not stand any serious political or moral scrutiny."

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Between War And Slump, A Little Room For Congress

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN years past, Presidential State of the Union Messages often laid out legislative agendas as Congress convened. Nobody is sure whether that will happen when President Bush gives his speech to Congress and a national television audience on Tuesday. For, even without the war in the Persian Gulf and the Soviet troubles in the Baltics, two likely topics, Mr. Bush has shown little inclination to develop a substantial domestic program.
In fact, the television audience might hear more about domestic legislation in the brief response from the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, than it hears from the President. 
 Of course, the war will concern Congress directly. A supplemental appropriation bill to pay for it might be the main occasion for Congress to look at the conduct of the conflict and for arguments about how much help other countries are providing.
In the end, voting the money will be relatively easy. But the issue of how to pay for it, through taxes, borrowing or stringency elsewhere, will be harder. The recession could be made worse by higher taxes, and paying for the war by borrowing would deepen the deficit, making it especially hard to launch any major initiatives in areas where Democrats crave action, like health care.
But Congressional leaders hope for more to do than pay bills and cheer for the war. "I hope and expect that it will not divert us from other serious national problems," Mr. Mitchell, a Democrat, said last week. "If we're going to be strong, these challenges are just as important as the challenges we face in the Middle East," said Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, the Democratic chairman of the Education and Labor Committee. "There's a real concern that we're just standing around and not doing anything to get us out of the recession," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri, the House majority leader.
But the war is an immense distraction. Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the House Republican minority leader, is anxious to renew efforts to pass campaign finance reform, a bill that requires early action if a House-Senate conference is to have any hope of reconciling different approaches in time to affect the 1992 elections.
Both houses are likely to pass bills similar to those they voted last year. The Senate sought to bar contributions by political action committees, while the House only tried to limit them, and in general the House bill was not as stringent as the Senate's. In both chambers, the burden of fund raising and the insistence of editorial complaints are spurs to action. But, Mr. Michel said, "It's hard to get anyone to focus, with this doggone war."
The distraction is general. "We're sort of on automatic pilot, beginning necessary hearings," said Senator Wyche Fowler, an assistant Democratic whip. "I don't think you'll see anything of any moment until the war is over." If the country isn't paying attention and pressing for action on Capitol Hill, he said, then lawmakers are less likely to cast tough votes.
There are a few familiar, off-the-rack items that may see action sooner than that. The family leave bill, which would require employers to provide unpaid leaves of absence for employees to provide for births and illnesses, is likely to get out of Mr. Kennedy's committee quickly and then win passage in the House, too, before another Presidential veto and a new attempt to override.
That isn't the only important bill that doesn't need to be made to measure. Just about every argument has been made on either side of the civil rights bill that Mr. Bush vetoed last year. The legislation was intended to reverse Supreme Court decisions making it harder for minority members and women to prove job discrimination. One last effort might be made to find common ground with the White House before that one goes forward again.
 
Education and Handguns
 In the Senate, Mr. Kennedy might push ahead with a bill designed to formalize education goals set by the nation's governors and to establish an independent authority to measure success in meeting them. In the House the Brady bill, a measure that would require a one-week waiting period before handgun purchases, is likely to come to the floor before Easter. It's not clear whether the votes are there to pass it; nor is it clear what the Senate would do if the House acts.
Then there are a range of important measures that will take time and whose eventual shape will be affected by the cost of the war and the depth of the recession.
The reauthorization of highway, bridge and mass transit programs is one major task, and money is a big issue. Even if there had been no distraction from a war in the gulf, it could easily take two years to renew the 1986 Higher Education Act, as Democrats seek to provide more help for middle-class students.
With these bills, as with legislation to restore the health of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation in an era of shaky banks, Bush Administration views will affect but not control the eventual laws, and those recommendations are not yet in.
Clean water, garbage and pesticide legislation constitute an environmental agenda. But they could all be delayed because some of the same Congressional committees deal with energy, and the Middle East troubles are a reminder of the need to be more self-sufficient, whether through conservation or by drilling in places like the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.
It is clear that there is concern about the recession, but just what measures, if any, are likely to emerge is anything but clear. Mr. Kennedy talked about lowering payroll taxes and bolstering unemployment compensation. The longer the downturn lasts, the more likely it is that Congress will act.
And there is one other priority area, legislation to help troops and veterans. Last week, with no dissenting votes in either chamber, Congress passed bills easing the income tax burden for Persian Gulf troops and providing a cost-of-living allowance on veterans' pensions.
But the war might, in the long run, have more effect on the Congressional agenda than serving as a distraction and a check on spending.
David Obey, a veteran liberal Democrat from Wisconsin, said that the short-run impact, while troops are dying in the gulf, would be that "it's going to be excruciatingly difficult to make people aware of the pain other people are suffering in the economy."
But later, he said hopefully, the sacrifices of the war might make it easier to muster support for domestic measures, as people ask, in Mr. Obey's words, "Is government willing to do for Americans what it did for Kuwaitis?"
Representative Newt Gingrich, the House Republican whip, offered an even more intriguing postwar legislative theory. Noting that Mr. Bush's approval ratings in polls already match Franklin D. Roosevelt's after Pearl Harbor, he predicted that if the war went well, the President would come out of it with "dramatically more authority than any President since Eisenhower."
That authority would not last forever, he said, but Mr. Bush would have three or four months at least to push for a conservative domestic agenda and to achieve much of it. To skeptical conservatives at a luncheon on Friday, the optimistic Georgian said he was sure that was where Mr. Bush's heart was, and he invited them to watch carefully.

HEADLINE: The World;
Japan Counts the Costs Of Gulf Action -- or Inaction

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
AS surely as it is for the United States, Japan's response to the gulf war is seen increasingly as a defining moment for Tokyo in the post-cold-war world order. That response so far has been marked by anguished debates about what Japan's role should be, with its actions until now limited to some financial aid and the promise of more. But perhaps the most striking aspect of Japan's behavior is the growing perception that the Japanese see little at stake for themselves in the war's outcome, despite their dependence on Middle East oil.
On the surface, as usual, the arguments in Japan revolve around the constraints arising from Tokyo's postwar pacifist tradition and its constitutional renunciation of the use of force. Constantly fearful of generating hostility among its Asian neighbors, Japan clings more tightly than ever to these pillars of its identity in a post-cold-war environment. 
 But at the same time, a much deeper struggle over the war is under way. It is one in which Japan is trying to balance public anxiety over involvement against the widespread fear of angering its longtime patron, the United States.
To be sure, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu has repeatedly denounced Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, and there is some discussion here of the rightness or wrongness of fighting aggression. But many more Japanese are behaving according to the dictates of an old folk phrase that has gained currency as a description of this war, "taigan no kaji" -- fire on the other side of the river. And resentment that Japan is being drawn in is starting to show.
Last week, Mr. Kaifu announced his intention to add $9 billion to the $4 billion package of economic and quasi-military aid appropriated so far. The United States welcomed the pledge, but there were concerns. Legislative approval is not a sure thing. And less than half the funds set aside so far have been disbursed, partly because of strings attached by Tokyo. None of the aid is supposed to be used for anything related to combat, for instance. The United States is appealing to Tokyo to lift the restrictions -- so far to no avail.
Lately, internal critics of Japanese slowness of action have become harsh in their judgments. "If I were an American, I would see Japan as not reliable as a friend," said Masashi Nishihara, professor of international relations at the National Defense Academy. "When I saw the faces of the P.O.W.'s on television, I thought, 'My God, the Americans must be thinking very critically of the Japanese writing their checks and not suffering along with them.' "
The proponents of a Japanese role argue not so much that the cause is just, but that Tokyo must do something to avoid criticism. Typical was the blunt warning of Michio Watanabe, a leader of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, that Japan risked becoming an international "orphan" before world opinion if it ignored appeals for help. "The Japanese people don't want to shed their own blood or sweat themselves," he said. " 'Let's have the foreigners do it' -- that's what they think."
In addition, there appears to be rising public opposition, particularly from business and consumer groups, to Mr. Kaifu's plans to raise the cash by issuing a bond and repaying it with a new tax, perhaps on energy.
 
Roadblocks for Aid
 Despite repeated American requests for a direct role in the gulf, Tokyo has shied away. Mr. Kaifu's initial proposal to send 1,000 military men in noncombat roles was killed last year by a public outcry. Last week, he ordered "preparations" for military planes to airlift refugees from the war zone, but some officials doubted the initiative would get anywhere. Many in the Government are afraid that if it did, opposition parties whose votes are needed in Parliament would withdraw their support of the money package. Others fear that Japanese businessmen and diplomats abroad would be subjected to terrorism.
As Japan has temporized, it has become increasingly clear that it has developed a policy that actually serves its sense of self-interest. This, in turn, has dismayed many experts, including the United States Ambassador, Michael Armacost, who reminded Japan recently that "impressions forged in a major international crisis like this one do tend to have a durable lasting effect."
Before war erupted, for instance, Japanese officials said the one thing they wanted to avoid was the impression that Japan was capable of acting only under United States pressure -- an impression current last fall. Then the war broke out, and Japan became paralyzed over what to do. It sent Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto to ask the United States what it wanted, and only then did Japan come up with a sum of aid to supply. No matter how hard they try, the Japanese seem to end up looking as if they are acting in response to pressure.
The idea that Japanese do not see that they have much at stake in the gulf, other than preserving ties with the United States, might seem to contradict the fact that Japan, more than any other country, depends on Middle East oil -- in fact, for 70 percent of its supplies. But since the Iraqi invasion last August, Japanese have been hearing cautious but bullish reports from their economic mandarins about the prospects for weathering the storm. And in recent decades, Japan has gained quite a lot of experience dealing with Middle East countries -- not through its political and diplomatic establishment, but through its trading companies and other business arms of Japan Inc. No one has come out and said it bluntly, but businessmen privately express the view that it makes little difference which sheiks or dictators own the oil fields; they all have to sell their oil somewhere.
Even Japanese diplomats complain that there is no historical tradition of Japan standing up for a set of values, so it is not surprising that the blitzkrieg in Kuwait did not move people here. In any case, there is also a feeling that Washington has met the problem with too much force.
There are those in Japan who see the entire paralysis as a function of the current weakness of Prime Minister Kaifu, a politician without a power base of his own who is beholden to a handful of power brokers jockeying among themselves. But this too assumes that inside the bloated and inactive Japanese system is a lithe and aggressive foreign policy that is somehow struggling to get out. Perhaps it is time, then, to see that Japan's aloofness toward the gulf is in fact the policy most people want.

HEADLINE: The Region;
The Next Battle in Yonkers Will Be Over Power

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON

 BODY:
EARLIER this month, in a windowless 35th-floor office of the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development in Manhattan's Federal Plaza, signatures were affixed to a document that was the product of five years of civic and political strife and an estimated $12 million in lawyers' fees.
The document was a contract between the Yonkers Municipal Housing Authority and DeLuxe Homes Inc. for the court-ordered construction of 142 units of low-income housing on five sites in the city's mostly white neighborhoods, remedies for what a Federal judge decided in 1985 were 40 years of segregated housing of blacks. 
 To those in Yonkers who had urged the city to comply with the housing order so they could get on with long-delayed development, the contract represented a major advance. To those who have been fighting the subsidized housing as a potential threat to community standards and real estate values, the contract was just another setback.
Either way, the signing ushered in what could be a portentous year for this hilly suburban city, New York's fourth largest. The modular homes, the first of 1,000 subsidized units planned under the court order, might be completed by Election Day, when voters will select their first strong mayor under a change in government structure.
The two events are related because the most prominent of a half dozen potential candidates for the newly strengthened post of mayor is the incumbent, Henry J. Spallone, who has been the most outspoken opponent of the housing order. Mr. Spallone's fierce resistance to the integrated housing plan helped catapult him from the City Council to the mayor's office in 1989.
That same election saw Yonkers voters approve a referendum discarding the council-manager form of government that has been in use here since the 1930's in favor of a system that will give the new chief executive the power to make high-level appointments, draw up budgets and veto City Council actions. The position of city manager will be abolished, thus ending the Council's influence on that executive's policies and actions. Currently, the Council appoints the manager, and in the case of Yonkers that has been done frequently. The city of 188,000 has had 11 managers in the last 20 years, which averages out to a tenure of 20 months, compared with the national average of nearly six years. Under the new plan, the mayor will serve for four years instead of two.
A City Council president, elected citywide, will assume the mayor's present role, presiding over the Council, which will still have six other members elected from districts. Council approval will still be required for the budget and top-level appointments, although the new Mayor will have veto power.
 But who will be wielding this power? Some, even among Republicans, hope it will not be Mr. Spallone.
The Mayor speaks of Yonkers in rosy terms, describing a $9 million surplus from the 1989-1990 fiscal year that brings the accumulated surplus since 1985 to $64 million. But Yonkers's fiscal experts say any surplus is illusory. All but $700,000 of the $64 million, they say, is earmarked in the four-year plan required by an Emergency Financial Control Board, which was imposed by the state when Yonkers faced default.
Mr. Spallone, a former New York City policeman, talks about about Yonkers as a potential center of global trade "with a market of 35 million people," phrases civic leaders recall from his 1989 election campaign. The City Manager, Neil J. DeLuca, has described Mr. Spallone as an "utter fool" who has "no idea what's going on."
The Mayor, in the meantime, has vowed to continue fighting the housing plan. "We will take them to court on every issue," he said last week. "Every violation of any city regulation will be challenged. I don't think it will be built." He has denounced the judge, Leonard B. Sand, for "social engineering."
"It just hasn't sunk in," said John R. Zakian, executive director of the Yonkers Industrial Development Agency, "that the housing will be built." The plan ordered by Judge Sand, which has been challenged all the way to the Supreme Court and was endorsed by the city under threat of contempt, includes 200 units of low-income housing on seven sites and designed as town houses to blend into middle-class neighborhoods in East and North Yonkers. H.U.D. will pay for the units, which will be on city land.
Another 800 units of affordable housing are to be built by private contractors who would be granted incentives to include the apartments in market-rate developments totaling 4,000 units. So far, no one has come forward.
"Housing has overshadowed everything in this city," Mr. Zakian said. "If we didn't have the housing issue, the magnitude of changes we can expect in city government, a possible turning point for this city, would be more on people's minds."
Mr. Zakian, among others, says he believes that Mr. Spallone's re-election is far from certain. At its winter meeting two weeks ago, the executive committee of the city's Republican Party withheld its endorsement, which is highly unusual in the case of an incumbent who has declared his interest in running again. The next meeting isn't until April.
Other possible Republican candidates include Peter V. Chema, the majority leader of the City Council, and Angelo R. Martinelli, a former Mayor who is now a publisher.
Democrats being mentioned as possible candidates include James Mannion, a restaurateur who appears to have the endorsement of the city's Democratic leader, Ralph Arred, State Assemblyman Terence M. Zaleski and former Mayor Nicholas C. Wasicsko, who supported compliance with Judge Sand's order and lost the election to Mr. Spallone.
"The preoccupation with the housing issue has been terribly harmful to the city," said Mr. Wasicsko, who was instrumental in forming the commission that recommended the change to a strong mayor. "We missed the economic boom of the 1980's, and now with the economy contracting our failure to expand will be more acutely felt."

HEADLINE: Soviet Doubts Before Talks

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 26

 BODY:
Before leaving for Washington today, Foreign Minister Bessmertnykh underlined the Kremlin's displeasure with the United States Congress for linking American economic aid with the harsh new military drive against the Baltic republics' attempt to regain independence.
"I hope I will be able to clarify what's going on there," he declared, stressing that "it would be extremely dangerous" if the improved Soviet-American relations of recent year were reversed or seriously changed. 
 Senior Bush Administration officials said Friday that the Soviet Foreign Minister would be informed that the meeting between Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev had best be "postponed" indefinitely because of the Soviet crackdown in the Baltics.
 
No Apology on Baltics
 In his departure remarks, Mr. Bessmertnykh offered little to reverse such pessimism in Washington. The burden of his comments was to express greater sympathy for Iraq in the war and to offer no apology for the Gorbachev Government's severe steps in the Baltics, in which 19 civilians have been killed by soldiers in the last two weeks.
Mr. Bessmertnykh, previously the Soviet Ambassador in Washington, left on his initial mission as Foreign Minister with the Bush Administration increasingly concerned that the now rapid reversal of President Gorbachev's democratization promises would next be reflected in Soviet-American relations. These had been buoyed by several years of historic disarmament progress, culminating in the declared end of the cold war.
But today Mr. Bessmertnykh reflected a different tone, saying that "not all is well" in such pending disarmament issues as conventional weapon reductions.
 
A Warning by Shevardnadze
 The world was dramatically alerted to the reactionary changes in Mr. Gorbachev's Kremlin by Mr. Bessmertnykh's predecessor, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, who abruptly resigned as Foreign Minister last month, warning that fresh dictatorship was looming.
Since then, Mr. Gorbachev has issued a series of presidential orders and personnel changes, confirming a rapid shift back toward the Kremlin's traditional hard-line, centralized state methods and away from his own promises of liberalization.
In a matter of days, the Soviet leader has defended troop attacks on Baltic civilians, proposed crimping the press freedoms he pioneered, and, in the name of ferreting out economic crime, authorized broad new police powers for both the K.G.B. and the army.
On the Persian Gulf war, Mr. Bessmertnykh said that while the Kremlin still abided by the United Nations' resolution approving the military action against Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, it now saw a need to "see to it that actions in the area do not exceed limits" on the United Nations mandate.
"There are apprehensions that we are entering the second serious phase of the conflict, when, in addition to the task to liberate Kuwait envisioned in Security Council resolutions, there is a growing threat that Iraq is subject to very grave damages, there is a growing danger for the country's civilian population," he declared. "Naturally, this is a cause for our concern."
 
'Wrong Interpretaion'
 The Foreign Minister said he would work to dispel the Americans' "wrong interpretation" and "emotional perception" of what has been occurring in his country.
"I have to admit that difficulties have emerged at present, especially in the U.S. Congress, which tries to link this sphere to events in the Baltics," he told reporters.
Both the Senate and the House have approved nonbinding resolutions calling on Mr. Gorbachev to halt his use of force in the Baltics and urging President Bush to freeze or review a range of economic help planned on the basis of previous summit meetings.
"The linkage on the Congress's part is a fact," Mr. Bessmertnykh conceded. "I want to find out what the Administration, the President and the Secretary of State think on the issue."

HEADLINE: Lithuania's President a Genuine Democrat

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Over the last few days, we have observed a rapid fallback of the Soviet authorities to the rhetoric of the cold war period. The representation of events in Lithuania and of its President, Vytautas Landsbergis, is a perfect example of this. 
 After the invasion of tanks in Vilnius, the Soviet sources, controlled by the Kremlin, put to work the old propaganda machine, portraying President Landsbergis as a "fascist," an "extreme nationalist" and an "imperialists' accomplice," who is trying to bring back the "bourgeois dictatorship." They did not bother to support these accusations with facts or evidence. Who, indeed, are these imperialists? Could it be the Americans or the Germans who rushed to provide economic help to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's (and not Mr. Landsbergis's) Government?
I know my friend and colleague Vytautas Landsbergis very well. Over more than 20 years, I have maintained professional and personal relationships with him. This intelligent, calm man with a businesslike approach and a great sense of humor is one of the most extraordinary and intellectual people I know. A musicologist and an art critic, a pianist and a music professor, he personifies the cream of the crop of the rich and diverse Lithuanian culture.
Vytautas Landsbergis comes from a remarkable family of intellectuals. His father is a well-known architect, and his grandfather's writings are recognized as classics of Lithuanian literature. His wife and daughter are also musicians, and his son's goal is to become a film maker.
There is nothing more absurd and vile than calling Mr. Landsbergis a fascist. As a Jew who lived in Moscow, I had many friendly talks with him about the ethnic and political problems in relations among Lithuanians, Russians and Jews both past and present. He is a genuine democrat in his convictions and his actions.
Recently President Gorbachev spoke disdainfully of "musicians who govern Lithuania." Yes, indeed, President Landsbergis is a musician. And President Lech Walesa of Poland is an electrician, and President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia is a playwright. And it is not they who send tanks to suppress people fighting for their freedom.
 
FELIX ROZINER
West Newton, Mass., Jan. 17, 1991
 
The writer is a Russian Research Center fellow, Harvard University.

HEADLINE: Technology;
In Search of Short-Order Chips

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

DATELINE: STANFORD, Calif.

 BODY:
Amateur photographers once sent their film for developing to huge plants that took days or weeks to return the finished photos. Then film processing machines were built that were small and inexpensive enough to be used by small shops that could deliver the film in an hour.
"It has revolutionized photography," said Krishna C. Saraswat, a professor of electrical engineering at Stanford University's Center for Integrated Systems. 
 Professor Saraswat and a growing number of other experts believe the semiconductor industry is sorely in need of a similar revolution to help it compete internationally.
The cost of building a computer-chip fabrication plant, a "fab" in industry lingo, is rising to the point that many companies cannot afford them. A large advanced fab now goes for about $300 million, and in a few years is expected to approach $1 billion. The high costs are very troubling to American semiconductor companies, which lack the resources of their larger Japanese competitors. Most small American companies now contract out manufacturing because they can't afford to build their own fabs.
The mega-fabs are generally used for only high-volume chips like dynamic random access memories. But high costs also makes it difficult to produce small volumes of specialized chips, just as it is uneconomical for a Boeing 747 to make short trips.
Professor Saraswat's group at Stanford, then, is helping Texas Instruments to design small, inexpensive micro-fabs that could indeed do for semiconductor manufacturing what the one-hour photo shop did for photography. The micro-fab is just one of several ideas that are being tried to help take the semiconductor industry off what is otherwise bound to be an economically suicidal course.
Capital costs are rising because chips are getting more complex. To get more transistors on a fingernail-sized piece of silicon, the circuit elements must be made smaller, to the point where circuits are only one-hundredth the width of a human hair. Making such small circuits requires extremely sophisticated equipment.
Moreover, as circuit elements become smaller, the requirements for keeping the factory clean become more stringent and more expensive. An invisible speck of dust falling on a chip has the same effect as a boulder falling on a road. Semiconductors are made in "clean rooms," in which the air is extensively filtered and workers are covered from head to toe in "bunny suits" to keep dust from their clothes or flakes of their skin from ruining the chips.
One seemingly simple cost-cutting idea is to clean only the air right around the silicon wafer rather than the entire roomful of air. "We're spending millions and millions of dollars cleaning up the room," said Paul Castrucci, a consultant in Boston and the former chief operating officer of Sematech, a consortium of computer chip producers. "It's completely asinine."
Asyst Technologies, a company in Milpitas, Calif., makes equipment to create a micro-environment around the silicon wafer. Each piece of chip-making machinery is surrounded by an enclosure in which the air is kept very clean. The silicon wafers are carried from machine to machine in a sealed box called a standard mechanical interface (Smif) pod. The wafers are always either in the pod or in the enclosures around each machine. They never get exposed to the air in the room, so the requirements for cleaning the ambient air are reduced.
While micro-environments can cut the cost of cleaning the air, they do not reduce the biggest element of cost -- the sophisticated machinery needed to make chips.
Texas Instruments, with help from Stanford, aims to tackle that problem. The Air Force and the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency in 1988 awarded T.I. a $113 million contract for the project.
In another three years, the Dallas semiconductor company is expected to have completed a prototype factory able to produce low volumes of chips inexpensively. "It's an affordable chunk that you can put in for going after quick turnaround business," said Pallab Chatterjee, director of the company's semiconductor process and design center.
One way to produce low-cost chips in low volumes is to build small machines that can do more than one step in the manufacturing process, rather than have separate machines for each step. At Stanford, researchers have designed a prototype machine that does some of the common steps, like cleaning the wafer and depositing material on it.
Another approach is to design small modules for performing different steps and to cluster the modules around a central chamber. A robot arm inside would move the wafers between chambers.
While existing semiconductor manufacturing equipment now processes large batches of wafers at a single time, the micro-fab would work on a single wafer at a time. The computerized micro-fab would be capable of switching quickly from one product to another.
The micro-fab industry is already moving toward such clustered systems. Applied Materials, one of the largest producers of semiconductor manufacturing equipment, has since 1987 sold a machine that processes a single wafer at a time with multiple chambers for different processes.
Companies are also trying to arrive at standards to make it easier to hook each other's production modules together. Right now, each company making a piece of equipment must design its own robot for handling wafers and its own system for handling gases. If there were industry-wide standards, the cost of equipment could come down.
If the micro-fabs catch on, companies that make semiconductor manufacturing equipment might be able to make many small modules instead of a few big machines. That could allow them to use cheaper mass production techniques to roll out the fabs instead of building them, essentially, by hand. Now, "the equipment is made like they used to make Ferraris," said G. Dan Hutcheson, president of VLSI Research, a San Jose market research company. "A run of 100 is a big run for the equipment industry."
Still, Mr. Hutcheson is skeptical about micro-fab idea working. "When you try to link everything together and automate it, you make it more complex and usually make it more costly," he said.
But others say, that micro-fabs are the best hope for capital-short American companies. As T. J. Rodgers, president of the Cypress Semiconductor Corporation, a chip maker in San Jose, Calif., put it: "A fab that allows the garage shop to become a viable wafer manufacturer again is a super idea."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 3, 1991, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A caption with the Technology column last Sunday misstated the capacity of an Applied Materials machine. It works on one wafer at a time and can accomplish several -- but not all -- of the steps in the making of computer chips.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
The War's 3d-World Reverberations

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:
What will be the economic and political effect of the gulf war on other countries? Benjamin Weiner, president of Probe International, a political risk-analysis firm in Stamford, Conn., is telling his corporate clients that much of the Middle East and the third world will be affected. The Philippines, Egypt and perhaps even Saudi Arabia may grow unstable as the war continues. Mr. Weiner discussed his views with Joel Kurtzman of the New York Times. 
 Question: What effects will this war have on the countries and economies of the region?
Answer: The third world is going to suffer grievously if this war continues. First, they've suffered from higher oil prices, and if oil prices go up again, they will suffer again.
But they will also suffer because so many of their nationals work in the gulf and have had to leave. In Kuwait, as of Aug. 1, the day before the invasion, there were 3 million foreign workers primarily from the third world. There were 1.6 million Egyptians, 190,000 Indians, 500,000 from the Philippines, 150,000 Sri Lankans and lots and lots of Palestinians. There were also lots of foreign workers in Iraq from these same countries as well as from others, and they had to go as well.
The people who work in the gulf have been extremely important economically to their countries. They sent home their paychecks, which were paid in hard currencies. These payments benefited their home countries as a whole. And by working in the gulf, these people weren't contributing to unemployment at home. Now, with these people unemployed, the money has stopped flowing in and unemployment is growing.
Take Egypt. About 16 percent of its total work force was working in the gulf. Losing that income will give the the Egyptian economy a big jolt. It could even make Egypt unstable. All these people coming home with nothing to do and with no incomes could contribute to instability. The fundamentalists in Egypt could get a boost.
Take the Philippines. The Philippine army is now on alert. There is no martial law, but it could come to that. As soon as their workers left Kuwait and Iraq, they tried to go right back on planes to go to Saudi Arabia. They have nothing to come home to, no incomes and nothing to do.
Q. What impact will this war have on Saudi Arabia?
A. I worry about Saudi Arabia. There are lots of experts who say Saudi Arabia is stable, but I have my doubts. The political and economic structure of Saudi Arabia is based on foreign input -- foreign scientists, foreign engineers, foreign administrators, foreign labor and even foreign soldiers from Pakistan. I don't see the country running well without these people and if war spreads to Saudi Arabia, with ground fighting and frequent bombings, the foreign workers might leave. That can be a real problem for Saudi Arabia.
In addition, you know there is opposition in Saudi Arabia to the United States and its involvement in the gulf. There is a split within the royal family. And all this time during the buildup and war, I have been wondering, where is the Saudi Crown Prince Abdullah? He is the head of the Saudi National Guard and the First Deputy Prime Minister. The National Guard is a tribal organization and more closely aligned with the royal family than the army, which has universal conscription. The Crown Prince has dropped out of sight. He is less amenable to American and Western influence than King Fahd. Is he opposed to American involvement in the Gulf? Was he gotten rid of? What does it mean that he's not around?
Q. What does it mean?
A. I don't know. It could be as simple as some people say -- that he is in Morocco with his mistress. But I am concerned because the country is divided between Westernizers and those who are very conservative, and the royal familiy is split along these lines as well. So it bothers me that the country's No. 2 man is not anywhere around.
Q. How real is Saddam Hussein's threat to attack the interests of America and its allies?
Q. Saddam's attempt to turn this into an Islamic holy war will have no success. First, most Moslems are not Arabs. Malaysian, Indian and Pakistani Muslims are not necessarily going to find solidarity with Iraq. And then among Arabs pan-Arabism just isn't a realistic possibility, let's face it. Twice, Egypt tried to unite with Syria -- unsuccessfully. Then Egypt was an outcast after the Camp David accords. Now Jordan is an outcast member of the Arab family. And among the Arabs, some countries favored Iran and some Iraq during their recent war. There is, of course, always the possibility of Libya or Iraq funding existing groups of terrorists, but we will not see any general uprising of Muslims or of Arabs uniting over this.
Q. Where will the Palestinians and Jordanians come out after the conflict is over?
A. The Palestinians are on the outs right now with the wealthy gulf states for throwing their support to Saddam Hussein. Saudi Arabia and Kuwait contributed large sums of money to the Palestinian cause. But the Palestinians have painted themselves into a corner before and emerged from it. I don't think this will be any different. In time, they will emerge and maybe even get funds once more from Saudi Arabia. The Jordanians are the same. They will emerge from this.
Q. Will the fires Iraq set to some Kuwaiti oil wells do much economic damage?
A. No. This doesn't worry me too much. As long as they haven't destroyed the refineries, damage to the wells is not a problem. Some of the Saudi wells even have cutoffs so that if someone tried to destroy them they could only destroy them so far down the hole. The question is the refineries. These take longer to fix. So far these have not been hurt.
Q. While attention is focused on the gulf, do you expect other areas to heat up?
A. Yes. This will be a time for settling some old scores. We have already been seeing the crackdowns occurring in the Soviet Union as the war escalates in the gulf. The Chinese Government in the north is increasingly eyeing the more reform-oriented south with suspicion. Another old score is along the India-Pakistan border. India fears the Pakistani nuclear bomb program and would love to take out the Pakistani reactor near Islamabad.
And then there is Muammar el-Qaddafi. Why has he been so quiet? He has Chad, Algeria, Niger, Egypt, Tunisia and the Sudan on his borders -- none of which he likes very much.

HEADLINE: Cracking the Whip

BYLINE: By Michael R. Gordon; Michael R. Gordon covers national security issues for The New York Times.

 BODY:
SEVERAL DAYS BEFORE the United States went to war with Iraq, Dick Cheney took a break from the final preparations for battle to discuss the crisis, the Pentagon and his improbable career. Toward the end of the conversation, he was asked about his visits to American troops in the desert.
"It is something that I will live with for a very long time," the Defense Secretary said, referring to his encounters with the soldiers in Saudi Arabia. The comment cracked open a window on the emotions of the man who has guided the largest American military operation since the Vietnam War. 
 And then the window closed. "I think that is all I am going to say on the subject," he said. "It is personal."
The television in his office overlooking the Potomac flickered with the latest reports of the failed meeting that day between Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Iraq's Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz.
There was a long silence. Our hourlong conversation was over.
From the very beginning of the crisis in the Persian Gulf, the 49-year-old former Wyoming Congressman was an Administration emissary to the Arabs and a trusted spokesman, valued for his cool demeanor and measured testimony. He repeatedly reinforced the President's gut instincts for military intervention and helped to translate them into a deployment of 425,000 troops by mid-January.
On Aug. 4, two days after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, the Defense Secretary pushed for use of American troops to protect Saudi Arabia. In October, with Saddam Hussein not budging, Cheney recommended that the President send reinforcements to provide a credible "offensive military option." The aim was to intensify the pressure on Saddam Hussein to withdraw and lay the groundwork to defeat him in battle if he didn't. Cheney later told Congress that only military force, not economic sanctions, could insure that Iraqi troops would leave Kuwait.
The Defense Secretary, who never served in the armed forces, took a more hawkish stand than several of his predecessors and many military officers. Harold Brown, James R. Schlesinger and Caspar W. Weinberger, the hard-line Reaganite, all argued that sanctions be given more time before any military attack began. That was also the public position of Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the American commander in the Persian Gulf.
"I would not go so far as to say Cheney is egging the President on, but he is on the same wavelength," a senior Administration official said in December. "Much of the military seem more reluctant. They are way behind Cheney."
Why is he such a hawk? The answer rests partly with his innate conservatism and partly with his loyalty to George Bush.
If Cheney had doubts about the United States march toward war, he contained them behind his iron reserve. He gave no hint of the worries openly voiced by military experts like Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who favored the sanctions approach and warned before the American strike on Iraq that Washington might be caught in a prolonged, costly and unnecessary war.
On Sunday morning news programs, week after week, Cheney coolly presented the Administration's case. And at press conferences before and during the war, he and Army Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, made a stoic team.
"He is calm inside," Lynne Vincent Cheney, his wife of 26 years and chairwoman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, said of her husband's mood a few days before the United States launched its attack. "He is a man with a deeply held conviction, and he does sleep well. But he is not dispassionate. He never talked much. But he is even quieter now. He is quieter and thinking more."

FIGHTING IN THE Persian Gulf was about the last thing anybody expected when Cheney came to the Defense Department in March 1989. In the months that followed, it looked as if his main challenge would be to scale down and reorganize the post-cold war military in line with new White House policies toward Moscow. Change in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe was overturning decades-old precepts of strategic planning. When Defense Department officials weren't on Capitol Hill, they were worrying about third-world trouble spots like the Philippines and Central America.
The defense of the Arabian oil fields, a priority that had long been second only to the security of Europe, was suffering from benign neglect in light of the cease-fire between Iraq and Iran and a perceived lessening of the Soviet threat to Iran. The Persian Gulf was mentioned only in passing in National Military Strategy, a classified report issued in August 1989 by Adm. William J. Crowe Jr., then Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. The report mentioned protecting the gulf in the same breath as maintaining access to the "critical natural resources of South American and Africa."
Before August, the Defense Secretary's chief accomplishment -- with help from General Powell, his trusted ally -- was a plan for reducing the military by 25 percent. The Defense Secretary has also been credited for his efforts, belated though they were, to shake up the Pentagon's procurement bureaucracy. His cancellation of the Navy's $57 billion A-12 Avenger attack plane this month followed complaints that military contractors misled him about the cost and progress of the project. Nonetheless, his decision stunned the weapons industry, which had grown accustomed to cost overruns and Government bailouts.
One of Cheney's first tests as a crisis manager was the American standoff with Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama. In 1989, he plucked a hard-charging Army general, Maxwell R. Thurman, from the verge of retirement, installing him as the head of the United States Southern Command in place of Gen. Frederick A. Woerner Jr., who opposed American intervention in Panama. More important, Cheney recommended the appointment of General Powell as Chairman of the Joint Chiefs, rejecting Admiral Crowe's chosen successor, Gen. Robert T. Herres of the Air Force.
General Powell, who had been President Reagan's national security adviser, was more open to military intervention than Admiral Crowe. Generals Thurman and Powell moved quickly to rework plans for invading Panama, laying the basis for Bush's decision to send troops after Noriega in December of that year.
Only in Soviet relations did Cheney appear to be out of step with the White House and State Department. He advised caution in discounting the Soviet threat, and expressed skepticism of the permanence of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reforms. With the recent resurgence of military influence in the Soviet Union and the crackdown in the Baltics, his deep-seated doubt has lost its taint as the anachronistic mind-set of a cold warrior.
But the Defense Secretary, along with Powell, will be measured primarily by one standard: his skill in supervising the war in the Persian Gulf. That indisputably has made Cheney the most important Pentagon chief since Robert S. McNamara during the Vietnam years. Starting as a Secretary for Peace, he became a Secretary for War.

THE LAST TIME THE United States was at war, Cheney was studying for his doctorate in political science at the University of Wisconsin in Madison. Protests against the Vietnam War disrupted the campus in the 1960's, but Cheney, who was working part time for the Republican Governor of Wisconsin, was not swept up in the turmoil. He says he was "generally supportive" of the war and opposed the demonstrators. He had a deferment and was able to avoid military service. "As did most other Americans, I watched the war from afar," he says.
Born in Lincoln, Neb., Richard Bruce Cheney was raised in Casper, Wyo., where his father worked for the Agriculture Department. It was "an 'American Graffiti' kind of place," says Lynne Cheney, who was his high school sweetheart. "The big thing to do was to drive cars up and down, and go from one root beer stand to another," she recalls. "Dick never did that, which was a great disappointment to me. He worked. He always had a job. He read a lot." He had his own idea of fun; he was the captain of the football team and an outdoorsman.
Cheney went to Yale on a scholarship, but dropped out in his second year because of poor grades. "He probably did a few things I'd just as soon not read about in The New York Times," his wife says.
He rambled around the Western United States for a while, working for an electric company laying power lines, before settling down at the University of Wyoming. There, the Ivy League dropout bore down, earning bachelor's and master's degrees in political science and marrying Lynne Vincent. He then entered graduate school at the University of Wisconsin and, at 27, was selected for a one-year internship in the Capitol Hill office of Representative William A. Steiger, a Republican.
From this launching pad, Cheney began his meteoric career in Washington. When President Nixon chose Representative Donald H. Rumsfeld of Illinois to head the Office of Economic Opportunity, Cheney brashly sent Rumsfeld a 12-page memo on how to run the agency. Rumsfeld liked what he read, and the college intern became the director of Congressional relations for the agency, never returning to Wisconsin to finish his studies.
For much of the next decade, he lived in Rumsfeld's orbit, one of the legion of Washington special assistants who hitch their fortunes to a political star. It was a career marked by total loyalty, dedication and a certain subjugation of ego -- qualities that he still exhibits and demands of his subordinates at the Pentagon.
When Gerald R. Ford became President, Rumsfeld was named White House chief of staff and Cheney assumed his familiar role as Rumsfeld's deputy. When Rumsfeld was appointed Defense Secretary, his loyal lieutenant, then only 34, replaced him in the White House.
President Ford's loss to Jimmy Carter in 1976 was a turning point for the quintessential Washington staff man. Deciding that it was time to create his own political identity, he returned to Wyoming and ran for Congress.
Kenneth L. Adelman, former director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency and a friend of Cheney's from their days together at the Office of Economic Opportunity, remembers that period: "He had politics in his blood. After leaving the job of chief of staff, he had many lucrative offers but decided to run for an unsure seat. He went from the top of the top in politics, namely chief of staff for the President of the United States, to the bottom of the bottom, a candidate from a minority party running to become a freshman member of the House."
No sooner was his Congressional campaign under way than Cheney, then 37 years old, suffered a heart attack. He briefly considered dropping out of the race. But six weeks later he had quit his two-pack-a-day smoking habit and was back on the campaign trail.
"I finally concluded," he says now, "and this may be a little bit of rationalization, that it was more stressful to contemplate spending your life doing something that was not what you want to be doing and found a cardiologist who believed hard work never killed anybody." (Cheney had two more heart attacks. In 1988, he had a coronary bypass operation, was pronounced fit and now exercises regularly.)
After winning a seat in the House in 1978 as Wyoming's only Representative, Cheney rose rapidly in the Republican ranks. He was elected House minority whip in 1988 and became heir apparent to Robert H. Michel, the House Republican leader. He was seen as a pragmatic conservative who was more conservative than pragmatic, and as a hawk who admitted that he never met a weapon system he didn't like.
Unlike other leaders of the legislative branch, notably Senator Nunn, who heads the Senate Armed Services Committee, Cheney was not interested in protecting Congressional prerogatives from White House incursions. He repeatedly argued for giving President Reagan wide discretion in using military force and making foreign policy.
"He was the guy whom the Administration depended on to defend its interests on the hill," says Tony Coelho, the former Democratic whip in the House. "Part of his demeanor was that he would not be the one to talk to the press on the record about it. If others wanted to take credit, that was fine with him."
With the Senate's rejection of John G. Tower, Cheney quickly became the Administration's choice to be Defense Secretary. For the White House, he appeared to have the right mix of characteristics. A team player, he would not aggressively contest Secretary of State Baker's pre-eminent foreign policy role as Caspar W. Weinberger tried to do with George P. Shultz in the Reagan years. A popular Congressman, Cheney was eminently confirmable.
And his personal life was a contrast to that of Tower, who was accused of womanizing and heavy drinking. Cheney and his wife have not been fixtures of Washington night life, though they have attended cultural functions related to her job at the National Endowment for the Humanities. The couple's two daughters, Mary and Elizabeth, are grown.
On the morning of the vote against Tower, John H. Sununu, the chief of staff, called Cheney and asked him to come to the White House. The ostensible purpose of the visit with Sununu and the national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, was to solicit his ideas on suitable replacements for Defense Secretary. After some desultory conversation, however, Scowcroft asked if he would accept the job ifthe President offered it.
The Congressman wanted a night to think it over. That evening, Baker called to urge him to take the job. The two men, friends since the Ford Administration, consult often on political matters and go on wilderness trips together. (Last November, Cheney and Baker, along with Baker's sons, took a respite from Washington and flew to Wyoming for a hunting and fishing trip.)
When Bush formally asked him to head the Pentagon, Cheney accepted. He arrived in March 1989, seven months before the Berlin wall came down. "I clearly did not anticipate, nor did anybody else, the radical changes that 1989 would bring," he says.

THE SECRETARY'S cavernous office is decorated with old military emblems, as well as signs of the changing world order. On a far corner wall is a framed cartoon from a Florida newspaper of Cheney spoiling a toast between Bush and Gorbachev. In the room's center is an immense wooden desk, first used by Gen. John J. Pershing during World War I.
Cheney says he feels like a wagon driver trying to control galloping horses. It is not so much that the horses are running at different strides, he says, but that the horses "are not all hitched to the same end of the wagon." He has not hesitated to crack the whip. But in the beginning he was better at gathering power than at using it effectively.
In his first weeks in the job, he alerted the military that he was in charge when he reprimanded the Air Force Chief of Staff, Larry D. Welch, for trying to reach budget compromises with Congress without his authorization. Later, when Gen. John T. Chain Jr., then head of the Air Force Strategic Air Command, publicly differed with the Bush Administration's position on nuclear arms, Cheney ordered him to fly to Washington for a dressing-down. After Welch's successor, Gen. Michael J. Dugan, made unauthorized comments last September about Israeli advice on fighting the Iraqis and touted the Air Force as the main instrument for winning a war in the gulf, the Defense Secretary removed him. An open war between Pentagon officials, like one that raged between Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. and Deputy Defense Secretary Paul Thayer during Weinberger's tenure, is unthinkable today.
But in the beginning, Cheney's efforts to use the levers of his power were unsure. After ordering a review of aircraft like the A-12, the C-17 transport plane and B-2 Stealth bomber, the Defense Secretary admits that he paid too much attention to adjusting the weapons projects in light of the receding Soviet threat and too little to managing the expensive programs themselves.
His early moves to reshape the military were also somewhat halting. The Defense Department's report to Congress for its 1990 budget was the briefest in memory and gave little hint of the possibilities opened up by the cold war's end. In fact, the report declared that it was "the worst possible time to contemplate changes in defense strategy."
Cheney and his deputies wanted to buy time to study the changes in Eastern Europe and to put the brakes on the Capitol Hill budget makers who were eager for a peace dividend. But the statement sent a message inside and outside the Pentagon that big innovations were not required.
Cheney's efforts to win support for his budget led to an unnecessary public dispute with the Director of Central Intelligence, William H. Webster. In his testimony to Congress last spring, the C.I.A. chief said the changes in Moscow were "irreversible," a stand that undercut Cheney's argument that Soviet intentions were too uncertain to justify deep reductions in the military.
In a rare display of irritation, the Defense Secretary told CNN that Webster's testimony had been "unhelpful." The remark created the impression that Cheney was trying to stifle an intelligence assessment to protect his budget. (It turned out that the C.I.A. had sent a draft of Webster's testimony to Cheney's top deputy on intelligence matters, but because of a bureaucratic snafu a copy never made it to the Defense Secretary.)
By mid-summer, however, Cheney was ready to act on his own strategic assessments. Working with General Powell and the Under Secretary of Defense for Policy, Paul Wolfowitz, he outlined plans to shrink the military by 25 percent, mostly by cutting the Army and Air Force units set up to defend Europe and by emphasizing "reconstitutable" partly manned Army divisions that could be brought up to full strength in a prolonged crisis. Cheney's plan was a major revision of Pentagon thinking: it was now assumed that the United States would have a year or more to prepare for a global war with the Soviet Union instead of the two weeks assumed by war planners for 40 years.
The department planned an elaborate coming-out party for its new blueprint. President Bush was to unveil it in a speech in Aspen, Colo., and Cheney and Brent Scowcroft were supposed to be on hand to brief the press. But Cheney never made it to Colorado. The evening before the trip, the Defense Secretary received a telephone call at his suburban Virginia home from Adm. Bill A. Owens, then his military assistant, who has since been promoted to commander of the Sixth Fleet in the Mediterranean. Saddam Hussein's forces had moved into Kuwait.

THE INVASION CAUGHT the Pentagon in the middle of updating its strategy in the Persian Gulf. Early last year, Cheney and Powell approved a classified document that stressed the need for more contingency planning for a war in the region and placed the Arabian Peninsula on a par with the Pacific in spending priorities. Cheney gave General Schwarzkopf the go-ahead to work on a new gulf strategy that put more emphasis on defending Saudi Arabia and less on guarding against a Soviet invasion of Iran. But the Defense Secretary did not discount the Soviet threat altogether. "We should retain our capability to defend there against either a Soviet-led or Soviet-supported contingency or a robust regional threat," the document said. It did not specifically mention the prospect of an Iraqi attack on Saudi Arabia.
Though incomplete, General Schwarzkopf's planning aided the Administration in its initial response to Saddam Hussein. By the time of Iraq's invasion, he had finished two parts of a plan to defend Saudi Arabia in the event of an attack. The first plotted the deployment of tactical aircraft; the second detailed the mobilization of ground troops. But General Schwarzkopf was never directed to plan for counterattack. Moreover, the Pentagon had not asked for sufficient funds to support its planning. While Cheney sought billions for "Star Wars" and new strategic nuclear weapons, he never requested money for sealift ships, which speed the transport of troops. Indeed, he wanted to reroute funds already allocated for such ships to other areas. Meanwhile, the Naval Ready Reserve sealift fleet was not well maintained.
"They kept coming to us with less than enough money for the very type of actions in which we are now involved," said John P. Murtha, a Pennsylvania Democrat who is chairman of the House Appropriations subcommittee on defense.
Caught off guard by the invasion, the White House scrambled into action. The night of Aug. 2, President Bush offered to send a tactical fighter squadron to Saudi Arabia as a demonstration of support. The Saudis turned down the offer.
Cheney pushed the military hard for an assessment of American options. He was quick to accept its view that immediate retaliatory air strikes would fail without backup from ground troops. That fateful judgment set the stage for months of pressure diplomacy, including economic sanctions.
The large number of troops initially envisaged by Powell reflected the military's tendency to err on the side of caution. But that sheer mass of air and ground forces called for in the August plan -- about 240,000 airmen, sailors, marines and soldiers to be based throughout the gulf -- raised the question of Saudi sensitivities to such a huge foreign presence.
President Bush accepted the Pentagon's plan two days after the invasion, and it was left to Cheney and Powell to sell the idea to the Saudis. That afternoon, Cheney asked the Saudi Ambassador, Prince Bandar bin Sultan bin Abdul Aziz, to come to his office.
The Saudi response was not preordained. Not only had the Saudis turned down Bush's offer to send fighter squadrons, but in July Prince Bandar had quietly protested the American decision to send two military refueling planes to the United Arab Emirates as part of an aerial exercise.
The emirates had proposed it after being threatened by Iraq. President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt also sent a message to President Bush after the drill, asking the United States to keep a low profile in the gulf. In the Administration, there had been initial disagreement over whether to go ahead with even this small step, and Cheney intervened to overcome early suggestions by the State Department that the emirates be advised to conduct the exercise with the Saudis.
In his Pentagon meeting with Cheney, Prince Bandar seemed stunned by the projected size of the American deployment, according to an account by a Pentagon official. "There was a catching of breath," the official recalls, as Bandar contemplated the problems of such an overwhelming presence in Saudi Arabia. Then the Prince's expression changed. "I guess that means you are serious," he said with a smile. "Now you see why we did not want a tactical fighter squadron. That is enough to get us in trouble but not enough to do anything."
The Prince urged American officials to fly to Saudi Arabia to present the plan to King Fahd. But virtually up to the last minute it was unclear whether the Saudis were prepared to receive Cheney. His departure was delayed twice. Finally, the signal came.
In King Fahd's marble palace in Jidda, he presented President Bush's offer to send more than 200,000 troops to the Persian Gulf. Without such numbers, he argued, Saudi Arabia would risk becoming another Kuwait. Cheney told King Fahd that the troops would stay only so long as they were wanted and that Washington would build up Saudi defensive capabilities -- an allusion to an arms sale.
After the presentation, the King conferred with his advisers in Arabic, which Charles W. Freeman Jr., the American Ambassador to Saudi Arabia and the only American present with any knowledge of the language, strained to understand. There seemed to be some argument, when one Saudi royal official asked whether the Americans would ever leave. Finally, King Fahd said he would accept the troops.
"I was surprised with how quickly he agreed," Cheney said a few days before war broke out. "I anticipated that I would be forced to wait a day or two for an answer. They clearly understood the scope of the problem."
It was the beginning of a long road. In mid-December, as hopes for peace dimmed, the Defense Secretary, wearing cowboy boots, a blue work shirt and jeans, inspected an Air Force unit in eastern Saudi Arabia.
He and General Powell gave speeches of support to the troops, preparing them for battle with Saddam Hussein. "It's far better to deal with him now than 5 or 10 years from now," Cheney said. He also referred to Vietnam. "The only acceptable outcome is absolute, total victory," he said, vowing that American troops will not have "their hands tied behind their backs." Later, on a plane back to the city of Dhahran, he was even quieter and more absorbed than usual.

HEADLINE: Minnesota's Teacher of the Year Is Laid Off in Budget Crisis

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
Cathy Nelson has been a teacher for 15 years, the last 13 of them teaching social studies at Fridley High School, in Fridley, Minn., near Minneapolis. She has found innovative ways to interest students in history, and has found time to earn a doctoral degree from the University of Minnesota.
Along with the admiration of her students, Ms. Nelson has won a number of awards. Last October she was named Minnesota's Teacher of the Year.
The only trouble was, she had just been laid off. 
 The 37-year-old teacher, the third generation in her family to teach, was a victim of budget cuts, a declining student enrollment and the seniority system at the Fridley Independent School District.
"What happened is obvious," said Donald A. Meyers, principal at Fridley High School. "Last hired is the first fired."
 
Laid Off, Again
 Unfortunately for Ms. Nelson, this is the fourth time that has happened. With 13 years at Fridley, she had the shortest length of service among the school's five social studies teachers.
"It was real hard for me to accept the fact that I'd been laid off when I work so hard," said Ms. Nelson, who will learn next month if the district has enough students and money to hire her a fifth time next fall. "But in truth, many good teachers are laid off."
Indeed, teachers lacking seniority have long been vulnerable when schools hit hard times. But many experts in education policy find an unpleasant irony in laying off a widely respected teacher at a time when the quality of teaching is under assault by public opinion.
"I think this is an outrage," said Joe Nathan, a senior fellow at the Hubert H. Humphrey Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Minnesota who is studying ways to improve schooling. Despite economic ills, "school districts need to think about priorities," he said, "and I would like to think that districts could find ways to keep good teachers."
 
No More 'Yo-Yo' Treatment
 The Fridley district did try to keep Ms. Nelson, offering her a part-time job in teaching combined with another part-time job in staff development. But she declined, saying she was weary of the "yo-yo" treatment.
Since the latest layoff, Ms. Nelson said, she has been working as a curriculum consultant, helping local schools design and submit state-mandated plans showing how these school systems plan to make their curriculums more culturally diverse.
She has also tackled the job of representing the state's teachers with zest, As Teacher of the Year, she has addressed about 30 educational, civic and business groups since October, stressing the importance of good teachers.
"I'd go back to the classroom in a minute," said Ms. Nelson, who comes from a family of educators. Her mother, Norma, teaches second grade in Lake Park, Minn., and encouraged her children to pursue education careers. Ms. Nelson's sister, Terri, is a school psychologist, and a brother, Bruce, coaches a high school girls' basketball team. Ms. Nelson's grandmother also taught school.
 
Teachers Don't Often Leave

Norma Nelson maintains that "teaching is a good job," despite what has happened to her daughter. She pointed out that part of her daughter's problem is that teachers with seniority rarely leave their jobs, especially in good school systems like Fridley's.
In each of the last two years, for example, two of the district's four schools have received national citations of excellence from the Federal Department of Education; the awards are based on student test scores, class size, dropout rates and graduation rates.
But Fridley, like many areas, has been hit by shrinking enrollment -- to about 2,500 students now, from about 6,000 in the early 1970's -- and by tough economic times. The recession has forced Fridley for the second straight year to cut $250,000 from its annual budget of about $12 million.
Losing her job for the fourth time "has taken a little of the luster off the plaque," acknowledged Ms. Nelson, who also received $1,000 for winning the state honor.
"I used to say it's unbelievable," she said of her layoffs. "Now I say it's all too believable."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Cathy Nelson, who last October was named Minnesota's Teacher of the Year, was laid off for the fourth time. (Michael Zerby for The New York Times)
