HEADLINE: SUPER BOWL XXV;
Levy Takes Scholarly Path to Tampa

BYLINE: By GERALD ESKENAZI, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 26

 BODY:
In his choice of words (how many head coaches use "oxymoron" in a press conference?), style of dress and preparation, Marv Levy could be standing in front of an eager young collection of students at a prestigious college.
Instead, the young men who listen to him invariably weigh a lot, are possessed of remarkable strength and are so motivated after he speaks that they go out and tackle people. 
 Levy is a rarity, but not unique: highly educated and erudite, and a National Football League head coach.
The terms are not mutually exclusive. Tommy Prothro, a Duke graduate and onetime coach of the Chargers, is an internationally recognized bridge player. Bill Walsh retained the aura of Stanford University, where he coached, although he went to San Jose State.
The Giants' defensive coordinator, Bill Belichick, was an economics major at Wesleyan. Tom Bresnahan, the Bills' offensive-line coach, received cum laude honors in economics and philosophy from Holy Cross, before earning a master's.
 
Following in Footsteps
 At the age of 62, Levy is finally enjoying the sort of success that few coaches, from football factories or ivory towers, achieve: his club is playing in a Super Bowl.
Levy says he doesn't remember if there was a moment, the shock of recognition, when he realized that there was something more important than being Phi Beta Kappa and heading for Harvard Law School.
"I had such wonderful coaches at Coe," he said of his undergraduate football days at Coe College in Cedar Rapids, Iowa. "I idolized them. I got to know their families, I enjoyed the camaraderie. And I thought what a life that is. That's what I want to do with my life."
And so he has.
Levy grew up in Chicago, where his father, who was born in England, was in the wholesale produce business. He remembers him as "a wonderful, supportive man."
After graduating from high school, Levy joined the Army Air Corps, and then entered Coe. He was a halfback, but also a scholar, and he enrolled in Harvard Law School.
"I had prepared for Harvard," he said. "But then I had real doubts. I'd sit in law school and think, I'd rather be coaching."
He called his father, a man, he recalled, "who never told me I couldn't try anything."
"When I told him of my decision, he said, 'Just be a good one,' " Levy said.
 
Change in Plans
 But Levy didn't leave Harvard. The law school had started classes a few weeks before the other graduate schools did.
"I thought a master's degree would be valuable, no matter what I wanted to do," Levy said. Harvard allowed him to switch to the graduate school of arts and science, and he graduated with a master's in history.
There were times the master's might have been valuable, indeed. This is his 14th coaching job.
That number evokes an anecdote from his days at Coe.
"I remember in my senior year they gave a psychological profile to the students," he said. "The dean called me in and said, 'You're the only guy in the class who listed security as the last consideration.' "
Yet just months after he earned his master's in 1951, he took a job at a high school in St. Louis. "I just wanted to be the best high school coach the area had ever known," Levy recalled.
Then he was an assistant at Coe, to his former high school coach, Dick Clausen, at New Mexico, and, finally, head coach at New Mexico, where he was Skyline Conference coach of the year in both 1958 and 1959.
But Levy thought it was possible to coach big-time winning football at a more intellectually oriented school. ("I made a mistake.") He tried the cachet of coaching at the University of California at Berkeley. He thought, "I can outcoach the other guys."
 
Getting to the Pros
 Instead, he was to admit, he ran across "tremendously stringent entrance requirements." Good coaching does not overcome your scholars against the other team's football players.
From there, Levy spent five years at William & Mary in Virginia, and then one as an assistant with the Eagles. George Allen tapped him as assistant coach with the Rams, where Levy became one of the first special-teams coaches in the league, charged with organizing punting and kicking teams. He followed Allen to the Redskins.
In 1973, Levy left for the Montreal Alouettes. In five years in the Canadian Football League his teams won two championships. Finally, he got his first N.F.L. head-coaching job with the Kansas City Chiefs, which lasted five seasons. He was able to land a job with the United States Football League's Chicago Blitz and finally at Buffalo late in the 1986 season.
Levy's wry humor has not been sullied by the pressure of coaching and of constant movement.
"People think that because of his background he's very serious all the time," said the Bills' general manager, Bill Polian. "But he's more like George Burns than George Santayana."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 5; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Fidelity's Secret Agent Man

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES

 BODY:
Alfred Fenaughty is the president of Information International Inc. in Culver City, Calif., a publicly traded company that makes advanced computer equipment for the publishing industry. When a pleasant analyst showed up one day in 1987 saying he was from the Boston-based Kelso Management Company, which provided investment recommendations to "the Fidelity group," Mr. Fenaughty was pleased and proud.
Who did Mr. Fenaughty think was at his door? "Fidelity -- the mutual fund people," he said. "In all their communications, they were presenting themselves as advisers to Fidelity. They came in under the same cloak. And their thoroughness, their studiousness -- it all suggested a long-term investor. So we did what we could to encourage them." 
 It was Fidelity -- but it was a little-known side of the financial company's sprawling empire, one that plays hardball under the firm hand of Kelso's intense and aggressive president, Dorsey R. Gardner. And now, three years later, Mr. Fenaughty is fighting for his corporate life. Kelso, backed by Fidelity money, owns nearly 34 percent of his company and is pressuring it to pay out its cash to shareholders and put itself up for sale. Mr. Fenaughty, in short, is convinced that he has been the victim of a brutal ruse, and that Fidelity bears much of the blame.
If he saw the Kelso-Fidelity group buying a big stake in a public company today, he said, "I'd assume it was with the intention of finding the quickest way of exploiting the company and making the quickest buck. I'd prepare for attempted rape."
As Mr. Fenaughty and a growing number of executives at other midsize companies approached by Kelso now know, the investors represented by the management company are not members of the vast family of public mutual funds operated by the Boston-based Fidelity group, a behemoth with $124 billion in managed assets, including $12 billion in the stellar Magellan Fund. Fidelity's public mutual funds typically buy a limited stake in a company and quietly sell if they lose faith in its future.
 
Fidelity's Other Face
 The Kelso investors, by contrast, are members of a far less benign side of Fidelity: a loose collection of private pools of money, in European and Caribbean tax havens, marked by a strong appetite for speculative profits and a willingness to engage in whatever level of boardroom warfare is necessary to achieve them.
Separately organized and legally distinct from the mutual funds, this other operation functions as Fidelity's second, tougher face. It is financed in part by profits generated by the mutual fund business. And it is headed by Edward C. Johnson 3d, chairman of the privately held FMR Corporation, Fidelity's parent company, and shares many other officers with the mutual fund organization. But this group, largely operated by FMR's international arm through management contracts, is run on a day-to-day basis by Mr. Gardner.
Mr. Gardner insists that he tries to make it "very, very clear" to those he deals with that he is independent of Fidelity's public mutual fund operation. "If people let themselves be led astray, it's not our fault," he said.
Over the past decade, Mr. Gardner has used money raised by FMR entities to rewrite the history of more than a dozen corporations, all in an effort, he said, to protect shareholders from the negligence of management.
Representing such little-known investment vehicles as the Integrity Fund and the Domestic Values fund -- and armed with powers of attorney to vote their shares as he sees fit -- Mr. Gardner has been a combative director of at least nine of these corporations, eventually becoming chairman of three. In those roles, he has presided over the sale of three companies and has pushed hard for major financial or managerial changes at five others. Right now, he is openly battling management at four companies, including Information International, and he is quietly building up sizable holdings in at least 10 more.
 
Using a Reputation
 These muscular tactics, of course, are commonplace among "corporate raiders" like Irwin Jacobs and Carl Icahn, who state their mission as "the enhancement of shareholder values." And no regulatory agency has accused Fidelity in any of its permutations of a breach of securities laws.
Nonetheless, numerous executives at companies targeted by Mr. Gardner say that he has used Fidelity's friendly reputation as a smokescreen for his bare-knuckles activities. After all, they say, the Fidelity known to the public carefully projects a straightforward image as a responsible but hands-off investor. The executives say they had no reason to suspect a different agenda when Mr. Gardner came calling, and Mr. Gardner, they say, had an ethical, if not legal, duty to disclose which Fidelity he was representing.
"They don't want to say anything that would tarnish their reputation as long-term investors," said Wendell Hung, chief executive of the Deltak Corporation, an energy equipment manufacturer in Minneapolis that Mr. Gardner helped to push into a leveraged buyout in 1989. "But they're not investors. They're traders. And they have gone completely unnoticed -- that's the cunning part. That's the only difference between them and somebody like Irwin Jacobs."
More than corporate confusion is at issue in these deals, however. The role that Fidelity has played in financing Mr. Gardner's work shows clearly the raw financial power that Ned Johnson and his FMR Corporation have acquired during the mutual fund boom of the past decade -- and how they could use that power to duplicate Mr. Gardner's activism on a grand scale in the 1990's.
"It is important for people to realize that the Fidelity organization is not just a friendly family of open-end mutual funds; it is a complex maze of many different types of investment vehicles," said Don Christensen, editor of the Insider Outlook newsletter in New York and one of the few analysts to keep track of what Fidelity and Mr. Gardner are doing. "What they have done already is simply a dress rehearsal for what they can do in the years ahead."
 
'Never Tried to Hide It'
 Mr. Johnson declined several requests for an interview to discuss Mr. Gardner's work and how the foreign operations he runs fit into Mr. Johnson's vision of FMR's future. Robert C. Pozen, FMR's general counsel, said he could not say whether corporate America was confused about the agenda Mr. Gardner pursues for FMR. "But we've never tried to hide it," he said. "We really can't say how other people understand it."
The company "makes a great effort to explain that this is a completely separate organization," he said, although he could cite no specific steps it has taken to remedy whatever confusion may exist. Mr. Pozen emphasized that the Gardner-run investment pools are not sold to the American public, and that Mr. Gardner's activities represent "a very, very small" aspect of FMR's business. Mr. Gardner does not report publicly on his funds' results. But a review of the record shows that many of his deals have been spectacularly successful while others were major disappointments.
It is true that the partnerships, trusts and other entities that Mr. Gardner manages are small -- about $4 million was raised from private investors for the first one in the early 80's, and $40 million was raised for the most recent one. In all, Mr. Pozen said, Mr. Gardner controls less than $100 million in foreign and FMR corporate money in pools that trace their lineage back to Fidelity's domestic discount brokerage unit in Boston or to Fidelity International Ltd. in Bermuda, which sells public mutual funds and other financial services abroad.
But FMR intends to sharply expand its international business, and its domestic mutual funds provide both the profits and the influence that underwrite that effort. "We have become the dominant force in the mutual fund industry in the United States and the United Kingdom," said Barry Bateman, a Fidelity International executive, in announcing a new set of foreign retail funds last September. "It is our intention to repeat this success on a global scale during the 90's."
If FMR accomplishes that aim, it will also be in a position to expand this much less visible side of its international operations: the private tax-haven partnerships run by raider-style managers like Mr. Gardner.
 
Rising Through the Ranks
 Dorsey Robertson Gardner, who was born in 1942, is a graduate of Yale and the Harvard Business School, and spent several of his student summers as a Fidelity intern. After a brief experiment running his own market forecasting firm in New York -- "I didn't like New York. My wife had nightmares," he said of the experience -- he returned to Boston and to Fidelity in 1970.
In the 70's, Mr. Gardner rose through the ranks at Fidelity, becoming a member of the company's policy committee. He still boasts of his close relationship with the enigmatic Ned Johnson, who took over as chairman of the family-controlled Fidelity organization in 1972. Four years earlier, Mr. Johnson had set up an international unit at Fidelity; in 1980, it was spun off as Fidelity International. The reason, said Mr. Pozen, was that American tax laws deter foreigners from investing through domestic organizations.
Also in 1980, Mr. Gardner resigned from Fidelity to start his own firm, Kelso Management. But the separation seems more symbolic than real. Kelso occupies space in an FMR-owned building three doors from Fidelity's Boston headquarters. A recent request for an interview with Mr. Gardner was handled by Fidelity's public relations staff, and Mr. Pozen sat in on the session, saying he was acting, "in an informal way," as Mr. Gardner's legal adviser. But most revealing is Kelso's client list: The only names on it are FMR and Fidelity International.
As for the efforts Mr. Pozen said FMR has made to clarify its relationship with Mr. Gardner, they seem to consist of detailing the complicated lineage of the various Kelso-run investment pools in documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Indeed, on the few occasions Mr. Gardner's activism has drawn news media attention, it has been portrayed as some special role thrust upon him by events. In February 1987, for example, a management buyout proposal at the Purolator Courier Corporation put a spotlight on Mr. Gardner, who had joined the board in October 1986 and then resigned a few months later to seek other bidders for the company. In interviews at the time, Mr. Gardner portrayed his directorship as a rarity. "We normally don't go on boards," he said. "But we were concerned that the company would pay 'greenmail' and we wanted to make sure they didn't."
 
'A Lot of Problems'
 The same theme was struck at the corporate level in August 1989 when Peter Lynch, who was then the manager of the huge Magellan Fund, went on the board of W. R. Grace & Company. At that time, Mr. Pozen described Mr. Lynch's directorship as a rare departure from company policy.
"While we believe strongly in shareholder rights," Mr. Pozen said, "we do not subscribe to the view that institutional investors should be represented on boards. It causes a lot of legal problems." Indeed, Fidelity insisted that Mr. Lynch sell Magellan's Grace shares and not discuss the company's internal affairs with other Fidelity managers.
Yet on the day Mr. Pozen made those comments, Mr. Gardner was on the board of numerous companies and it was Fidelity's muscle as a shareholder that had put him there. Mr. Pozen now says that he intended his statement to apply only to Fidelity's public mutual funds.
Even when Fidelity executives do talk about Mr. Gardner, their responses are often less than complete. For example, a review of dozens of public records in the S.E.C. files shows that Mr. Gardner is the "adviser" or "sub-adviser" of eight investment vehicles -- six foreign entities set up by Fidelity International; the Domestic Values fund, which is simply an account FMR set up with its own money, and the Integrity Fund, a domestic subsidiary of a unit of Fidelity Brokerage Services. Until last year, he also managed two other foreign funds, the Fidelity Discovery Fund and the Fidelity World Fund, both in Luxembourg.
 
Difference in Numbers
 Yet when Mr. Gardner and Mr. Pozen were asked recently how many entities Mr. Gardner managed, they initially mentioned only a group of four Caribbean funds and two of their subsidiaries set up by Fidelity International under the name "American Values." Only after numerous follow-up questions did they confirm the full roster, including the corporate accounts he manages for FMR.
Whatever the scope of Mr. Gardner's duties, several executives who have been approached by Kelso say they misunderstood his mission, at least at first:
* When the funds Mr. Gardner runs first bought their stake in Deltak, "I was somewhat naive," said Dr. Hung, Deltak's chief executive. "I didn't know all the details, but I thought it was Fidelity. I thought it was great to be associated with Fidelity mutual funds."
Later, Mr. Gardner and John R. Kountz, his vice president, demanded seats on the Deltak board and began to insist that the company be sold. They even tried to interest Deltak's chief competitor in buying the company, without the prior knowledge of others on the Deltak board. Finally, after a long and distracting auction, Dr. Hung organized a group to take Deltak private in 1989, buying out Mr. Gardner's clients and other public investors. Today, the company finds itself sailing into a recession with a worrisome level of debt and high interest payments.
"Business people don't always agree on absolutely everything," said Mr. Gardner. "But we were very constructive at Deltak. John and I made a very big contribution."
* Between October 1989 and March 1990, funds run by Mr. Gardner accumulated 11.8 percent of the shares of Nuvision, an optical products company in Flint, Mich. "I recall talking to one or more people about who he was," said Jonathan Raven, the company president. "We understood him to be part of Fidelity -- which we saw as relatively benign and certainly not a raider-type investor. We sure didn't think he was who he ended up being."
Mr. Gardner ended up being a very assertive shareholder. First, he and another money manager, Leopold Swergold, teamed up to try to engineer a merger between Nuvision and D.O.C. Optics, a competitor in which Mr. Gardner also held a large stake. Their matchmaking alliance was not revealed on any of Mr. Gardner's S.E.C. reports, he said, because "these were very preliminary discussions" that he felt were not subject to disclosure. Then, after the merger idea got a cool reception at Nuvision, Mr. Gardner sent a public letter to the company last April to demand that its chairman be removed. Nuvision has so far ignored the demand.
Mr. Gardner defended his actions as being protective of shareholders. "It's a case of a public company acting as if it's a private company," he said.
* Mr. Gardner also used Fidelity's off-shore funds to buy a stake in House of Fabrics of Sherman Oaks, Calif., which owns a large chain of fabric stores. By late 1988, his 8.8 percent stake attracted public and corporate attention. Gary L. Larkins, the company's president, told reporters at the time that he continued to view the FMR group as "passive investors." By January 1990, Mr. Gardner controlled nearly 21 percent of the company, and in February he became a company director.
 
Quiet, Then a Shakeup
 "There is a pattern," said Mr. Christensen, the newsletter editor, to Mr. Gardner's efforts on Fidelity's behalf. "He picks small companies that nobody pays attention to, companies with fairly unsophisticated management. He buys slowly. There's a long period of quiet. And then there is some kind of major shakeup."
One reason that the pattern has gone largely unnoticed, Mr. Christensen said, is Mr. Gardner's use of confusing nomenclature. "It's not just the Fidelity thing -- even the name he chose for his own firm is confusing," Mr. Christensen said, noting that "Kelso Management Company" is very similar to Kelso Asset Management Company, a much larger investment company which is widely known for its pioneering work on corporate employee stock ownership plans.
"He plays little games," Mr. Christensen added. "But what is so interesting is the number of games he plays -- and that he plays them with Fidelity's money."
While Mr. Gardner conceded that Kelso frequently gets telephone calls from executives asking about his status, he said, "Anybody who was reasonably diligent and asked the question would get the correct answer. We've never tried to confuse anybody."
 
 
THE BITTER BATTLE OVER G.R.I.
 What is Dorsey Gardner, Fidelity's abrasive investment adviser, like in battle? Judging by some of his recent campaigns, he is highly aggressive, but not always successful.
For the wealthy investors who finance Mr. Gardner's activities, the spoils of war sometimes have been quite handsome.
But Mr. Gardner also has faced major disappointments, bruising battles that drag on for years without a profit. Few have been messier than the fight over the G.R.I. Corporation, a direct-mail retailer of cosmetics and household products in Chicago.
In May 1988, G.R.I. management proposed taking the company private for $10 a share. Mr. Gardner objected on behalf of his Fidelity investors who owned about 20 percent of the company, saying the price was too low. To block the bid, he formed an alliance with two other large investors: Albert Friedman, a Florida businessman, whose representative on the G.R.I. board was Bernard Zimmerman, an investment banker in Westport, Conn.; and the Minneapolis Employees Retirement Fund, a public pension fund that was represented by its executive director, John Chenoweth.
The trio blocked the buyout and elected Mr. Gardner to the board, where his relationship with David Rubin, the company's chief executive, rapidly deteriorated. On Jan. 13, 1989, Mr. Rubin resigned. Mr. Gardner became the company's chairman and, for the three months it took to replace Mr. Rubin, its president and chief executive as well.
Having taken power, Mr. Gardner turned on his allies. Minutes before a board meeting on Feb. 2, 1989, he abruptly announced a plan to reduce the board's size and eliminate the seats held by Mr. Chenoweth and Mr. Zimmerman, who he later said were "not supportive of my efforts to turn the company around." Defiant, Mr. Chenoweth announced that his fund would vote its shares to re-elect Mr. Zimmerman.
The warfare escalated sharply. On March 28, 1989, Mr. Gardner had the company sue Mr. Zimmerman, charging he had violated antitrust laws by serving as a director of another company Mr. Gardner considered a G.R.I. competitor. (Other G.R.I. executives later disputed that view.)
Mr. Gardner also wrote the Minneapolis pension fund board, objecting strenuously to Mr. Chenoweth's behavior. He flew to Minneapolis, arranged a meeting with Mayor Donald Fraser and complained widely about Mr. Chenoweth's alliance with Mr. Zimmerman.
Mr. Gardner said recently that his complaint to the fund dealt only with Mr. Zimmerman's "conflict of interest." In fact, his letter did not mention that point. "I don't care what the letter says," Mr. Gardner said, after briefly scanning a copy. "That's what the issue was."
The pension board backed Mr. Chenoweth, telling Mr. Gardner that its policies were none of his business. With the fund's backing, Mr. Zimmerman was re-elected to the board on May 11, 1989; embattled, he served until February 1990, when he finally resigned and settled the lawsuit, with G.R.I. paying $44,200 toward his expenses and legal fees.
Mr. Gardner said he sees his role at G.R.I. as being beneficial to shareholders. But under his leadership, G.R.I.'s shares have sunk to about $3 apiece.

Winning Seats on Boards
 
Aritech, Framingham, Mass.: On Feb. 12, 1990, Kelso-run Fidelity funds disclosed that they had bought 9.8 percent of this electronics security equipment company for investment purposes. On April 19, Kelso reported that Aritech had complied with its request and added a Kelson executive to its board.
 
Ports of Call Inc., Denver: Representing Fidelity investors, Dorsey Gardner took control of this struggling travel club in June 1989 and liquidated its assets. Mr Gardner continues as president of the company, renamed P.O.C.I. Inc.
 
Primark Corp., McLean, Va.: Mr. Gardner joined the board in August 1989. In April 1990, he stepped down as manager of the Fidelity World Fund. The same month, Primark purschased 996,500 of its own shares from the fund, thereby allowing the fund to sell ist stake without driving down the market price.
 
Quaker Fabric Corp., Fall Rover, Mass.: In April 1989, Mr. Gardner joined the board . Three months later, he helped negotiate the sale of the company.
 
Victoria Station, San Franciso: Mr. Gardner became chairman in 1982, representing Fidelity investors. A diversification plan faltered, and Fidelity sold out in late 1984. The company went bankrupt in May 1986.
 
And Challenging Management
 
Binks Manufacturing, Franklin Park, Ill.: After visiting the company last June, Mr. Gardner announced that the president had told him of a "friendly offer" for Binks. Mr Gardner demanded that the board "form a committee of independent directors to explore the offer which has been made." The president responded that there was no such offer and "there must be some misunderstanding." So far, no offer has surfaced.
 
Crowley, Milner & Co., Detroit: Mr. Gardner bought a 29.4 percent stake from an heir of the founding family in 1988, and has notified the board that Kelso would like to see steps taken to enhance shareholder value. A family adviser said recently that an investment banker has been hired to advise the board.
 
D.O.C. Optics, Southfield, Mich.: Mr. Gardner's funds backed a buyout and then a merger, but both plans faltered. The company bought out Kelso's stake at the market price in a private transaction in October.

LENGTH: 1228 words

HEADLINE: Where Some See Recession, Others See Opportunity

BYLINE: By ANDI RIERDEN

 BODY:
IN August, despite glum economic forecasts for Connecticut, Vivian Blaha decided to start a business. Without any advance advertising, she rented space in a shopping center in Guilford and hung up her handmade shingle: "Thimble Weeds: Tailoring and Alterations for Men and Women." Before long, she said, her rack was filled with garments awaiting new zippers, linings and hems. Lately, she has asked a local seamstress to take care of her overflow work.
"I always do well in recessions," said Ms. Blaha, who has been a tailor for 29 years. "It's the best time to be in business." This is especially so now, she said, because "retail stores that had alteration departments simply cannot afford to run them anymore." 
 Even as the level of economic uncertainty increases around the state, many entrepreneurs say they are prospering. And some attribute their gains to the recession itself. Economic analysts say that among the businesses that are least affected by the current downturn are exporters and others that do not have to rely on the region for their profits.
Overseas demand for American products prompted Roman Roftafis to leave his marketing job to open American Sports Products in Bethel. The wholesale distributor exports sports equipment, from rowing machines and treadmills to golf clubs and soccer balls. Most of the customers for his six-year-old company are based in South America, where demand is highest, he said, but he also distributes to Europe and Japan.
 
Seeking to Build Up
 The decline in the housing market has also boosted business for home repair and remodeling concerns, like the Home Depot chain, which has opened three stores in Connecticut since 1989 and said it plans to open others. "The recession doesn't both us one bit," said Jackie Bryans, an assistant manager in North Haven.
Homeowners are also looking for advice on how to repair, remodel or redesign their homes, said James Lomuscio, assistant editor of Practical Homeowner, a home-improvement magazine published in Fairfield.
"Instead of trading up, people are now wanting to know how to build up," he said, "in hopes that when the market rebounds, their homes will be worth more." Advertising revenues for the magazine increased 55 percent in 1990 from the previous year, he said.
The flurry of foreclosures in the last two years has also generated business for the ailing real estate industry, as banks turn to management companies to oversee commercial and residential properties. "Despite all the negative news, management seems to be the healthiest area within the real estate sector," said Joseph M. Ergolano, vice president of economic development for the Southwestern Area Commerce and Industry Association in Stamford.
But the companies that are gaining the most during the current hard times are those that export, said Matthew J. Broder, director of the international division of the State Department of Economic Development. "These are companies that are able to mitigate the U.S. recession by reaching to the overseas market, where the dollar is weak," he said. "They are definitely our economic advantage for 90's."
According to the department's latest figures, exports contributed $3.8 billion to the Connecticut economy in 1989, a 17 percent increase from the previous year.
Some of the major exporters in Connecticut, Mr. Broder said, include companies that manufacture transportation equipment, like Pratt & Whitney Aircraft in North Haven and Bauer Aerospace in Farmington, along with those that specialize in scientific testing devices, like Gerber Scientific in South Windsor. Several other Connecticut companies have recently started exporting. World-Wide Games in Colchester, for example, began selling to distributors in Japan and Europe almost a year ago, said the company's president, Stephen Lloyd. "Sales have been way ahead of our projections," he said.
The 35-year-old mail-order company initially sold its hardwood games to Boy Scouts and churches. In 1985, it expanded into the adult market and currently mails 3.5 million catalogues annually to consumers in the United States. As a result, sales have tripled, said Mr. Lloyd, who said he expects great results from the overseas market.
"The lower dollar is the big factor," he said. "But foreign consumers are more than eager to get a hold of quality American products."
Mr. Roftafis of American Sports Products in Bethel said he could not survive if he relied on markets in the United States. Without his foreign customers, "I'd be hurting big time," he said.
Several chambers of commerce around the state are helping their members search for overseas possibilities. The Southwestern Area Commerce and Industry Association recently sponsored a conference on exporting attended by business leaders from The Netherlands who discussed potential markets for Connecticut businesses and how to set up a sales office in Europe. "A lot of businesses have been asking for advice about how to export," said Mr. Ergolano of the business group in Stamford. "Certainly, any manufacturer in Fairfield County is a viable candidate."
Some buisnesses have found foreign customers right in Connecticut. The state's Department of Tourism reported that desite a slump some hotels have succeeded in attracting tourists from other countries. Last year at the Simsbury Inn, business increased 13 percent from the previous year, thanks in part to an increase in international clients, said J. Robert Gengras, co-owner of the inn. He said he has directed his marketing to corporations in the region that have clients visiting from overseas. The inn has staff members who speak German, Japanese, French and Russian, he said, and its dining service caters to Continental tastes.
"In tough times," he said, "you've got to be as flexible and accommodating as possible."
Even without relying on foreign customers, some people have succeeded in starting new businesses in this uncertain economy.
 
A Hunch Paid Off
 Denise Mendelsohn said she had reservations about moving to Milford in 1989 and starting an advertising agency. "Here I was, opening up this shop in this new place where I didn't know anyone, and business was clamping up everywhere," she said. "But I simply wanted to take the risk."
Ms. Mendelsohn said she believed that her industry would survive the recession because of an increasing demand for creative marketing, and her hunch has paid off. After winning several assignments from companies in Manhattan and other parts of the country, her company, Metropolis Design and Advertising, increased its sales last year by 150 percent from the year before, she said, adding, "We ended the year feeling rather excluded from all the recession news."
Others planning to start businesses in Connecticut should be aware of the state's changing demographics, said Peter M. Gioia of the Connecticut Business and Industry Association. He and other analysts said they anticipate a rising need for services that cater to the growing population of elderly consumers with disposable incomes and to the increasing numbers of working women with children. Time-saving businesses, from packaged-food companies to cleaning services, will be in demand, Mr. Gioia said.
The path to success has lots of pitfalls, he said, adding, "There's also opportunity, if you're on target."

HEADLINE: THEATER;
An Unexpectedly Moving 'Menagerie'

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

DATELINE: PRINCETON

 BODY:
EVERYONE expects to be moved by "The Glass Menagerie," but not so unexpectedly as in Emily Mann's exceptional production at the McCarter Theater here.
Unlike the transparent, closed-in representation of an apartment and the tenenment exterior that one customarily associates with Tennessee Williams's first masterwork, the vision of Ms. Mann's production is of vastness. The lamplike fixtures hanging on high appear intermixed with the staged lights and the long narrow corridors that flank Ming Cho Lee's set design extend into the beyond. Even the furniture and objects inside have a spatial relationship. These are simply not the expected living and dining rooms of the Wingfields. At first sight, things seem all wrong. Before long, it all feels right. 
 In her staging, an auspicious debut as the McCarter's artistic director, Ms. Mann may have taken her cue from the narrator's, Tom's, opening lines: "I have tricks in my pocket. I have things up my sleeve." Ms. Mann appears to view the play not in illusory, but in sensible, almost contemporary terms. But fear not. There is no tampering with time here. Since the period specified by Williams is of "a dissolving economy," updating would be redundant. Ms. Mann's trick is that she has grasped the play in new -- yes, unexpected -- and never less than loving ways.
Nowhere is the unexpected more evident than in Shirley Knight's fulfilling performance as Amanda. This is a no-nonsense woman of earthly demeanor and concerns, not one filtered through an ethereal film or adrift in a field of jonquils.
She has a frantic mother's clear priority: to make "plans and provisions" for a daughter who won't ever be able to make them on her own.
Ms. Knight's Amanda is a failed planner, not a dotty dreamer. When she retreats into her memories -- it's her memory play too, not just Tom's -- babbles incessantly or even gets into an outlandish ball gown to greet the Gentleman Caller, the ever-practical Ms. Knight seems to be telling us that, well, people do that.
Amanda's regretful admission -- "I wasn't prepared for what the future brought me" -- permeates Ms. Knight's portrayal. It explains her panic and the tacklessness, bordering on cruelty, that Southern charm cannot conceal.
Through all her maneuvering, the inimitable catch in the actress's voice unfailingly finds -- in a phrase, in unexpected moments -- the lyric wonder of Williams's sensibility. When she recalls her long-departed husband, "the telephone man who fell in love with long distance," one witnesses the momentary transformation that defines poetic acting.
To top it off, Ms. Knight's characterization is shot through with an extraordinary comic sense, most deliriously by the scene on the fire escape landing when Tom tells her the Gentleman Caller is coming.
As soon as that "emissary from the world of reality" arrives, Jeff Weatherford's smooth, easygoing playing and Judy Kuhn's rapturous response as Laura turn familiar moments into newly discovered ones. Ms. Kuhn's final withdrawal, bathed in the glow of Robert Wierzel's lighting, is as ominous as it is unutterably sad.
One could quibble with the program's self-conscious identification of characters: the Mother, instead of Amanda Wingfield; Her son, Her daughter. Their names are embedded in theater legend; why universalize them so obviously?
And Dylan McDermott is an overly gruff, wild, impetuous and showy Tom (the son). When he knocks over one of Laura's ornaments, one could almost say he did it accidentally on purpose.
But in the end, the soul of the play cannot elude even this Tom, as he unexpectedly wipes away a tear in his last monologue. It's likely that you'll be doing the same thing.
"The Glass Menagerie," by Tennessee Williams, at the McCarter Theater, 91 University Place. Performances through next Sunday. Box-office telephone: (609) 683-8000.

HEADLINE: A Singer Sways To Beat From Rio

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

 BODY:
ONE singer flew in from Paris, one from Bahia and two from Rio de Janeiro. But all Kenia had to do to show up for her star turn in a festival of Brazilian music in Manhattan was take the Long Island Expressway.
It was not until she moved to St. James that, Kenia said, "I began to go back, deeper and deeper, into my Brazilian roots." 
 On Jan. 6, the 33-year-old performer, who was born and raised in Rio, was the opening attraction of the first Brazilian season at the Ballroom at 253 West 28th Street. The festival runs through Feb. 16.
 
29 Artists in All
 In separate appearances, seven women, two of whom live in New York, and their backup musicians -- a total of 29 artists -- display the diversity of the genre, encompassing the samba, bossa nova and a percussive African-influenced sound.
With her soft pop-jazz style, Kenia performs today and next Sunday at 3 and 7 P.M.
Kenia avoids her possible surnames, Acioly, by birth; Gould, by her first marriage, and Ashby.
Her husband, Jay Ashby, is her musical director. At the end of her act, when Kenia introduces the five musicians, whose exotic instruments include the hadgini, a clay pot; caxixi, a shaker full of beans, and a ganza, a sort of tambourine, in addition to drums, guitars and a piano, the singer, who is seven months pregnant, tells the audience that Mr. Ashby is "on percussion, on trombone and on baby."
For a year and a half, the couple and Kenia's 6-year-old son, Thomas, have been renting a house in St. James.
 
An Exchange Student in 1975
 "After a vagrant musician's life," Mr. Ashby said, "this is my sense of stability. I come home and feel it's a place I know, and the car is in the garage. I don't have to get up and switch it from one side of the street to the other."
Kenia first went to the Island as an exchange student in 1975, when she attended Woodmere Academy and lived in the home of Burt and Carol Levy in Lawrence. Kenia calls them "my American parents." Mr. and Mrs. Levy now live in Head of the Harbor, north of St. James.
Kenia's parents, 4 sisters and 10 nephews and nieces live in Rio, where Kenia returned after completing her studies. By 1980, she had left again, this time to live in New York for seven years and in Los Angeles for three. She met Mr. Ashby there.
"It was pretty rough -- a crisis economically and the politics were heavy -- a third world reality," Kenia said about Brazil. "Once you are back, you had to sign a document that you wouldn't return to the United States for two years.
"I was a bilingual secretary there and I got away with a lot of stuff at 20. I was exposed to what democracy really is, and it was hard for me to keep my mouth shut. Luckily, I split before I got into a lot of trouble."
 
New Album Due in Spring
 In her act and on her three record albums -- another is due out in the spring -- Kenia sings in Portuguese and in English. "And I throw in a little romantic Spanish," she added.
At the Ballroom, the material ranges from "Aqui Oh!" and "Ahora" to "Don't Let Me Be Lonely Tonight" and "Over the Rainbow."
Of the Harold Arlen classic, Kenia said:
"Thomas had a music box that played it, and so I sang it to him in a playful way, with a samba beat, and Jay said, 'It really works.' "
"The songs are about love and freedom, and the freedom to love."
Kenia said of her mellow, sultry delivery punctuated by scatting:
"The more I do it, it's somehow becoming more and more Brazilian. And I end up as a jazz singer. At least that's what they're calling me.
"I don't like tags, and I was never really trained or prepared to be a jazz singer. So it seems audacious, but it's a natural thing for me. I don't think I can do it, but I end up doing it."
"Brazilian music is still a little elitist in a way," the singer said, "but it's catching on. The bossa nova was a craze in the 60's, and in the 70's it was Sergio Mendes. Now the moment seems right for the whole richness of Brazilian music, which is popular all over Europe.
"The American market has been closed to Brazilian music and there's never been a festival like this before. We're just this close to a breakthrough."

HEADLINE: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Laurens, S.C.;
Two Boons For Economy

BYLINE: By LYN RIDDLE

 BODY:
TWO large distribution centers -- one under construction and another built two years ago -- have given the economy of this northwestern South Carolina city a jumpstart.
With about 10,000 residents, Laurens and surrounding Laurens County, with 45,000 people, have relied on textile manufacturing since the first mill was built here in the late 1800's. But in recent years, county leaders have sought to diversify because of layoffs and plant closings throughout the South. 
 The success of the new centersdepends primarily on Interstates 26 and 385, which connect Laurens County with Atlanta, 165 miles south of here, and Charlotte, N.C., 98 miles to the north. Another key factor is that undeveloped land suitable for industry is inexpensive -- about $5,000 an acre.
Four textile mills still employ about 1,800 people, and now 1,630 work at the 1.6 million-square-foot distribution center for the Wal-Mart discount chain, built on 140 acres here two years ago, and its new store.
Michelin Corporation recently started a 700,000-square-foot distribution center two miles to the north on I-385. It is to be completed in 1992.
Michelin, with its headquarters in Greenville, about 30 miles away, chose Laurens County because it is convenient to the company's four South Carolina plants, company officials said. The tire manufacturer also operates a proving ground on 2,500 acres in Laurens County.
The Wal-Mart distribution center, a round-the-clock operation, fills 240 trucks a day, shipping to stores in a dozen states.
Despite the heavy traffic in this pastoral setting of rolling hills and lush farmland, many residents say the facility improved their lives.
"Wal-Mart changed the spirit in the community," said Mr. Morton, who now works as a fund-raiser for Presbyterian College in Clinton, S.C., also in Laurens County. "People saw themselves in a more positive light."
He said Wal-Mart, in addition to the large payroll and the $584,473 a year in taxes it pays, also encouraged the opening of other businesses, including three motels, several fast-food restaurants and some stores.
The facility did not bring about a housing boom, Mr. Morton said, because most of the people hired already lived within a 30-mile radius.
"Our unemployment rate was something like 3.9 percent when Wal-Mart opened, a 15-year-low," said Mr. Morton.

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
Anchor for the Arts Rising in Stamford

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
WHEN the Stamford Center for the Arts opens its new 46,000-square-foot multimedia complex next September, organizers and supporters say, Atlantic Street will take its place as the entertainment center of southwestern Connecticut.
"There is a sense of community building here," said Randall Brion, the center's executive director. "Stamford has become the leisure focus for the entire region." 
 The Palace Theater on Atlantic Street, acquired last year by the center to complement its new theatrical complex, is already fully booked by music and theater groups. Already open on Atlantic Street are a branch of the Whitney Museum and the American Ballet Academy, as well as a dozen new restaurants and nightclubs.
Nearby are several art galleries and Mr. Brion said that the city is considering converting the 30,000-square-foot old City Hall, now partially occupied by municipal offices, into a museum with exhibition space.
Charles T. Lee, chairman of the city's Urban Redevelopment Commission, said his agency has proposed developing the four-acre Columbus Park off Atlantic into an entertainment complex with four movie theaters and new restaurants and nightclubs.
"We have the opportunity to make Stamford's downtown into an exciting entertainment and cultural district," Mr. Lee said.
Some residents have questioned at meetings on various arts proposals whether Stamford could support this type of district, with New York's theaters and galleries so close. But Mr. Brion said that since 1986, when demolition of the old Stamford Theater began to make way for the new theatrical complex and the Center for the Arts began producing shows in the Palace under a lease arrangement, ticket sales have grown from $500,000 to $1.8 million a year.
"New York is New York, and nothing is ever going to change that, Mr. Brion said, "but a city has grown up in Stamford and it has come into its own culturally."
The new center has been supported heavily by Stamford's corporate community, and Christopher P. Bruhl, president of the Southwestern Area Commerce and Industry Association, said businesses hope the arts will vitalize the downtown.
"It's the equivalent of a department store's anchoring a mall -- a center for the arts anchors the pedestrian life of a city," Mr. Bruhl said.
Mr. Bruhl also said that the white-collar businesses of Stamford and the area rely on cultural attractions when recruiting new executives. "People in this area don't stop feeling creative after 5 P.M.," he said.
When the new Center for the Arts structure was first proposed in 1982, it was expected to cost $6 million. The project has expanded considerably in scope, size and cost since then, to $16 million, and it is still growing.
The project has received $3.9 million in grants from the state, and about $750,000 from the city out of a tourism fund financed by a hotel room tax. The rest has come from private and corporate contributions.
The restored Palace, a 1,580-seat, 1926 vaudeville theater, is home to dance, music and theater productions by the Center for the Arts, the Stamford Symphony Orchestra, the Stamford Chamber Orchestra, the Stamford City Ballet, Connecticut Ballet Theater, New England Lyric Operetta and the Connecticut Grand Opera.
Anita M. Leury, director of development for Connecticut Grand Opera, said the arrangement with the Center for the Arts has enabled all the organizations to present reasonably priced, high-quality productions.
"Our goal is to take away the opera's elitist reputation," Mrs. Leury said. In March, the Grand Opera will put on the United States premiers of two French operas at the Palace, Bizet's "Djamileh" and Massenet's "La Navarraise." She said the French Consul General in New York City will attend the opening nights.
THE new theatrical complex, Mr. Brion said, is designed to complement the Palace, not replace it. It will have a 700-seat theater for drama and dance productions, and a 150-seat studio theater for community presentations and educational events.
The smaller theater will also be used to tape productions for Connecticut Public Television, WEDW, which is moving its Channel 49 offices into the new building.
Donald C. Lamy, chief engineer for WEDW, said he does not know of another public television system that is based in a center for the arts.
"It is unusual, but it's a great match," Mr. Lamy said. The new location will allow WEDW to broadcast many of the cultural events live, which officials hope will lead viewers in the area to think of Channel 49, rather than its New York counterpart, as their station, a perennial problem in southwestern Connecticut.
Mr. Lee said the redevelopment commission worked closely with the center and its architect and engineers to design something that would fit into the neighborhood. "The problem was how to make a two-story building, and an unusually shaped building, look monumental and important when you're surrounded by office towers," he said.
The front of the building, facing Atlantic Street and Tresser Boulevard, will rise two stories from the street, with a glass and masonry exterior and a wraparound marquee facing the intersection. The masonry back of the building, housing the theater and mechanicals, will rise to about 75 feet.
The lobby, where art exhibits will be mounted, will have a large glass wall. "It's like the lobby becomes a stage as well, facing out into the city," Mr. Lee said.
Mr. Brion said the new theater will also incorporate as its main entryway an arch from the old Stamford Theater, containing a likeness said to be a cross between the first manager of the theater and a famous early 20th-century dancer who had performed there. The arch was designed by Gutzon Borglum, the Stamford sculptor best known for the Mount Rushmore reliefs.
Mr. Brion said the center plans to announce later this winter what the first production in the new building will be.
"We have already seen tremendous growth, just on the promise of its opening," he said. "There are more restaurants and clubs opening, and there's a sense that there's more to the city than office buildings."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The new Stamford Center for the Arts, scheduled to open in the fall. The Palace Theater on Atlantic Street is now part of the theatrical complex. (Photographs by Steven Castagneto for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Towns' New ZIP Codes Bring Pride (Mail, Too)

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
FOR Jerry B. Lucas, Killingworth's First Selectman, the best part about his town's getting its own ZIP code is that his subscriptions will now be addressed properly.
"I don't like to see my Time magazine coming in addressed to Deep River," Mr. Lucas said. "I don't live in Deep River, I live in Killingworth, and it's about time the post office recognized that." 
 Salem, which shares a ZIP code with neighboring Colchester, is also getting a new ZIP code soon, and the First Selectman, Hugh C. Teel, said the issue involves more than just a name on a mailing label.
The state Motor Vehicles Department, for instance, sorts tax bills on car purchases by ZIP code, so Salem's tax bills could be incorrectly routed, Mr. Teel said. And when the town seeks financing for a project, the interest rate is often based on factors like community unemployment, whichthe Labor Department ties to ZIP codes, he added.
 "It leaves the town without any identity as far as state and Federal records are concerned," Mr. Teel said.
 
Five New Codes
 Killingworth, currently ZIP code 06417 and soon to be 06419, and Salem, 06415, soon to be 06420, are among five Connecticut towns that will get new ZIP codes on July 1, under a decision announced last month by the Postal Service.
The others are Bethany (06525, switching to 06524), Oxford (06483, soon to be 06478), and Preston (06360, soon to be 06365), said Philip A. Piccolo, a Postal Service spokesman.
But not every town is excited about the prospect.
"It's such a non-issue. I wasn't even aware of it," said John Ford, First Selectman in Bethany. He added with a laugh, "I guess we're really going on the map now."
 Mr. Piccolo said the service often gets petitions from towns that want their own ZIP code. "It's considered a form of community recognition," he said. When assigning ZIP codes, the Postal Service weighs factors like population and volume because mail sorting machines can only be programmed to handle a limited number of codes.
But some town officials say they cannot understand how the decisions were made.
Mr. Lucas pointed out thatalthough Killingworth is larger, much of its mail carries a Deep River address because it uses the code assigned to Deep River. This is often the case with magazines and catalogues that use computerized mailing systems based on ZIP codes.
 
Cause of Delays
 That did not make much difference when both towns were small and postal clerks knew the addresses, Mr. Lucas said.
"But both towns have grown, and there are streets now that have similar names," Mr. Lucas said. "So it has meant delays in some mail deliveries."
Mr. Lucas, who took office last November, said his predecessors tried for more than a decade to get a ZIP code, mainly by writing to members of Congress.
But he said he appealed directly to the Postal Service.
 "I finally found somebody in a little back room who told me we were going to be getting our own ZIP code in July," Mr. Lucas said. "The 30 people we talked with before him all told us, 'We can't do it, the machines won't handle it.' "
 Mr. Teel related a similar experience. He said Salem was promised its own ZIP code more than two years ago, after it had gotten rid of its rural delivery routes and numbered all its streets.
"After we went to all that trouble," Mr. Teel said, "they told us they were putting in new optical scanning equipment and it would be a while before we could get our own ZIP code."
"Working through the bureaucracy of the Postal Service has been a real lesson in frustration," Mr. Lucas added.
But he said it had been worth it to get Killingworth's own ZIP code. He said he had ordered new town stationery and notified vendors of the change, even though it will not take effect for six months.
"I find it a matter of personal pride in one's community," Mr. Lucas said. "If you live in Killingworth, that's what it should say on your mail."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Many Print Ads Revive 'A Bare and Open Look'

BYLINE: By RANDALL ROTHENBERG

 BODY:
Wide open spaces are returning to American print advertising and publication design.
In newspaper and magazine advertisements for Toyota cars, Royal Viking cruise ships and Aspen, Colo., the gaps between letters, words and lines are growing wider. The mixing of disparate typefaces, which reached a peak in Entertainment Weekly and Spy magazines, is declining. Borders are reappearing around photographs and text that once bled to the edge of advertisements. And the "clutter" and "typographic frenzy" that Print magazine criticized in regional ads and magazines last year are settling down into a plain, no-frills look. 
 "There's been a kind of sea change over the last year," said Martin Fox, the vice president and editor of Print. "There has been a real return to simplicity, to a bare and open look in design. It's a reaction against the dense-looking page, against the mixing of styles, against the sense that design is its own artifact and that direct communication is not the most desired of goals."
 
The 'British Look'
 Some ad agency art directors and graphic designers are referring to the style as the "British look," because the ample spacing, ornate borders and traditional typefaces like Garamond and Goudy are borrowed from English book publishing.
Others, like David Metcalf and Dennis D'Amico, the co-creative directors of the Lowe & Partners agency, argue that the British were only appropriating the direct, open and occasionally witty style made famous by Ogilvy & Mather and Doyle Dane Bernbach in the 1960's.
Wherever the responsibility lies, the "British look" is one of several examples of a new simplicity in visual communications.
"Environmental issues, economic austerity and a state of war exist, so the post-modern design of the 80's no longer makes sense," said Philip B. Meggs, a design professor at Virginia Commonwealth University.
Until the 1960's, type was set on metal blocks that had fixed spaces between them. With the introduction of phototypesetting, art directors could cut type apart and set letters and words much closer together.
During the 1970's, ligatures -- letter combinations that touched -- became more prevalent. Condensed type grew increasingly popular. "Huge, tight, shouting headlines became de rigueur," Mr. D'Amico said.
The look grew even denser in the mid-1980's, when the so-called new wave graphic style, with its uncentered page, mixed typefaces and bright, primary colors attracted many designers. And computers allowed art directors to break apart and distort letters and words in previously impossible ways.
Today, however, "we're coming back to headlines you can actually read on the page," said Bob Cox, the creative director of Cox Landey & Partners, a New York ad agency.
 
'Fairly Ordinary-Looking Stuff'
 Not all graphic designers are entirely taken with the new look in print. Tibor Kalman, who has led the movement to reintroduce classic elements to print design, nevertheless said the new simplicity was "just another attempt to take fairly ordinary-looking stuff and give it class."
And Milton Glaser, the designer responsible for New York magazine and the interior of the A.&P. supermarkets, cautioned that the "British look" was but one of many design options for trend-seekers.
Russian constructivism and social-realist styling have also made a comeback that is most evident in ads for Lowenbrau beer and DHL Worldwide Express, which appropriate the look of New Deal-era posters.
But if anything is crowding American print advertising, it is nothing. Even the forthcoming International Design Conference in Aspen, of which Mr. Glaser is chairman, has taken it as its theme this year. The conference's title is "Bare Bones: Making More With Less."

HEADLINE: U.S. Policy Increases Abortions in Romania

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The lack of adequate contraceptive resources and services in Romania has forced women to rely on abortion as a primary method of birth control ("Romania Seeks to Reduce Abortions," news article, Jan. 17). Ironically, this tragedy can be partly attributed to United States policies to eradicate abortion. 
 Restrictive United States policies prohibit nongovernmental organizations from receiving assistance if they choose to counsel women about abortion. As a result, two respected and effective international organizations -- the International Planned Parenthood Federation and the United Nations Fund for Population Activities -- are barred from United States assistance. Though both have programs operating in Romania, Congress cannot name either as a recipient of funds to aid the situation in Romania.
Last June, the House of Representatives approved $1.5 million for family-planning programs in Romania. The funds were channeled through the Agency for International Development, which is bound by the restrictive policies. In a June 27 letter to several members of Congress, Ron Roskens, A.I.D. administrator, said A.I.D. could have family-planning programs in place in Romania "immediately." He named four organizations that could begin the programs.
These promises were made more than six months ago, but A.I.D. has not designated an organization to receive the $1.5 million, and no United States-funded programs have been implemented in Romania. Meanwhile, Romania's abortion rate has skyrocketed to 100,000 a month.
Because of our policies, the most capable family-planning organizations in Romania cannot receive United States funds. Instead, we waste our funds trying to replicate these organizations, and Romanian women pay the cost of our inefficiency. Representative Olympia Snowe and I will shortly reintroduce legislation that is aimed at halting these destructive and counterproductive United States policies.
 
CHET ATKINS
Member of Congress, 5th Dist., Mass.
Washington, Jan. 18, 1991

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Herman H. Kahn, 81, An Expert on Securities

 BODY:
Herman H. Kahn, a longtime partner in the Lehman Brothers investment banking firm, died on Friday at the Mary Manning Walsh Nursing Home in Manhattan. He was 81 years old and had homes in Palm Beach, Fla., and Manhattan.
He died of a stroke, his assistant, Ann Finkelson, said.
Mr. Kahn was born on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, graduated third in his class at the High School of Commerce and was a $15-a-week runner for Lehman while earning a bachelor's degree at night in economics and finance at New York University.
He soon specialized in statistics and security analysis and became a leading expert in private-placement financing -- the sale of securities to selected investors without their having to scramble for it in the open market. He became a partner at Lehman Brothers in 1950, and retired in 1986.
Mr. Kahn's clients included more than a score of the nation's major corporations, and he had been a director of the Allied Stores Corporation, Avco Corporation, Dayco Corporation, Fruehauf Corporation, Microwave Associates and the Seaboard Finance Company. He was a founder and president of the Herman and Ruth Kahn Foundation, which contributes to charitable, educational and cultural organizations.
Surviving are his wife, the former Ruth Schulman; a son, Sidney, of Locust Valley, L.I.; a daughter, Geraldine Karetsky of Aspen, Colo.; a sister, Sylvia Silber of Manhattan, and seven grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Japan Poised for Postwar Boom

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 27

 BODY:
With many countries struggling against slowdowns or recessions, economists are hanging on every development in the Persian Gulf for signs of how much economic damage the war is likely to cause. But few economies appear poised to benefit as much as Japan's in the event of a brief war, or have the staying power to endure a long war with as little strain, a range of experts say.
Japan has been criticized for contributing money but not personnel to help in the allied effort to force Iraq out of Kuwait, even though it is more dependent on Middle East oil than any other industrial country. Now some economists say that in the war's aftermath, Japan may enjoy the greatest economic boost, particularly if the risk of soaring oil prices is reduced.
 
A Difficult Transition
 This is not to say that Japan's economic forecast is entirely rosy. Even before the crisis began, Japan was in the midst of a difficult economic transition. Growth is slowing from its blistering pace of the last several years, a problem in a country that considers expansion of less than 3 percent a recession. The stock market plunged 40 percent last year as interest rates soared, corporate profits are falling, and many are predicting property prices will decline after big increases in the 1980's. The recession in the United States is also threatening to cut into Japanese exports. 
 Most menacing, economists say, are the glaring weaknesses in Japan's financial sector: many fear that a sharp slide in Japan's real estate prices is posing a threat to banks, which have made hundreds of billions of dollars of loans with land as collateral.
The mounting difficulties Japan faces sound similar, in fact, to those in the United States. But there is one huge difference: while America's policy makers are rapidly cutting interest rates and fighting to save banks, protect jobs and stave off an economic contraction, the Japanese Government has deliberately slowed the boom here by tightening its monetary policy and keeping interest rates high.
"The biggest possible cause of a recession in Japan is too tight a monetary policy by the Bank of Japan," said Takao Akabane, formerly the vice minister at the Economic Planning Agency.
Overly easy monetary policies during the latter half of the 1980's, then a severe tightening in the last year, are responsible for the current precarious balance in the markets, economists say.
It is a risky policy, to be sure, because the markets have already shown a tendency to spiral out of control when investors panic in the face of big price declines. But many analysts are confident that Japanese economic managers are skillful enough to succeed, barring a huge external shock.
"Our real fear is outside disturbances like the Persian Gulf, not internal forces," said Yoshihisa Kitai, chief economist at the Long Term Credit Bank. "As for the internal factors, the Bank of Japan has chosen this tight monetary policy so it can avert a collapse if it wants to" by trimming interest rates should the economy slow too much, he said.
Moreover, because of its long-standing budgetary conservatism, Tokyo has the leeway to increase growth with higher Government spending, if that becomes necessary. Japan has already agreed with the United States to increase public investment and could accelerate this program.
 
Revamping the Banking System
 Underlying the tight money is a broader policy goal that could affect Japan's financial system for years: the restructuring of the banking sector. The Finance Ministry wants to encourage smaller banks to merge with stronger institutions, forcing the long-protected institutions to be more competitive.
It was reported Friday in the Nihon Keizai Shimbun, Japan's leading economic daily, that the Finance Ministry had even created a special group within the deposit insurance system to handle mergers between small- and medium-sized banks. Ministry officials denied that such a mergers unit had been created, but the report was consistent with comments made publicly and privately by officials for months.
Many worry that this approach may succeed in improving the profitability and innovativeness of a few Japanese banks, while weakening many others and perhaps causing a rash of bank failures because of tight money and a crash in the property market. Any failures or crashes -- which have never occurred in Japan -- could strain the Government's ability to engineer a controlled strengthening of the industry.
 
Unprepared for a Shock
 Susumu Saito, director of the Trilateral Institute, a research and advisory body, warned that few banks were really prepared for another shock to either the stock market, on which they are dependent for capital, or the property market, on which so many of their loans are based. "Many of the banks are assuming that the worst is past," he said.
But Mr. Akabane, the former Government economic planner, said: "A severe economic situation would be an inviting time to restructure. The bureaucrats don't say this explicitly, but I think this is in their minds."
The overall goal is to produce a financial sector that would match in strength the vibrant health of the industrial economy, which was strengthened considerably by Government policies of the last five years. Big corporations used the booming markets of the late 1980's to remove debt from their balance sheets and go on an unprecedented capital spending binge, sharply improving their efficiency.
"There is going to be a shakeout among the regional banks and tremendous pressure on the city banks," said Kenneth Courtis, chief economist here for Deutsche Bank. "The Ministry of Finance clearly believes and says it will use this environment to restructure the sector. The trick is to accomplish this without causing a crash."
What Japan calls a slowdown, of course, would be a solid year in the United States. The economy grew 5.4 percent in 1990, with unemployment slightly higher than 2 percent and inflation close to 3 percent.
Officially, the Government is forecasting a 3.8 percent growth rate this year, as high interest rates begin to bite. The official discount rate for Government loans to banks has been jacked up to 6 percent, from 2.5 percent just 18 months ago.
There have been a rash of real estate-induced bankruptices as a result, not to mention the collapse of stock prices last year. In December alone, the number of business failures rose 45 percent.
 
Few See Doom
 Some economists see growth of closer to 3 percent in 1991, but few accept the predictions of doom that have made headlines in recent weeks.
"The world has seriously mistaken what has happened in Japan," said Richard Koo, a senior economist at the Nomura Research Institute. "The Bank of Japan is trying to slow the economy with every tool they have. This is a policy-led slowdown because it's the only way they can clear out all the excesses of the past few years, when monetary policy was too easy."
Added Susumu Kato, chief economist for Goldman, Sachs (Japan): "There are problems, but they're manageable. We don't see those kind of crash scenarios taking place."
Indeed, hardly a day passes when Yasushi Mieno, the governor of the central bank, does not deliver another insistent sermon on the need to keep interest rates high to bring sky-high property prices down and cool the economy. He has said publicly that he would not mind a decline in land prices of 20 percent, a figure that he also said would not cause unmanageable losses for banks.
"The extreme case is several hundred billion yen in losses from real estate loans for each major bank," said Mr. Kitai. "But I still see the chances of this extreme case as relatively low."
 
Lower Debt Ratings
 Even some of the tougher critics of Japanese banks take this view. For instance, Moody's Investors Service, the credit-rating agency, stunned many here by lowering the ratings of Japan's big banks over the past year, warning of real estate-related difficulties.
But Roger Arner, head of the Tokyo office of Moody's, said his concerns were for the profitability of the banks in a tough environment, not their ability to survive, as is the case with many large American banks.
"You have to remember that their ratings are still very high, on balance," Mr. Arner said. "This is not New York."

HEADLINE: Tool Orders For Factories Rise 43.7%

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
The machine tool industry reported a surge in capital spending by American manufacturers in December.
New orders for American-made machine tools climbed 43.7 percent in December from November, to the highest point since September 1989, according to a monthly report by the industry's trade association. 
 New orders for machine tools increased to $291.3 million in December, from $202.7 million a month earlier, the Association for Manufacturing Technology said in a monthly report to be released today.
 
'Spending Plans Are Holding'
 "The continued strong order levels are an indication that capital spending plans are holding firm despite current economic weakness," said Albert W. Moore, president of the association, which is based in McLean, Va. "The mentality of United States manufacturers has changed. Investment is no longer the first thing cut from the budget when a downturn approaches."
Machine tools are power-driven devices that cut or shape metal parts used in products ranging from appliances and vehicles to aircraft and construction materials. The strength of tool orders generally reflects the strength of industrial production, and economists consider patterns of machine tool sales to be important indicators of capital spending by manufacturers.
The increase in orders in December was magnified by the poor showing in November, when orders fell 24.1 percent from October's level. Orders in October had increased only slightly from September. Orders are often volatile at the end of the year because auto makers, which are large buyers, generally shut down production then for several weeks.
For all of 1990, machine tool orders were up 5.4 percent, to $2.96 billion, from the 1989 level of $2.8 billion. The growth in new orders last year was largely attributed to foreign customers, who have found American-made machine tools attractively priced because of the declining value of the dollar. Orders from foreign customers increased 16.8 percent last year from their 1989 level. Orders from domestic customers were up 3.7 percent for the year.
But orders from domestic customers showed particular strength in December, rising 57.3 percent from November's level. Compared with December 1989, all machine tool orders were up 41.2 percent, the report said.
Compared with November's level, shipments of machine tools rose 31.2 percent in December, to $350.9 million. Shipments were up 45.8 percent to foreign customers, and 28.4 percent to domestic customers, from November's levels.
Analysts and executives of machine tool companies said that orders for machine tools from the aerospace industry had remained firm and that orders from auto makers had begun to rebound after languishing for most of the year. Auto makers typically account for more than a third of all orders, and sluggishness in that industry caused machine tool orders to slow for much of 1990.
 
Shifting Money to Production
 "The machine tool industry has been and will be helped by higher orders from the automotive industry for new production equipment," said Eli S. Lustgarten, a machine tool analyst with Paine Webber Inc. He added that because of new clean air legislation "uncertainties have begun to unfold and the auto companies appear to be in the process of shifting expenditures back to their production facilities."
