HEADLINE: Many Builders Say Inspectors Expect Bribes

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
The bribing of city inspectors to obtain approval to occupy new or completely renovated apartment buildings is widespread in New York, developers and contractors say.
Sometimes inspectors take money in return for overlooking construction problems in a building, 16 contractors, developers and architects said in separate interviews. 
 More often, they said, builders pay bribes simply to avoid time-consuming delays that can cost tens of thousands of dollars in additional financing, lost revenues and related expenses. The builders said inspectors were commonly paid to push forward the paper work and physical inspections needed to obtain the critical final city approval, a certificate of occupancy. The certificate signifies that construction has been completed and enables an owner to let tenants move in.
 
'The More Weapons They Have'
 "If you are a contractor playing it straight, you can have a hard time getting things done," a housing developer said. "When you help move the process along financially, you don't avoid the legal requirements. But at least you move the process along."
A contractor, who acknowledged that he had paid bribes to avoid inspectors' delays, said: "The layers of rules and regulations just breeds this kind of response. The more things are open to interpretation, the more weapons they have to stymie you."
Those builders, like nearly all of those interviewed, spoke only on the condition of anonymity. They said they feared that if they were identified, inspectors would retaliate by withholding approvals on current and future projects.
Those who conceded that they had paid bribes or paid people to pay bribes were unwilling to say so publicly because those are crimes.
 
Four Months for a Certificate
 City officials said that some inspectors did accept bribes, but that corruption was not nearly as pervasive as most people in the housing industry believed.
An experienced developer in Manhattan, Norman Segal, said it took him four months to obtain a certificate of occupancy after his crews had reconstructed an abandoned six-story apartment building in Harlem last June. It usually takes four to six weeks for the certificate, many developers and contractors said. Mr. Segal said that he would not pay bribes and that he suspected that was why the approval took so long. He added that no inspector directly solicited a bribe, but that he thought inspectors' actions demonstrated that they were punishing him for having failed to offer money.
There were no major problems in his building, at 241 West 113th Street, Mr. Segal contended. The reconstruction was financed largely by the city to create subsidized housing affordable for working people.
Responding to the broader questions raised by Mr. Segal and the other developers, contractors and architects, Buildings Commissioner Rudolph J. Rinaldi said some corruption undoubtedly existed. But he also said it was not as pervasive as many people thought.
"Most of the people are honest," Mr. Rinaldi said of his department's 300 inspectors. Sixty-two examine basic construction. The rest conduct more specialized inspections, like those for plumbing or electricity.
 
'To Encourage You to Offer'
 The final approval for his building was held up, Mr. Segal said, by a series of bureaucratic obstacles, including many missed appointments and paper work that was lost by inspectors, and the continual raising of minor objections after previous objections had been satisfied.
"The problem is that the system is administered by the supervisors to encourage you to offer money," Mr. Segal said. "The regulations are used only to prevent you from doing something, not to expedite it."
Mr. Segal said the delays cost him $40,000 in lost rentals. It undoubtedly would have been cheaper, he said, to have paid a bribe. He said he did not know how much he would have had to pay for his relatively small building, which has 24 apartments.
 
'City Spent a Fortune'
 "But the larger issue," Mr. Segal said, "is it was three or four months that people couldn't live in the building, a building that the city spent a fortune to rebuild."
In essence, he contended, building inspectors temporarily sabotaged a part of the ambitious program created by another municipal agency, the Department of Housing Preservation and Development.
The housing department spent $43,000 an apartment for the renovation under a $5.1 billion 12-year housing program. Mr. Segal paid the rest of the cost, which came to $65,000 an apartment altogether, financing most of it. Tenants are drawn from a lottery, and they have to be low- and moderate-income New Yorkers.
Mr. Rinaldi called Mr. Segal's case "a strange one." After his top aides reviewed the department's files on the building, Mr. Rinaldi said he concluded that much of the delay was the developer's fault.
Several safety issues had to be resolved before the building could be occupied, the Commissioner said. On three occasions between last July and October, he said, inspectors issued objections about the fire escapes at the building. The rear escape had been removed, Mr. Rinaldi said, and a new escape was added on the side of the building in October.
 
Question of the Original Plan
 The changes required amendments to the approved architectural plan, Mr. Rinaldi added, making it more difficult for Mr. Segal to obtain the final approval. If the developer had wanted swift approval, he should not have altered his plan, Mr. Rinaldi said.
But Mr. Segal said the Commissioner was mistaken. The original plan, approved by the Buildings Department, called for the removal of the rear escape and the new one on the side, he said. There was no reason for the inspectors to issue objections, because there was no problem with the escape, he said.
"None of their explanations are really plausible," Mr. Segal said.
 
Fewer Than 10 Arrested
 Federal, state and city law-enforcement agencies have been investigating the inspectors for two years trying to find bribe takers, he said, adding that fewer than 10 had been arrested.
"There is something going on, but it is not as prevalent as everyone thinks," Mr. Rinaldi said.
He said he had repeatedly made it clear that he would not tolerate inspectors' accepting bribes. Inspectors are rotated, to make it more diffcult for build up familiarity with contractors. Appointments for inspections, which used to be made by the inspectors, who could reward friends, are now made solely by clerks.
Mr. Rinaldi said he had told the inspectors that undercover employees of the Building Department would offer them bribes. "The word is entrap," he said. "We told them, 'We have people in the department who are going to offer you money.' "
 
Acceptance of $5
 The money was offered a few times and declined, the Commissioner said. But within two weeks of the initial warning, an inspector accepted $5 from an undercover worker and was discharged.
"Has this kind of thing happened in the past?" a deputy commissioner, Stewart D. O'Brien, asked. "Unfortunately yes. Has it continued? Unfortunately yes."
Contractors, developers and architects contended, though, that bribe-taking continued to be common. "Some inspectors are always looking for it, and some aren't," a contractor said. "It's pretty blatant."
Obtaining a certificate of occupancy is critical in development. Contractors can usually collect their remaining fees and free up letters of credit only after obtaining final approvals. Developers can begin charging rent and gain long-term financing only after they are granted.
The certificate's financial significance gives inspectors enormous leverage. Builders also said the complexity of the Building Code gave inspectors wide latitude in granting final approvals.
 
Hand Signals and Code Words
 Many contractors and developers said that a bribe was usually just part of the cost of doing business in New York and that it was less expensive than the cost of a delay in obtaining a final approval. No one was willing to detail the size of a typical bribe.
"It's much cheaper to pay it, and they know it," said a contractor with wide experience in the city.
Inspectors never directly solicit a bribe, contractors and developers said. They use hand signals or code words to indicate their intentions. The contractors, including some who said they had paid bribes, declined to describe the signals and code words.
A person familiar with construction and development said a contractor had recently told him this account: Eager to obtain final approval on a building, the contractor was sent by an inspector to see his supervisor. The contractor met the supervisor in the official's office, where the supervisor shook hands and identified himself as "Mr. Green." The contractor was confused, because that was not the name listed on the office door. Then he realized that the supervisor was not identifying himself but was describing the desired form of payment -- cash.
 
Major Cases Six Year Ago
 Accusations that inspectors use their economic leverage to elicit bribes are not new. In 1984, in separate undercover sting operations, city and Federal officials arrested 10 water and sewer inspectors, 12 electrical inspectors and 2 supervisors in bribery cases.
The officials said then that they were amazed how pervasive the corruption appeared to be. They also said new law-enforcement techniques, including undercover operations, offered hope of altering long-entrenched patterns of corruption.
But contractors and developers asserted that the patterns have continued. Some practices have become more subtle, they said, in part because of fears of being caught.
Payment is never made if more than two people are present, contractors and developers said, and usually the person handing over the money has to be well known to the inspector. Sometimes an intermediary, a consultant called an expediter, passes the money to an inspector, many builders said.
"We hire expediters, which is a legal way of paying someone to pay someone," a developer said. "That's the difference between getting it done and not getting it done."
"All I know is that we when hire expediters who are well known down there," he said, referring to the Buildings Department, "it gets done, usually in extraordinary time. And when we don't, things go much more slowly. Appointments get missed, and new objections are constantly raised."

HEADLINE: Investors Challenging Banks on Bad Loans

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Shareholders and the Securities and Exchange Commission are questioning whether some banks violated securities laws by concealing bad loans for months before they announced large losses.
Bankers and their lawyers respond that the large increase in loan losses reflects the rapid deterioration of the economy and the decline in real estate prices, events that are beyond their control. 
 Lawyers for shareholders who have filed suits against banks say the banks were required to disclose the problems months before they were reported.
Many of the questions have been raised about banks in the Northeast, where loan losses have been greatest. Lawsuits have been filed against such well-known banking companies as Citicorp and the Bank of New England, as well as small New Hampshire banks that are little known outside the state.
At the Securities and Exchange Commission, a special task force in the Division of Enforcement has been concentrating on banks and savings institutions for a year.
The S.E.C. team consists of 16 lawyers and 5 accountants. It has been operating at full strength for about six months and has more than 20 investigations under way, said Joseph Goldstein, an assistant director at the commission. "The most common theme is that income was overstated as a result of an understatement of loan-loss reserves," he said.
A bank's loan-loss reserve is supposed to represent management's estimate of losses expected on bad loans. Banks have been reporting huge losses because the money added to these reserves every quarter is subtracted from profits.
A lawyer whose firm has been representing shareholders in lawsuits against banks suggested that many banks had understated their loan problems to preserve the appearance of profitability in their financial reports.
"The provision of reserves for bad loans is, to a large degree, discretionary, and many banks take advantage of that to mislead the public," said Mark C. Rifkin, a lawyer at Greenfield & Chimicles, a law firm in Haverford, Pa. Mr. Rifkin added that "although shareholders own the company, they are outsiders who don't have access to the records showing how much a bank knew about its problems and when they knew it."
 
Proving Fraud
 One of the great difficulties shareholders face in their lawsuits is obtaining information to show that a bank knowingly concealed bad news. In some cases, judges have said that comparing a heavy loss with optimistic statements made by bank management in previous quarters is not enough to prove fraud. Several of these cases have been dismissed before shareholders had an opportunity to study internal bank documents.
On Friday, a Federal judge in Rhode Island dismissed a lawsuit by a disgruntled investor who claimed that the Eastland Financial Corporation, a banking company in Woonsocket, R.I., had fraudulently exaggerated its financial health in the months before the bank announced a large loss in September 1989.
The court said the shareholder, Marshall Haft, failed to describe specifically how fraud was committed. "A complaint must do more than offer speculation," Judge Raymond J. Pattine said in dismissing the suit. "It must make some step toward showing that fraud was actually committed."
Some judges have been more sympathetic to investors and have denied banks' requests that the lawsuits be dismissed. Motions to dismiss shareholder suits against the Midlantic Corporation in Edison, N.J., and the Northeast Bancorp in New Haven, have recently been denied, clearing the way for shareholders to collect more detailed information, said Mr. Rifkin, whose firm was involved in the suits. Other banking companies facing shareholder lawsuits handled by Greenfield & Chimicles include the Boston-based Bank of New England, which was recently taken over by Federal regulators, and the Dime Savings Bank of New York and Citicorp.
Douglas M. Kraus, a partner at Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, a New York law firm representing Eastland Financial, said some lawyers were taking advantage of bank losses by "claiming in effect that the bank's alleged failure to predict the current recession or to avoid its effects amounts to security fraud." In addition to the Eastland case, he said a shareholder suit against MNC Financial, the holding company for Maryland National Bank, was also dismissed recently.
 
'Litigation Factory'
 Lawyers at Skadden, Arps complained that 11 shareholder suits handled by Stull, Stull & Brody, a New York law firm, used almost identical language even though the financial condition and loan portfolios of the banking companies differ widely.
In a suit against the Greater New York Savings Bank brought by a shareholder represented by Stull Stull & Brody, lawyers at Skadden, Arps charged that the similarity of language in all 11 suits presents "a clear picture of a litigation factory."
Officials at Stull, Stull & Brody, declined to discuss the issue.
Other banking companies sued by shareholders represented by Stull, Stull & Brody include the Bank of New England Corporation; the BankWorcester Corporation, Worcester, Mass.; Barnett Banks, Jacksonville, Fla.; Eastchester Financial Corporation, White Plains, and the Southeast Banking Corporation, Miami. Three bank companies in Manchester, N.H., were also sued by shareholders represented by Stull, Stull & Brody: Amoskeag Bank Shares, the BankEast Corporation, and the United Savers Bancorporation, which changed its name to Dartmouth Bancorp last April.

HEADLINE: End of Jobless Benefits Pushes Many Near Despair

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TROY, Ohio, Jan. 25

 BODY:
Swollen and weary in her ninth month of pregnancy, 28-year-old Lisa Bramlette sat chatting at her kitchen table while her 5-year-old son, Tyler, romped around the house in a Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtle outfit.
Mrs. Bramlette's mother, Edith Crowell, was by her side in case labor began because Mrs. Bramlette's husband, William, was more than 1,000 miles away in Florida. "He doesn't know what's going on with me," Mrs. Bramlette said. "While he's down there working, he doesn't know if I'm in labor or if the baby's here until I call him at 9:30 each night." 
 Laid off a year ago from his job at Dinner Bell Foods, a local meat packing plant, Mr. Bramlette has been taking odd jobs ever since he exhausted his unemployment insurance benefits in July. Recently, he and a friend were hired by a local woman to help her parents pack up their home in Clearwater, Fla., and move back to Ohio.
"This really stinks," Mr. Bramlette said by telephone from Clearwater. "I really don't like it, but you have to do what you have to do, and we need the money."
 
Running Out of Benefits
 The 40-year-old Mr. Bramlette is one of about 2.3 million jobless people nationwide who used up all their unemployment benefits in 1990, a 16 percent increase over the year before. The number is expected to jump again this spring when those who were laid off as the recession took hold in recent months begin to run out of benefits.
In addition, a recent study by Mathematica Policy Research, based in Princeton, N.J., determined that 75 percent of the unemployed had not found work four weeks after their benefits had expired, and 60 percent were still jobless 10 weeks after depleting their benefits.
Yet, unlike its actions in the recessions of 1975, 1980 and 1982, Congress has not acted to extend unemployment benefits beyond the maximum period allowed by individual states. At present, 48 states provide unemployment compensation for a maximum of 26 weeks. Massachusetts and Washington allow a maximum of 30 weeks.
Any benefits paid beyond the states' maximum period are shared by the states and the Federal Government. But changes in Federal law in the 1980's made it more difficult for states to pay benefits beyond the basic period, and no states are currently paying those extended benefits. In contrast 30 states paid extended benefits in 1982.
Representative Thomas J. Downey, a Suffolk Democrat who is acting chairman of the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Human Resources, which has jurisdiction over unemployment compensation, said he would introduce legislation next month to ease the restrictions on states' payment of extended benefits.
"We have consciously denied people the benefits they need and deserve," he said.
 
Thousands of Job Applications
 Any liberalizing of the law could have a significant effect on Troy, a blue-collar town set amid cornfields 20 miles north of Dayton. In December, the jobless rate for Miami County, where Troy is the county seat, was 6.1 percent, matching the national average, but above the 5.8 percent mark for Ohio as a whole.
For many in Troy who have bleak job prospects and have depleted their unemployment benefits, life seems perilously close to the financial and emotional edge. Bills go unpaid, houses and automobiles remain in need of repair, medical insurance is allowed to lapse and self-confidence is damaged.
Six years ago, when she had her first child, Mrs. Bramlette quit her job in her third month of pregnancy. This time she continued to work as a sales representative for an insurance company until Thursday, four days after the baby was due. Even so, the Bramlettes were $300 behind on their utility bill and got through Christmas only by using food donated by Mr. Bramlette's former union.
The pressure was too much for Mrs. Bramlette. On the night before Mr. Bramlette left for Florida, she erupted, pouring out her anger and frustration until 3 A.M.
"I'm holding down the fort," she complained the other day, her blue eyes blazing. "I'm paying the bills. I'm paying his child support. I'm keeping things together. I'm pregnant. I'm tired, and I can't do it all."
 
Work When the Weather Is Good
 In good years, Daniel Dever, 34, earned $20,000 to $25,000 a year boning hams at Dinner Bell Foods. After he lost his job a year ago, he collected $257 a week in unemployment benefits until the end of July. Since then, he has worked three days a week at a local carwash when the weather is good enough. He earns $4.16 an hour.
His family gets by with the income from Mr. Dever's two stepsons who live with him in his three-bedroom home. One earns $7 an hour at a local fiberglass factory and the other makes $4 an hour at another factory. But even with his stepsons' earnings, Mr. Dever has not paid his $407 mortgage payment in three months and is afraid he might lose his house. Mr. Dever and his wife have no medical insurance, and he failed to renew the insurance on his 1977 Ford because he could not pay the $200 premium.
"This is the first time since I had a driver's license that I haven't had insurance on a car that I own," Mr. Dever said. "I just hope I don't get into an accident."
For Mike and Gail Lee, the concern is staying healthy. "We don't have any health insurance," said Mr. Lee, 42, "If either one of us gets sick, everything will be gone." Until Mrs. Lee recently got a job earning $64 a week as a part-time teacher's aide, the Lees had been out of work for more than a year. Their unemployment checks stopped coming last fall.
The Lees have been able to hold onto their house by taking in Mrs. Lee's son by a previous marriage and his wife, who both hold temporary jobs. "I don't want to lose my home and all the stuff we have," said Mrs. Lee, her voice cracking. "But how do we get out of this situation? I don't know if we will."
 
Savings Nearly Depleted
 So far, Wayne Larck, 40, does not have the same sense of desperation as the Lees, though he has traveled throughout the area looking for work. Unlike the Lees, Mr. Larck has paid off the mortgage on his home, and his jobless benefits just expired last month.
Nonetheless, after he pays his next property tax bill, Mr. Larck said his savings will be nearly depleted. To save money, he and his wife, Gloria, 41, eat only one meal a day. Despite his own troubles, Mr. Larck says he is more concerned about his son, Donald, who is with the Army in Saudi Arabia. "So far, we worry about our boy more than anything else," he said.
Miscalculations and misinformation have contributed to the plight of some of the former Dinner Bell workers whose unemployment checks have stopped. Mr. Dever, for example, has not applied for welfare or food stamps, believing that he is ineligible because he owns his house. Officials at the Ohio Department of Human Services say home ownership does not necessarily disqualify a person from receiving public assistance or food stamps.
Rather than looking for another job immediately after he was let go, Mr. Lee bought a restaurant in Springfield, Ohio, 21 miles from Troy. He lost $15,000, virtually his life savings. when it failed. By the time he began searching for work, the recession had taken hold and job prospects had dried up.
"I've just got to find a job or it's not going to work at all," he said softly. "I have to find a job."

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Oil Workers;
Americans at Aramco Report Facing Job Loss if They Leave

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia, Jan. 27

 BODY:
Frightened by almost nighly attacks by Iraqi missiles, American employees of the Saudi national oil company are describing themselves as economic hostages, forced to choose between their jobs and their safety.
Several American and other Western employees of the Government-controlled Saudi Arabian Oil Company, or Saudi Aramco, said they had been told by their managers in recent days that if they left the country, they would face dismissal. 
 "I feel like I'm being held against my will," said John Saadi, an electrical engineer from Boston who has worked at Aramco for 12 years. "I feel in danger."
Despite the threat to their jobs, many of the 3,000 Americans who work for the oil company -- Aramcons, as they call themselves -- are gathering up their families and leaving anyway.
"I see no reason for the company taking this stance that it's business as usual," said Kathy Cox, who spent much of the weekend packing up her life's belongings in preparation for returning to the United States.
 
Sacrificing Early Retirement
 A 54-year-old teacher at Aramco's English-language school, she resigned from her job even though she is only seven months shy of her 10th anniversary at Aramco, a milestone that would have entitled her to early retirement.
She is part of an exodus of foreign workers from scores of companies in eastern Saudi Arabia who despite the loss of their salaries and their pensions, are fearful of remaining here while Iraqi missiles continue to be fired into the country.
Aramco's senior vice president for industrial relations, Abdallah Jumah, acknowledged in an interview that some workers were being offered a stark choice between leaving Saudi Arabia and keeping their jobs.
"We are not holding anybody against his will," Mr. Jumah said. "All we are saying to our employees is, look, you are here because we need you, and we need you now. If you leave, you will have to forfeit certain things that you otherwise would have."
 
Began as American Company
 It is an attitude that many employees say is destroying the trust built up over decades between Aramco and its thousands of expatriate workers. The company dates to 1933, when Standard Oil of California received a concession from the Saudi Government to drill for oil. Until 1974, Aramco was owned by American oil companies.
Beyond concern over their job security, foreign workers at Aramco complain that the company, which pumps 96 percent of Saudi Arabia's oil, has also been slow in demonstrating concern for their safety.
Until late last week, the company lacked an adequate air-raid warning system, and some workers who live in Aramco housing said they had slept through the initial missile attacks on Dhahran. Large pieces of shrapnel from the missiles have been found in the Aramco compound here.
"Basically you're going to have a hard time finding anybody who is real pleased with the way the company is handling the situation," said Robert Cashill, a 44-year-old industrial engineer from Newark who has worked at Aramco for eight years.
Mr. Cashill spent Friday night huddled with his wife in a bathroom in his home in the sprawling Aramco complex in Dhahran -- the bathroom has no windows that might shatter in an attack -- waiting for the all-clear to sound after a volley of Iraqi missiles.
The Cashills carry their gas masks almost everywhere, fearing that one of the Iraqi missiles might carry some of the chemical or biological agents that Iraq is known to have stockpiled.
 
'Coercion' Is Criticized
 Jack Devine, a geologist from Saskatchewan, Canada, who has worked at Aramco for 12 years, described the company's handling of its employees during the war as "heavy-handed."
"They seem to think that by coercion and force, they can keep people on the job," he said.
One of the geologists on his staff has already left, and the other was scheduled to leave today. "He's pretty shook up," Mr. Devine said.
Although there have been no reports of injuries from Iraqi missile attacks on Dhahran, a Saudi man was killed and 23 other people injured Friday when the warhead from one of the Iraqi Scud-B missiles landed in downtown Riyadh, the Saudi capital.
It was the first death from a Scud attack on Saudi Arabia. Most of the Scuds launched against Saudi Arabia have been intercepted by American-made Patriot missiles.

HEADLINE: Soviets Said to Hedge on War With Future in Mind

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
Administration officials said today that they viewed the statements by the Soviet Foreign Minister, Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, cautioning the United States against destroying Iraq as the beginning of an effort by the Soviet Union to preserve its influence in the Arab world in the aftermath of the Persian Gulf war.
A senior Administration official, speaking after Mr. Bessmertnykh's talks Saturday night with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, said that for now the Bush Administration was notparticularly concerned about the Foreign Minister's remarks, which were the harshest criticism leveled by Moscow against American policy in the gulf since the crisis began. 
 The official said Washington would really be concerned about the Soviet Union only if it showed any sign of supporting the various efforts by North African and nonaligned countries to have the United Nations order a cease-fire in the war.
The official said that neither in public nor in private did Mr. Bessmertnykh evince any support for a cease-fire, which Washington has opposed on the ground that it would only give theIraqis a chance to regroup.
"The Soviets are positioning themselves with the Arabs for the aftermath of the war," the official said. "They are thinking about the future. But they have also made clear that they are still totally on board with us. The important thing is that they are not joining in the calls for a cease-fire. That is key."
Another Administration official said, "What Mr. Bessmertnykh was doing was trying to put an arm's length between us and the Soviets regarding the actual conduct of the war." The Soviet Union, this official said, does not want to be inextricably linked to the United States in case Iraq is devastated andthere is a backlash in the Arab world.
Speaking to reporters after his talks with Mr. Baker, Mr. Bessmertnykh walked a fine line, saying: "I have never put in doubt the commitment by the Soviet Union or the United States or any other member of the alliance to the Security Council resolutions. I think what's being done is in complete accord with those resolutions. They are intended to free Kuwait from oppression."
With Mr. Baker at his side, the Soviet minister added: "The source of the concern that I have expressed before is that there may be a danger of the conflict going more in the direction of the destruction of Iraq and in the direction of involving more casualites on both sides. So we have to think about it and try to avoid it."
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney saidtoday on the NBC News program "Meet the Press" that the Pentagon had no evidence to substantiate press reports that factions of the Soviet military were sending truckloads of equipment into Iraq through Iran.
Administration experts on Soviet affairs say a fundamental breach in the two countries' attitudes toward the gulf could come in the aftermath of the war.
American officials are already talking about instituting some type of "security structure" in the gulf that would protect Kuwait and Saudi Arabia from future attacks by Iraq or Iran. Although the officials have not said so publicly, such a structure would involve in the short term an American ground presence in the gulf and in the longer term an expanded American naval presence, as well as pre-positioned military supplies in Saudi Arabia.
The Soviet military is said to be uncomfortable with such a permanent increased American military presence along the Soviet Union's southern flank.
The Baker-Bessmertnykh talks on Saturday were devoted largely to the situation in the Baltics, an American official said. Mr. Bessmertnykh tried to impress upon Mr. Baker the point that if the United States and its Western European allies imposed economic sanctions on Moscow because of the Soviet crackdown in the Baltics, it would only serve to undercut President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's position. He said it would strengthen conservative forces in the Kremlin who are ambivalent about the improvement in Soviet-American relations to begin with, American officials said.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Congress;
Explaining War Votes Back in Home Districts

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
Senator Sam Nunn scrapped a speech on the economy and spent three hours with the Chamber of Commerce in Gainesville, Ga., the other day, laying out details of tactics and strategy in the Persian Gulf war. He also explained his vote against authorizing the use of force.
But, like many Democrats all over the country, Mr. Nunn insisted that "this debate is over," and that he was squarely behind his country's war. Members of the chamber listened intently. 
 Senator Al Gore, who voted to support the use of force, traveled through his home state of Tennessee and found audiences "pensive." He said he was struck by how often people who strongly disagreed with his vote "recognize some legitimacy in the arguments on the other side."
The approaches of these two potential Democratic Presidential candidates mirrored what dozens of other lawmakers were doing in recent days, discussing their positions on a war that divided the nation before it began and now enjoys overwhelming support.
As Republicans were firing their first partisan salvo on Democrats who voted against force, members of Congress were hearing a complex variety of responses from their constituents. The variety underlined the risks in instant political judgments about how votes on the war will affect politics, Presidential and Congressional.
 
Conflicting Message
 Some lawmakers got conflicting messages at the same time. Representative Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn, got 949 critical letters from his district and only 61 backing his vote for the use of force. But he found that the reaction in person -- from audiences at speeches to people passing him on the street -- almost the reverse and "extraordinarily supportive."
Representative Ed Jenkins, a Georgia Democrat who represents Gainesville, said he was sure the voters of his district disagreed with his vote against the use of force, but "they're not angry." He credits that partly to the quality of the Congressional debate on the war. "People were very, very impressed with the caliber of the debate and what they were hearing and learning," he said, and this led many to tell him that while they disagreed with him, "I respect your position."
Prof. Gary Jacobson of the University of California at San Diego, one of the nation's foremost experts on Congressional elections, said he believed that the war vote, pro or con, was a vote that should not cost members of Congress support because they had taken care to explain their views carefully. On a major issue like this, he said, a vote that can be thoughtfully explained is likely to be safe.
The sort of political calculus commonly employed in Washington looked on Mr. Nunn's "no" vote as one that helped soften his generally conservative image with the liberals who traditionally dominate Democratic Presidential nominating contests. It treated the more liberal Mr. Gore's "yes" vote as one that covered his right flank. Each Senator laughed off the assumed motivation.
 
Big Factor: How the War Goes
 The intentions aside, the biggest uncertainty about political impact, on the Presidential hopes of Mr. Nunn or Mr. Gore or even President Bush, or the prospects for a second term in the House of someone like Representative Larry LaRocco of Idaho, is whether the war goes well or badly.
A quick, easy war seemed to be the assumption behind this week's attack by Clayton K. Yeutter, the new chairman of the Republican National Committee on Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska and other Democrats who voted against authorizing force. He said they could suffer for their votes in the 1992 elections.
But some elected Republicans were more cautious. One of the most partisan Republicans in the House, Representative Robert S. Walker of Pennsylvania, said, "It was for most members a vote of conscience." The Lancaster Congressman, who voted for force, said that if the news turned bad "we have vulnerabilities."
"Our vote of conscience has a definite down side," he said.
There was plainly Democratic concern, and just after the war started, both houses passed resolutions pledging their support to the troops and to President Bush. Many members, like Senator Nunn and Speaker Thomas S. Foley, had punctuated their speeches against force by saying they would support the use of force if they lost the vote in Congress, as they expected to.
 
A Sudden Change in Reaction
 And Mr. Nunn explained this week in Gainesville that he had always said war and force were justified against Iraq, but that his doubts were about timing and whether all other options had been exhausted. Moreover, he said, support was now easy because "when our men and women are on the battlefield, and when the shooting starts, I believe we must all stand together with them as they unfurl the flag and face the foe."
Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota noted a sudden transformation of reaction. His mail ran heavy before the vote, with 95 percent of it in opposition to force. But now, with a war on and South Dakotans fearful for their friends and relatives in the service, the issue is different. "These people can no longer afford the luxury of arguing the policy," he said, adding that their concerns are now that the troops be "safe and successful."
Even with the sudden transformation of national public opinion, from an even split on war or sanctions before the bombing began to nearly four to one support for war after it started, some supporters of the war, like Mr. Solarz or Representative Mel Levine, a Santa Monica, Calif., Democrat, encountered protests. Mr. Levine, whose district office was occupied by antiwar protesters before his vote for force, faces a threat of another sit-in if he does not hold a large meeting with his constituents who are critical of his vote, a step that his spokesman said he was unwilling to take for security reasons.
 
Importance of Being Honest
 But for many lawmakers, there is a suprising calm. Representative Jim Olin, a Democrat from Lynchburg, Va., said that before his vote against force he got a great deal of mail in opposition to war. Since then, though he is sure his district backs Mr. Bush, he said, "I've heard almost nothing from anybody."
Mr. LaRocco said he, too, was experiencing "a bit of a lull." In three town meetings he held after voting against force, he said, "I really didn't take any flak over it."
Representative Gene Taylor, a Democrat from Gulfport, Miss., said that his mail had stayed supportive of his vote against the use of force, and that while one Republican State Representative had threatened to offer a resolution against him a number of military veterans in the Mississippi Legislature had squelched that effort.
Again and again, lawmakers said that explaining their position thoughtfully had been critical. Representative Stephen L. Neal, a Democrat from Winston-Salem, N.C., said he knew his vote against force "may come back to haunt me some day." But for now, he said, he was confident that "voters understand that no representative is going to agree with them all the time."
"People understand," he said. "If you've done your homework and thought about your vote, they'll support you."
And Wyche Fowler Jr., Georgia's junior Senator, said he had never thought this would be a politically critical vote for him. "Most people accept that when you're voting on matters of life and death you vote devoid of political consideration," he said.

HEADLINE: Slump Forcing Up Albany's Aid to Poor

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 27

 BODY:
In blaming New York's fiscal slide on the national recession, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has been highlighting the corrosive effect of hard times on state revenues. But the recession is also applying great pressure to the spending side of the state budget by increasing the mandated costs of caring for the poor.
After several years of steady decline, the state's caseloads of public welfare and Medicaid recipients started to rise steeply in late 1989, and the growth is projected to continue unabated through this year. State budget officials expect the welfare rolls, which averaged 1.28 million people in 1990, to grow by nearly 100,000 people. 
 Welfare and Medicaid are programs any state resident is entitled to join if he or she is poor enough. The state is required to cover much of their costs, along with the Federal and local governments. And as the economy worsens, more people qualify and the costs rise. At the current rate, the costs would rise by hundreds of millions of dollars, although plans abound in Albany for ways of cutting them back.
"You have a fabric of social programs that are means tested, and they all closely reflect what's going on in the economy," said Russell Sykes, a policy analyst for the State Communities Aid Association, a nonprofit group that lobbies for social service programs.
 
15 Percent Medicaid Rise Seen
 Officials in the Cuomo administration said the Governor's 1991-92 budget, which will be released on Thursday, would include growth of about $600 million for Medicaid, a 15 percent increase, and about $130 million in welfare costs, a 12 percent increase.
Because state revenues are growing less than 2 percent, those increases contribute significantly to the $6 billion budget gap that Mr. Cuomo announced on Thursday. In this year's $29.2 billion budget, those programs ran about $75 million over budget, adding to a $900 million deficit that the Governor will close through short-term borrowing at the end of this fiscal year in March. That borrowing, in turn, will contribute nearly $1 billion to the $6 billion figure.
Most of this year's deficit and next year's shortfall can be attributed to what the Governor describes as "a precipitous decline" in revenues produced by everything from the personal income tax to the lottery. To help balance next year's budget, Mr. Cuomo is expected to propose tax increases for the third consecutive year.
But he has said that most of the shortfall will be attacked with spending cuts. And as the fastest growing segment of a state budget that must be slashed by billions, the "safety net" programs will attract great attention this spring from the Legislature.
 
Republicans to Propose Cuts
 Next week, the Republican leaders of the State Senate plan to propose cutting $1 billion from social-service programs like welfare, Medicaid and foster care, largely by restricting eligibility and reducing costs.
But advocates for the poor argue that a recession is the worst time to cut spending for society's most vulnerable members. They predict that such cuts will only worsen homelessness and crime, cementing the permanence of the underclass and passing an even greater burden to future generations.
Mr. Sykes and others have lobbied for an increase in the welfare grant, which now leaves recipients living below the poverty line. The typical welfare grant for a family of three in New York City is $577 a month, which includes a housing allowance of $286.
Administration officials said Mr. Cuomo would propose neither an increase nor a decrease.
 
Limiting Services to Poor
 Michael J. Dowling, Mr. Cuomo's deputy secretary for human services, said much of the growth in welfare and Medicaid would be offset in the budget by proposals to contain their costs and limit the amount of services that local governments would have to provide.
But Cesar A. Perales, the State Commissioner of Social Services, said his department would have to balance some of its growth in mandated costs through cuts in other areas. "We're going to have to take a very big cut on the services side, like programs to prevent teen-age pregnancy, expand child care and assist victims of domestic violence," he said.
Medicaid and welfare are not the only state programs susceptible to an economic downturn. Crime rates generally rise, and along with them go needs for more prison space, court officials and public defenders. Losing a job often causes depression, and a bigger burden on mental health clinics. And families break apart in hard times, leaving children in foster care.
But because the state must pay for Medicaid and welfare, those programs cannot escape the impact of recession.
 
Extra Growth in Home Relief
 Using the most recent numbers available, which reflect October statistics compiled by the Department of Social Services, the number of welfare recipients rose to a peak of 1.32 million in that month. The average was 1.28 million from January 1990 to October, compared with 1.22 million for all 1989. At $1.07 billion, the state's cost of providing for those recipients absorbed 4 percent of the current budget.
Almost three-fourths of the growth has been in the home-relief program, although the program accounts for less than a quarter of all welfare cases. Its average caseload grew by 20 percent in 1990, with 80 percent of the growth in New York City.
Home relief provides grants to childless couples and single men who qualify because of their income level or disabilities. The home-relief population is particularly vulnerable to job scarcity.
The larger component of welfare -- Aid to Families With Dependent Children -- has been been more stable, with an average caseload that grew by 2 percent in 1990.
About 10 percent of the growth in the welfare rolls stems from more Soviet immigrants and a surge in AIDS patients. "The rest of it is pretty much economically driven," said Paula Wilson, the state's deputy budget director. State studies show that the increase in New York's welfare caseload has been following the gradual increase in the state's unemployment rate.
The impact of the recession on the state's $4 billion in Medicaid spending is harder to track. But most welfare recipients also receive Medicaid benefits.

HEADLINE: Some in Congress Harden on Trade

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
Many members of Congress are preparing for another confrontation with the Bush Administration over trade legislation.
Resentments about the slow pace at which Japan and South Korea are opening their markets to American companies is feeding a drive for laws that would require Washington to retaliate against countries that keep markets shut. 
 The Administration insists it has enough legal authority to do the job and bridles at curbs of Presidential discretion that the spate of new bills would produce if they are enacted. It also wants to avoid riling trade partners while the Persian Gulf war is under way. And it fears that legislative initiatives could turn protectionist in the current recession.
One focus of the conflict is on what to do about the expiration last year of what is known as the Super 301 provision of the 1988 trade legislation. That provision attacked foreign barriers by identifying "priority" nations and practices that needed attention and then set deadlines for negotiation and retaliation.
The chairman of the Senate Finance Committee's Trade Subcommittee, Max Baucus, a Montana Democrat, called the law "the most successful provision" of the 1988 trade act and wants it back, with better enforcement provisions.
The ranking Republican on the subcommittee, John C. Danforth of Missouri, concurs that "enforcement has become the principal interest here."
But the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, says there is "already an ample arsenal of tools," and expressed her opinion that Super 301 was actually "quite clumsy" because it required retaliation "on a date specific" even while the United States was engaged in negotiations that could open foreign markets.
 
Undermining World Trade Pact
 The law also enraged many foreign partners, who said the measure's unilateral imposition of sanctions undermined the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the 101-nation agreement that serves as the world's trade charter.
One Congressional proposal is a bill on financial services introduced by Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan, the chairman of the banking committee, and Jake Garn of Utah, its ranking Republican.
It authorizes regulators to deny bids for expansion in the United States by financial institutions based in countries that bar American companies from comparable competitive opportunities.
The sponsors acknowledge that the bill is aimed mainly at Japan, which despite some progress over the years still maintains an elaborate web of laws and practices, American Treasury officials say, that keeps foreign banks and securities firms from competing on equal terms with the Japanese.
 
More Retaliation Feared
 The Administration opposes the Riegle-Garn bill on the ground that narrow reciprocity as a principle of trade policy would lead to escalating retaliation. But it has not yet decided on whether to veto the bill.
"We've seen this coming and warned the Japanese that if we don't see more progress, Congress could become so enraged that it will legislate," said a senior Treasury official who asked not to be identified.
On Monday in Washington, Bush Administration and Japanese officials will tangle once again over demands the United States has been making for seven years about a faster pace for Japanese financial deregulation.
One American complaint is that interest rate controls keep money rates unusually low in Japan, providing a considerable advantage for Japanese banks as they expand in the United States. Japanese banks now have a 25 percent share of the lucrative California market, for example.
Officials at Japan's Finance Ministry insist that foreign and Japanese companies are treated equally and that the American campaign is merely an effort to seek excuses for American businesses that are not doing well in Japan.
 
Allowed to Expire
 Super 301 was the popular name applied to a 1988 amendment to Section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974, which is generally aimed at unfair trade practices. It was allowed to expire last year amid the general truce engendered by global trade talks. But those talks collapsed last month.
Should the trade discussions be revived, which is appearing more likely, many lawmakers are now saying that Super 301, or something like it, will be enacted as the price Congress exacts for approving any global agreement.
Congress historically demands -- and gets -- trade policy changes, usually in the form of some improved protection for domestic industry and workers, in return for supporting international agreements that open the United States to more imports.
"For the past two years," said William T. Archey, a vice president of the United States Chamber of Commerce in Washington, "Congress has granted to the executive branch the leadership in trade policy. It is doubtful that such deference will continue during this Congress."
 
Japan Reassures U.S.
 TOKYO, Jan. 27 (REUTERS) -- Japanese negotiators sought to reassure the United States over the weekend that Tokyo's procedures for buying computers were fair, Japanese Government officials said. Washington wants an increase in sales of American computers to the Japanese Government and sought assurances that bureaucratic foot-dragging would not get in the way. Kenichiro Sasae, a Foreign Ministry official, said the Japanese policy was consistent with that of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Travel;
FEAR OF TERRORISM IS CURBING TRAVEL

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
Frightened by the threat of terrorism and preoccupied with the war against Iraq, Americans are canceling vacation plans and choosing to stay close to home.
In the clearest indication yet of the war's effects on the economy, operators of group tours, airlines and cruise lines all report an increase in cancellations and a drop in bookings since United States-led forces started attacking Iraq on Jan. 17. 
 While many canceled trips involved travel to the Middle East and Europe, people are also postponing other overseas flights as well as domestic vacations that involve air travel. Foreign travel to the United States has also fallen off.
Concern about flying anywhere is the reason most often given for canceling trips. But some people say they are staying home for other reasons as well. Some potential travelers are riveted to their television sets, captivated by the constant news reports about the war, a condition that some people are calling the "CNN effect."
One traveler staying home is Chuck Santoro, who runs an insurance agency in Bergenfield, N.J.. He canceled a family trip to New Orleans for Mardi Gras.
"It is not really a great time to party," he said. Mr. Santoro said he was worried about being part of the unruly mass of people that gather to celebrate Mardi Gras. "Who knows what could happen?" he said. "Somebody could chuck a bomb in there."
Tourism to New York, Washington and other large cities has fallen as people try to avoid potential targets of terrorism.
Along with the drop in tourism has come a reduction in business travel, reflecting both the recession and corporate bans on international travel because of the war.
Whether more Americans will take vacations this year in the family car, staying at hotels and motels or camping out, is impossible to determine yet. Even if such trips are planned six months in advance, few people make reservations that early. So that shift in vacation plans would not turn up in hard numbers.
Indeed, precise numbers on the changing travel patterns are difficult to come by, and January and February are generally the slowest travel months of the year anyway. Still, many hotels and airlines say customers are making reservations at levels below their projections. In the cruise industry, January is the most important month, in terms of reservations being made. A bad January could have repercussions for the rest of the year.
 
Cruise Cancellations
 Carnival Cruise Lines Inc. in Miami is the nation's largest cruise operator, with numerous vacations to the Caribbean. It says it is receiving 10 to 20 cancellations a day, compared with 3 or 4 daily last January.
Bookings through American Express travel agents have dropped by nearly 10 percent since the beginning of the year. "It is a significant drop in a very short period of time," said Roger H. Ballou, president of the Travel Services Group, a division of the American Express Company.
The packaged-tour business at the Carlson Travel Network dropped 40 percent after war broke out, said Ronald Letterman, president of the travel agency and tour operator in Minneapolis. "The week after the war started, our advance bookings just stopped."
Other travel executives agree that travel plans seem frozen since the war began. "People are just putting their trips on hold," said Charles D. Platt, president of Alamo Rent a Car Inc. in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. If people do not fly, he said, they do not rent cars.
The drop in vacations comes at a bad time for the travel industry, which was already bracing for a rough year because of the recession. Companies in the travel business say it is too early to tell how long the slowdown will last and if it will lead to layoffs or other cost-cutting measures.
Many airlines have ended flights to the Middle East, and some have announced plans to cut flights to Europe. Trans World Airways said it would halt up to half its overseas flights. Delta Air Lines has canceled its daily Cincinnati-to-Paris flight, and airline industry analysts said similar moves by other carriers were likely.
 
Fewer London Flights
 British Airways has trimmed flights in the face of falling demand. The airline is now flying two rather than three flights a day between New York and London. One of the two Concorde flights on Sundays has been canceled. A spokesman for British Airways said the war was compounding the ecomomic slowdown. "It will have an effect on revenues and profitability," said John Lampl, an airline spokesman.
British Airways has pulled its advertising. But to combat slack demand, it began offering a special $249 round-trip fare for New York to London through travel agents last week.
Several airlines, including United and American, have relaxed their penalties for canceling flights. Travelers concerned about flying can exchange their tickets for vouchers that can be traded for tickets during the year.
Even before the terrorism scare, hotels had been offering discounted room packages to attract guests. John Fox of the accounting firm Pannell Kerr Forster said the industry would face additional pressure to cut rates if the slowdown continued.
 
'Nobody Really Wants to Travel'
 Several large cruise operators canceled cruises to Europe this week when reservations failed to materialize because of safety concerns. Princess Cruises in Los Angeles decided this week not to send a second cruise ship to Europe this summer as planned, because the war had depressed bookings.
Crystal Cruises also decided not to sail to Europe this summer. "Nobody really wants to travel across the Atlantic," said Arthur Sbarsky, senior vice president of marketing for the Los Angeles-based company.
The war has also altered the course of the Cunard Line's Queen Elizabeth 2. The ship will not go through the Suez Canal or stop at any Mediterranean ports. Instead, the ocean liner will steam around Africa as part of an around-the-world cruise.
There are some indications that people may choose to take short driving vacations to areas close to home. Since war broke out, "the phones are ringing a heck of a lot more than they had been," said Bobbi Doren of the Pines Resort Hotel in South Fallsburg, N.Y., a family resort in the Catskills two hours from New York City. "It is closer to home," she said.
 
Traffic on Amtrak
 An Amtrak spokesman said yesterday that it could not be determined if its ridership had changed since the war began. Passenger traffic on the rail system has increased 2 percent to 3 percent since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in August, he said.

HEADLINE: Pump-Priming Pail Is Dry As U.S. Budget Comes Up

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
In the textbook world, a primary tool to fight recession is an expanding Federal budget deficit. Extra Government stimulus, the theory goes, will make up for diminished spending in the private sector and thereby soften the economic downturn.
Even before the outbreak of war, the reality did not match the ideal, and the conflict in the Persian Gulf is not expected to bring the two any closer. By contrast to the industrial mobilization for World War II, which pulled the nation out of the Great Depression, this conflict is backed by a well-stocked military inventory. 
 When the budget debate opens on Capitol Hill this week with the President's request for spending and revenues for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1, the gap between the theory of pump-priming and the reality of the 1990's will be painfully apparent.
Since the Government failed during the prosperous 1980's to run budget surpluses, or even achieve balance, it lacks the wherewithal to pump up a deflated economy. A long-feared prospect is thus at hand: a recession that hits when fiscal policy is already immobilized.
"A deficit is appropriate during a recession because you need the stimulus," said Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company. "The problem is the base from which we start -- the deficit is already so high."
Recessions automatically increase the deficit, now estimated at somewhat more than $300 billion this year even if the downturn proves to be short-lived. During a recession, spending for unemployment insurance and other elements of the social safety net rises while revenues from income taxes and other levies fall. But the Government seems unable to go beyond these so-called stabilizers, a fact acknowledged by economists and legislators across the political spectrum.
"We should not try to counteract the downturn with pump-priming," Representative Lee H. Hamilton, an Indiana Democrat and member of the Joint Economic Committee, said recently. "We already have enormous stimulus through our large deficit. As economists have said for so long, we have pushed our fiscal accelerator to the floor while holding hard on the monetary brake. If we want to go faster, we should ease up on the brake, not try to push the accelerator through the floorboard."
Mr. Hamilton's point was reinforced Tuesday by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, who urged that Congress remember the long-term goals of last fall's agonizingly achieved five-year budget-cutting agreement.
 
Social Security Tax Cut Proposal
 And while the war itself is unlikely to provide large stimulus to the economy, additional spending on a myriad of things from chemical weapons suits to combat pay is taking place. But the bulk of the stimulus is being offset through the initial stages of the war by the tax increases and spending cuts the budget package calls for.
The magnitude of the deficit is not the only barrier to a reflexive turn to Government jobs programs, stepped-up spending on public works and tax cuts. Even former supporters of such moves agree that such programs take so long to put in place that their effect is generally not felt until the economy is recovering on its own.
One of the few proposals for such a move comes from Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, who has revived legislation to cut Social Security payroll taxes. The main goal is to halt the use of Social Security surpluses to help finance the deficit. But Senator Moynihan contended in reintroducing the measure last week that it would serve to cushion the recession.
In theory, tax policy could be used as a countercyclical tool, said Alice M. Rivlin, a former head of the Congressional Budget Office, if Congress were only "good at figuring out when we were going into a recession." The task, however, seems to be beyond the ability of any forecaster.
In fact, any substantial fiscal stimulus risks provoking enough anxiety about the integrity of the budget legislation to be counterproductive. "You'll send all the wrong signals" to the bond market, raising interest rates and thereby worsening the slump, said Lyle E. Gramley, a former Federal Reserve official who is now chief economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association.
"I really don't think there's much the Administration can do" to fight recession, Mr. Gramley added.
 
 Constraints on the Fed

The near-paralysis of fiscal policy leaves Federal Reserve monetary policy as the main anti-recession tool. Unfortunately, many analysts say, the Fed also faces constraints not normally considered in textbooks.
The most prominent is the battered condition of the nation's banks, the main agents through which policy makers increase the money supply. Because so many loans have gone sour, banks have become reluctant to extend new loans and to reduce rates. This situation means that an easier Fed monetary policy cannot be pursued with the traditional confidence that it will help business activity.
"I don't ever remember the banking system being an independent element of weakness" in the economy, said Milton W. Hudson, economic adviser to the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.
A $300 billion budget deficit itself also affects this process, economists at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. said in a market letter. "The implied huge Treasury financing needs will provide the paper for cautious commercial banks to invest their reserves in, while they refrain from lending to real estate and corporate sectors saddled with falling profits, shrinking asset values and deteriorating liquidity," they declared.
If the Treasury's huge demands lead to a sharp increase in long-term interest rates, as seems possible even in recession, this not only would further hobble the economy, it would also raise the deficit, since interest on the debt now accounts for more than one-fourth of the budget.

HEADLINE: Andover Journal;
At a Missile Maker, Pride and Relief

DATELINE: ANDOVER, Mass., Jan. 21

 BODY:
For many workers in this Boston suburb of 27,000 people, the success of the Patriot missile in the Persian Gulf war is more than just a matter of pride. It's a matter of job security.
The Raytheon Company plant here began making the radar and guidance systems for the missiles in 1980. Since then, people from throughout the Merrimack Valley have come to Andover, the well-heeled town where President Bush went to prep school, looking for work. But defense cuts and threats by Congress to scrap the Patriot, which tracks and intercepts attacking missiles, have made continued employment uncertain. 
 In the last six months, the Andover plant laid off more than 300 of its 6,000 workers, sending them into a battered local economy whose unemployment rate has doubled in just over two years, to 7.3 percent.
Until news came two weeks ago that the Patriots had begun knocking out Iraqi Scud missiles, morale had been low, workers said.
"I was laid off from the plant before, so I had been worrying about my job," said an assembler, who spoke on condition that her name not be used. "But I feel good about what I do, especially now that the war is on and the Patriot is working. Maybe if it continues to do well, Raytheon will get more contracts and there will be more secure jobs."
Workers at the plant had been expecting additional layoffs early this year, but instead they are working around the clock to keep up with orders brought in by the gulf crisis.
"I think we just all feel good about the fact that the Patriot is doing its job," said Joseph O'Donnell, another assembler at the plant, as he soldered parts on to a missile's circuit board. For three weeks last year, Mr. O'Donnell was laid off from his $12.99 an hour job. Now, he said, his bosses are asking him to work overtime.
Since 1980, Raytheon, the largest private employer in Massachusetts, has delivered more than 108 high-tech Patriot missile systems, which includes the missile, the launcher and other ground equipment, and more than 4,500 missiles. The Pentagon pays $50 million to $55 million for a complete system and $600,000 for each missile.
Led by sales of the missile, Raytheon today announced record profits of $557.3 million on sales of $9.3 billion for 1990. Besides the United States, which has asked Raytheon to step up production, buyers of the missile include Germany, the Netherlands, Japan, Italy, and, since the gulf crisis began, Israel and Saudi Arabia.
Andover officials hope the money that goes into the company will spill out to the community. "Raytheon is a good neighbor to us, and we are pleased the Patriot is doing well," said R. S. Stapczynski, the town manager. "Maybe there'll be some jobs created by this success. This whole state could use a boost."
Tightened security at the Andover plant, which is surrounded by a chain-link fence topped with barbed wire, serves as a reminder that the United States is at war against an enemy whose weapons could include terrorism. On the other side of Boston in Quincy, workers at another Raytheon plant , have petitioned for stricter security measures.
Raytheon officials would not comment on security measures, but employees said entrances to work areas, once staffed by one security guard, now had four to six guards. All handbags and knapsacks are now inspected as workers enter and leave the plant.
"They are checking everything," said Cindy Cote, a 31-year-old assembler whose husband works as a mechanic on the morning shift. "They just seem to be afraid of people coming in here illegally."
Elation about the Patriots' successes has also been dampened by the increasing numbers of friends and family called into military service. More than 100 people from the Merrimack Valley are serving in the gulf, at least 13 of them from Andover.
While no war protesters have made their way to Raytheon's gates, Andover residents have gathered in homes and churches to pray for peace and the soldiers' safety. "A lot of people have relatives over there and are worried," said Mr. O'Donnell, a 43-year-old veteran of the Vietnam War.
Mrs. Cote said her worries had been of a different nature.
"At first I had a hard time thinking about making weapons that are killing people," she said. "But now I think about the fact that it's saving our own people and it's for our country. I guess if it wasn't me making it, it would be someone else. And it's a good job."
