HEADLINE: As Urban Blight Worsens, Victims Find Their Isolation Is Deepening

SERIES: The Missing Agenda; Poverty and Policy - Second of three articles.

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS

 BODY:
In the St. Thomas housing project, with its rows of boarded-up red brick buildings, the ghosts speak more eloquently than the living about the despair at the bottom of urban America.
There's the spindly crape myrtle tree and a modest plaque marking the spot where 5-year-old Coco Vessel died in a crossfire of bullets on Nov. 19, 1989. There's a weed-choked patch outside the apartment where Elnora Barnes for many years tended her begonias and roses, green peppers, eggplant and okra before gunfire drove her away. 
 There's no missing the dreadful toll of inner-city decay in America's urban slums. But for those outside the blighted districts, insulated by money and geography, there's a terrible paradox. As the problems of the urban poor become more toxic to those inside, their immediate impact on most Americans is becoming more distant and elusive.
 
Effects Are Widely Felt
 In a nation now more suburban than urban, with residential segregation common, jobs increasingly following residences out from the urban core, and regional growth and corresponding political power moving away from the most affected areas, the impact of urban poverty is more like a tornado than a hurricane, ripping apart some cities, neighborhoods and lives, but leaving others almost intact.
 
Far-Reaching Effects
 But even though elusive, the effects of urban poverty can be far-reaching. They strain big-city budgets, produce criminal behavior that is altering urban life, poison race relations and threaten to create an undereducated work force that could haunt the nation for decades. The presence of the homeless, like battered refugees from a blighted kingdom, in even the most prosperous cities serves as a reminder of the depth of the nation's social ills.
One of the political challenges of the 1990's is finding a way to summon the national will to address a problem that the nation has done its best to isolate and flee.
"After the riots of the 1960's, a quite elaborate social reorganization of American metropolitan life has taken place based on the principle of everbody getting as far away from the underclass as possible," said Nicholas Lemann, author "The Promised Land," a book on poverty to be published in March by Alfred A. Knopf.
"A place like New York is a very special case where the richest neighborhood is right next to some of the poorest," Mr. Lemann said. "That's very rare. Most people know the conditions in the ghetto are terrible, but it's a problem that doesn't directly affect them."
 
View From the Projects
A Daily Assault Of Fear and Despair
To Lilianne Flavin, a Dominican sister from Ireland who is an incongruous, healing presence at the St. Thomas housing project here, the urgency of the problem is as unmistakable as the despair she sees daily. "The question shouldn't be what these people are doing to society," she says. "It's what society is doing to them."
St. Thomas was once a stable home to white working class residents, with neat three-story brick buildings, French Quarter-style iron grillwork and leafy oaks. Now, about 550 of the 1,500 apartments are gutted and abandoned and the project is a patchwork of decay -- an uprooted toilet in front of one building, a pile of dilapidated furniture forming a makeshift playground in front of another.
 
Perils to the Children
 The overwhelming majority of the residents are the victims, not the perpetrators. They are people like Rose Bailey, worried about the lead poisoning of her 3-year-old son, Theresa Delmore, hoping her four children can escape the crack to which she is addicted, or Earnestine Lather, resolutely trying to protect her children from the slum's perils.
"Being here, I feel like we're living in the Last Days," said Mrs. Lather, invoking a term from Revelation to describe the project's slide toward chaos.
As she waited to meet her 6-year-old's school bus, Mrs. Lather added, "Mostly, you try to keep them away from the drugs and the violence, but it's hard. I tell my oldest boy I don't want him hanging out with the boys who are getting in trouble, and he says, 'Aw, mama, ain't nobody else for me to be with.' "
There is rage at St. Thomas. Its explodes in the gunfire at night and lurks just beneath the surface of daily life, evident in the touch football game played each afternoon with a fury that's more blood sport than play.
 
'It's Like Being in Jail'
 But far more common is simple despair.
"I feel like I'm a different person when I'm not here," said Ms. Delmore, who stopped working as a nurse's assistant when she became addicted to crack three years ago. "I feel good. I feel I don't need drugs. But being in here, you just feel like you're drowning. It's like being in jail. I hate the projects. I hate this rathole."
 
View From Next Door
Cities Transform As Many Escape
New Orleans is one of the rare cities where rich and poor live in close proximity and where conditions at the bottom have a direct effect on everyone. Fear of crime is transforming some neighborhoods, like the lovely Uptown district near Tulane University, from some of the nation's most appealing to some of its most besieged.
Chink Ogden is a 34-year-old lawyer with two young childen who grew up in New Orleans and until June lived in the house that his grandfather built in 1898. But in June he sold the house, moved to suburban St. Tammany Parish and cannot imagine moving back.
"I didn't want to raise my kids in a crime-ridden city, and I didn't see it getting any better," he said. "This city was the greatest city in the world to live in. I like to party and the city never died. You could always go out and have a good time. Now you have to be careful and watch where you go, and that's not living."
In the French Quarter, the party still goes on. But New Orleans now is more like a caricature of America's racial politics at their worst instead of symbolizing the joys of urban life. It is a city that is 65 percent black with almost 15 percent of the population living in public housing. Just across the parish line is the all-white suburban district that sent a former Ku Klux Klan leader, David Duke, to the Louisiana House of Representatives.
 
Flight From New York
 The same sort of frustrations are probably felt most acutely in New York City, where the nation's largest concentration of inner-city poverty exists in the densest urban environment.
Irena Choi Stern is a 32-year-old mother of three who after eight years on the Upper West Side is planning to leave for the suburbs.
After being a victim of a series of violent or abusive incidents -- some random crime, some tied to her Korean ancestry -- she has decided she would rather see her children learn about life from the distance afforded by the suburbs than the turmoil of the city streets.
"I find I'm becoming much more racist personally living in the city, and I don't want my kids to be that way," she said. "I find the people who grew up in the suburbs and then moved to the urban centers are more open minded than people who've had so many negative experiences with other racial groups."
Tom McCarthy, a 45-year-old freelance editor and lifelong New Yorker said he has been mugged five times since 1983, most recently by black youths on a crowded street. He does not consider himself a racist, but neither does he object when a bartender, alluding to three recent robbery attempts by blacks, refuses to buzz in a neatly dressed black man to a bar in upper Manhattan.
 
Events Embitter a Black
 "If life is not about playing the percentages, I don't know what it's about," Mr. McCarthy said. "If I'm a bar owner and three out of three black men in suits come in and rob me, then you don't have to know much about statistics to be skeptical about opening your door to black gentlemen wearing suits and ties."
 To blacks, even the most advantaged, that attitude is a bitter reminder of the souring of the urban dream.
Phil Isom, a 26-year-old black man and a third-year law student at Columbia University, recalls with bitterness and anger a recent incident in which a store owner refused to allow him into a stationery store frequented by Columbia students until he presented an identification card.
"The stereotypes being perpetuated about black men are not working to solve the problems," said Mr. Isom, who grew up in East Harlem. "If anything, they add fuel to the problems. There are a lot of angry young black males out there, and every time you're not buzzed into a store, every time you cannot catch a cab, every time you get on an elevator and everyone gets off, every time you're asked for an ID card when no one else is, it just gets you much more angry and it turns you further and further away from trying to be a part of this society."
 
View From Across Town
Most Are Aware But Not Affected
Largely because of the haunting visibility of the homeless, most Americans have at least some personal experience with the worst ravages of poverty.
A New York Times Poll found that 54 percent of Americans say they see homeless people in their community or on the way to work. In the survey of 1,028 adults, 48 percent said they have taken some special precaution against crime and 29 percent said they see people buying and selling drugs in their community or on their way to work. The margin of sampling error was plus or minus three percentage points.
Homelessness, drugs, crime -- these most obvious urban problems break through the public consciousness from time to time and get the most attention from politicians. But interviews around the country indicate that many Americans, even those in big cities with the worst poverty problems, feel largely isolated from the problems of the poor.
Michael Rosenzweig, like Mr. Ogden of New Orleans, is a lawyer with two young children who lives in a city with soaring poverty and crime. But when asked how the problems of the urban poor affect his life in a neighborhood north of downtown Atlanta, he gives a very different answer.
"I find it impinges on my life very little, if at all," he said. "I find I simply am not forced to confront those problems physically or visibly in any real way. I read that stuff in the papers and see it on the news, but I don't ever really experience it."
In Atlanta, with little downtown living, widespread residential segregation and most residences and jobs spiraling away from the urban core and toward the northern suburbs, it is a common experience.
 
'You're Insulated From It
 That experience is the norm, not the exception in American life.
Charles Lockwood of Los Angeles observed, "In New York, you're forced into dealing with people on the street or on the subway; here so much of life is lived behind the windshield of your car, you're insulated from it."
Mr. Lockwood, who writes articles and books on urban and architectural issues, added, "I think it's one reason why these issues aren't being dealt with in this country, outside of a sort of moral malaise."
The effect of moving residents as well as jobs out of cities is a new kind of community. "If you go to a place like Reston Town Center outside Washington," Mr. Lockwood said, "they've created a downtown without crime, without graffiti, without poor people. It's not only white flight, it's total abandonment of the center city."
James Alan Fox, a professor of criminal justice at Northeastern University, notes that the explosion in murder rates in recent years has been almost entirely limited to the nonwhite poor. From 1987 to 1989, when the murder rate for nonwhites rose by 16 percent, it declined by 2 percent for whites, he said.
"I think there's a moral obligation to deal with these problems," he said. "But I can't say that if we don't do anything about it all these kids in the inner city will grow up and attack us. It does not tend to happen that way."
 
View Into the Future
Experts See Peril To Nation's Health
Sometimes the reality of inner city life intrudes in jarring ways. In Dallas, for example, a group of elderly people were lined up outside a building at Fair Park, site of the annual State Fair of Texas, for a Junior League crafts fair last fall when one woman suddenly collapsed with what people took to be a heart attack. When she was taken to a hospital, it turned out she had been hit in the ankle by a stray bullet, apparently from a low-income area nearby.
Sometimes, the problems show up in the growing acrimony of racial politics in places like Milwaukee and Dallas. Black officials in both cities, citing the growing decay and despair in the city's black districts, have recently raised the specter of the kind of urban violence that convulsed the nation in the 1960's.
More often there is the sense, even by those like a writer from Austin, Tex., who describes the problems of the ghetto poor as "a storm in another county," that something has gone terribly wrong in American life and that it is diminishing both those who are at the bottom and those who are not.
"There has to be some kind of hope restored," said Charles Norman, director of field operations for Community Youth Gang Services, the largest non-law-enforcement organization dealing with gangs in Los Angeles County. "Hopeless people are very dangerous."
 
Some Neighborhoods Thrive
 In Chicago, where strong neighborhood identities have blunted much of the sense of urban decline, the downtown area remains the hottest real estate market in the metropolitan area. Even in New York, a surge of immigration -- Russian Jews, Haitians, Dominicans, Vietnamese -- is bringing the promise of new vitality to some sections of the city even as some other sections continue to decline.
But evidence is strong that in general America's cities are continuing a long, slow decline.
Larry Long, a demographer and sociologist with the Census Bureau says that a few years ago researchers wanted to know whether gentrification indicated a lasting return of the middle class to urban America.
"Now everyone is asking the same question in reverse," he said, wondering whether the decline of the cities is accelerating.
 
Much Depends on Cities
 In the end, some experts say, what is at stake is not just the health of cities, but the urban sensibilities and values that have shaped the nation's culture.
Kevin Starr, a professor of urban and regional planning at the University of Southern California, says that in the Middle Ages the city was said to represent the "plenum mundi," the pulse of the world. One thing that seems to have drained out of American politics is a sense of cities as organs whose health is essential to the survival of the social body.
"If cities are the matrices of our civilization, if our great ideas, our intellectual and moral consciousness comes from there," Mr. Starr said, "then woe and betide us if we have a national policy to let our cities become scenes from 'Escape from New York' or 'Blade Runner,' the city of dreadful night. You can't have a policy that lets cities decline, because in the decline of cities comes the decline of everything."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
Americans are canceling vacation plans and choosing to stay close to home, fearful of terrorism and preoccupied with the war against Iraq. Operators of group tours, airlines and cruise lines report an increase in cancellations and a drop in bookings. [Page A1.]
The F.T.C. is flexing its antitrust muscles, after taking a laissez-faire approach under the Reagan Administration, and is renewing its interest in cases affecting the public's pocketbook. [A1.]
Shareholders and the S.E.C. are questioning whether some banks violated securities laws by concealing bad loans for months before they announced large losses. [D1.]
A surge in capital spending by U.S. manufacturers lifted orders for American machine tools by 43.7 percent in December from the November level, the industry's trade association reported. [D1.]
A long-feared prospect is at hand: a recession that hits when fiscal policy is already immobilized. The huge budget deficit makes it unlikely that Government can provide economic stimulus. [D1.]
Many in Congress are preparing for another confrontation with the Administration over trade legislation. [D2.]
A change in Federal labor law will mean that thousands of computer programmers will no longer receive overtime pay. [D3.]
 
COMPANIES
Sears's board will consider sweeping changes, including the possible sale or closing of the Sears catalogue, when directors meet next month, retail executives and others say. [D1.]
Some American employees of the Saudi national oil company are describing themselves as economic hostages. They say they are forced to choose between their jobs and their safety. [A10.]
The wartime success of the Patriot missile is more than a matter of pride for workers in Andover, Mass. In the town where Raytheon makes the missiles, it is also a matter of job security. [A14.]
A.T.& T. is trying to lease out most of the space in its Madison Avenue headquarters building and shift employees to less-expensive office space elsewhere in New York City. [B3.]
 
INTERNATIONAL
Few economies appear poised to benefit as much as Japan's in the event of a brief war in the Persian Gulf, or have the staying power to endure a long war with as little strain. [D1.]
 
THE MEDIA BUSINESS
New management has developed an aggressive strategy for the Reader's Digest Association. The company has been buying up specialty magazines and starting others. [D1.]
Wide open spaces are returning to American print advertising and publication design. [D6.]
Dutton/New American Library is gambling that a lower-priced, more widely distributed mass-market paperback will sell more than enough copies to bring in additional profits, even though it could eat into sales of a trade paperback. [D6.]
The war is proving to be exceptionally strong television programming, and could bring long-term profits to the networks' news divisions. Bill Carter: Television. [D6.]
The anticipated replacement for a top executive at Levine Huntley Schmidt & Beaver has decided not to defect. Andrew Langer will remain at Lowe Group. Kim Foltz: Advertising. [D7.]
Coca-Cola toned down its elaborate ads for a $1 million giveaway during the Super Bowl because of the war. The company gave away the prize, but without the fanfare. [D7.]
 
TODAY'S COLUMNS
A much smaller than expected drop in G.N.P. has raised questions among analysts about whether the downturn is a full-blown recession or a three-month phenomenon. Credit Markets. [D5.]
Wall Street still finds it hard to love Kodak, even though recent news out of Rochester has been good. Market Place. [D4.]

HEADLINE: F.T.C. Is Re-Emerging As Watchdog on Prices

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
The Federal Trade Commission, slowly emerging from the laissez-faire attitude of the Reagan Administration, is starting to use its antitrust muscles and renew its interest in cases that affect the public's pocketbook.
The agency has begun to challenge manufacturers that seek to limit price discounting by retailers and is also investigating the possibility that makers of infant formula colluded to set prices. The number of cases involving false and deceptive advertising, another area regulated by the agency, is also up. 
 "There is a new vigor and commitment at the agency," said Michael Pertschuk, a commission member from 1974 to 1984 who is co-director of the Advocacy Institute, a public interest group in Washington. "This infant-formula investigation might have been brought under the Reagan Administration, but the economists at the F.T.C. then would have figured out why price fixing is good for consumers."
 
Inquiries in Other Areas
 In the formula case, the agency subpoenaed the records of all leading makers of infant formula after state welfare officials and consumer groups complained that the manufacturers had raised prices in a uniform way over the past decade.
Although the infant-formula case has attracted the most attention, the agency has undertaken a number of other efforts, including these:
*It recently settled the first retail price-fixing case in eight years, and an inquiry is expected to result soon in a call for action against the United States subsidiary of Nintendo, the Japanese producer of video games, over its sales policies.
*In the first deceptive-advertising case since 1985 to be brought against an advertising agency, the F.T.C. challenged television commercials for a toy manufacturer that said -- erroneously -- that a doll could twirl on its own.
*The agency has filed a growing number of consumer-protection lawsuits, including the first involving a "900" telephone number.
Just how aggressive the agency will become under the Bush Administration is uncertain, but Janet D. Steiger, who was appointed F.T.C. chairwoman in August 1989, is getting much of the credit for the agency's new mood. Mrs. Steiger is also moving to coordinate Federal and state consumer-protection actions, something that did not happen often during the Reagan years.
"This Administration has begun the process of improving relationships," said Robert Abrams, the New York State Attorney General.
 
'Nowhere to Go but Up'
 But some public-interest advocates are not impressed. "The F.T.C. had nowhere to go but up," said Bruce Silverglade, legal director of the Center for Science in the Public Interest in Washington. "But in terms of activism, it has not turned around like the Environmental Protection Agency or the Food and Drug Administration."
Whatever the case, the F.T.C. that greeted Mrs. Steiger had lost virtually half of its staff and nearly a third of its budget in the 1980's. Some enforcement also declined under James C. Miller 3d, who was chairman from 1981 to 1985, and his successor, Daniel Oliver, both advocates of a laissez-faire approach.
A 1989 American Bar Association report found that approach translated into effects. "Too rarely has the public received the message that the F.T.C. believes it is important to move aggressively against false and deceptive advertising," that report stated.
In an interview, Mrs. Steiger described herself much as others do, not as an ideologue but as a bureaucrat who can be expected to take a middle course. "I want this to be a judicious enforcement agency that is interested in the public's health and welfare," she said.
 
Focusing on Retail Prices
 In her first 18 months, Mrs. Steiger has already overseen changes in the agency's attitude in one antitrust area: efforts by manufacturers to prevent retailers from discounting products below minimum prices.
During the Reagan years, some Administration economists argued that this form of price fixing was not illegal and could even help consumers because excessive discounting by retailers might reduce customer service.
But F.T.C. officials are now taking a different view. They recently settled a suit against Kreepy Krauly U.S.A., a Florida-based producer of swimming pool cleaners, after charging that the company had illegally entered into a written agreement with dealers in which the dealers agreed to maintain suggested retail prices. And investigators plan to recommend that the agency file a complaint against the American subsidiary of Nintendo into the possibility that the company is trying to keep its prices artifically high, said a person at the F.T.C. who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
The agency may also move to expand its antitrust powers. In the infant-formula investigation, for instance, it is relying on a relatively new antitrust theory that holds that actions other than traditional written or spoken agreements may constitute price fixing or improper division of markets.
"You don't have to sit around in a room together conspiring," said Kelly Signs, a lawyer on the Senate Subcommittee on Antitrust, Monopolies and Business Rights, which held hearings on infant-formula pricing in May. "If a business, for example, relies on information supplied by competitors to set prices rather than doing it independently, that could be a problem."
 
A Theory Is Tried Out
 In 1979, the F.T.C. invoked this theory of antitrust for the only time when it sued several petrochemical companies over similar practices in the sale of gasoline additives. But in 1984, a Federal judge dismissed the suit, saying the F.T.C. could not prove its claim.
Some of the agency's aggressiveness on antitrust matters is spilling over into the area of advertising. Over the past 18 months, the number of enforcement actions involving deceptive-advertising claims is up about 40 percent, said Joel Winston, the agency's assistant director for advertising practices. Also, for the first time in six years, the F.T.C recently brought charges against an advertising agency.
In that complaint, the commission accused Lewis Galoob Toys Inc., a San Francisco-based manufacturer, and its advertising agency, Towne, Silverstein, Rotter Inc., of producing television commercials that falsely implied, among other things, that a toy doll could twirl without human assistance. In settling the case, the companies, which admitted no wrongdoing, agreed not to make deceptive claims in the future.
Mark Silbergeld, legislative director of Consumers Union, said his group, whose 1989 complaint initiated the Galoob investigation, was pleased with the F.T.C.'s handling of it.
Over all, the number of consumer-protection complaints filed by the F.T.C. the past two years virtually equals the number filed in the previous four years, agency statistics show.
 
Hostility Is Recalled
 F.T.C. officials are also mending fences with state attorneys general. In the late 1980's, these state officials, moving to fill what they saw as a Federal regulatory void, began coordinating the filing of consumer-protection lawsuits against airlines, car-rental companies and others. F.T.C. officials accused their state counterparts of trying to usurp Federal powers.
"There was a lot of hostility" said Linley E. Pearson, the Indiana Attorney General. Now, Mr. Pearson and others credit Mrs. Steiger for healing that rift. Unlike her predecessors, those officials said, she actively courts their views and has worked to coordinate Federal and state actions. One example: a joint investigation into claims by companies that their products are environmentally beneficial.
But the agency's wheels still grind very slowly. The infant-formula investigation, for example, is in its eighth month. And Mrs. Steiger said in Congressional testimony last July that the F.T.C. was looking into advertisements for alcoholic beverages aimed at minors. But she declined in an interview to comment on the progress of that inquiry.
F.T.C. officials argue that such delays are not unusal. But Mr. Miller said that Mrs. Steiger's tenure may produce more rhetoric than change. "I would characterize any difference as one of style rather than any substantive shift in philosophy," said Mr. Miller, who is chairman of Citizens for a Sound Economy, an advocacy group.
The F.T.C.'s future is by no means in Mrs. Steiger's hands alone. A majority of the agency's five commissioners must approve major actions, and the views of Deborah K. Owen and Roscoe B. Starek 3d, the two other commissioners appointed by President Bush, are largely unknown. Both remaining Reagan appointees, Mary Azcuenaga and Andrew J. Strenio Jr., are well regarded by public interest advocates and the business community alike.
For her part, Mrs. Steiger appears resolute on more changes: "The record will have to speak for itself."

HEADLINE: A.T.&T. Is Hoping To Lease Out Space At Its Headquarters

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company is trying to lease out most of the space in its headquarters at 550 Madison Avenue and planning to shift its employees to less expensive office space elsewhere in New York City.
Walter Murphy, a spokesman for the nation's largest telecommunications company, said last night that the building, between 55th and 56th Streets, would remain its headquarters. He said employees would be moved only if a large tenant or tenants were found. 
 If A.T.& T. succeeds with its plan, it will have to return to New York City about $16 million in tax abatements.
The plan to lease the building has been rumored in real-estate circles for months and was reported today in Crain's New York Business.
 
The Sole Occupant
 The headquarters, designed by Philip Johnson and John Burgee, is sometimes called the Chippendale skyscraper for its pediment resembling the top of an 18th century highboy.
A.T.& T. has 1,300 employees in the 35-story building and is the sole occupant. The leasing plan would put more than 600,000 square feet of office space on the market. Given the depressed state of the Manhattan office market, it is not clear if the company will find a tenant at a rent it finds acceptable.
After construction began on the building in 1978, A.T.& T. received $26 million in local tax abatements for agreeing to maintain a substantial presence in the city. In 1987, in exchange for a continuation of the abatements, A.T.& T. promised to remain the sole tenant and to keep 1,000 employees in the building. If A.T.& T. breaks that agreement, it will have to repay the city as much as $16 million, Mr. Murphy said.
Jeanne Nathan, a spokeswoman for Sally Hernandez-Pinero, Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, said last night, "A.T.&T. has assured us that they would honor their obligation to return any taxes due us should they lease the building, and that any employees that leave the building would be placed elsewhere in the city."

HEADLINE: Dispute Over Lease Threatens a Musical

BYLINE: By C. GERALD FRASER

 BODY:
The producers of the long-running black musical "Mama, I Want to Sing" say they will close the show on March 30, the eighth anniversary of its opening.
The decision to close "Mama" follows years of wrangling between the producer and the New York City Government. At issue is the right of Reach Productions, the producer, to use the Heckscher Theater on Fifth Avenue at 104th Street, which is in a building set aside for nonprofit organizations. 
 "Mama, I Want to Sing" has been running at the Heckscher Theater since 1983. In its first five years the show grossed $25 million, and in 1988 it earned $8.7 million. Companies have toured the United States and performed in Japan and Turkey. A sequel has been playing in repertory at the Heckscher since March.
The producers' lawyer, Paul Batista, said his clients, Vy Higginsen and Ken Wydro, have a lease that went into effect in 1984 and is valid for the run of the play.
 
'I Have Just Had Enough'
 Both sides presented arguments on Jan. 7 in the Appellate Term of State Supreme Court on the validity of that lease, which the city contends is month-to-month, and await a decision. The city appealed a 1989 verdict by Judge Carol H. Arber that Mr. Batista said upheld the producers' right to rent the theater and affirmed the sublease from the prime tenant, the East Harlem Arts and Education Complex.
A decision has not yet been handed down, but Ms. Higginsen said, "I have just had enough."
"I surrender," she said. "I give up. I accept the fact that they don't want us in this theater. I couldn't accept this for years. I couldn't see why anyone would want to put people out of work. I have stopped asking why."
Ms. Higginsen said she obtained her lease legally and with the city's full knowledge of her profit-making status. She said that the theater had been empty for 15 years before she took her production into it and that the musical has brought significant economic benefit to the surrounding neighborhood.
She also said: "We have no air-conditioning in the summer. The ceiling is falling down. There are not sufficient bathrooms, and there are leaks."
Barbara J. Fife, the Deputy Mayor for Planning and Development, said she had been familiar with the issue since she was in the Manhattan Borough President's office. "The building is used for nonprofits," Ms. Fife said, and Ms. Higginsen's production, she said, "is not nonprofit."
Ms. Fife added, however, that her office hoped to negotiate an agreement between Reach Productions and the city's Department of Real Property that would allow the show to stay at the Heckscher for five more years. "She can operate with stability and then leave," Ms. Fife said.
But Ms. Higginsen, who wrote the musical with Mr. Wydro, to whom she is married, said: "I can't continue to do business under this threat of eviction. And this threat has been relentless."

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
What the U.S. Can Do to Pay for Its Past Mistakes

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT

 BODY:

Within Our Means
The Struggle for Economic Recovery After a Reckless Decade
By Alfred L. Malabre Jr.
Illustrated. 167 pages. Random House. $21.
Four years ago, Alfred L. Malabre Jr. published a book called "Beyond Our Means: How America's Long Years of Debt, Deficits and Reckless Borrowing Now Threaten to Overwhelm Us." It foresaw an economic hurricane producing three possible results: the kind of hyperinflation that Germany experienced in the 1920's, or the sort of radical disinflation America had in the 1930's, or, most likely of all, flat-out socialism. Reviewers turned purple with panic, and rushed to stuff their money in mattresses. 
 Now four years later, Mr. Malabre, who is an editor and columnist for The Wall Street Journal, has written another jeremiad called "Within Our Means: The Struggle for Economic Recovery After a Reckless Decade." It foresees an economic hurricane, but, well, uh, maybe there's time to tie the furniture down and tape the windows. Hyperinflation or deflation are still possibilities. (Socialism seems to have blown out to sea.) Yet now, Mr. Malabre writes: "The United States will probably be spared such Draconian punishment, but something close to it is entirely possible, for the American economy, as this book will document, is far sicker than it should be after so many years of recession-free growth."
What happened in the interval between the two books to make Mr. Malabre lighten his dark forebodings? The world neglected to come to an end. The stock market crashed but recovered. It is as if Mr. Malabre had been an actor onstage and someone backstage had missed his cue. Mr. Malabre stamped his foot and called for molten lava and a plague of frogs, and -- stamp! -- nothing happened. Stamp! Nothing. Well, maybe he had better improvise. So improvise is what he sets out to do in "Within Our Means." The trouble is, he never really finds his theme.
He starts out seeming to promise a prescription for our woes. He explains that if the first book's title, "Beyond Our Means," held the double meaning that it was beyond our means to stop living beyond our means, the title of his new book also has two meanings: It is within our means to learn to live within our means, "though the task will entail some self-inflicted pain -- higher taxes, less Federal largess, tighter regulation of business activity."
But having suggested that his book will be prescriptive, he spends five out of his six chapters detailing our problems again. Numbingly detailing our problems. Every reader knows the litany: the annual budget deficits, the huge national debt, the negative balance of trade, the lack of productivity, the mounting private debt, the dependence on foreign investment, the savings-and-loan crisis, the downturn in the business cycle. These things have been described before, not only by Mr. Malabre. For all their reality, they've become boring to read about.
And then in the last chapter, "Looking Ahead," Mr. Malabre equivocates. At various points, he writes the following sentences: "The road ahead will be rough." "There are a few bright spots." "Hope springs eternal, but it is difficult in such circumstances to believe that very deep trouble can in fact be avoided." "But it is not beyond our means to weather it and move on, through more sensible behavior to sounder prosperity." One begins to long for that hurricane.
And what is his prescription for the incurable disease from which we may be recovering? Are you ready? Higher taxes and reduced Federal spending. He concludes: "A greater effort must be made to attract able people to Washington." "Congres sional operations also need an overhaul." "A smaller budget deficit would reduce the Treasury's need to borrow, which would help lower interest rates and free funds to invest more in productive facilities and less in simply helping the Treasury roll over its debt. This in turn would serve to improve U.S. competitiveness and thus strengthen the nation's trade balance." Yes. And if chickens had teeth they would chew bubble gum.
Mr. Malabre's two books teach one invaluable lesson. It is dangerous to speculate about what lies ahead. Events have a way of undermining one's expectations. Mr. Malabre writes: "It is also time, with the Cold War over, that wherever possible foreign aid of a largely military nature be sharply curtailed. The largest recipient by far is Israel, which receives some $3 billion in aid from the United States each year. With such Soviet clients in the Middle East as Syria receiving far less aid from the U.S.S.R. and Eastern Europe, there is no reason for the United States not to cut back as well. But to do so would . . . require political courage." Also maybe a loss of touch with reality.
Whatever happens to the crisis in the American economy, if crisis is indeed the state that it is now in, the outcome will most likely surprise us. It has been said over and over that those who forget the past are condemned to repeat it. But economic events result from the behavior of people who remember the past all too well. The sum of their memories is unique, because each new generation remembers what none has remembered before, and so the consequences of its behavior must be unique. We cannot predict it; we can only blindly guess.
Mr. Malabre can stamp his foot or patiently explain. He can announce that now is when "the defense sector offers large cost-cutting opportunities." He can predict: "Cutting the tax rate on capital gains would also raise the incentive to save, making it more attractive for investors to put money into assets offering the potential for long-term growth. . . ." But whatever happens in the future will only make sense in retrospect.

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
A Sense Of Proportion

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
U.S. and allied planes have flown 11,000 combat missions so far against Iraqi targets. But air bombardment will not be enough, intelligence officials say. The 500,000 troops massed in Saudi Arabia, most of them American, will have to go into action on the ground. The fighting may go on for months.
This enormous war effort is necessary, President Bush says, to achieve a "new world order." 
 But as our attention is on the gulf war, something else is happening. In Moscow and Vilnius and Riga, the hopes of democracy and freedom are slipping away. The Soviet Union is moving rapidly back toward repression: a militarized form of the totalitarian state.
The headlines have been dwarfed by the war with Kuwait, the television coverage glancing. But think what has happened in the last two weeks.
* Soviet soldiers have shot and killed 19 civilians in Lithuania and Latvia.
* The Soviet Government has ordered armed soldiers to join the police in patrolling all major cities in the country.
* President Gorbachev has granted sweeping powers to the K.G.B. and the police to search private businesses -- foreign as well as domestic -- and to freeze their assets.
Those ominous actions have been accompanied by ominous rhetoric. Soviet military officers describe the elected government of Lithuania as "fascist." Secret "Committees for National Salvation" ask for presidential rule of the Baltic states -- as Czech Stalinists invited Warsaw Pact forces to crush the Dubcek Government in 1968.
Mikhail Gorbachev's position is still something of a mystery. He has not so far imposed presidential rule on the Baltics. He told the foreign press that events there were "tragic."
But what is clear is that Mr. Gorbachev is more and more relying on the new Soviet right, and deferring to it. Made up of military officers, K.G.B. leaders and Communist bureaucrats, it is deeply conservative and xenophobic. It fears economic reform, private enterprise and foreign investment. It denounces "bourgeois" ideology and demands a return to "Socialist" central control.
The right is deeply suspicious of the United States. Some question Mr. Gorbachev's joining American policy in the Persian Gulf, saying that it will lead to American domination there and will menace the U.S.S.R. A key right-wing figure, Col. Victor Alksnis, has denounced what he called Soviet "appeasement" in the gulf.
The trend of events in the Soviet Union must be of the deepest concern to President Bush, and to all of us. But the American Government's capacity to address the problem has been compromised by Mr. Bush's decision to go to war against Iraq.
Mr. Bush has criticized the shootings in Vilnius and Riga. He will probably postpone the summit meeting scheduled for next month. What more could he do to protest Soviet developments?
What he could do is to deal directly with the crucial immediate issue: the three Baltic republics. The United States has never recognized the Soviet takeover of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia in 1940. Nor, lately, has it directly encouraged their claims to renewed independence -- a cautious policy that seemed to me wise.
But the cynicism and brutality of recent Soviet military actions in the Baltics require a reappraisal of our policy. How can we just wring our hands when we see what looks like the development of an internal Brezhnev Doctrine, the use of armed force to suppress freedom in the republics? Today it is Lithuania; tomorrow it would be Georgia or the Ukraine or Russia.
There are no easy answers for the United States in the chaos now overtaking the Soviet Union. But President Bush should be forcefully protesting the repression in Lithuania and Latvia. He should be talking with those who are struggling for democracy in Vilnius and Riga and Moscow. But he cannot when he so urgently needs Soviet support for his policy in the Persian Gulf.
Mr. Bush is obsessed by the gulf crisis. He told David Frost that there has been "nothing like this since World War II. Nothing of this moral importance." As Haynes Johnson wrote in The Washington Post, Mr. Bush was saying: Not the Marshall Plan, not the cold war, not Korea, not Vietnam. Nothing to equal this conflict.
Mr. Bush and his Administration have lost their sense of proportion in this war. And if the Soviet Union goes down the road to darkness, they will have lost their new world order, too.

LENGTH: 586 words

HEADLINE: The Killing Fields Aren't Level

 BODY:
Close to 30 percent of the Army's troops in Operation Desert Storm are black, though blacks are just 14 percent of the nation's population between the ages of 18 and 24. In a land war, black casualties will be similarly disproportionate. Is it fair? Is it inevitable? For answers, one must search the soul of American society.
Gen. Colin Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs and a black, has pointed out that it is "simply a given" that any group suffers in proportion to its presence in the fighting force. Rejecting charges that the proportion of blacks is unfair, he says he's "proud that African-Americans have seen fit to volunteer to join the armed forces." 
 From World War II through Vietnam, most U.S. servicemen were drafted, the armed forces were larger, and minority representation was in closer proportion to the population. Today's all-volunteer system replaced the draft in 1973.
A big pay hike and cash benefits for education have raised the caliber of enlistments. More than 90 percent of recent recruits are high school graduates -- far higher than the national percentage or the percentage for draftees in the past. According to the Pentagon, the average G.I.'s socio-economic background is slightly below average for his age group, but -- nonpartisan analysts agree -- he is not a dropout from society. Still, blacks are more likely to enlist than whites. Almost 21 percent of U.S. forces worldwide are black; the figure is higher in the gulf because of large Army and Marine contingents.
Clifford Alexander, a black who was Secretary of the Army in the 1970's, explained the imbalance at the time in a few pointed words: "(Ask) why there is almost 40 percent unemployment among black teen-agers before you ask why they enlist or why they re-up." Their jobless rate is still above 30 percent, and the point endures: the military offers blacks more opportunities than life on the outside.
Once laggard, the military is now a leading force for integration. General Powell has said that before the gulf crisis, some blacks complained that planned cutbacks in the armed forces would hurt them, but "now I'm sort of getting the reverse, that perhaps they're overrepresented."
While the attractions are real -- rewarding career, education, escape or proud service -- they do not match the risk to life itself. Army recruiters don't advertise it. Casualty lists will tell it loud and clear. But life at home holds terror, too. Listen to a 19-year-old black who enlisted in Los Angeles last month: "It's nothing out there in the streets for you but trouble. I don't want to die at a young age getting caught up in the gang thing."
The Brookings Institution's Martin Binken, an authority on military service, says equal representation under current conditions is next to impossible; unless black enlistments were barred, the services would have to expand considerably, enlisting or drafting enough whites to balance the blacks, taking men now rejected. And blacks would still sustain more casualties than whites, because men with less schooling get low-skill duty, which includes combat.
The disproportion is unfair on its face. Tragically, it may be almost inevitable -- rooted in unequal opportunity. America owes its minorities a better chance, as offered by the job rights bill that President Bush vetoed last year. Meanwhile, despite the indignities they suffer in civilian life, or perhaps because of them, blacks in the military serve their nation with honor -- disproportionately.

HEADLINE: Americans Should Buy a Bit More American;
Their Surplus Dollars

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Buy American. American What?" (editorial, Jan. 12) criticizes Manuel Lujan, Secretary of the Interior, for advocating that we buy American cars. You argue that by buying foreign-made products we put dollars in the hands of our trading partners to buy our products. This is partly true. 
 Some of our trading partners (Japan and Germany) enjoy huge trade surpluses with the United States. They have plenty of dollars to buy our soybeans, commercial jetliners and computers. With their surplus dollars, however, they buy our real estate and corporations and build new factories in the United States.
The United States, with its year-after-year trade deficits, can only finance those deficits by selling assets such as a quarter of downtown Los Angeles, most of Honolulu, corporations in the entertainment business and the best golf courses.
The trade deficit is equal to the difference between what we save and what we invest. All Americans would do well to heed Mr. Lujan's advice. Narrowing the trade deficit would produce more jobs and increase investment at home. If continued trade deficits are so desirable, as you imply, why don't Japan and Germany alter their economic policies so that they can enjoy the rewards of massive trade deficits? Until a more compelling argument is made than you give, I'll stick with Mr. Lujan's advice and buy American.
 
FRED WEEKES
Berkeley, Calif., Jan. 14, 1991

HEADLINE: Brief History of an Earlier Antiwar Group

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Half-Century Later, F.B.I. Doesn't Forget" (letter, Dec. 29) contains serious errors about the American League for Peace and Democracy. The organization was not "founded by clergymen to keep the United States from entering World War II," was not infiltrated by Communists, nor was it dissolved overnight when Hitler invaded the Soviet Union, and "the party line reversed itself." 
 It was founded as the American League Against War and Fascism in September 1933, six years before war broke out in Europe, as part of an international movement headed by the French author Henri Barbusse to prevent war following Hitler's takeover of Germany that year.
Although prominent religious leaders, including Dr. Reinhold Niebuhr of Union Theological Seminary and Rabbi Israel Goldstein of the Social Justice Commission, Rabbinical Assembly of America, were among the original supporters, they were part of a coalition at the founding meeting in New York City that included representatives of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom, the Fellowship of Reconciliation, the War Resisters League, the Women's Peace Society, the Socialist-led League for Industrial Democracy, several labor unions, organizations of the unemployed and the Communist Party, whose leader, Earl Browder, addressed that gathering along with the pacifists A. J. Muste and Devere Allen, William Pickens, field secretary of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, and the union leader Emil Rieve. Plainly, there was no need for Communist infiltration. While some of the original supporters dropped away, others, especially labor unions after the founding of the C.I.O. in 1936, joined in its activities.
The American League for Peace and Democracy held its last meeting, in Philadelphia, in December 1939. Hitler's armies invaded the Soviet Union on June 22, 1941.
I regret that the letter writer feels it necessary to withhold signing his name half a century after he joined an organization dedicated to fighting Hitlerism and war, because of which his son was denied the right to wear a Navy uniform. Meanwhile, organizations seeking to persuade the Federal Bureau of Investigation to release uncensored copies of the mountainous lists it set up in those tragic times when the fundamental rights of Americans were severely restricted run into an impenetrable wall.
I was national youth secretary throughout most of the American League for Peace and Democracy's existence. Dr. Harry F. Ward, professor of Christian Ethics at Union Theological Seminary, was the League's national chairman.
 
JAMES LERNER
Brooklyn, Jan. 11, 1991

HEADLINE: Manhattan Bridge Had a Design Load Problem From the Start;
And Scrap the Tolls

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Jonathan Lang's idea in "Scrap Transit Fares" (Op-Ed, Dec. 29) can be extended to the highway transportation mess caused by the archaic system of tolls on highway bridges and tunnels. Delays in traffic caused by toll booths damage the economy and quality of life of the region: increased travel time; increases by millions of dollars in the cost of doing business; air pollution and fuel consumption caused by millions of hours of idling motors.
The revenue collected by tolls could equally and more efficiently be collected through a moderate increase in state motor fuel taxes in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
History shows the rise and fall of an economy parallels its transportation facilities.
 
HOWARD CRANDELL
Centerport, L.I., Jan. 5, 1991

HEADLINE: Woman In The News;
Dynamic Advocate; Nadine Strossen

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
The founding principles of the American Civil Liberties Union come to life in the family history of Nadine Strossen, its newly elected president.
She remembers her parents' stories of her maternal grandfather, a recent immigrant from Italy, who endured public ridicule by local officials for refusing to fight in World War I. The A.C.L.U. started about the same time, established in part to defend dissenters from government attacks on free expression. 
 "Because he was a conscientious objector, he was made to stand up against the courthouse so people could spit on him," she recalled, moments after her election on Saturday as the civil liberties union's first female president. "I had a strong sense of individual rights and sticking one's neck out on behalf of unpopular causes, even at the risk of personal ostracism."
 
Interest in First Amendment
 Members of the A.C.L.U. called Ms. Strossen a dynamic spokeswoman and an astute constitutional scholar with a keen interest in the First Amendment. In interviews and a seemingly nonstop schedule of debates and speeches, she talks about the group's work with an enthusiasm that blends plainspokenness and sophistication.
"I think this is the most important organization in the country, if not the world," she said. "To say what we're doing is controversial is to say the Bill of Rights is controversial. I want to emphasize the American in American Civil Liberties Union."
Sam Walker, an A.C.L.U. board member and author of a recent history of the group, said of Ms. Stossen: "She really believes this stuff. It's not just campaign rhetoric."
Ms. Strossen, a 40-year-old professor of constitutional law, Federal courts and human rights at New York Law School, has served the A.C.L.U. as a board member in 1983 and as general counsel since 1986. She taught at Columbia and New York University law schools and practiced commercial litigation at several New York firms.
 
Planned 'Traditional' Career
 Born in Jersey City on Aug. 18, 1950, Nadine Strossen moved with her family to Hopkins, Minn., when she was 8 years old after her father, an oil company executive, was transferred. Her father, Woodrow J. Strossen, emigrated to the United States after American troops liberated him from a German labor camp, where he had been imprisoned for anti-Hitler activities. He later changed his first name to Woodrow, in honor of President Woodrow Wilson.
Although Ms. Strossen said she planned on a "traditional" woman's career like teaching or graduate school, her involvement in debating and feminist groups while at Radcliffe College sparked an interest in law. "I met women lawyers in women's issues and that gave me a sense of confidence," she said. She attended Harvard Law School, where she was editor of the Law Review and graduated magna cum laude in 1975.
Noting that the A.C.L.U. has long addressed issues like reproductive rights and sexual equality, some observers said Ms. Strossen's victory was a greater shift not for the organization but for the legal profession. "It's the coming of maturity of women who entered law school in the 70's," said Sylvia A. Law, a professor and co-director of a civil liberties program at New York University Law School.
A.C.L.U. officials said her election sent a signal that the organization is committed to affirmative action.
Feminists have criticized the A.C.L.U., saying it had too few influential women, but Ms. Strossen said her election could help underscore the organization's commitment to women's rights. She noted that the A.C.L.U. has been responsible for 80 percent of all Federal cases involving reproductive rights.
When she assumes the presidency on Feb. 1, Ms. Strossen will inherit an organization that has grown to a membership at 300,000 and that includes projects on issues like abortion rights, censorship, capital punishment and workers' rights. She expects that the war in the Persian Gulf will revive traditional challenges to dissent, conscientious objectors, foreigners and the media.
"There are tremendous assaults on civl liberties people are wiling to accept as part of a wartime mentality," she said.
But she is also concerned about another conflict, one that will continue after the last bullet has been fired: the nation's war on drugs, which she believes has imposed limits on basic freedoms in the pursuit of public safety.
Although many board members said the national organization is stronger than ever, Ms. Strossen said she wants to enhance the vitality of its local affiliates, helping them with fund-raising and public education efforts. "That's where civil liberties are implemented," she said. "It's one thing for the Supreme Court to decide something and another for a local school board to abide by it."
Those efforts will help, she said, because the group's defense of unpopular causes like pornography or the rights of neo-Nazis to demonstrate has been misunderstood by the public and by an increasingly conservative Federal judiciary.
Reflecting her personal interest in human rights, she said she wanted to explore ways of applying international human rights laws to issues before state courts like gay rights and capital punishment. She wants to expand the A.C.L.U.'s outreach, establishing chapters not only at colleges, but also in high schools, where disputes over censorship and minors' right to abortion have put them "on the cutting edge" of civil liberties.
She lives on the Upper West Side of Manhattan with her husband of 10 years, Eli M. Noam, an economist and lawyer who teaches at the Graduate School of Business at Columbia Univeristy. A former member of the Public Service Commission, Mr. Noam also directs the university's Center for Telecommunications and Information Studies.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
Review of California's Debt May Result in Downgrading

 BODY:
The ever-thinning ranks of triple-A-rated states may soon lose another if the Standard & Poor's Corporation lowers the rating of California's general obligation debt.
Standard & Poor's announced yesterday that it had placed under review for possible downgrading some $11.6 billion in California general obligation bonds as a result of a rapidly developing deficit that is projected for the fiscal years 1991 and 1992. 
 The rating agency said it was also placing under review about $3 billion of debt issued by state agencies, whose ratings are guaranteed or supported by state appropriations.
S.& P. noted that the state's economic growth, while still stronger than that of most of the nation, slowed strikingly in the second half of 1990. General fund revenues on a $42 billion budget are expected to be $2 billion less than those of the state's most recent forecast, made in November.
"Historically, budget reserves have been more than adequate against shifting economic conditions," the agency said. "But the current shortfall will eradicate reserves and leave the state with a 1991 deficit approaching $1.8 billion."
Analysts at S.& P. plan to review the situation during the months leading up to the next formal revenue forecast in May, waiting to see whether the state government takes action to reduce the projected deficits for 1991 and 1992. In the absence of a rapid economic recovery, failure to address the budget gaps will result in a rating in the double-A category, the agency said.
Moody's Investors Service, which rates California's general obligation debt Aaa, does not have the outstanding debt under review.

HEADLINE: Careers;
Marketing Holds Up In Recession

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
ADVERTISING spending is down and there have been many layoffs and forced retirements in the field, but demand for corporate marketing executives continues strong, according to Miles L. McKie, a managing director in the Chicago office of Russell Reynolds, the management recruiting firm.
As a general rule during a recession, many companies cut their advertising spending to save money, Mr. McKie said in a telephone interview last week. 
 "My contacts with senior executives indicate it is no different in this recession," he said. "But the interesting aspect is that there is currently a continuing strong demand by corporations for experienced marketing executives, with good credentials."
"Also, I would call this a bicoastal recession, not a heartland recession, such as we had a few years ago," he said, noting that job losses tended to be heaviest in the Northeast and on the Pacific Coast. For example, recruiting for financial and accounting executives is down sharply in Eastern cities like Boston and New York and in major West Coast cities, but demand for manufacturing executives has held up well, especially in the Midwest, he said.
"Having said all this about the recession, I do see some companies spending more to build their market share," he said, adding that the focus is on upgrading marketing staffs. One indication is that the demand for marketing executives has not changed during the last 12 months, despite the recession. "It seems to go from strength to strength," he said.
"We are doing consumer-driven searches for senior vice presidents and down the ranks through directors of marketing," he said, "and I think there is demand at lower levels, too. In other words, the recession has not affected demand."
The demand is coming from basic consumer-oriented companies like food producers and other packaged-goods companies as well as service organizations, he said.
He said that hiring skilled, creative marketers was one way for large companies, intent on gaining market share, to upgrade their staffs. "Now, especially for the top spots, companies demand marketers with service-company experience, such as with airlines, financial services and hotels, in addition to or instead of packaged-goods experience." he said.
While advertising expenses have been cut sharply, companies have been using their in-house marketing staffs to increase sales-promotion efforts, like dealer incentives, coupons, samples, rebates, advertising on supermarket carts and special sales. The marketing staffs often work with consumer-promotion companies. "My observation is that the outside consumer-promotion companies like to hire people out of their client companies rather than from advertising agencies," Mr. McKie said.
He noted, however, that "it is well recognized that companies cannot build permanent market share just on sales-promotion efforts." Temporary sales promotions do not buy long-term loyalty, but advertising does, he said.
Some insight into the current situation for marketing executives comes from Lee Hecht Harrison, an outplacement firm. It has just issued its latest quarterly booklet of resumes of job-seeking executives.
First offered in June 1989, the list then had a few pages of brief anonymous descriptions of the talents of middle managers seeking new jobs through the firm. Now it has evolved into the Directory of Executive Talent, a 60-page booklet published quarterly, with brief descriptive paragraphs about 360 middle managers seeking jobs. The increase in the number of job seekers indicates the tough times facing middle managers who have been dismissed.
The firm sends out 5,000 copies of the quarterly to corporations and to management recruiting firms, both of which can request full resumes from executives on the list.
Among the listings in the directory, about 13 percent are marketing executives, about the same percentage as in the previous directory published in September.
About 11 percent of the requests for resumes from the September issue were for marketing executives, said Penny J. Shaw, a senior vice president of the firm. She agreed that "a lot of upgrading is going on" as companies try to improve and strengthen their marketing staffs.
Based on the September issue, about 65 percent of the requests for resumes came from companies and 35 percent from search firms, she said. "That compares with about 50-50 when the directory first began," she added.
The new directory has been out only a few days, and so far there has not been enough time to measure the number of requests for resumes,
"The good news" Ms. Shaw said, "is that executves in our directory are finding jobs, although it takes them longer than it did a year ago."

HEADLINE: Affordable-Housing Owners Get a Tax Cut in New Jersey

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON Jan. 28

 BODY:
The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that owners of subsidized low- and moderate-income housing were entitled to reduced property taxes.
The court, in a 7-to-0 decision, upheld a lower-court ruling that said local tax assessors must recognize restrictions on the resale value of housing units designated as affordable and not tax them at full market value. 
 "There was a danger that families already living in low- and moderate-income housing units would no longer be able to afford it if the court had allowed towns to assess the units at full value," said Donald M. Palombi, a deputy attorney general representing the Council on Affordable Housing. "There would have been a lot of foreclosures."
 
Housing Is Mandatory
 In a series of rulings known as the Mount Laurel decisions starting in the early 1970's, the State Supreme Court said all municipalities must provide affordable housing opportunites for low- and moderate-income families.
Today's ruling stemmed from a decision in 1986 by the Village of Ridgefield Park inBergen County to assess its affordable housing at fair market value without recognizing deed restrictions that lowered the units' resale value.
The owners of two condominium units, whose resale value was limited to $46,000 but whose tax assessments exceeded $80,000, appealed. A state tax court ruled in favor of the municipality, but the Appellate Division of Superior Court overturned that ruling, and the Supreme Court today concurred.
Sidna B. Mitchell, a spokeswoman for the Council on Affordable Housing, said more than 7,500 housing units would be affected immediately by the ruling. Eventually, shesaid, if the state meets its goal, the owners of 145,000 affordable housing units will be covered.
Stephen Eisdorfer, an assistant public advocate, said only one other municipality, Peapack-Gladstone in Somerset County, had tried to assess units in a low- and moderate-income development for the elderly at full market value. The borough changed its mind after the Appellate Court decision in the Ridgefield Park case in 1989.
Today's Supreme Court decision settling the issue will not have a major impact on the tax structure in Ridgefield Park. The vil lage of about 12,000 residents has only four units that carry restrictions to ensure their sale to low- or moderate-income buyers.
Brian T. Campion, the lawyer for the two families who appealed their assessments, said his clients had paid the higher taxes of more than $1,000 a year while the appeal was being decided and would now be entitled to a partial refund.
 
A 'Burden' on Property
 The State Supreme Court did not write a majority opinion, instead adopting the Appellate Division ruling written by Judge Sylvia B. Pressler, who said, "The deed restriction limiting resale price constitutes a patent burden on the value of the property."
"It is, moreover, a restriction whose burden on the owner is clearly designed to secure a public benefit of overriding social and economic importance -- namely the maintenance of this state's woefully inadequate inventory of affordable housing."
Justice Gary S. Stein, filed a concurring opinion that supported Judge Pressler's analysis but expressed some concern that ownership of affordable housing units by families whose incomes had increased beyond the low- and moderate-income levels "could dilute the public purpose and benefit of the deed restriction."
Justice Stein said the problem might be "self correcting," since low-income families that experience significant income increases "may tend to seek better-quality housing."
But he recommended that state housing regulators re-examine their program to make sure the aim of insuring adequate supplies of affordable housing "is not frustrated by attrition."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Narrowly Mixed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in extremely listless trading yesterday, as bond prices inched higher and short-term notes moved a bit lower.
"The only news is that the market is holding, which is somewhat surprising in light of the fact that we have lots of supply to bid on soon," one government-bond trader said. 
 The Treasury is expected to announce tomorrow that it will sell between $34 billion and $35 billion worth of notes and bonds at its quarterly refunding auctions beginning Feb. 5.
Market participants largely ignored a report showing that personal consumption, which had lagged badly in the first two months of the fourth quarter, bounced back in December, rising by seven-tenths of a percent in the month.
 
Surprise for Analysts
 The report came as a surprise to some analysts. They said that based on the consumption figures, the odds that the economy would contract in the first quarter had been reduced.
"It is too early to make a prediction, but the assumption that G.N.P. is definitely going to be down in the first quarter has been shaken," said Raymond W. Stone, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., research firm.
"Unless we see consumption start to contract again, the odds now seem to favor that first-quarter growth will be positive."
The consumption figures, in conjunction with last Friday's preliminary estimate that output in the economy fell at an annual rate of 2.1 percent in the fourth quarter, had a dampening impact on prices of short-term notes and bills.
Traders said the figures made it slightly less likely that the Federal Reserve Board would move to lower short-term interest rates when its policy-making Open Market Committee meets in Washington next week.
 
Higher Bill Rates
 Interest rates on new three-month and six-month Treasury bills auctioned yesterday moved higher, partly in response to the recent economic reports.
The new three-month bills were autioned at an average discount rate of 6.22 percent, up from an average rate of 6.14 percent at last week's sale.
Meanwhile, bids on new six-month bills produced an average discount rate of 6.28 percent, up from an average rate of 6.21 percent a week ago.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 105 31/32 late yesterday, up 1/8 point, to yield 8.20 percent, down from 8.22 percent late Friday.
Among note issues, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 103 3/ 32, up 1/32, to yield 8.03 percent. And the 7 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 26/32, down 1/32, to yield 7.10 percent.
 
BankAmerica Notes
 In the investment-grade corporate bond market, the BankAmerica Corporation offered $100 million of new 12-year notes through an underwriting group led by Merrill Lynch & Company.
The 10 percent notes, which mature Dec. 1, 2003, are noncallable for life. They were priced at 99.85 to yield 10.022 percent, 1.97 percentage points higher than the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service and A- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Activity in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds was extremely light, traders said. However, they added that in the wake of Moody's ratings downgrade late Friday, bids on outstanding Citicorp securities fell by as much as 2 points.
"There is not that much trading of Citi paper," one corporate trader said.
As an example, the trader said that bids on an outstanding 9 percent Citicorp issue maturing in 1999 fell to $82 yesterday, to yield 12.53 percent. On Friday, the same securities were offered at $84, to yield 12 percent.
 
California Ratings Cut
 Activity in the tax-exempt municipal bond market was also very slow. Traders said they were trying to assess the impact of a move yesterday by Standard & Poor's to place the State of California on "credit watch," a step that could lead the agency to lower its current AAA rating on California securities.
Market participants said that bids on outstanding California general-obligation bonds fell by 1/2 point to 3/4 point after the Standard & Poor's announcement.
"The good news at the moment is that there are not a lot of California bonds around right now," one trader said. "But the Street is still confused about what this will mean."
California normally sells between $500 million and $700 million worth of securities every six weeks.
But traders said yesterday that because of the state's fiscal problems, there were rumors that California, which is expected to sell new bonds next month, might have to increase the size of its auctions to well over $1 billion.

HEADLINE: Weicker Sees $1 Billion Rise In State Taxes

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Jan. 28

 BODY:
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. said today that he was prepared to cut the preliminary state budget for the next fiscal year by 10 percent but that Connecticut's shortfall in tax revenues was so large that residents faced $1 billion or more in new or higher taxes.
"Let's not tiptoe around on this -- that's the dimensions of the problem," he said at a news conference in his office. 
 Mr. Weicker, a former Republican who took office on Jan. 9 as a third-party governor, had declined until today to tip his hand in even a general way about how much might be needed in new taxes to close a budget gap that is projected to reach $2.2 billion over the next 17 months.
He still did not provide any specifics about what state programs might be cut or what taxes raised in the budget plan he is to present to the General Assembly on Feb. 20.
 
$850 Million in Cuts Identified
 He said $850 million to $900 million in cuts had been identified in the $8.6 billion preliminary budget for the fiscal year starting July 1. While most of the remaining $1.3 billion shortfall might take the form of new or higher taxes, he said, further cuts are being explored.
Connecticut, along with dozens of other states, has seen its tax collections, especially those from sales and corporate profit taxes, plummet in the recession. The sales and corporate taxes together provide more than 50 percent of the state's revenues.
Leaders of the Democratic majority in the General Assembly reacted cautiously to the Governor's announcement, with several saying his numbers were simply too vague to have much meaning. Republicans were less kind.
"I don't think that that kind of tax increase is at all reasonable," said the House minority leader, Edward C. Krawiecki Jr., a Republican from Bristol. "We're going to have a very long haul during this legislative cycle if those numbers are in fact the kinds of numbers that the Governor recommends on Feb. 20."
Mr. Weicker stressed in releasing the figures that discussions on the budget were continuing. He said, for example, that negotiations had yet to be completed with unions representing state employees about what their "part of the solution" will be in terms of pay or benefit concessions or possible layoffs. But he added that he would try to avoid wide layoffs that could make a bad economy even worse.
Mr. Weicker also repeated his opposition to borrowing money -- through the sale of state bonds, for example -- as even a partial solution to the problem. But he conceded that all revenue measures were still on the table and that "absolutely nothing" has been ruled out.
Connecticut's biggest single revenue source is its 8 percent sales tax. Budget estimates project that each percentage point increase would bring in only about $310 million toward filling the budget gap.
The second biggest source is the corporate profits tax, where each additional percentage point would be expected to bring in about $5.4 million. Both of those taxes are also already among the highest in the country.
 
Unexpected Announcement
 Mr. Weicker's announcement, which came unexpectedly at a routine question-and-answer session with reporters, did not shed any light on whether his budget plan would try to patch existing state finances or overhaul them by introducing an income tax on wages.
Connecticut is one of only 10 states that do not tax regular income, although it does tax money earned from dividends, interest and capital gains.
Some lawmakers, including the co-chairman of the Assembly's Finance, Revenue and Bonding Committee, Representative Richard T. Mulready, a Democrat from West Hartford, said they thought Mr. Weicker's tentative tax numbers were so high that an income tax might ultimately emerge as the only option.
 
Two Income-Tax Plans
 Mr. Mulready said his committee had already decided to consider an income-tax plan whether Mr. Weicker suggested one or not. Two proposals are under consideration, he said, one a flat wage tax of 5.75 percent on all income over $25,000 and one a graduated tax that would begin at 4 percent for income over $25,000 and rise to 8 percent for income over $100,000.
Both plans would generate about $2.5 billion in revenue, Mr. Mulready said, a figure that he said would allow the state to balance its budget and -- along with Mr. Weicker's $900 million in spending cuts -- still include $800 million in reductions in other taxes.
Mr. Krawiecki, the Republican minority leader, said he believed Mr. Weicker's preliminary numbers pointed down the wrong road for the state. He said the $900 million in cuts were not really cuts, but rather simply reductions from the "unreasonable and illogical" spending plans filed last year by agency heads working under Gov. William A. O'Neill, a Democrat.
Those budget plans called for a 21 percent increase in spending for the fiscal year that begins July 1. The cuts proposed today would reduce the total growth rate in the budget next year to 11 percent, Mr. Krawiecki said. He said Republicans would seek a growth rate that was closer to 5 percent.

HEADLINE: Credit Card Defaults Rise

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The number of Americans defaulting on credit card payments soared in November, Moody's Investors Service Inc. said yesterday.
"Charge-offs and delinquencies in each of the past few months have been considerably higher" than a year earlier, a Moody's economist, Andrew Silver, said. "We're starting to see the effects of a slowing economy and the high levels of debt accumulated by consumers in the 1980's."
In what Mr. Silver said was "another indication that households are having increasing difficulty making their monthly debt payments," the portion of total debt paid back by consumers slipped to 10.33 percent from 11.75 percent.
Credit card debts, like mortgages, are sold to investors in the form of bank-issued securities. In November, Moody's Aggregate Charge-off Index -- which tracks losses on these securities -- rose 49 percent over the previous year.
The index rose to 4.5 percent, from 3.03 perent in November 1989, the bond-rating agency said. Total delinquencies rose to 5.9 percent of debt outstanding, against 4.37 percent a year earlier.
