HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Facing Heavy Losses, Tonka Seeks a Buyer

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: MINNETONKA, Minn., Jan. 28

 BODY:
The Tonka Corporation, the nation's third-largest toy maker, predicted substantial losses today for the fourth quarter and for 1990 and said it had been involved in talks about a possible sale of the company.
Tonka did not identify any potential buyer. The company said the discussions were preliminary. 
 Analysts said a sale of Tonka might be necessary because of its heavy debt load and expected losses. Tonka, maker of Tonka trucks and Play-Doh, took on $555 million in debt when it acquired Kenner Parker Toys Inc. in 1987.
Another toy maker, Lewis Galoob Toys Inc., said on Friday that it had retained Bear, Stearns & Company to explore financial alternatives, including the possible formation of "strategic alliances."
Citing slow retail sales, Galoob reiterated a forecast of a "significant loss" for the year. Galoob makes Micro Machines miniature vehicles.
News that its rivals were involved in possible buyout talks sent Tyco Toys Inc. stock higher, analysts said. Tyco makes the Ideal toy line. Its shares rose $1.625 today, to $10, in over-the-counter trading. On the New York Stock Exchange, Galoob fell 25 cents, to $3, and Tonka slipped 75 cents, to $4.375.
Analysts said it was unclear whether Hasbro Inc. and Mattel Inc., the largest and second-largest toy makers, respectively, would try to acquire Tonka. A Mattel spokesman would not comment, and a Hasbro representative could not be reached.
Carol Palmer, an analyst at Duff & Phelps, said Tonka's troubles stemmed partly from the economy and partly from the fact that it does not have a hit toy.
Tonka estimated its sales for 1990 would be about $786 million, down from $870.5 million in 1989. For the first nine months of 1990, Tonka reported a loss of $25.4 million, on sales of $541.3 million. For all of 1989, Tonka reported a profit of $7.7 million, or 90 cents a share.

HEADLINE: Spreading the Faith, and the Debate

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS

 BODY:
Some people are calling it the "stealth" encyclical -- the long papal letter on missionary work that appeared last Tuesday with little advance notice and no English texts available in the United States.
 In Rome, Vatican spokesmen said the document, "Redemptoris Missio," reflected fears that Catholicism was lagging behind Islam in expansion in Asia, Africa and the Middle East. But when American Catholic officials read the text, they found it aimed more at debates within Christian ranks about the whole point of missionary activity. And officials of Jewish groups sought reassurance that the letter did not signal a setback for Catholic-Jewish relations. 
Pope John Paul II apparently wanted to counter any impression that the church's effort to spread the faith through missionary work might be eclipsed by its dialogue with other religions and its involvement in economic and political struggles. Earlier papal documents have dwelt on the economic and political struggles; what is special to "Redemptoris Missio" ("Mission of the Redeemer") is the Pope's concern with theological views that suggest Christianity has no special status as a means to salvation.
Scholars in comparative religions have been drawn to the idea that all world religions, even in their differences, are about equal in their potential for spiritual fulfillment. The idea has also gained adherents among academic Christian theologians, especially those deeply engaged in discussions with representatives of major faiths like Buddhism, Islam and Hinduism.
 
Missionary as Hero
 What effect these views have had on missionary work is an open question. Auxiliary Bishop William J. McCormack of New York, American director of the church's mission arm, the Society for the Propagation of the Faith, said missionaries in the field were "getting on with the job and not letting various theories interfere with their work." But he added: "These theories are greatly discussed. Intellectually, if they stay there long enough, they will have an impact."
Clearly, the Pope would like to restore a heroic image of missionaries, harking back to the days when their courage and ingenuity in far-off lands made them a religious equivalent of Indiana Jones. That image has been weakened by the declining number of people joining the priesthood and religious orders, the mainstays of Catholic missionary work.
In addition, many Christians have recognized that in the past missionary efforts were linked to colonization or foreign domination. That awareness has increased self-consciousness about claims of Christianity's superiority to other world religions, especially when the Christian faith seemed to be losing ground in the missionaries' own homelands in Europe or the United States.
 
'Myth' of Uniqueness
 William R. Burrows, managing editor of Orbis Books, the publishing house of the Maryknoll order of missionaries, speaks of a division between younger and older missionaries. Those under 55 years old are more likely to see validity in non-Christian religions as a simple matter of their experience, he said. But they struggle with "how to square the circle" of fitting that experience into their older theology.
In 1988, Orbis Books published "The Myth of Christian Uniqueness," co-edited by John Hicks, a Protestant scholar, and Paul Knitter, a Catholic theologian. Mr. Knitter said Vatican officials had called his work inimical to missionary efforts, charging that his approach would remove all incentive to preach Christianity and gather converts.
Mr. Knitter denied that accusation but acknowledged that in his view, seeking converts should be subordinate to interreligious dialogue and to practical cooperation for human progress. For such a dialogue to be genuine, he added, all religions would have to be on equal footing.
By rejecting this view, the Pope's encyclical wades into a debate cutting across Christian denominations. It will play a part at the sessions when representatives of hundreds of Protestant and Eastern Orthodox groups gather in Canberra, Australia, next month for a World Assembly of the World Council of Churches.
It is also a debate in which individual positions remain in flux and party lines are not fixed. In "Christian Uniqueness Reconsidered," another book published by Orbis, several strong supporters of interreligious dialogue reply critically to the religious pluralism advocated by Mr. Knitter and Mr. Hicks. This kind of pluralism, the criticism goes, tries not to impose Christian standards on non-Christian religions but ends by imposing the standards of some form of modern liberalism on Christian and non-Christian religions alike.
 
Keeping the Dialogue Going
 The Pope's insistence on retaining some traditional priorities does not mean that he rules out the newer concerns. The encyclical strongly endorses missionary efforts to relieve poverty, counter political oppression and defend human rights.
Its recognition of God's saving presence in other religions goes well beyond the Second Vatican Council's decree on missions and Pope Paul VI's 1975 letter on evangelization, said the Rev. John F. Hotchkin, executive director of the American bishops' Secretariat on Ecumenical and Interreligious Affairs.
The encyclical said interreligious dialogue could lead to spiritual growth and asked all the faithful to engage in some form of it. Father Hotchkin called it "as positive a statement as I've seen" in authoritative church declarations.
Responding to concern expressed by spokesmen for some Jewish groups about the document's stress on Jesus as the source of salvation, Father Hotchkin said the encyclical was not meant to address relations between Christianity and its parent religion, Judaism. They are in a different category from Christianity's relations with other major faiths, he said.
Rabbi Jack Bemporad, interreligious affairs officer for the Synagogue Council of America, agreed with this interpretation. But two other leaders in interreligious discussions, Rabbi A. James Rudin of the American Jewish Committee and Rabbi Leon Klenicki of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, said they regretted that the distinction had not been made explicit in the encyclical.
In fact, the document left a lot unstated. It restated the Christian teaching that all salvation comes from Christ and that this occurs ordinarily and most fully through the churches. But the encyclical also said many people would attain salvation even though they would never be Christians.
The "mysterious" relation of their salvation to Christ and the church is something the encyclical did not try to explain theologically. The Pope has left plenty of puzzles for theologians to ponder and, no doubt, debate.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Dips on Thin Volume; Recession Fears Are Cited

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar drifted aimlessly lower in thin trading yesterday, undermined by a lack of compelling news about the Persian Gulf war and continued worries about the recession, analysts said.
The dollar initially edged higher in domestic trading against major foreign currencies on a Commerce Department report that personal incomes in December rose seven-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.75 trillion. 
 Some market participants said the figure was more than double what many traders were expecting. The rise, however, was not enough to offset the general downward pull of the stagnating United States economy.
"The market still feels the Fed will ease more before the economy bottoms out," said Tom Benfer, a senior marketing representative in the currency trading department of Bank of Montreal.
Concern that lower interest rates and the United States recession could erode the dollar's value continued to lessen the currency's appeal as a safe holding during the Persian Gulf crisis.
Traders said the war was considered a non-event yesterday, with few developments major enough to spur buying or selling of dollars.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.07 Japanese yen, to a closing 132.45 yen. It was quoted at 132.15 yen late in London trading. In New York, the dollar fell to 131.60 yen from late Friday's 132.55 yen.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.9645, from $1.9580 late Friday. Later, in New York, 1 cost $1.9650, more than the $1.9564 late Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday, included: 1.4871 German marks, down from 1.4910; 1.2617 Swiss francs, down from 1.2628; 5.0515 French francs, down from 5.0685; 1,116.25 Italian lire, down from 1,120.50, and 1.1624 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1643.

HEADLINE: McDonald's Net Up 8.8% in the 4th Quarter

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 28

 BODY:
The McDonald's Corporation reported today that its net income rose 8.8 percent in the fourth quarter, to a record $186.2 million, and was up 10.4 percent for all of 1990, to $802.3 million, also a record. But analysts said that the earnings were inflated by unusual gains and other additions to profits that came from outside of its basic fast-food operations.
McDonald's latest results compared with fourth-quarter income in 1989 of $171.1 million and full-year income of $726.7 million. Revenues for the fourth quarter were $1.73 billion, up from $1.58 billion a year ago; revenues for the year were $6.78 billion, compared with $6.14 billion in 1989. Earnings per share jumped to 51 cents from 46 cents, for the quarter, and for the full year rose to $2.20 a share, from $1.95. 
While McDonald's, in a statement, painted a glowing picture of its performance, several securities analysts who watch the company said that after putting aside special items, the company's adjusted profits were down and that management was trying to minimize a fundamental deterioration in McDonald's business.
"The fourth-quarter results were awful," said Caroline Levy of Lehman Brothers. "This is a company that has severe, severe problems."
In particular, Ms. Levy and other Wall Street analysts pointed to what they called McDonald's anemic United States operations.
 
Profits Down at U.S. Restaurants
 For more than two years, sales and profits have been falling at McDonald's Ameican restaurants. The decline has come partly because of the domestic recession, partly because of consumer concerns over cholesterol, high fat foods like burgers, and partly because of stepped-up competition, particularly price cutting, by rivals like Burger King, Wendy's, Taco Bell and Pizza Hut.
Ms. Levy, for instance, calculates that among McDonald's company-owned restaurants in this country, operating profits companywide fell 2 percent in the first quarter, 9 percent in the second quarter, 12 percent in the third quarter and 14 percent in the fourth quarter. This figure is somewhat exaggerated by the fact that the number of company-owned McDonald's restaurants fell in 1990 from 1989.
Michael G. Mueller of Montgomery Securities, meanwhile, calculates that in the fourth-quarter average sales at individual, company-owned McDonald's restaurants in this country fell 1.8 percent from a year ago. "Real" sales per restaurant, he says, which are sales adjusted for price increases, fell 5.6 percent.
Analysts say that results at franchisee-owned restaurants in this country have been equally weak. Customer counts have been flat, real sales have been declining, and the restaurants have been losing share to more feisty rivals, particularly Taco Bell.
"McDonald's just has not been as aggressive as the competition in delivering value to the consumer," Mr. Mueller said.
For McDonald's shareholders, the good news is that the company has been doing extremely well in Europe and Asia. Indeed, the strong overseas results were the principal factor behind the record fourth-quarter results that the company reported today.
McDonald's stock closed at $27.75, today, down 62.5 cents in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
Analysts, who consider the per-share numbers to be perhaps the best indicators of a company's health, noted that the 51-cent figure was inflated by unusually big gains on the sale of company-owned McDonald's restaurants as well as by a lower tax rate in 1990's fourth quarter versus the comparable 1989 period. The analysts said that adjusted for these items, McDonald's per share results were flat compared with a year ago, at about 45 cents.
Publicly, McDonald's officials are not nearly as pessimistic as the analysts about the company's United States situation. But the officials do acknowledge that the recession is cutting into McDonald's domestic business. And they confirmed today that the company was taking several steps in response.

HEADLINE: 3 Governors React To Budget Pressure

 BODY:
As the recession in the region worsens and a new fiscal year approaches, three states are contemplating stringent measures to balance their budgets.
Staring at a $6 billion deficit, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo will propose raising New York's gasoline tax by 10 cents a gallon.
In Connecticut, which faces a $2.2 billion budget shortfall over the next 17 months, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. plans to trim spending by 10 percent and raise taxes.
And Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey approved toll increases on the New Jersey Turnpike.

HEADLINE: Japan's Stern Warning on Trade Sanctions

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28

 BODY:
A top Japanese Treasury official warned today that if the United States applied sanctions against his country because of slowness in opening financial markets, Tokyo would respond by curbing credit to the United States, creating a "very, very harmful" situation.
The warning by Makoto Utsumi, the Vice Minister of Finance for International Affairs, was considered unusually blunt, underscoring rising tensions in negotiations that Washington and Tokyo are holding over longstanding American demands for better access to Japanese financial markets for American financial institutions. 
 It has long been speculated that American sanctions against Japan could lead to Japanese reprisals in the financial sector. But rarely have Japanese officials spoken so openly about consequences for the United States.
 
Differences Not Narrowed
 After a daylong meeting here, Mr. Utsumi and his American counterpart, David C. Mulford, the Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, failed to narrow any of their differences over the pace of Japanese financial services deregulation. No date was even set to continue negotiations.
Mr. Utsumi's remarks were delivered at a news conference with Mr. Mulford after the meeting. The meeting was a continuation of talks that began in 1984 to remove barriers in Japan's financial services industry.
The talks have assumed rising importance against the backdrop of a strong Congressional push for legislation that would impose sanctions and Bush Administration plans, expected to be announced soon, for reforming the nation's banking system.
 
Japan Is Primary Target
 The sanctions bill -- introduced by Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan, the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, and Jake Garn of Utah, its ranking Republican -- would authorize regulators to deny bids for expansion in the United States by financial institutions based in countries that bar American companies from comparable competitive opportunities.
The bill is aimed mainly at Japan, which despite some changes over the years, still maintains an elaborate web of laws and practices that Washington believes keeps foreign banks and securities firms from competing on equal terms with the Japanese.
American officials assert, for example, that controls over interest rates allow Japanese banks to compete more successfully for money, giving them substantial advantages when they expand overseas, like in the United States.
 
No Bush Support
 But the Bush Administration opposes the Riegle-Garn legislation, saying that narrow reciprocity as a principle of trade policy would lead to escalating retaliation.
Mr. Mulford told reporters today that the United States was trying to get Japan to "address the changing environment with regard to rising Congressional concerns about deregulation and access in Japan." He spoke of "new forces that could result in a substantial politicization of the process unless there could be very rapid progress in Japan."
Responding to questions about the Riegle-Garn legislation, which almost cleared the last session of Congress and was recently reintroduced, Mr. Utsumi noted pointedly that the United States "is experiencing a credit crunch."

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: RECRUITING;
Many Are Calling; Some Will Be Chosen but Not All Will Fight

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME

 BODY:
For recruiters finding themselves with both a popular war and a shrinking military, the Persian Gulf is providing a new sort of Catch-22.
As in Joseph Heller's satirical World War II novel, in which almost everything came with a catch, those most interested in fighting in the Persian Gulf are often finding the military a hard place to join, and those the military most wants may be harder to recruit. 
 "I've had a number of phone calls from people who want to join the Air Force to help fight Saddam, but unfortunately those are the ones that are often unqualified," said Staff Sgt. Danny Williams, the top Air Force recruiter in Los Angeles.
Recruiters for the Army, Navy, Air Force and Marine Corps say they have received a surge in calls from people interested in fighting overseas, many of them veterans. The Army says that on Jan. 18, a day and a half after fighting began, twice as many applicants as normal came in for the Army physical and entrance testing.
Some will qualify. But with standards rising and the ranks still shrinking, at least in the war's early stages, many of those expressing interest are either too old or otherwise unqualified.
On the other hand, officials say they are having to work harder to persuade promising young high school students, and particularly their parents, that now is a good time to join the military.
"I think at this point it's been a wash," said Lieut. Col. Donald Tarter, commander for the United States Army Recruiting Battalion based in Atlanta. "Some people are interested because of it, and some are less likely to sign up because of it. Right now, the long-term effect is an unknown."
Colonel Tarter said the outbreak of war has brought a flood of calls to recruiters from would-be soldiers, many of them a bit long in the tooth.
 
'Thank You Very Much'
 "Two-thirds of them you can tell them on the phone, 'Thank you very much, we appreciate your patriotic interest, but we can't help you,' " he said. "A couple of people said, 'Just let me drive a truck so some soldier can do what needs to be done,' but you ask how old they are, and they're 51." Under most circumstances, the age limit for enlisting in the Army is 35.
Potential recruits interviewed yesterday expressed a wide range of reasons for joining up. For some, the war and the patriotic mood it has engendered was a big part of their decision.
"I'm here because I like the Army, and I want to do something with my life," said Moises Gonzalez, 24 years old, who was interviewed at a Boston recruiting office. "Besides, I agree with the war. We have to put a stop to Saddam Hussein. If we don't, he will own the world."
Staff Sgt. Angel R. Rivera, a recruiter at the same station, said he had seen an increase in the number of Hispanic people signing up since the war began. "Ninety percent of them are saying, 'I have a commitment to this country, and I want to serve,' " he said.
 
'For the American Way'
 At the Times Square recruiting office in Manhattan, Frank Gonzalez, a member of the Army Reserves, said he was there to join the regular Army. He said the war is "a good thing for the American way -- we don't need people who take over small lands."
But the war is only one reason for enlisting. Studies by the Army in recent years have shown that money for college and job training are the two biggest reasons cited by military recruits.
Sean Daley, a 23-year-old Coast Guard recruit from Boston, said he decided to enlist after being laid off from his job as a metal worker. "I'm all for my country, and I want to support Bush, but my being here has to do with the economy basically," he said. "I want to better my education and get back to school and get a job I am interested in. But if my country calls me to war, I would go."
 
Giving It a Second Thought
 Frank Bayley, a 17-year-old from Marietta, Ga., who plans to join the Marine Corps after he graduates from high school, said he has wanted to be a marine since he was 12, but the war was having sharply differing effects on his friends.
"Some guys are watching what's happening and deciding that this is something they've got to do," he said. "And there are others who are saying to themselves, 'Wait a minute. I'm not so sure about this.' "
Army recruiters say that, in general, the beginning of the gulf buildup and the outbreak of war have made their job harder, and they have had to spend more time both with potential recruits and with their parents.
"Our enlistments are now coming from an older age group, say 26 or more years," said Sgt. First Class Doug Chapman, a recruiter in Charlotte, N.C. "We spend a lot of time in the local area in gyms, in fast-food places, wherever we are having to do that more. We still work the high schools, but we're not having nearly as much success now that the war has started."
 
Highest Standards Ever
 The Army expects to recruit 88,000 soldiers this year, down from 119,000 two years ago. Officials say that in the first quarter of the current fiscal year, October through December, 97 percent of applicants had high school diplomas and 72 percent scored in the top half of the entrance aptitude test, the highest standards the Army has had.
A question for the Army, with its recruits' emphasis on college money and job training, is whether the war will affect its ability to keep those standards.
For other branches, the war may help. Marine recruiters say the Corps' emphasis on esprit de corp and patriotism probably makes the war a plus for recruiting.
Air Force recruiters cite the television coverage of F-15E fighter pilots roaring over the Persian Gulf. "This attention focused on the Air Force has helped us," said Technical Sgt. Tony D. McClain, supervisor of the Atlanta area Air Force recruiting office.
For all the emphasis on the war, however, it is not at all clear that any recruits who sign up now will fight in it.
Marine officials say recruits not learning specialized skills will train at least 17 to 22 weeks before being assigned to a unit. Those learning specalized skills could train for from 52 to 58 weeks. "It's a lot more things than getting a haircut and a uniform," said Sgt. Christopher Carr, a Marine spokesman for recruiting in Manhattan.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Prices for Platinum Plunge To Near a Five-Year Low

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Platinum futures prices approached five-year lows yesterday as industrial and investment demand for the metal lagged.
Platinum futures settled $8.40 to $9 lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with the contract for delivery in January at $379.30 an ounce, the lowest spot platinum price on the exchange since Feb. 14, 1986. The more actively traded April contract finished at $383.50. 
 Gold futures settled $1 to $1.60 higher on New York's Commodity Exchange, with gold for January delivery up $1, to $376.70 an ounce and the active February contract at $377.10 an ounce. Silver was 2.3 cents to 2.5 cents higher, with March at $3.842 an ounce.
Platinum soon could be trading at a discount to gold for the first time since 1985 unless the market's fundamentals change, analysts said.
Bernard Savaiko, senior metals analyst with Paine Webber Inc., said recession worries had strangled platinum demand by investors and industrial users, which include car and jewelry manufacturers.
The price of silver, which also has a large industrial component, has also fallen sharply lately, though gold has remained relatively firm.
One factor that could give platinum a lift is the tension in the Soviet Union, the world's second-largest platinum producer.
"If law and order break down, we could see a supply disruption over there," Mr. Savaiko said. "It is a possibility that should not be overlooked."
World sugar futures fell sharply to new life-of-contract lows in a late selloff on New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange.
It was sugar's sharpest one-day drop since the Persian Gulf war began, halting most sugar exports to the Middle East.
Harry Schwartz, a analyst with Cargill Investor Services Inc., said that because most of the selling occurred in the last five minutes, traders would be watching today's early action to determine whether "this is significant or just a bear raid."
Sugar settled 0.16 cent to 0.2 cent lower, with March at 8.76 cents a pound.
Livestock and meat futures rose on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in line with stronger cash cattle markets.
But gains in cattle were limited by selling prompted by Friday's quarterly Agriculture Department cattle-on-feed report. The report showed the largest on-feed inventories since 1979 in the 13 largest cattle states.
Live cattle futures settled 0.05 cent to 0.4 cent higher, with February at 78.10 cents a pound; feeder cattle were 0.17 cent to 0.4 cent higher, with January at 90.50 cents a pound; live hogs were 0.1 cent to 0.77 cent higher, with February at 54.27 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 0.35 cent to 1.22 cents higher, with February at 69.47 cents a pound.
Stronger domestic feed-grain demand lifted corn futures prices on the Chicago Board of Trade and helped push most other grain and soybean futures higher as well.

HEADLINE: Florio Approves a Rise In Tolls on the Turnpike

BYLINE: By PETER KERR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 28

 BODY:
Gov. Jim Florio today approved a toll increase on the New Jersey Turnpike of 70 percent for cars and 100 percent for trucks, on the same day that his Treasurer announced that some of the toll revenues will be used indirectly to balance the state budget.
The Treasurer, Douglas C. Berman, also announced that the Governor would seek to freeze wages for state workers and to impose severe cuts in state contributions to health and pension benefits. 
 For months, the New Jersey Turnpike Authority has been comtemplating the toll increases as a way to pay off $2 billion in bonds borrowed in 1985 and to pay for construction projects centered around Newark International Airport. The increases will go into effect before April 1.
"The turnpike is giving people something for their money," Governor Florio said after approving the increase. "The plans they will carry out will ease congestion, improve safety and give a big boost to our economy."
 
Sale of State Roads
 Mr. Berman, in a briefing on the state budget today, said that in addition to layoffs and service cutbacks, the state plans to sell state roads to the turnpike authority for $400 million in an effort to balance the budget for the fiscal year that begins on July 1.
If approved by the Legislature, Mr. Berman's plan would mean, in effect, that a part of the higher tolls drivers would be paying on the turnpike would be used to finance state government and avoid more layoffs. Officials estimated that about 10 percent of the toll increases would be used to pay off the $400 million in road purchases.
The move has severely split the administration, including officials who say the toll increases will be perceived as a new tax on drivers, just three weeks after Governor Florio promised no new taxes in his State of the State address.
A number of top aides to the Governor have argued that the idea of selling state roads to balance the state budget was ill-conceived and expressed hope that Mr. Florio would still distance himself from the plan.
 
Still Lower Than Other Tolls
 "Its like selling your furniture when you can't pay your electric bill," one administration official said.
Under the toll increases approved today at a meeting of turnpike commissioners and supported by Mr. Florio, the toll for a car traveling the full length of the turnpike, which stretches from the Delaware border to the Hudson River crossings, would rise to $4.60, from $2.70.
According to Gordon Hector, a spokesman for the turnpike authority, tolls on the New Jersey Turnpike are still considerably lower than on many other toll roads. As of January 1991, for example, the cost for a car was $2.29 for 100 miles on the New Jersey Turnpike, compared with $3.10 on the main line of the New York Thruway, $4.15 on the Massachusetts Turnpike, and $2.88 on the northeast section of the Pennsylvania Turnpike.
The New Jersey Turnpike Authority, an independent agency, borrowed $2 billion for a 1985 road widening project, which suffered many years of delays. As a result of the borrowing in 1985, turnpike officials said some toll increases were inevitable. More than $1.3 billion of that money remains, and the authority has plans for major widening projects that will cost $900 million.
 
$400 Million to Purchase Roads
 In his announcement today, Mr. Berman said the remaining $400 million would be used to buy adjoining roads, which would be administered by the authority. They would not become toll roads, Mr. Berman said.
"We are in economic hard times," Mr. Berman said in explaining the budget that will be presented to the Legislature on Tuesday. "It will keep New Jersey building for the future."
Other administration officials said the roads likely to be sold to the authority would either be the connection between the northern end of the turnpike and the George Washington Bridge on Interstate 95 or the sections of Interstate 295 running parallel to the turnpike in the southern part of the state.
Before Mr. Berman's announcement the turnpike authority had proposed that the remaining $400 million could have been returned to bond holders, or it could have been used to pay for other planned road improvements, like an improved connection between the turnpike and Route One to Trenton, or improved connections with the Pennsylvania Turnpike or the Atlantic City Expressway.
 
Hard Times Ahead
 David Goldberg, the chairman of the turnpike authority, said that if the authority spent $400 million on buying roads from the state it would have to cancel other plans for road improvements. He also questioned whether the authority could purchase roads it took responsibility for maintaining, if it did not charge tolls on them.
In his news conference, Mr. Berman painted a bleak picture of state government in the next fiscal year. The state will try to impose $160 million in wage freezes, forcing state workers to forgo their cost of living increases, and save $75 million in state contributions to health benefits and $40 million in pension reimbursements. Mr. Berman said the state could impose those changes without renegotiating contracts with state workers.
The state also hopes to earn $25 million in increased revenues by raising user fees on a variety of state services, including litigation fees and fees imposed by the Department of Environmental Protection.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Collagen Goes Beyond the Cosmetic

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PALO ALTO, Calif.

 BODY:
The Collagen Corporation takes its name and has always made most of its money from a product that makes people look younger. Now the company is moving beyond products with cosmetic uses to ones that treat medical problems. And Wall Street, after neglecting the stock for years, is again enthusiastic about Collagen.
For nine years, injectable collagen, a purified protein derived from cowhides, has provided the company with a stable earnings base and steady if not spectacular growth. About 700,000 people, some attracted by before-and-after shots in magazines like Vogue and Harper's Bazaar, have had collagen injections to smooth wrinkles and scars. More recently, it has been used to give lips a fuller, more pouty look. 
 But the product has been challenged in lawsuits contending that patients developed autoimmune diseases after receiving collagen injections. So after initial optimism when the company when public in 1981, the stock fell to a low of $4.125 in October 1987 after reaching a high of $19.50 earlier that year.
 
New Medical Applications
 Excitement about Collagen's diversification into medical products, which are more recession-proof than cosmetic products, has helped the stock recover, although it has been volatile. It rose sharply on Friday and reached a new high yesterday of $26.75, but fell later to close at $23.875, down $2.125, in over-the-counter trading.
One new collagen-based product, Contigen, promises to bring relief to millions of sufferers of urinary incontinence, who have had few alternatives to adult diapers. Another such product, Collagraft, could speed healing of severe bone fractures. A tiny, steerable catheter produced by the company's majority-owned subsidiary, Target Therapeutics Inc., is gaining acceptance in treating tumors and vascular disorders.
Finally, Collagen's earnings prospects could be improved by the fact that the company's cash-burning biotech unit, Celtrix Inc., will soon be spun off as a separate company.
For the near term, Collagen, which is based in Palo Alto, will continue to derive the biggest share of its income from its namesake product. First approved by the Food and Drug Administration in 1981, injectable bovine collagen has the blue-white color of skim milk and the consistency of heavy cream, and is shipped to dermatologists and plastic surgeons mixed with a saline solution and lidocaine, a local anesthetic.
Physicians who have administered collagen injections say that they primarily treat women between 25 and 45 years old and that the patients are typically pleased with the results. Collagen is gradually absorbed by the body, so injections must be repeated two to four times a year. The annual cost is about $1,000.
"The void in our specialty that it fills is the person with the early aging changes that you couldn't in good conscience recommend surgery for," said Robert Harvey, a San Francisco-based plastic surgeon who has done thousands of collagen treatments. "Before this came out we could only say, 'Come back in 5 or 10 years for a face lift.' "
 
Lawsuits Outstanding
 But Collagen still faces lawsuits linking the product with autoimmune diseases, in which the body attacks its own tissues. Collagen's insurance carrier settled the first suit, but the company has fought subsequent claims; juries have ruled in its favor in the five that have come to trial. Four cases have been dropped, and six have yet to be heard.
The litigation focused attention on Collagen. In October 1989, Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, began an inquiry into the F.D.A.'s approval of injectable collagen. He raised questions about why it was approved as a medical device rather than as a drug, which would have required more stringent review. "That investigation has continued, and there will be a report issued later this year with conclusions and findings," said Dennis Fitzgibbon, a spokesman for Mr. Dingell.
Collagen officials say that there are no data to support a link between their product and autoimmune diseases, and note that they have gone out of their way to document every adverse reaction. They say these are mostly localized allergic responses, which occur in 1 or 2 percent of patients; doctors administer a skin test to weed out these patients. A January 1990 report by the Department of Health and Human Services found no greater incidence of autoimmune disease among collagen patients than among the general public.
Howard D. Palefsky, Collagen's president and chief executive, said, "The scientific evidence to me is just so obvious and so well supported by data and physicians in the field that there's no question in my mind" about collagen's safety.
One reason Collagen has come under scrutiny is its high-profile advertising, unusual for a medical product. Mr. Palefsky said the advertising was appropriate. "While injectable collagen for the treatment of wrinkles is certainly a medical product, it is basically a product that treats healthy people," he said.
The controversy surrounding cosmetic collagen has not stopped its sales from growing about 15 percent a year. The company had 1990 earnings of $4.1 million, or 46 cents a share, on revenues of $54.3 million, of which $41.4 million came from injectable collagen products. But its real hopes for growth come from finding medical uses for the material.
 
Help for Incontinence
 The first of these uses, Contigen Bard Collagen Implant, received unanimous recommendation for approval from the F.D.A.'s Gastroenterology and General Use Devices panel on Oct. 18. The implant involves the injection of collagen into the tissue surrounding the urethra, which narrows the opening from the bladder and allows the patient's muscles to control urination better. It will be marketed by C. R. Bard Inc., a leading company in the urology field.
"Contigen is potentially a very big product," said Jim McCamant, editor of the Medical Technology Stock Letter. "It's got the things you look for," he said, noting that more than three million patients are candidates for the therapy, that C. R. Bard is already a primary supplier to urologists, and that Contigen is much simpler and more effective than wearing a diaper or having surgery.
The company estimates that for every 25,000 patients treated, its earnings per share could grow 25 cents. Competition for Contigen will come primarily from the Mentor Corporation, of Santa Barbara, Calif., which has a similar treatment, called Urethrin, in which Teflon is injected.
Collagen officials say Contigen has the advantage of being a natural protein. But some physicians may prefer to use Urethrin because it will not be absorbed by the body and will not require subsequent injections.
After Contigen, Collagen will seek F.D.A. approval for Collagraft Bone Graft Substitute, which combines ceramic materials with collagen. The material is intended to provide a scaffolding onto which a fracture patient's bone cells will grow; as the ceramic materials are slowly dissolved by the body, they are replaced by natural bone. Collagraft could be used instead of bone grafts taken from elsewhere on the patient's body or from bone banks.
In addition, Target Therapeutics, a company that began as a joint venture of Collagen and Eli Lilly but is now majority-owned by Collagen, has developed some very small and specialized catheters. They have proved useful in delivering blood-clotting agents and chemotherapeutic drugs, and represent a growing market.
 
Changing 'Before Our Eyes'
 "The company is really changing right before our eyes," said Kurt H. Kruger, a medical-technology analyst with Hambrecht & Quist. "It is becoming a true medical-products company, which implies much more stable earnings and sales growth than a cosmetics company, which is what they were."
While the cosmetics business has been very profitable for Collagen, its earnings have been obscured in recent quarters by the high costs of maintaining a unit devoted to biotechnology research and development. That unit, Celtrix, will be spun off within a few months. It is primarily developing genetically engineered proteins that cause bone growth.
James T. McKinley, Collagen's senior vice president and chief financial officer, said that while Celtrix's technology was promising, its need for cash and lack of near-term revenues were not compatible with Collagen.

HEADLINE: Personal Income Up Strong 0.7%

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28

 BODY:
Personal income ended the year on a buoyant note, rising seven-tenths of 1 percent in December and helping to lift wages by 6 percent for the year as a whole, the Commerce Department said today.
The yearly total, however, fell just short of matching the 1990 inflation level. Consumer prices last year rose 6.1 percent. 
 December's gain in personal income -- which reflected the fact that workers put in longer hours at higher pay levels -- followed a revised report of a rise of four-tenths of 1 percent for the month before.
And while analysts said the gain was better than expected and spelled good news for the economy, they warned that it did not signal a quick end to the recession.
Personal consumption matched the gain in income, also moving up seven-tenths of 1 percent in the month, compared with a gain of one-tenth of 1 percent in November.
Last year's 6 percent rise in income followed a 7.7 percent increase in 1989, the department said.
The gain in December income outpaced projections. The average Wall Street forecast had called for a rise of four-tenths of 1 percent.
The figures also appeared to fly in the face of overwhelming evidence that the United States had entered a recession, but economists doubted that they signaled a new trend.
"It's good news, but I just think it's presumptuous to say the economy has bottomed out," said Charles Lieberman, economist at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.
The data "would lead to the conclusion that perhaps the economy is beginning to stabilize," said Norman Robertson, economist at Mellon Bank, but he cautioned against making too much of one month's numbers.
Separately, a Federal Reserve Board governor, John P. LaWare, projected that the United States economy will climb out of recession no later than the third quarter of 1991.
In remarks before an economic group in Boston, Mr. LaWare said that if the Persian Gulf war was short, its end "should see a dramatic return of consumer confidence."
Analysts said the December rise in income came after industry moved earlier than usual to cut staff as the recession loomed, with the remaining workers putting in longer hours to maintain production levels.
 
Fewer Higher-Level Job Cuts
 At the same time, fewer high-level service and production jobs were cut in December, and this improvement showed up in higher wages. Morever, employees working longer hours were getting overtime, which also raised the figures, analysts said.
But the gains could be short-lived.
"I don't expect to see these numbers repeated anytime soon," said Donald Ratajczak, an economist at Georgia State University.
Most economists now believe that the current recession will be short and should end by midyear, depending on the outcome of the gulf war.
On Friday, the department reported the economy contracted at a 2.1 percent annual rate in the last three months of 1990, recording its steepest downturn in eight years.

HEADLINE: Health Care A Growing Burden

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
With health-care costs pushing relentlessly upward, companies and employees are feeling the burden. Last year, in fact, fully 26 percent of the average company's net earnings went for medical costs, a survey released yesterday shows.
Health care cost an average of $3,217 for each worker in 1990, an increase of 17.1 percent from 1989, A. Foster Higgins & Company, a benefits consulting firm, said yesterday. The survey combined dental, vision and hearing with spending on traditional medical coverage, the type that most employees have. Traditional costs alone increased by 21.6 percent in 1990, to $3,161 an employee, according the firm's survey of 1,955 business and government employers. 
 The costs at large companies, with at least 40,000 employees, were even higher: $3,999 an employee. John Erb, a Foster Higgins managing consultant, said costs were higher at large companies because they often have contracts with unions and provide more generous medical coverage. The steepest increases were among concerns with 5,000 to 9,999 employees; their costs per employee rose 31.6 percent, to $3,302.
 
Traditional Costs Rose Faster
 Spending on health maintenance organizations increased less rapidly than in traditional medical plans, which pay doctors and hospitals with few questions asked.
But traditional medical costs have risen by more than 20 percent annually since 1988, Mr. Erb said, and will exceed $22,000 an employee by 2000 if the current rate of growth continues.
Although most companies offered employees a chance to join a health maintenance organization, only one-third of their workers joined one, the survey found. About one-third of employers also offered incentives to use networks of doctors and hospitals that agree to accept discounted fees. At such companies, 59 percent of the employees actually used the discount networks.
But the Foster Higgins findings showed that the H.M.O.'s and discount networks had made only a relatively small dent in overall medical spending increases.
Uwe E. Reinhardt, a health economist at Princeton University, said he was "surprised at how many companies still pay for largely conventional coverage." In the Middle Atlantic States, where there are relatively few discount networks and other health-cost containment plans, traditional medical expenses rose 28.3 percent, to $3,500 an employee, Foster Higgins found. On the West Coast, by contrast, the increase was 19 percent, to $3,271 an employee. It was $2,922 in the Southeast, $2,893 in the South Central states, and $3,138 in the Midwestern and North Central states.
Mr. Erb said 82 percent of the employers required workers to pay part of their family health-care costs. Individual employees contributed $396 a year on average, up 43.5 percent, from $276 in 1989, while family payments rose 29 percent, to $1,068.
The highest traditional medical costs, $4,296 an employee, were in the highly unionized utilities industries, with many older employees (40 years old on average). Retail and wholesale employers, with fewer unions and younger employees (age 34 on average), spent $2,323.
 
Costs Doubled in 5 Years
 The cost of traditional medical coverage has doubled in five years. A survey by the Wyatt Company, a consulting firm, found that traditional medical costs in 1986 were $1,460 an employee, said John Menefee, a Wyatt health economist in Washington. In 1980, such costs were only $860.
In other measures of rising medical costs, the Health Insurance Association of America, an insurers trade group, said that premiums rose in 1989 by 28 percent, to $3,216 a year, for families with traditional coverage, and 29 percent, to $3,132, for members of the type of health maintenance organization that has a staff of salaried doctors. Individual premiums rose by 21 percent for traditional coverage and 33 percent for H.M.O. members.
The Commerce Department said national spending on health care rose 11.9 percent in 1990, to $675.7 billion, of which $398.7 billion came from private employers, insurers and out-of-pocket payments by individuals. Government health programs spent the remaining $277 billion.

HEADLINE: Bush Speech to Urge Bank Law Changes

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28

 BODY:
Although the Persian Gulf war will dominate his State of the Union Message on Tuesday, President Bush will also address domestic issues and will offer sweeping proposals to revamp the nation's banking laws, Administration officials said today.
Mr. Bush was still considering today what to include in the speech. He may mention proposals to increase educational opportunities for low-income people, to encourage homeownership by poor families and to combat infant mortality in about 20 large cities. 
 While Mr. Bush is not likely to propose any major changes in social welfare programs, he is almost certain to recommend a comprehensive overhaul of the nation's banking laws. His proposals would make it easier for banks to operate across state lines and would break down barriers that now separate commercial banks, investment banks and stock brokerage firms.
The Bush proposals would permit investment banks and industrial corporations to own commercial banks, Administration officials said. In addition, under the proposals, commercial banks would be allowed to underwrite and deal in corporate securities.
Administration officials acknowledge that there is little new money for domestic programs and estimate that the Federal budget deficit will soar to $318 billion this year, more than double the $153 billion deficit in the 1989 fiscal year. But they insist that the gulf war need not paralyze efforts to deal with domestic problems.
 
Emphasis on Foreign Affairs
 With President Bush and many Americans preoccupied with war, this year's State of the Union Message will emphasize foreign affairs much more than usual.
Mr. Bush is expected to devote more than half of the speech to reporting on the progress of the war and to affirming his view that it is "a just war" with a noble aim. He is also expected to describe his ideas for promoting peace in the Middle East after the war ends.
Administration officials said the domestic side of the speech had been a subject of intense wrangling inside the White House, a reflection of the political struggle between two wings of the Republican Party.
An early draft of the speech, ringing with statements about the need to empower poor people with more choices, was rewritten under the direction of Richard G. Darman, the budget director, and John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, to keep it in line with traditional Republican themes about the need for good government and sound management, the officials said.
"Young Turks" in the Administration, including James P. Pinkerton, deputy assistant to the President for policy planning, and other conservative Republicans like Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp and Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia had advocated the stronger language but lost out when the final version of the message was drafted for Mr. Bush.
The main speech writers, Mark Lange and David F. Demarest Jr., were sympathetic to the conservative emphasis on economic growth as a means to increase opportunities for poor people. But White House officials said Mr. Darman and Mr. Sununu diluted those themes.
Last year Mr. Darman publicly ridiculed some of the economic and political ideas espoused by Mr. Gingrich, the House Republican whip, and Mr. Pinkerton. Though they patched up their personal quarrel, the philosophical disagreements persist.
In a speech last week at the Cato Institute, a research and policy center here, Mr. Pinkerton said: "The war has eclipsed the domestic agenda, at least in the short run. But I don't think the debate that really counts, the intellectual debate, will be much affected" by it.
 
Changes in Banking Laws
 Mr. Bush's proposal for a comprehensive overhaul of the banking laws comes as some members of Congress, noting the financial problems of many banks, say they would hesitate to relax Federal requirements for the industry. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said last month that prospects for approval of the changes in the banking laws were "probably no better than 50-50."
Administration officials have apparently not decided how to shore up the Bank Insurance Fund, which insures deposits at more than 13,000 banks across the country. The Federal system of deposit insurance for commercial banks faces greater dangers today than at any time since it was born in the Great Depression. But in his State of the Union Message, Mr. Bush is unlikely to say much about the issue because Treasury officials and bankers have yet to reach agreement on specific proposals.
In a gesture to conservatives, Mr. Bush is expected to reaffirm his support for a cut in the capital gains tax, but he will not make it a centerpiece of his agenda as he did in the past, Administration officials said.
 
Voucher Proposal Revived
 Mr. Bush also plans to revive a Reagan Administration proposal for education vouchers as a means to expand the choices available to low-income families. Parents could use such vouchers, which would be a form of Federal aid, to enroll their children in the public or private elementary and secondary schools of their choice.
In an effort to underline his concern for children of the poor, Mr. Bush may also mention new proposals to combat infant mortality by expanding prenatal care and other services in cities with the highest infant death rates. Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, persuaded Mr. Bush to include those proposals in his budget for the 1992 fiscal year, which is to be submitted to Congress next week.
Administration officials said Mr. Bush would make a fresh appeal for Congressional approval of proposals to reduce crime, especially violent crime by drug users and drug dealers. The proposals call for new sentencing procedures to permit greater use of the death penalty, stricter limits on appeals by death row prisoners and rule changes to permit the use in criminal trials of some evidence illegally obtained by law-enforcement officers.

HEADLINE: Poll Says Most Blacks Prefer 'Black' to 'African-American'

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28

 BODY:
Despite the increasing use of the term African-American, most black Americans still prefer to be called black, according to a survey.
The survey, by the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a Washington research organization specializing in black issues, found that 72 percent preferred black, 15 percent African-American, 3 percent Afro-American and 2 percent Negro, with the rest giving no opinion or other responses. 
 Milton Morris, the center's vice president for research, said the poll was conducted by telephone last fall among a random sampling of 759 black people nationwide. The survey had a sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points, he said.
The term African-American has gained currency recently, at the African-American Summit in New Orleans in April 1989 and when Ramona H. Edelin, president of the National Urban Coalition, suggested that the term would give black people a greater sense of their history. The Rev. Jesse Jackson endorsed the change, and the term has since been adopted by prominent blacks including Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York, Mayor Maynard Jackson of Atlanta and Representative William H. Gray 3d, Democrat of Pennsylvania.
The Joint Center has not embraced the change. "Individuals here use the term, but as an institution we have not adopted it," Mr. Morris said. "Frankly, we think that among other practical considerations it is a bit more cumbersome than is convenient for much of our communication."
Mr. Morris said Mr. Jackson's endorsement appeared to have been the chief impetus for the movement to use African-American instead of black.
"There is a strong inclination among what you might call the elite in the black community to fall in line with such pronouncements, so they have, and the white community has been very responsive," Mr. Morris said.
 
Seeking a Sense of Public Mood
 Mr. Morris said his organization had undertaken its survey because "at no time have we had any sense of what the public preference was, what the mood was."
In polls in 1989 by Time magazine and The Chicago Tribune, a quarter of black respondents said they preferred African-American. In the Time poll, three-fifths said they preferred black; in the Tribune poll, two-fifths favored black and a third accepted either term.
The Joint Center poll also considered preferences offering only the terms black and African-American. It found that black was preferred by 72 percent to 28 percent in the East, 76 percent to 24 percent in the Midwest, 85 percent to 15 percent in South and 78 percent to 22 percent in the West.
The survey found more support for African-American among black men than among black women, 28 percent to 15 percent.
Blacks with some college education favored African-American more than those who had not gone beyond high school, by 20 percent to 15 percent.
Older blacks liked African-American the least, 17 percent for those of ages 50 and over, compared with 19 percent for those of ages 30 to 49 and 28 percent for those 18 to 29.

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
War Won't Open Too Many Jobs

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
FOR all its divisiveness, the Vietnam War broke down job barriers in ways the Persian Gulf war is never likely to match.
As the armed forces swelled in size in the late 1960's, men and women who had not sought work before were drawn into the labor force. The first big civilian job gains of the civil rights movement came then for blacks, and the rapid entry of women into jobs also began in this period. 
 But the Vietnam military buildup coincided with an economic boom and the draft drained away young men, starting in 1965, just as the civilian sector was running short of workers. The unemployment rate, as a result, plunged to less than 4 percent over the next four years, forcing companies to bid for people they had not previously considered.
"Poverty and joblessness declined across the country," said Paul Osterman, a labor economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
A quite different experience -- the unfolding of a recession -- has accompanied the first six months of the gulf crisis, and most Americans expect the war to be far shorter than the fighting in Vietnam. Unemployment, instead of declining, is rising much faster than the military buildup. For each of the 180,000 reservists activated by President Bush since Aug. 2, three other people have joined the unemployment lines. With the unemployment rate above 6 percent, employers are not hiring all those who seek jobs, much less those who remain outside the labor market.
The situation probably would not change even if President Bush activated all of the 1.15 million men and women in the Reserves and National Guard. A Defense Department study showed the reservists to be mostly high school graduates, in their late 20's and 30's, holding a great variety ofjobs: teachers, civil servants, mechanics, police officers, office workers, self-employed. But if all 1.15 million were to be called to active duty tomorrow and replaced in their civilian jobs by the unemployed, the jobless rolls would decline only to their levels of last spring. The unemployment rate then was 5.3 percent.
"The armed forces and the Reserves are too small a number to have any impact," said Gregory Weyland, a Census Bureau economist.
Making an impact would require a renewal of the draft, an end to the recession and months or years of gulf warfare, economists say. Only then might employers find themselves so short of workers that they would turn to those on the margins of the labor force, particularly black and Hispanic young people, who stay out of the labor force in large numbers today, neither holding nor seeking jobs.
The armed forces are still well below the level that set off the influx of workers into the labor force in the late 1960's. During the Vietnam War, the military grew to more than 3.4 million people in 1967 and 1968, or 4.3 percent of the total labor force. That was enough to produce a shortage of civilian workers, and jobs opened up for millions of womenand minorities, in many cases in the retail and service industries then beginning to expand.
By comparison, the 2.1 million men and women in the regular armed services today represent only 1.7 percent of the labor force. If all 1.15 million reservists were called up, the total in uniform would rise to only 2.8 percent of the labor force, which is much larger today than in the Vietnam years.
Even the busy Raytheon Corporation, maker of the much-used Patriot missile, is not hurting for workers. The Defense Department asked the company to speed up Patriot production at its Andover, Mass., plant, where 6,000 employees produce Patriots and other missiles. The speed-up has been achieved through overtime and the hiring of only 250 additional workers, said Edward Powers, a company spokesman.
Were these skilled missile makers hard to find? "We have had no difficulty, because other companies in the area have been laying off good people, particularly the computer companies," Mr. Powers said.
The General Dynamics Corporation and the Grumman Corporation, two other manufacturers of weaponry widely used in the gulf, also report that skilled workers are relatively easy to find, although neither has hired additional workers in response to the gulf crisis.
The ample pools of skilled people would presumably disappear if the war lasted long enough and the armed forces swelled in size. When this occurred during the Vietnam War, many employers endorsed federally subsidized job training for unskilled new workers drawn into the labor force. And the Government obliged under the Manpower Development and Training Act of 1962.
Most of the subsidized training was later phased out, but a prolonged gulf war might bring it back, Mr. Osterman said. "The reservists are older, skilled people embedded in their jobs, so it is hard to think you could replace a reservist with a 19-year-old dropout," he said. "But if the war were sustained, there would be a trickle-down effect. People would be trained and would get hired."

HEADLINE: Big Cut in U.S. Deposits Hastened Fall of Freedom Bank in Harlem

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28

 BODY:
While public funds were being used to shore up the Bank of New England, the Treasury Department sharply cut back similar deposits at the Freedom National Bank, thus hastening the collapse of the small minority-owned Manhattan institution.
According to former officials of Freedom National and bank documents, the Treasury in March suddenly curtailed its longstanding practice of keeping at Freedom as much as $300 million of income-tax withholding payments in what are known as "tax and loan" accounts. 
 "The loss of the tax and loan revenue almost doubled our losses on a monthly basis, forcing us into insolvency on a faster basis," said George A. Russell Jr., Freedom National's former president, who unsuccessfully lobbied senior Treasury Department officials to reverse the decision to cut back on their deposits at the Harlem bank.
 
Boston Bank's Plan
 The Bank of New England, based in Boston, had drawn up a plan early last year to use tax and loan accounts to help improve its cash position, and that plan was agreed to by officials at the Treasury and the Federal Reserve, bank officials and regulators said in December.
The different experiences of Freedom National, with $100 million in assets, and the Bank of New England, with $15 billion, adds to the debate about regulatory unfairness that arose after both institutions collapsed. The disclosure of the way the Treasury handled its deposits at Freedom National came on the eve of the department's release of a plan to overhaul the banking system, a plan that is expected to include changes in the "too big to fail" philosophy.
After the Bank of New England and two sister banks were seized by Federal regulators on Jan. 6, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation guaranteed all deposits, even those exceeding the $100,000 legal limit for insured deposits. The agency said that failing to repay completely all depositors of the third-largest banking company in New England would have been catastrophic for the region's economy.
But depositors at Freedom National who had accounts exceeding $100,000, including churches and a nonprofit organization that cares for poor children in Harlem, were not fully reimbursed after the institution was taken over on Nov. 9.
Frank Rush, a former executive vice president at Freedom National who tried to get the Treasury to be more flexible in its dealings with the bank, said Federal regulators "exercised discretion based on the policy that big banks could not fail but there was no such policy for minority banks."
 
Officials Deny Favoritism
 As for the tax and loan account program, Treasury officials say that since Treasury deposits are "blindly" placed, there is no preferential treatment. They also insist the program is safe because the public money is fully collateralized.
But the case of Freedom National suggests that Treasury officials are not always unaware of tax and loan account activity and that repeated though temporary collateral deficiencies had been tolerated for years.
Last year, Treasury officials denied that minority banks received any special treatment from the tax and loan program.
At the beginning of 1990, both Freedom National and the Bank of New England were experiencing heavy losses and had problems raising cash. When asked today for the reason for the different experiences of the two banks, a Treasury official who insisted on anonymity said the Bank of New England could meet the department's collateral requirements and Freedom National could not.
The Boston bank was allowed to use commercial loans as collateral, a practice that is frowned on by financial experts but permitted under Treasury regulations for tax and loan accounts. Most other banks in the New England region post Treasury bills or other high-quality collateral against their Treasury deposits, according to Dan L. Sanford, the vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston who administers the Treasury accounts in that region.
 
Overnight Deposits
 The Treasury tax and loan program includes deposits by businesses of employee income tax withholding payments, which are placed temporarily at hundreds of institutions and sit overnight without any interest being paid to the Treasury. The program also covers Treasury operating cash, which is dispersed nationwide to hundreds of institutions that pay the Treasury a return on its balances. The various Federal Reserve banks act as the Treasury's agent, monitoring and holding the collateral required as security.
Over the years, Freedom National had been allowed to have for short periods of time $200 million to $300 million in tax and loan accounts from the withholding payments while it posted a small fraction of collateral inventoried at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, according to bank documents and former bank officials. The Treasury deposits provided Freedom National an interest-free source of short-term cash and an important source of income.
But in mid-March, the Treasury and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York banned the keeping of large business deposits overnight at Freedom National. They also cut sharply, from $15 million to $8 million, Freedom National's maximum balance for absorbing deposits from the tax and loan accounts, according to the bank's 1990 proxy statement. The reduction came even though Freedom National had Government securities worth at least $19 million posted as collateral, according to bank and Treasury officials.
 
A Matter of Timing
 Mr. Russell and other Freedom officials said they wanted to eventually reduce the bank's dependence on these funds, but not as fast as required by Treasury and the Fed.
But Freedom National officials said that when they talked to officials of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and Treasury officials in Washington, the New York officials told them to talk to Washington and vice versa. Freedom eventually appealed directly to the Secretary of the Treasury, Nicholas F. Brady. (The Bank of New England had hired as its chief liaison with Federal regulators R. T. McNamar, a former Deputy Secretary of the Treasury under President Ronald Reagan.)
In May, Mr. Russell, the bank president, wrote Mr. Brady that he was concerned that "for the first time in Freedom's involvement" in the tax and loan program the department had begun enforcing its collateral requirements. He proposed that the bank use as collateral "reverse repos." Reverse repurchase agreements are a common financing technique in which Government securities are purchased on a short-term basis with an agreement to sell them back at a set price.
 
An Official's Reply
 Gerald Murphy, the Treasury's Fiscal Assistant Secretary, wrote a reply to Mr. Russell, stating that "the frequency of the collateral deficiencies had exceeded Treasury's tolerances."
Mr. Murphy also wrote that while the use of reverse repos for collateral was not prohibited by Treasury regulations and was being done at two other minority-owned banks, the Treasury could not approve Freedom's plan "because of Freedom's financial situation."
"Treasury regulations are currently silent with regard to the use of reverse repos to collateralize" such deposits, Mr. Murphy wrote.
The Treasury official told the bank it was being granted the leeway to hold uncollateralized tax deposits the same day they were received, but not overnight. Overnight use of funds, Mr. Murphy wrote, "was not intended by Treasury to provide a major source of revenue to a financial institution," adding that some institutions "place too great reliance on that feature."
 
Order to Cease and Desist
 It was concern about Freedom National's condition that caused the bank's regulatory agency, the Office of the omptroller of the Currency, a unit of the Treasury Department, to propose last March a cease and desist order against some of the bank's lending activities. That was at about the same time that the Treasury and Federal Reserve officials curtailed the New York institution's use of Treasury deposits.
In late February, the Comptroller had issued a cease and desist order against the Bank of New England, and the bank then submitted the liquidity plan that called for, among other things, the use of Treasury tax and loan accounts, according to bank officials.
Soon thereafter, Treasury's balance at the Boston bank soared to $1.8 billion, helping the bank drastically reduce its dependence on higher-cost loans from the Federal Reserve, according to bank officials and documents. After the bank collapsed earlier this month, financial analysts said the Treasury funds had helped the bank stay alive.
Last month, Robert R. Glauber, the Treasury's Under Secretary for Finance, told the Senate Banking Committee that Treasury funds were not being used to finance weak banks and that any collateral deficiencies were "quickly" corrected.

HEADLINE: U.S. AND MOSCOW POSTPONE SUMMIT

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28

 BODY:
The United States and the Soviet Union announced today that they were postponing the meeting between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev that had been scheduled for Feb. 11-13 in Moscow.
The official reasons given for the delay were Mr. Bush's reluctance to travel far from Washington during the Persian Gulf war and the inability of the two sides to conclude the treaty on reductions in long-range nuclear weapons that they had planned to sign at the meeting. 
 Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, said the meeting would be rescheduled for sometime in the "first half" of 1991. They made the joint announcement after Mr. Bessmertnykh's talks at the White House with President Bush.
 
Administration's Reluctance
 Mr. Baker and Mr. Bessmertnykh presented the postponement as a mutual decision unrelated to the violent crackdown on pro-independence demonstrators in the Baltic republics of Latvia and Lithuania. But American officials said the decision was driven largely by the Bush Administration's reluctance to appear to be engaging in business as usual with Mr. Gorbachev.
Leading Republicans in the House and Senate warned Mr. Bush last week that a trip to Moscow at this time would be widely opposed in Congress. The White House apparently did not want to stir up a second foreign policy dispute at a time of division in the United States over the gulf war.
Nor apparently did the Bush Administration want to undermine or embarrass Mr. Gorbachev by canceling the summit meeting on account of his treatment of the Baltic republics.
The statement said simply:
"By mutual agreement, Presidents Bush and Gorbachev will be rescheduling their summit in Moscow, originally planned for February, to a later date in the first half of this year. The gulf war makes it inappropriate for President Bush to be away from Washington. In addition, work on the Start treaty will require some additional time. Both Presidents look forward to setting an exact summit date as soon as it becomes feasible to do so."
A deferential attitude also characterized public remarks by the two sides. Mr. Baker appeared to go out of his way to avoid criticizing the Soviets for their behavior in the Baltic states, and Mr. Bessmertnykh seemed to return the favor by muting his earlier criticism of the intense aerial bombardment of Iraq by American-led forces.
American officials said Mr. Bessmertnykh warned Mr. Baker in private talks that citing the crackdown on the Baltic republics as a reason for canceling the meeting would only strengthen the hand of conservatives is Moscow. Hard-liners might argue that since relations with Washington were already sour, the Kremlin need not feel constrained in repressing the Baltic independence movements, the Foreign Minister reportedly told Mr. Baker.
 
First Such Delay Since 1960
 The postponement marked the first time that a scheduled summit meeting between the two nations has been put off since 1960. Moscow canceled a meeting set that year between Khrushchev and Eisenhower after an American U-2 spy plane was shot down over Soviet territory and its pilot, Francis Gary Powers, captured.
The decision was also the most tangible sign that relations between the United States and the Soviet Union, which have steadily improved since the day Mr. Bush took office, are now beginning to cool. Mr. Gorbachev has increasingly failed to meet American expectations that he would shift from a Communist to a market economy and loosen his tight control over independence-minded Soviet republics.
Seeking to limit the damage to relations, Administration officials began trying several days ago to steer reporters away from the crackdown in the Baltics as a reason for the summit's postponement, saying their only concern was that President Bush remain in the country while the war is raging.
They argued that travel might make communications with the Pentagon difficult -- even though the White House has a traveling communications center that can put Mr. Bush in touch with the Pentagon from anywhere in the world.
 
Not Like 'Going to Cleveland'
 The White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said earlier today: "Our main concern is just the Persian Gulf conflict. A trip halfway around the world is fairly extraordinary. It's not like going to Cleveland."
Asked if the Soviet Union, which had pushed hard for the meeting, was disappointed, Mr. Bessmertnykh replied, "It was a mutual decision, so there was no disappointment."
Mr. Bessmertnykh's attempt to play down any differences over the meeting was typical of his public remarks and those of Mr. Baker. The Soviet official clearly abandoned his earlier harsh criticism of American military action in the gulf and Mr. Baker clearly muted any criticism of Soviet policy in the Baltics.
Pressed by reporters on whether the Baltics had any effect on the decision, Mr. Baker said: "The question of the Baltics was discussed at quite some length. It has been discussed by the Minister and myself over five hours. It was discussed here by the Minister and the President during the course of their meeting. We have made our substantial concerns known to the Soviet Union in a substantial way."
 
Says Gorbachev Is 'Wrestling'
 Asked for a more general assessment of Mr. Gorbachev's status, Mr. Baker said the Soviet leader was "wrestling with a number of problems" and was "coping with them to the best of his ability."
Then it was Mr. Bessmertnykh's turn. Asked whether the American military had gone too far in the gulf, something that he had suggested twice in the last three days, he responded:
"The United States is doing its important part in implementing the United Nations Security Council resolutions. And it is getting moral and the other kind of support in those actions, because the aim is to get the aggressor back from the country he occupied. And this is a goal which is a mutual goal, and we are going to get that task achieved."
While the joint statement appeared to be less than straightforward about the relevance of the Baltic republics to the postponement, its reference to the incomplete negotiations for a treaty to reduce strategic nuclear weapons was quite legitimate.
 
Hoping to Finish Treaty
 Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev had originally planned to sign the treaty at the meeting next month. Mr. Baker said that Mr. Bessmertnykh and President Bush agreed that the two countries would try to conclude the strategic arms reduction treaty, also known as Start, by the end of February. If completed, the treaty would slash Soviet and American long-range nuclear bombers and missiles by about 30 percent.
The eight-year negotiations are now down to some highly technical matters involving how the two sides monitor each other's missile factories to guard against cheating, and how they obtain data from each other's missile-flight tests to insure that weapons remain within the treaty's limits.
