HEADLINE: Trump Castle Lays Off 190

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 28

 BODY:
Nearly 200 employees were laid off today at the Trump Castle Casino Resort to save money. Donald J. Trump also announced that he had hired a new president for the Trump Plaza casino.
Roger Wagner, the president of Trump Castle, said the 190 workers laid off were from the management and executive levels. About 3,400 employees remain, said Mr. Wagner, who was hired away from the Claridge Casino Hotel this month to cut costs at Trump Castle.
Mr. Wagner said the declining economy and flat gambling market prompted the need to cut costs.
Trump Castle has been the weak sister of three Atlantic City properties owned by Mr. Trump. The third and newest of these is the Trump Taj Mahal.
The Trump Plaza's new president and chief operating officer will be Kevin DeSanctis, a former executive of the Mirage hotel and casino in Las Vegas and a former member of the New Jersey Division of Gaming Enforcement.
Mr. DeSanctis, 38 years old, replaces Gary Selesner, who had been interim president and chief operating officer since April. Mr. Selesner will remain in a senior executive position, Mr. Trump said.

HEADLINE: What Really Threatens the Environment?

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
ARE Americans preoccupied with relatively modest environmental threats while neglecting big ones that could unleash catastrophe?
To a large extent, some scientists and Government officials believe, the answer is yes. William K. Reilly, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, told a Senate committee in Washington on Friday that in many cases, the public and Congress are at odds with scientists over which environmental threats are the most serious. He has begun a campaign to reassess those priorities, and he leaves no doubt that his money is on the scientists. 
 "Sound science is our most reliable compass," he says in speeches calling for the nation to establish environmental priorities.
Mr. Reilly's campaign is intended to stimulate a national debate over environmental goals. And at a time when many of the most obvious and clear-cut environmental threats like air pollution and water pollution have been addressed and more subtle, complex problems are coming to the fore, the campaign may usher in a new, more complicated and more contentious phase in the national environmental struggle.
 
Mismatch of Perceptions
 There seems little doubt of a mismatch between public perceptions of environmental risk and those of the scientists. Oil spills, hazardous waste, underground storage tanks and releases of radioactive materials, for instance, have aroused high emotions, generated reams of reports and prodded Congress to spend billions of dollars. Opinion surveys place them in the front ranks of public concern about the environment.
But in terms of the actual magnitude of risk they pose, scientists advising the E.P.A. rate them near the bottom of a broad array of environmental threats. This, the scientists say, is because their effects are relatively limited or short-lived or both.
At the same time, global warming and the destruction and alteration of natural habitats rank relatively low in public perception, polls show. But the scientists place them among the top risks because their potential consequences appear to be so damaging in the long run and their effects so widespread and difficult to reverse.
Federal environmental laws "are more reflective of public perceptions of risk than of scientific understanding of risk," the E.P.A. Science Advisory Board said in a report on environmental risks last fall. The scientists' report was the basis for Friday's hearings. Mr. Reilly and others say environmental problems are addressed unevenly, usually on the basis of episodic, momentary public anxieties about problems that, while frightening, represent a relatively limited threat: contamination of a local waterway by hazardous wastes, for example.
No one is suggesting that these problems should be ignored. Oil spills and other low-ranking risks can cause "real damage where and when they occur," Mr. Reilly told the senators. But, he said, "they are in a different league compared to some of our other problems, such as stratospheric ozone depletion and climate change, which have the potential to affect life everywhere, and for many years to come."
The advisory board identified four environmental threats to health that it said were in the front rank: outdoor air pollution, exposure of workers to chemicals, indoor air pollution and pollutants in drinking water.
 
Major Environmental Threats
 It established three categories of risk for threats that humans pose to the environment. Relatively high-risk problems of this nature included the global warming that many scientists predict will result from an increase in heat-trapping atmospheric gases produced by human activity; depletion of the ozone shield that protects Earth from the Sun's harmful ultraviolet radiation, and destruction and alteration of natural habitats and the extinction of species, with an accompanying loss of biological diversity.
A middle rank includes herbicides and pesticides, pollution of surface waters, acid precipitation and airborne toxic substances. Relatively low risk was assigned to oil spills, escape of radioactive materials, acid runoff to surface waters and pollution of groundwater.
Risks in this area of ecological threats were assigned largely on the basis of how many people a problem affects, how wide a geographical area is involved, and how serious and long-lasting the harm might be, said Dr. William Cooper, a zoologist and aquatic ecologist at Michigan State University who headed the board's panel on ecological risks.
On that basis, oil spills, for example, ranked low because their effects on coastal areas are relatively short-term and local. "The public doesn't perceive it that way," Dr. Cooper said, "but those ecosystems bounce back real fast."
By contrast, he said, the loss of natural habitats and the disappearance of species are top risks because they affect the economic welfare of future generations worldwide and because the loss is "virtually irreversible." Similarly, ozone depletion and global warming were placed in the top rank because they are worldwide problems and because their effects are potentially catastrophic and reversible only over decades.
Given the substantial cost of environmental protection, Mr. Reilly argues, it is all the more important to set sensible priorities as the next phase of environmental protection begins. The E.P.A. estimates the United States will spend nearly 3 percent of its gross national product on environmental protection by the end of this decade. The nation "can probably afford to spend 3 percent," Mr. Reilly said, "but we're not rich enough to spend it in the wrong places."
 
Doubts Are Raised
 While many environmentalists and politicians say it is a good idea to set priorities, doubts and possible points of dispute are cropping up.
Environmentalists who have devoted themselves to causes ranked low on the priority list are unlikely to stop pushing their interests. Others resist anything that might look like an effort to practice environmental triage, concentrating on some problems to the exclusion of others.
"I don't quarrel with the conclusion that global warming is the No. 1 threat," said David Doniger, a senior lawyer with the Natural Resources Defense Council. "But I don't think the only way you can tackle global warming is by not tackling hazardous wastes. We can and should, and can afford, to do it all."
Several Senators questioned on Friday whether scientists knew enough to set priorities confidently. Senator Dave Durenberger, Republican of Minnesota, asked whether science was as good a guide as public values. People know what environmental assets are important to pass on to future generations, he said.
The Science Advisory Board acknowledged that assessing relative risks was an imprecise science, since much was unknown about some environmental threats. The board noted in its report that environmental policy making "necessarily embodies subjective values" and that policy makers should take both science and public perceptions into account.
As more complex and challenging environmental threats dominate the discussion, the debate will probably be complicated by increasing uncertainty about the nature of environmental risks, noted Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who presided over the hearing. Science, he said, is a matter of complexity and probability, not simple certainty.
What this means is that when science is invoked as a guide to priorities, as Mr. Reilly and others believe it must be, clear-cut answers are harder to come by. As science investigates an issue, it often tends to raise as many questions as it answers. In the eyes of the public, this could weaken the claim of science as an arbiter of priorities.
 
Danger of Inaction
 But on the biggest risks, some scientists argue, uncertainty must not become cause for inaction. Much is uncertain about the magnitude and effects of global warming, for instance. By the time scientists know whether they are right or wrong about predictions of climatic catastrophe, Dr. Cooper said, it will be too late to do anything.
This requires "a whole different mind set," Dr. Cooper said.
"You don't care about being right," he said. "You just don't want to be wrong. Once the cost of being wrong gets too high, you go into a risk-aversion mode. You avoid the risk no matter what the cost."

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 1; Science Desk

LENGTH: 1769 words

HEADLINE: Experts Differ on Dissecting Leaders' Psyches From Afar

BYLINE: By DANIEL GOLEMAN

 BODY:
AS Government officials and military tacticians struggle to determine the aims and methods of Saddam Hussein, questions are being raised anew about the usefulness of psychological profiles.
These profiles have established themselves in academic circles as a sound method for the detailed understanding of a single life, particularly in retrospect. But many experts on political behavior challenge their use in trying to predict the actions of a living world leader. 
 A detailed psychological study of Mr. Hussein, given in Senate testimony, depicts the Iraqi President as not clinically insane, but suffering from "malignant narcissism," a severe personality disorder that leaves him grandiose, paranoid and ruthless.
The study was prepared by Dr. Jerrold Post, a professor of psychiatry and politics at George Washington University.
For 21 years Dr. Post regularly made such psychiatric evaluations of world leaders as the founding director of the Center for the Analysis of Personality and Political Behavior, now part of an interdisciplinary Government agency that continues to provide psychological profiles of foreign leaders to the President and other senior officials.
Psychological profiles have their roots in Freud's work. In fact, some of the earliest psycholgical profiles were his case studies and his analysis of historical figures. Psychological profiles were first used by the Government in World War II and in the years since many experts have attempted to draw them. President Carter relied on psychological profiles of Anwar Sadat of Egypt and Menachem Begin of Israel when he conducted the talks that produced the Camp David accord.
Some experts object to the psychological effects of focusing on Mr. Hussein's personality flaws. "Making a demon of Saddam leads people to the assumption that he personifies all the troubles of the region, and that if we just get rid of him, everything will be all right," said Dr. Robert Jay Lifton, a New York psychiatrist whose books include a study of Nazi doctors.
And many experts question whether it is possible to draw useful conclusions about people from a distance. They particularly wonder about any profiles of Mr. Hussein, given the sparse and occasionally conflicting accounts of his early life.
"Psychoanalyzing someone from a different culture at a distance is very hard," said Robert Jervis, a political scientist at the Institute of War and Peace Studies at Columbia University.
Dr. Otto Kernberg, the Cornell University psychoanalyst who first proposed malignant narcissism as a diagnosis in 1984, said he knew too little about Saddam Hussein to apply the label to him.
 
'They Can't Empathize'
 But Dr. Post said there was evidence to show that Mr. Hussein meets the four conditions Dr. Kernberg set for a diagnosis of malignant narcissism: an extreme sense of grandiosity, sadistic cruelty, suspiciousness to the point of paranoia and an utter lack of remorse. Both Hitler and Stalin fit the pattern, Dr. Kernberg said.
Such people, said Dr. Kernberg, are so self-absorbed that they see other people solely as instruments to their own ends. "They can't empathize at all, but they can still make a shrewd assessment of how others will react," said Dr. Kernberg. "But they manipulate with no sense of how others feel inside."
Their grandiosity takes the form not just of arrogance, but of the deep belief that they have some special destiny in life that sets them apart from others. This grandiosity takes a malignant turn when it is combined with the conviction that any aggression is justified if it furthers one's goals.
Malignant narcissists are filled with sadism and "take pleasure in hurting others," Dr. Kernberg said. "They are extremely suspicious, seeing themselves as persecuted victims of a plot. They project their own cruelty on to their enemies."
The final malignant trait is lack of any moral sense or conscience. "They have none at all," said Dr. Kernberg. "They lie, cheat, exploit people without any remorse, though they can be loyal to people they feel they need."
Dr. Post sees these traits in Mr. Hussein, reflected in his speeches. "He identifies himself with Nebuchadnezzar, the Babylonian king who conquered Jerusalem in the sixth century B.C., and with Saladin, who captured Jerusalem from the crusaders in the 12th century," Dr. Post said. "Being at the center of the world stage fulfills the dreams of glory he's had since adolescence."
 
Paranoia Can Help
 Dr. Post sees paranoia in the Baathist Party ideology that Mr. Hussein has embraced. "Saddam Hussein says with sincerity that the problems of the Arabs came from the imperialist West, from the Jews and from the Persians," he said.
This doctrine was also articulated in a pamphlet written by Mr. Hussein's mentor and uncle, Khayrallah Tulfah, entitled "Three Whom God Should Not Have Created: Persians, Jews, and Flies." Mr. Hussein had the pamphlet reprinted in 1981.
"This paranoia can be helpful in political life, especially if you belong to a persecuted revolutionary group," said Dr. Kernberg. "But once you get into power yourself, you have to search out new enemies. For a dictator it typically takes the form, 'If you're not with me, you're against me.' "
Mr. Hussein's "paranoid outlook," said Dr. Post, "justifies his own aggression to himself.
"In his view, Kuwait waged economic warfare on him. His attack, then, was 'defensive,' in a war they initiated. He sees his own aggression as justified by the enemy, but does not see how he created the situation."
While Dr. Post's psychological analysis makes sense of many facts of Mr. Hussein's life, critics note that other interpretations are equally plausible, and that his diagnosis is based on a slim body of evidence.
For example, the key factor in childhood that seems to lead to malignant narcissism, said Dr. Kernberg, is "an extreme amount of cruelty, either witnessed or received."
 
A Cousin Could Read
 Because accounts of Mr. Hussein's childhood differ, Dr. Post is unable to say for sure that as a child the Iraqi leader was often beaten, as some biographers say. Mr. Hussein's father died at about the time the son was born. His mother married his father's brother, according to custom, and it was supposedly the stepfather who was cruel to the young Saddam.
The most famous incident of Mr. Hussein's childhood is his having been impressed at the age of 10 by the visit of a cousin who could read and write. When the young Saddam asked his parents if he, too, could go to school, the answer was no. That night, Saddam ran away to the home of his uncle near Tikrit, and went to school there. The uncle, an early member of the Baathist party and later a governor of Baghdad, shaped Saddam's world view.
Some political analysts point out that the Baathist ideology itself explains many or most of Mr. Hussein's actions. Other critics say that even if the diagnosis is correct, it may be of little use.
Saddam Hussein "seems a perfectly rational political decision-maker, given the circumstances, despite any personality twists," said Dr. Jervis. "For example, he can win by losing the war. If he survives he'll emerge a hero to the Arab masses."
Other experts object that diagnoses of a powerful leader are irrelevant. "When someone has immense political power, he transcends any psychatric label you might give him," said Dr. John Mack, a psychiatrist at Harvard Medical School and a founder of the International Society of Political Psychology. "You have to understand what he does in terms of his ideology, his culture and its view of the world, and his capacity to change the course of events."
 
Article on Goldwater
 Since World War II, when military intelligence commissioned a personality study of Hitler, there has been a cottage industry producing detailed psychological analyses of major political figures. The focal point of that industry, at least in the Federal Government, has been the center Dr. Post founded. The psychological assessments are used in briefings of Government officials for meetings or negotiations.
Within the behavioral sciences, however, the general approach has come under sharp attack over the years. Its greatest fall into disrepute came in the wake of an article in Fact Magazine in 1964 in which several hundred psychiatrists offered glib psychiatric assessments of Senator Barry Goldwater of Arizona, the Republican Presidential candidate. As a result, it is now considered unethical for psychotherapists to diagnose someone they have not interviewed or studied intensively.
That does not apply, however, to personality studies based on detailed research about the circumstances of someone's life. For example, Dr. Post's analysis, unlike the off-the-cuff psychiatric diagnoses of Senator Goldwater, drew on a wide variety of sources, ranging from the half dozen biographies of Mr. Hussein and his speeches, to interviews with people who have had personal dealings with him.
Recent years have seen increasing intellectual respect for such detailed psychological histories, or "psychobiography," often of historical figures like Woodrow Wilson, Virginia Woolf or Freud himself.
In making his study of Saddam Hussein, Dr. Post did not have access to many key details of his life. "To do a thorough psychobiography of Saddam Hussein, you'd need detailed information about his childhood and later life that we just don't have," said William McKinley Runyan, a psychologist at the Institute of Personality Assessment and Research at the University of California at Berkeley.
 
Friendliness as Weakness
 But despite the fragmentary information available about Mr. Hussein's personal life, Dr. Runyan said the psychological analysis was "still worth having," adding, "Knowing the psychological profile of a leader like Hussein seems a necessary component of knowing how to deal with him more skillfully."
For example, drawing on what is known about those with malignant narcissism, Dr. Kernberg said, "they only respect power and strength," adding, "They see friendliness or compromise as weakness. The danger is that they may not be able to assess that a danger is real, because their grandiosity may make them feel invulnerable."
But the predicitve value of psychological profiles has limits. Dr. Post, who said before Jan. 15 that Mr. Hussein would probably back down from a confrontation at the last minute, said, "These are patterns and tendencies. You can say how someone has reacted in past crises, but you can't make hard predictions" based on personality alone.

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
Qualify for Good Job

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
Times are hard and good jobs are not easy to get. But here's a simple test to find out if you qualify for a well-paying position as an opinion maker in the field of international affairs.
All you have to do is prove that over the past 12 months you have publicly taken the positions listed below on the Soviet Union and the Middle East. 
 The Soviet Union:
1. Mikhail Gorbachev's survival as leader of the Soviet Union is essential to American interests, the well-being of the Soviet people and world peace. Without him the deluge, never mind what Soviet democrats say to the contrary.
2. Under Mr. Gorbachev, the power of the K.G.B. is finished for good. No Soviet citizen will ever again fear the nighttime knock on the door, bless him.
3. The United States must channel money, credits, food, everything it can afford right to Mr. Gorbachev. We must hurry before we lose our chance to help him, and establish an economic foothold in his new Soviet free-market world.
4. The Baltic nations are making a nuisance of themselves by demanding independence. One day maybe he will give them all the freedom that is good for them. Until then, they should shut up and be patient.
5. That was a nifty decision of the Nobel people to give Mr. Gorbachev the Peace Prize.
On the Middle East:
1. The real problem of the Middle East is the struggle between Israel and the Palestinians. If the intransigent Israelis would settle that by giving up land to a new Palestinian state, the threat of any war in the Middle East would be all over.
2. Saddam Hussein is vital to the stability of peace in the Middle East, to say nothing about the stability of the price of oil. He may be a terrorist, but we need him and have to be pragmatic.
3. Saddam Hussein will not invade Kuwait.
4. Well, all right, he did invade Kuwait, but the way to get him out is to sanction him to death. He is already so weak that he couldn't stand more than a few more months of it. Forget that scare talk about how he is building up his strength, not fading away, as we wait.
5. Hafez al-Assad of Syria is vital to the stability of peace in the Middle East, to say nothing about the stability of the price of oil. He may be a terrorist, but we need him and have to be pragmatic.
Now, if you can prove you supported all 10 positions, there is no limit to the jobs for which you can qualify, including Secretary of State. Most experts outside the Government cannot claim number 3 in the Middle East section -- they never even thought of the possibility. But if you missed on a few, don't despair. You could still be one of those specialist-professors who are hired as experts by the networks, or a columnist, or an editorial writer, or appear on TV programs where everybody gets paid to shout at everybody else.
Plenty of all those types have taken anywhere from five to nine of those positions. Some score higher in one category than the other. Depends on which is stronger -- their wishfulness about the Soviet Union, or their detestation of Israel.
But please note the tricky opening paragraph. I said you would qualify as an international expert -- I never actually promised you the job.
There are four hitches.
1. The people who took so many of those stands are still in their jobs, so there are not many openings. They have no intention of resigning because of a few lousy mistakes.
2. To get one of these great jobs, you have to know how to hint that history will prove you right after all. You need the skill of rewriting history -- like saying that Gorby couldn't make it only because Soviet democrats pushed him too hard for freedom.
3. You also have to predict a future that will fit in with your past mistakes. Like: Total chaos will envelop the Soviet Union without Mr. Gorbachev, or the defeat of Iraq will leave a terrible "power vacuum."
4. This is important -- you also have to hold deep grudges. Never forget that one day the war with Iraq will be over and then we can really stick it to Israel.
So maybe you won't get the job after all. But there is a consolation prize. If you have taken the test, maybe you won't put so much credence in the words of all those opinion makers who have demonstrated their simple-mindedness about Communism or their soft-mindedness about Arab dictators, or both, but are still on the job, predicting away, analyzing like mad, same as ever.

HEADLINE: Patterns

BYLINE: By WOODY HOCHSWENDER

 BODY:

Couture in Crisis
It is an especially delicate moment for the couture business. Many clients and journalists have stayed away from the Paris shows, as much for fears of terrorism as for the fact that the declining dollar has made some dresses as costly as a Mercedes. 
 With a shrinking list of perhaps 2,500 clients worldwide for such high-priced frippery, there has been dark talk of haute couture dying out. Houses like Nina Ricci and Jean-Louis Scherrer are in distress because up to 50 percent of their customers come from wealthy Arab nations. Pierre Balmain canceled its couture program in December, saying it was too expensive to keep going.
The Chanel show scheduled for today will cost about $2.4 million to mount, including the price of the sample garments, according to a report in Le Figaro, a Paris newspaper. The cost is said to be justified in part by the publicity generated.
Aside from the fact that the major players don't eat, couture is not that much different from the Super Bowl. Both are pumped-up spectator sports with related spin-off businesses. Instead of promoting beer and cars, couture is said to promote sales of perfumes, accessories and ready-to-wear clothes.
But fashion executives, while acknowledging the hype, take the view that these collections represent the apex of fashion creativity.
"I always find the couture directional," said Anna Wintour, the editor of Vogue, who flew to Paris for the collections. "On one level or another it affects fashion. What you see in the spring couture sets the pace for the fall ready-to-wear."
As an example, Ms. Wintour mentioned the red asymmetric suits shown by Karl Lagerfeld for Chanel on the couture runway for last spring, which also cropped up in the Chanel ready-to-wear, or mass-produced, collection for fall.
"Particularly now, in difficult economic times for fashion, it's important to see everything," Ms. Wintour added.
 
Men's Wear and Reality
The Paris couturiers are not the only ones undergoing an existential crisis. American men's wear designers are staging their seasonal shows in New York this week, amid news of war and a continuing recession in their business.
Robert Comstock canceled his fall men's wear show, citing concern about the Persian Gulf crisis. Ronaldus Shamask called off his show because fabric shipments from Italy were delayed in customs. Isaac Mizrahi decided not to hold a show this week for other reasons. In his debut collection last year, Mr. Mizrahi may have overdazzled his audience.
"Honestly, I think I confused everybody," Mr. Mizrahi said. "With a women's fashion show, every passage has to be fascinating, or it doesn't walk. Women's sportswear buyers know enough not to order certain things. However, men's wear buyers insist that men wear the clothes styled as they were in the show."
Mr. Mizrahi's fall men's wear line had mixed results, he said. The coats, at $800 to $1,200, sold well; but suit jackets, at about the same price, were less successful. They didn't "look the money," as the saying goes.
For his new men's wear, Mr. Mizrahi said he was taking a page from Donna Karan's book and designing for real needs.
"If I wouldn't wear it," he said, "I won't do it."
 
Saks and the Larger Woman
Saks Fifth Avenue will begin stocking large sizes for women this spring.
"We think there is a need," said Helen O'Hagan, a senior vice president of the store. "There is a big petite market, but we really want to offer clothes in large sizes at our taste level." Large size is 16 and up.
So go ahead, eat.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 3023 words

HEADLINE: Ideas to Help Poor Abound, But a Consensus Is Wanting

SERIES: The Missing Agenda: Poverty and Policy - Last of three articles.

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE with PETER APPLEBOME

 BODY:
Wanted: An American anti-poverty policy. Strategy must offer reasonable prospect for ending cycles of dependency and despair that disfigure urban America. Long hours and serious commitment needed. Costs may be high. Costs of doing nothing may be higher.
The want ad for an American social policy might go on to list other requirements: a passionate leader to articulate it, taxpayers willing to pay for it, special interests that sacrifice for it, skilled administrators to apply it. 
 While some have argued that the nation has run out of ideas, a wealth of research in the late 1980's has produced many new proposals for helping the disadvantaged.
"There's been increased attention and vigorous debate among a range of specialists and some policy makers about new approaches," said Robert Greenstein, director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a Washington research and advocacy group. "But I think the public is only dimly aware of a fair amount of the policy debate."
Ideas on ghetto poverty tend to cluster in four schools of thought. One emphasizes an expanded network of traditional government social services. Another stresses economic policies to create more good jobs that would offer a way out of poverty. A third stresses welfare reform. The fourth calls for "empowering" poor people with programs that let them make choices in areas like housing and education.
Some of the strategies are complementary: expanded social programs and welfare reform might work hand in hand, for instance, and some experts call for both. But other proposals are in conflict. Some emphasize building up inner-city areas, while others talk about helping people escape them. Some suggest universal programs in which all Americans can participate, while others say efforts should be aimed at the neediest.
The last Congress acted on some of these ideas when it expanded tax credits that provide cash supplements for the working poor, and financing for Medicaid and Head Start, despite tight budgets. And Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp, the Administration's chief antipoverty strategist, has sent President Bush a list of possible initiatives and urged him to use tonight's State of the Union Message to propose "audacious solutions" to inner-city poverty. But Administration officials say that after much bickering among aides President Bush has chosen a less ambitious domestic line.
 
Attention Is Diverted
 With recession and war capturing the nation's attention, progress on the domestic front may be stopped cold, and that frightens social policy experts of many ideological shades. They argue that America is fighting a war at home to preserve its own ideal of an equal citizenry, and that this fight is one the country cannot afford to lose.
"I think we're fighting a second Civil War here, and like the first Civil War, money shouldn't be the problem," said Lawrence Mead, a political scientist at New York University who describes himself as conservative. "We're trying to prevent a secession of the poor -- from work, school, politics, from mainstream institutions of every kind."
"We're in the 1862 stage," he said, speaking of a year when the Union Army met several defeats. "It could go either way."
 
A Social Approach
 
Old Programs Provide Models
To many liberals, the bitterest element of today's domestic policy environment is the widespread perception that government programs for the poor do not work, an attitude they say was stoked by the anti-government attitudes of the Reagan Administration.
Liberal academics like Lisbeth B. Schorr of Harvard University or advocates like Marian Wright Edelman of the Children's Defense Fund argue that there is ample evidence that government spending, if properly targeted, on schools, housing, health care and job training can be invaluable in breaking the cycle of poverty.
"It's a lie that nothing works," said Ms. Edelman, "and I think more and more people are realizing that. The fact is we made dramatic progress in the 1960's in eradicating hunger and improving the health status of children, and then we just stopped trying."
When arguing the effectiveness of government programs, advocates cite one more than any other: Head Start. A study of the best-known program applying Head Start principles, the Perry Preschool in Ypsilanti, Mich., tracked students for 16 years after they finished the program, and concluded that each dollar spent saved $6 in subsequent expense for things like remedial education, criminal justice and social services.
Advocates say the Head Start principle of concentrated flexible programs can be employed in many other areas, including health care, education and job training. In her book "Within Our Reach," published by Anchor Press Doubleday in 1988, Ms. Schorr examines numerous poverty programs that she concludes are making important differences.
In Tacoma, Wash., she says, the Homebuilders program uses social workers to counsel the families of troubled teen-agers, keeping them out of foster care or jail. In Elmira, N.Y., she points to the Pre-Natal/Early Infancy Project, which has lowered rates of infant mortality by sending nurses and social workers into the homes of pregnant poor women.
 
Skeptics Raise Questions
 Many other experts have pointed to the work of Dr. James Comer, a New Haven educator, in arguing that the sustained efforts of educators and social workers can make a difference in the lives of the poor. His School Development Program has raised the academic performance of poor children by using teachers and social workers to get parents involved in the schools.
But skeptics abound. Some say that the successes, including Head Start, have been oversold and that few programs have worked for the most imperiled group: young, noncollege-bound males. Others say the underlying social ills of slums and larger economic forces working against the urban poor mean that government programs can produce only isolated successes at best. And some successes, skeptics argue, are built from the efforts of especially talented administrators. They may therefore be impossible to replicate on a large scale.
Cost is also often an issue in these times of tight budgets, with estimates for a broad array of antipoverty programs ranging from $10 billion to $25 billion. But Ms. Schorr argues that the problem is will, not wallet.
"I don't know why it is 'possible' to find $500 billion to bail out the savings and loan industry and the money it takes to fight Saddam Hussein," she said, "but it's not 'possible' to find the money it takes to meet this equally grave threat."
 
An Economic Approach
 
Job Opportunity Is Seen as the Key
While liberal intervention programs focus on raising the mental and emotional capital of the poor, a different set of policies focuses more directly on their economic prospects.
One of the most influential thinkers on urban poverty over the past decade has been William Julius Wilson, the University of Chicago professor and author of "The Truly Disadvantaged," published by the University of Chicago Press. He argues that poverty and its associated problems ultimately arise from economic forces that are beyond the control of poor people.
Slums deteriorated, he argues, primarily because well-paying industrial jobs died out or companies fled the central cities. Any serious solution must take aim at the roots of inner-city problems through economic policies that promote full and profitable employment.
"I really believe that if you increase educational opportunity and employment opportunity, a lot of the social problems would disappear," Mr. Wilson said. "If all of a sudden people see they have some chance of moving out of their situation, then their behavior changes."
Those who agree with Professor Wilson's analysis call for a broad array of economic approaches, including policies to promote full employment, programs to train and relocate all displaced or new workers and the creation of government jobs.
In addition, most call for other policies to insure that working people are able to support their families. These include the use of tax benefits to supplement the earnings of the working poor, national health insurance, and a stricter enforcement of child-support awards, with the Government making the payment when it fails to collect.
 
Programs Available to All
 Professor Wilson says the main provisions of his plan -- like the job training and relocation programs, the health insurance and the child support guarantees -- would be available to all Americans, not just the poor.
Supporters of such universal programs argue that they would bring more political support, and less social stigma, than programs exclusively for the poor. The call for universal programs also reflects the belief that the problems of the poor are not so much a separate phenomenon as they are a concentrated example of the larger national social and economic difficulties.
Other analysts who are skeptical of such a macroeconomic approach note that creation of a full-employment economy has eluded policy makers for most of the century. Some say racism is so much a part of the inner-city problem that a strong economy would not always benefit the black poor.
Others note that many immigrants continue to succeed in the American economy as it is. The main inner-city problem, they argue, is not economics but social ills like the underground drug economy and welfare dependency that leave many inner-city poor people incapable of capitalizing on the opportunities that already exist.
"The behavior of the long-term poor is a real mystery," said Professor Mead, the New York University welfare expert. "It's not clear why they don't do what most immigrants do -- work hard and get ahead."
 
A Reform Approach
 
Altering Welfare In Novel Ways
A different group of experts believes that any antipoverty strategy is doomed without an accompanying overhaul, or a complete replacement, of the nation's welfare system.
"If you change welfare you will change the material basis for the culture of poverty," said Mickey Kaus, a senior editor at The New Republic magazine and the author of an influential article on welfare reform who is writing a book about antipoverty strategies. "Everything else is tinkering. It's good tinkering, but it's tinkering."
The current system, he and others argue, allows generations of single mothers to view unemployment as a way of life. In addition, it penalizes women who do try to work, since the low-wage jobs they can land often fail to make up for lost Medicaid benefits and the additional expenses of child care and transportation.
But there is considerable disagreement about how far government should go in requiring mothers on welfare to work and in supplementing their income with benefits like tax credits, medical insurance and child care.
Among those who see welfare reform as the key to antipoverty policy is Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who is the architect of the 1988 Family Support Act, Congress's most recent attempt to change the welfare system. Senator Moynihan argues that in passing the law, Congress has already laid the groundwork for a successful welfare system and that further change should await the results of this legislation, which he said will not be clear for at least 10 years.
The law requires states to enroll 20 percent of their eligible welfare population in job training or education programs by 1995. And it tries to make work profitable by guaranteeing child care and Medicaid for a year after a mother leaves welfare.
 
Doubts, and Other Ideas
 Some skeptics doubt the policy will reach the most disadvantaged. They argue that it compels too few to participate and provides too little to those who do work.
"It's a good first step, as long as it's a first step," said Professor David T. Ellwood, a poverty expert at Harvard.
In calling for a more ambitious program, Professor Ellwood says the country should offer a guarantee that no full-time worker would remain in poverty. To do this, he calls for expanded tax credits, which provide cash to low-wage workers, and an increased minimum wage. In addition, he advocates Government guarantees of child support from missing parents, child care and health insurance.
Once these methods had insured that work was a road out of poverty, he said, the Government should combat dependency by placing a time limit of two or three years on welfare payments. Those still unemployed at the end of their limit should be offered Government jobs, he said, but denied the extra cash benefits.
Mr. Kaus accepts those principles, but wants to take them further and faster. "Why give young mothers two or three years to be sucked into dependency?" he said.
He argues that welfare should be abolished completely for new recipients and replaced with a system of guaranteed government public works jobs, to men and women alike. The pay would be just below the minimum wage, to encourage recipients to leave for the private sector.
Government would provide those working such jobs with tax breaks, child care and medical insurance, to insure that all who took the jobs would be lifted out of poverty.
"You put the moral choice in its simplest and starkest terms," Mr. Kaus said. "If you work, we'll make sure your income is above the poverty line. If you don't work, the Government is not going to give you a check."
Among the objections raised to Mr. Kaus's plan is its expense, which he estimates would be in the $40 billion range, and the enormous difficulty of administering it.
Others say an overhaul of welfare, in aiming at women, does not provide sufficient incentives for undereducated men, and does not address other urban problems like crime, lack of affordable housing or bad schools.
Moreover it raises the problem of what to do with people who simply refuse to work, by constantly calling in sick, for instance, or showing up drunk or on drugs.
Mr. Kaus acknowledges that such people -- and their children -- would be forced to rely on private charities and shelters. "Some of them might become a more severely straitened class," he said, "but it wouldn't be anywhere near the size it is today."
 
An 'Empowering' Approach
 
Making Success Matter of Choice
When Mr. Kemp, the Housing Secretary, is asked to summarize his plans for what he calls "a new war on poverty," he sometimes resorts to a single word: "empowerment."
What is it?
Philosophically, it is the argument that poor people have been robbed of the choices available to others by their reliance on monopolistic government bureaucracies, particularly in the areas of welfare, housing and schools. "Empower" them with choices, the argument goes, and they will thrive.
In its particulars, empowerment most often boils down to policies that encourage the poor to run their own housing projects or own their own homes and that allow parents to chose which schools their children will attend. If forced to compete for students, the empowerment argument goes, schools will improve.
In addition, Mr. Kemp has called for tax policies, most notably capital gains cuts and the creation of "enterprise zones," which he says will provide the incentives to attract businesses and new job opportunities to the inner cities.
Mr. Kemp often attacks the current welfare system, but he has been unspecific in proposing an alternative. Of programs that require work in exchange for welfare benefits he said, "Workfare is a form of a stick; I think we need, dramatically, more carrots."
In his own nod toward empowerment, President Bush last year appointed Mr. Kemp to head an Administration task force charged with finding other applications for the principle.
A list of options from across the Government, submitted to the President by Mr. Kemp late last fall, ranged from the bold to the bland. At one end was a proposal to "empower" families by raising the personal income tax exemption to $3,300 from $2,050, at a cost of $50 billion a year in lost revenue. At the other was a vague call to "enhance victims' rights."
Mr. Kemp rejects Professor Wilson's contention that the problems originate in the general economy. The problem, he argues, is that Government policies on housing, education and welfare have created what he terms socialist economies in the inner city that have eliminated incentives for personal effort.
Critics argue that Mr. Kemp has substituted windy optimism for a clear appraisal of the depths of inner city need. Exhortations about the joys of entrepreneurship and home ownership, they say, will do little for people who have never worked or whose skills can land them only minimum-wage jobs.
"It's Pollyannish," said Isabel Sawhill of the Urban Institute, a Washington research center. "I think it's too optimistic about the ability of the poor to suddenly transform themselves into middle-class citizens."
Some argue the best solution is not to build up slums but to get their residents out. One conspicuous success story is the Gautreaux program in Chicago, which, under a 1976 court order, has relocated more than 4,150 families from public housing into subsidized apartments in neighborhoods throughout the Chicago area.
Studies show that those relocated have far better chances of working and avoiding antisocial acts. Only budget constraints and a shortage of available apartments keep the program from being larger.
Ed Marciniak, an urban affairs professor at Loyola University in Chicago, says that Mr. Kemp "is in dream world when he talks of tenant ownership."
"What people in poverty need are neighborhoods, communities," Mr. Marciniak added, "and it's difficult to have a neighborhood in a public housing project. What you need to do is build ladders out."
But such complaints fall on deaf ears, and Mr. Kemp reponds evangelically. "Entrepreneurial capitalism and empowerment can work," he said. "Let's unleash the greatest wealth our nation has: the pent-up talents and potential of our people."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 2, 1991, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, a front- page article on Tuesday about poverty and the national political agenda referred imprecisely to a remedy proposed by Mickey Kaus, an expert on welfare policy. Under his plan to replace the welfare system with a program of guaranteed Government jobs, people who refuse to work would not receive Government payments but could be aided by Government programs that provide services.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: THE OVERVIEW;
80 OF IRAQ'S PLANES NOW IN IRAN; HOSTS' INTENT CALLED A PUZZLE; U.S. SAYS FLOW OF OIL IS STEMMED

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia, Jan. 28

 BODY:
More than 80 Iraqi warplanes have been flown to Iran by their pilots in recent days, including more than 60 fighters and bombers, the United States reported today.
American officials suggested but said they were unable to confirm that the exodus of Iraqi planes had been coordinated between Baghdad and Teheran and was not the result of individual defections by pilots. The exodus amounts to 10 percent of the Iraqi Air Force and includes some of Iraq's most advanced French and Soviet-made planes. 
 Lieut. Gen. Thomas Kelly, the Pentagon operations director, said the United States was ready to shoot the Iraqi planes down if they tried to leave Iran and enter the war.
 
Combat Role Doubted
 But he said he did not think that they would be used in combat because grounded aircraft "begin to break after a time" without spare parts and regular maintenance. He indicated that the Iranians were not in a position to provide such help, saying Teheran did not have similar airplanes, "or not very many of them, so they are somewhat in jeopardy in terms of their longevity."
With the Iraqi Air Force heading for Iranian sanctuary in ones and twos, the American command said an attack by United States warplanes apparently succeeded in cutting off Iraq's release of crude oil into the Persian Gulf. The Saudi Government estimated that the slick had reached more than 450 million gallons, or nearly 11 million barrels, making it the largest spill in history.
An international task force gathered here to fight the ecological and economic consequences of the disaster, including a team of American experts assembled at President Bush's orders. A specialized Norwegian ship fitted with huge booms arrived off the neighboring island sheikdom of Bahrain, and Britain began the dispatch of 70 to 90 tons of equipment to be used to protect power and desalting plants. [Page A11.]
 
Saddam Hussein Interviewed
 The Cable News Network's correspondent in Baghdad, Peter Arnett, reported that in an interview tonight, President Saddam Hussein asserted that Iraq was justified in using oil for self-defense. [Page A12.]
Mr. Arnett said that in the interview, conducted in a bungalow on the outskirts of Baghdad, Mr. Hussein strongly hinted that he would use chemical weapons if his back was to the wall. The Iraqi leader was also quoted by Mr. Arnett as saying he had dispatched Iraqi planes to Iran because the two countries were Muslim states that viewed the gulf war as a struggle against infidels. Mr. Arnett is the last correspondent for a major American news organization still in Baghdad.
British authorities put the total number of Iraqi planes now at various airfields in Iran at more than 100, but in Washington, officials said a recheck showed 80 to 85 planes had been recorded by the end of the day. The Foreign Office said that Teheran had given the British ambassador fresh assurances that the planes would be detained and the pilots interned for the duration of the war.
 
No Interceptions Made
 Although General Kelly said that the United States has seen some of the planes leaving Iraq on radar screens, no effort has been made to head them off or shoot them down. Asked to explain why, Pete Williams, the Pentagon spokesman, responded that "they weren't causing us any trouble."
The allies report that they have shot down 26 Iraqi aircraft since the war began on Jan. 16 and destroyed 24 other planes on the ground. Few have risen from their bases to challenge allied aircraft, causing some concern that President Hussein might well be husbanding his resources to try to mount a counterattack once allied forces invade Iraqi-occupied Kuwait.
"Their air force doesn't amount to much of a threat," General Kelly said at the daily briefing.
But Iraqi ground fire has brought down a number of allied planes, and seven American pilots are now listed as prisoners of war. Baghdad radio, which had previously said they would be used as human shields against allied bombing, said today that several had been hurt in American raids.
 
Marines Lose a Harrier
 In the air war, the United States lost its first plane in 72 hours, a Marine Corps Harrier jet that was brought down over Kuwait. The allies have reported the loss of 24 planes so far, 18 of them in combat, 11 of them American. With weather over Iraq again clear, allied pilots managed another 2,000-mission day, pushing the overall total so far to 24,000.
French Mirage and Jaguar warplanes took part in the assault, blasting Iraq's Republican Guards in their encampment along the Iraqi-Kuwaiti border. Italian Tornados also played a role. British Tornados, which have specialized in low-level bombing and suffered heavy losses, were joined by a squadron of Buccaneers, high-altitude bombers first built in the 1960's.
Iraq's only response was the launching of Scud missiles at Israel and at Riyadh, the Saudi capital. One projectile aimed at Riyadh was intercepted by American Patriot missiles, and there were no reports of injury or severe damage there. One Scud missile aimed at Israel broke up in the air before any Patriots were fired at it, the Israeli authorities said.
Asked about complaints from Red Cross workers that allied planes had bombed the main road linking Baghdad with the Jordanian border, Brig. Gen. Pat Stevens 4th, the American logistics chief in the gulf, responded, "We do target main supply routes," but he insisted that pilots were "extremely careful not to cause any civilian deaths."
 
Ground Preparations Continue
 Although preparations for a ground offensive continued, with waves of C-130 Hercules transports heading north at dawn and roads leading to the Kuwaiti frontier crowded with tank transporters, cargo trucks, tankers and other types of vehicles, any such assault appeared to be at least two weeks away. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said on television on Sunday that all American ground troops would be in position for action by late February.
A Baghdad Radio broadcast asserted that an allied air attack on Sunday had created the oil spill. The allies spotted the slick several days before that, and said they had sent in United States F-111 bombers with "smart bombs" to cut the pipes from which much of the oil had been flowing.
The Saudi oil minister, Hismah Nazer, estimated the flow to date at almost 11 million barrels, equal to 460 million gallons, and many others put it hundreds of millions of gallons higher. On Mr. Nazer's estimate, the gulf spill is already larger than the biggest previously recorded, which was the blowout of the Ixtoc One well in Mexico in 1979 and 1980. That spilled from 2.5 million to 10.4 million barrels, or about 100 million to 440 million gallons, according to Government estimates at that time.
Col. Ahmed al-Robayan, a Saudi military spokesman, said the fires within the huge oil slick were now "getting smaller and smaller."
 
Oil Slick Slows
 It appeared the speed with which the oil was spreading had slowed markedly. This afternoon it was officially described as covering an area 35 miles long by 10 miles wide, as it was 24 hours before, and its forward point was again said to be just off the Saudi port of Ras Mishab, where it was said to be on Sunday night.
That news gave Saudi officials more time to get oil-trapping booms into place farther down the coast, especially at the big desalting plant at Jubail, north of Dhahran, which supplies half of all Saudi drinking water. But there appeared little that could be done to save the wildlife.
"It's a choice between clean drinking water and fish, and we've got to protect our drinking water first," a Saudi official commented.
The Pentagon confirmed the Saudi Government's statement on Sunday that the oil that has been washing ashore at the town of Khafji, near the Kuwaiti border, had come from oil tanks near Khafji that had been ruptured by enemy artillery fire. The larger mass of oil has not yet reached the shore, officials in Washington said.

PUB-DATE: January 29, 1991

SECTION: Section A; Page 21; Column 2; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 897 words

HEADLINE: Bush Surrenders at Home

BYLINE: By Alan Brinkley; Alan Brinkley is professor of history at the City University of New York Graduate Center.

 BODY:
If anyone has reason to be grateful for the war in the Persian Gulf, it is the unfortunate White House speechwriter responsible for President Bush's State of the Union Address this evening. Without an international crisis, what would the President have to talk about?
Perhaps no Administration in this century has completed two years in office so devoid of domestic accomplishments and so uninterested in setting a domestic agenda. And there is no suggestion that anything will change soon. John Sununu captured the essence of the Administration's emptiness recently when he answered a question about what remained on the President's domestic agenda with a curt, "Not that much." Were it not for Saddam Hussein, the Bush Presidency would be nearly invisible. 
 The litany of Mr. Bush's domestic failures is already painfully familiar: the silly drumbeating for hopeless constitutional amendments, the embarrassing contortions leading up to a budget agreement that the President now claims makes him "gag," the bold promises about education, drugs and homelessness followed by almost complete inattention.
Not even Ronald Reagan managed to antagonize black leaders as quickly as Mr. Bush has done with his clumsy veto of the 1990 Civil Rights bill and his even clumsier handling of the Education Department's notorious directive on minority scholarships. With the nation heading into what could be a major recession and its banking and financial system on the verge of collapse, the Administration has no response other than to hope that things will get better soon.
What accounts for this vacuous record? The President blames it on the Democratic Party's control of Congress, and he is partly correct in that. Unlike Ronald Reagan, Mr. Bush inspires no fear -- and, if the budget negotiations are any indication, some contempt -- among Congressional Democrats, who seem eager to see him (and his obstreperous aides) fail.
But the President's critics are also partly correct when they blame the Administration's problems on its own conceptual emptiness. Throughout his nearly three decades in politics, Mr. Bush has been a man of highly malleable convictions. On domestic issues, at least, he has never given the slightest hint of a deep commitment to anything other than his own political needs. He entered office with no ideological base, no natural constituency and no discernible agenda. The Bush Administration not only lacks a domestic mission, it lacks the will to look for one.
But Mr. Bush's greatest problem is precisely what got him elected in the first place: the hard-won triumph of the right within the Republican Party, a triumph achieved -- after years of frustration -- by the creation of what is now being trumpeted as a "new paradigm." For 30 years after the New Deal, the Republican right struggled to halt and even reverse the growth of the Federal Government. All such efforts ended in futility.
Attacking Government programs directly, as right-wing Republicans from Robert Taft to Barry Goldwater discovered, does not attract majority support. Every Federal program has a political constituency. The biggest and most expensive programs have the broadest support. Voters might not like government in the abstract, but almost everyone has some stake in the things the Government does.
Not until Howard Jarvis launched a tax revolt in 1978 with Proposition 13 in California did the right discover that there was a better way to undermine government than by assailing specific programs: It was assailing taxes. By separating the issue of taxes from the issue of what taxes supported, the right achieved the most controversial elements of its own agenda (destroying the Government's ability to achieve new goals) without openly antagonizing the millions of voters who continued to expect a public response to social problems.
George Bush is now the unhappy legatee of this dubious victory, one he dutifully supported throughout the 1980's but in which he himself apparently never really believed. Unlike Ronald Reagan, he is not inherently hostile to government; on the contrary, he is its creature.
He speaks forlornly of social goals he would like to achieve if only there were more money, and is unable effectively to challenge the "new paradigm" of the Reagan years -- that cutting taxes and undermining government's ability to act is the best route to success. The President's feckless performance during the budget negotiations makes it clear that he has no idea how to make the case for increasing public revenues.
Trapped between a deteriorating social and economic climate crying out for Government intervention, and a deliberately emasculated public sector stripped of most of its traditional tools, the President is now little more than a not-very-interested observer of the course of domestic events. He has no apparent strategy and no visible ideas, only the faint echoes of stale campaign rhetoric.
"We have the kinder, gentler approach," President Bush told Time magazine recently. "It is catching on. They used to laugh about the thousand points of light. There are plenty of areas of this nature that I would readily concede we have got a long way to go [before we] fulfill what I would like to see done in the next two years." That is about as coherent as George Bush has ever been on the subject of domestic policy.

SECTION: Section D; Page 15; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 245 words

HEADLINE: Net at Scripps Declines 32.3%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CINCINNATI, Jan. 29

 BODY:
The E. W. Scripps Company, a diversified media concern, said on Monday that its fourth- quarter earnings dropped sharply because of reduced advertising revenues.
Earnings for the quarter that ended on Dec. 31 were $21 million, or 28 cents a share, down 32.3 percent from $31 million, or 40 cents a share, in the 1989 quarter, the company said. Scripps had an unusual gain of $2.3 million a year ago on the sale of its investment in American City Business Journals.
Revenue for the latest quarter was $345.5 million, down slightly from $346.3 million the previous year.
"The advertising recession continues to hurt our earnings," said Lawrence A. Leser, president and chief executive."Despite good cost control, the weakness impacted us significantly, particularly at the newspapers."
E. W. Scripps, which is based in Cincinnati, operates 19 daily newspapers, 9 television stations, 5 radio stations and cable television systems with 613,200 subscribers. It is also a worldwide syndicator of news features and comics.
For the year, net income was $48 million, or 63 cents a share, down 46.2 percent from $89.3 million, or $1.14 a share, in 1989. The 1990 figure includes a $36.4 million charge associated with the termination of the joint-operating agreement between The News-Sentinel and The Journal newspapers in Knoxville, Tenn. The charge reduced net income by $23.7 million, or 31 cents a share.
Revenue was $1.3 billion, up slightly from $1.27 billion.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises on War News; Gold Contract Prices Drop

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar closed higher against leading currencies yesterday, strengthened by news of at least one Iraqi raid into Saudi Arabia.
"Apparently Iraq knows its strength is on the ground," said Marc Cohen, vice president of Fuji Bank in New York. "Perhaps it it trying to lure the United States into a ground war prematurely."
 
February Contract Down 70 Cents
 Gold fell, meanwhile, with the price of the expiring January contract slipping 60 cents, to $376.10 an ounce on the Commodity Exchange. Gold for the active February contract fell 70 cents, to $376.40 an ounce.
The dollar, historically a safe holding for investors in time of crisis, tends to rise on bad news from the war zone in the Persian Gulf.
Accordingly, it closed at 1.4960 German marks, up from 1.4880 marks Monday. Against the Japanese currency, the dollar closed at 132.15 yen, up from 131.60 yen.
A senior United States military official said a dozen Iraqi soldiers slipped across the Saudi Arabian border Monday night and wounded three Saudis in an ambush.
 
'Next Step' in the War
 Iraq reported three cross-border attacks on Saudi Arabia, saying its units returned to their bases after seizing and destroying equipment.
"If Iraq continues these attacks, the U.S. will have to react," starting a ground war, Mr. Cohen predicted. "Apparently, we are embarking on the next step of the gulf crisis."
For most of the day, however, the dollar showed few trends. It was helped briefly by news that durable goods orders in the United States rose by a greater-than-expected 4.4 percent in December, but fell back somewhat when the Conference Board reported that the consumer confidence of Americans fell in January to its lowest level in 10 years.
The British pound closed at $1.9595, down from $1.9650 on Monday. Against the Swiss currency, the dollar closed at 1.2675 francs, up from 1.2630 francs.
The dollar closed at $1.1605 (Canadian), down from $1.1625 (Canadian) on Monday. The dollar also bought 5.0770 French francs, up from 5.0545 francs on Monday.

HEADLINE: India in an Uproar Over Refueling of U.S. Aircraft

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Jan. 29

 BODY:
A decision to allow United States military aircraft to refuel at Bombay's international airport en route from the Pacific to the Persian Gulf has set off a political outcry that could bring down the Government of Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar.
Beginning on Jan. 9, American C-141 transport planes stopped at Safar Airport in Bombay at the rate of about two a day, according to The Times of India, which first reported the refuelings on Monday. 
 The newspaper said the planes werecoming from the Philippines. A spokesman for the United States Embassy here, refusing to comment on the report, said today that diplomatic missions do not normally confirm or deny military movements.
Mr. Shekhar, who has since the beginning of the gulf war taken a stand more critical of Iraq than that adopted by nearly every other political party, is being accused of pandering to "American imperialism."
Among his sharpest critics are the leftists and the Congress Party of Rajiv Gandhi, whose support is needed to keep the Shekhar Government in power. Another former Prime Minister, V. P. Singh, has also opposed any policy that appears to favor the United States, saying that violates India's traditional posture of nonalignment.
A strategic analyst here, Bharat Wariavwalla, said in an interview today that it appeared that the Shekhar Government, in a significant departure, "was trying to distance itself from a kind of third-world romanticism about Saddam Hussein."
The decision to refuel American planes, which the Indian Government said were carrying no weapons or other war supplies, comes at a time when the domestic airline, Indian Airlines, has had to cut back its servicesby nearly one-third to conserve aviation fuel.
From the start of the gulf crisis in August, India has only half-heartedly backed United Nations condemnations of Iraq. Baghdad and New Delhi had close ties, diplomatically and economically. Indian expertise and labor had been used in Iraqi industrial and strategic development.
Last year, Iraq stood nearly alone among Islamic nations in refusing to join in condemnation of India's heavy suppression of an independence movement in Kashmir.
Soon after taking office in November, Mr. Shekhar, a pragmatic man with no experience in foreign policy, rejected attempts to link the annexation of Kuwait with Israeli occupation of areas claimed by Palestinians. On several occasions, he has said Mr. Hussein couldhave been more forthcoming in responding to efforts to avoid a war.
Mr. Shekhar's political enemies and Congress Party supporters, unable to deflect him from taking bold domestic steps like meeting leaders of militant Sikh organizations to discuss the crisis in Punjab or refusing to dismiss controversial ministers, have now found a potent weapon in foreign policy.
Mr. Shekhar's Foreign Minister, V. C. Shukla, was disqualified from Parliament with seven others in early January for having broken a law against switching parties without resigning a seat. The Law and Justice Minister, Subramaniam Swamy, was forced to apologize publicy to the Speaker of the House for having threatened to arrest him if he did not do the Government's bidding in postponing the disqualification decision.

HEADLINE: Only One U.S. Family in Four Is 'Traditional'

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29

 BODY:
The decline of the traditional family two parents with children -- continued in America in the 1980's but at a slower pace than in the 1970's, the Census Bureau said today.
In 1970, 40 percent of the nation's households were made up of of a married couple and one or more children under age 18. That proportion dropped to 31 percent in 1980 and to 26 percent last year, the bureau said. 
 The information came from a survey of 57,400 housing units conducted in March 1990. Household information from the complete census, conducted a month later, will not be available forseveral months.
"All of the things we saw happening at a rapid and destabilizing rate in the 1980's are continuing, but at a more moderate pace," said Steve Rawlings, a family demographer at the bureau who wrote the report.
"There's also a slowdown in the net increase of total households and a slowdown in the creation of new households," he said. "It may be the aging of the baby boom. And economic factors may well be depressing the ability of young adults to form their own households."
In other respects, the report depicted a nation leveling off from the breakneck pace of change in the 1970's:
*While the number of single parents hit 9.7 million last year, the growth in that category, 41 percent over 10 years earlier, was half the 82 percent increase in that category in the 1970's.
*The number of single mothers (8.4 million of those 9.7 million single parents) was up 35 percent from 1980, as against an 82 percent increase in the 1970's.
*The number of divorced mothers was up only 1.6 percent annually in the 1980's, as against 9 percent a year in the 1970's.
*Household size continued to decline, but at a slower pace. The size of theAmerican household was 2.63 people in 1990, down from 2.76 in 1980 and 3.14 in 1970. In 1940, it was 3.67 people.
The number of traditional families remained fairly stable throughout the 20-year period: 24.5 million in 1990, 24.2 million in 1980, and 25.5 million in 1970. But the total number of households grew at a more rapid pace.
"You could say that all the increase in households has taken place outside of traditional families," said Linda Waite, a sociologist with the RAND Corporation, a California research group. Thus, anything that tended to slow the growth in family households would increase the proportion of traditional families.
Late marriage delays formation of new families and can increase single households. Divorce increases the number of single households.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Hilton Plans to Seek Atlantic City License

BYLINE: By MICHAEL LEV, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 29

 BODY:
The Hilton Hotels Corporation said today that it planned to apply for a license to operate a hotel and casino in Atlantic City with an eye toward entering the market.
"An opportunity for our company in Atlantic City could occur," said Barron Hilton, the company's chairman, in a statement. "We want to be in a position to proceed." 
 Hilton owns or operates 254 hotels in the United States, including three hotel-casinos in Nevada.
Mr. Hilton said the company was not currently in any negotiations to purchase a casino in Atlantic City.
Hilton built a casino and intended to enter the Atlantic City market in 1985 but was denied a license by the New Jersey Casino Control Commission, which said it was aware of ties between some Hilton executives and people who had been linked to organized crime. Hilton denied the allegations.
The commission subsequently granted the company's request for a rehearing, but Hilton decided to sell the property, now known as Trump Castle, to Donald J. Trump for about $320 million.
Mr. Trump is now having severe financial difficulties and analysts speculated that Hilton might want to reacquire the Trump Castle at a discount. Mr. Trump also owns the Trump Plaza and Taj Mahal in Atlantic City. Mr. Trump issued a statement today saying that he had not had discussions with Hilton about the sale of Trump Castle and that "Trump Castle is not for sale."
The Bally Manufacturing Corporation, another troubled company, also owns a property in Atlantic City and could be compelled to sell, analysts said.
David Jackson, an analyst at the Western Group, a securities firm in Los Angeles, said the timing was right for Hilton to look in Atlantic City. With competition heavy and business off because of recession, Hilton could drive a hard bargain.
Joseph J. Doyle, an analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company in New York, said that despite the slowdown in growth in Atlantic City, the market holds promise in the long term because of the tremendous revenues casinos can produce.
Hilton shares closed down $1.125 today, at $34.875, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
Mark Manson, an analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in New York, said the share price fell because some investors believed that with Hilton expressing interest in Atlantic City, the chances were smaller that the company would reorganize or sell out. In 1989, management put the company up for sale, but later took it off the market.
James J. Murren, an analyst at C. J. Lawrence, Morgan Grenfell Inc. in New York, said some investors were worried that Hilton would find Atlantic City rough going.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Uses Image of F.D.R. and '32

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 29

 BODY:
Conjuring up the economic nightmares of the 1930's seems like perilous strategy for politicians facing hard times. But when the comparison invokes the image of Franklin D. Roosevelt, who was swept from Albany to Washington at the depth of the Great Depression, the strategy could have its benefits.
Such, at least, appears to be the reasoning of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. In recent weeks, Mr. Cuomo has invoked the dark days of the 1930's on several occasions, saying that the state government is as bad off today as it was 60 years ago. 
 New York is confronting "fiscal problems more severe than any we have faced since the Great Depression, and maybe more severe than anything this state has ever faced," Mr. Cuomo said in his recent State of the State address.
 
Referring to Government
 In an interview today, Mr. Cuomo stressed that he was referring only to the problems facing the government, not to the problems facing New Yorkers in general. "My distinction is between problems and fiscal problems," he said. "Social problems, for example, were much worse then than they are now."
Even taking such distinctions into account, however, historians say they find the comparison puzzling. "We certainly do not appear to face a crisis of the magnitude of the Great Depression," said William Leuchtenburg, a Roosevelt scholar and a professor of history at the University of North Carolina. "That's not the comparison that immediately jumps to mind."
 
Vast Differences in Scope
 By almost every measure available, New York's current problems are only a dollhouse version of the problems that it faced during the Depression. Statewide unemployment figures for the 1930's are not available, but local figures present a bleak picture; in 1932, for example, unemployment in Buffalo reached 33 percent, according to a State Labor Department survey. At the start of this year, in contrast, the unemployment rate in New York State was under 6 percent.
In terms of state finances, the focus of the Governor's remarks, the comparison between the Great Depression and today's recession is somewhat more apt, but still strained. In the grim winter of 1932, Governor Roosevelt presented to the New York State Legislature a budget with a shortfall of $124 million. This shortfall represented slightly more than half of the state's expected tax revenues for the year.
Governor Cuomo, who is to present his budget to the Legislature on Thursday, has said that for the upcoming year the state is facing a budget gap of $6 billion. This amounts to roughly one-fifth of the tax revenues that the state expects to collect.
Experts say that even if the raw numbers matched up, the historical analogy would be rendered almost worthless by the tremendous changes in the scope of state government.
Sixty years ago, state government was a relatively limited venture; New York State built prisons, paved roads, provided education aid and cared for crippled children.
Today, the state presides over a network of social service programs, administers a farflung university system, owns nuclear power plants and provides care for thousands of mentally ill adults.
"The basic conditions are just so different, you can't make a comparison," said Norman Hurd, who served as state budget director under Govs. Thomas E. Dewey and Nelson A. Rockefeller.
Governor Cuomo is something of a student of state history, and recently he received a briefing on New York during the Depression, including a copy of Governor Roosevelt's budget proposal for 1932. (The similarities between some of Mr. Cuomo's recent remarks and some of Mr. Roosevelt's statements are striking.)
Still, aides to Mr. Cuomo say they are not sure how he came to the conclusion that the state was facing a fiscal crisis along the lines of the Depression. The purpose of the comparison, they say, is largely scholastic, anyway.
"Part of it is an education in the size of the problem and the dramatic steps we're going to have to take to solve them," said Anne W. Crowley, the Governor's press secretary.
 
Some See Other Motives
 But others see trickier motives at work. Governor Cuomo, they say, is drawing an unspoken but emphatic analogy between himself and Governor Roosevelt, who was elected President in the bleak fall of 1932.
"Without saying anything explicit, the implication is that F.D.R. went on to be a great President," said Gerald Benjamin, a professor of political science at the State University of New York at New Paltz. "F.D.R. is not remembered as Governor; he's remembered as President, and that's precisely the point."
Mr. Cuomo, not surprisingly, denies any such implication, noting today that it was Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, not Governor Roosevelt, who led New York out of the Depression. "Lehman did a lot more socially than Roosevelt did," he said.
What Mr. Cuomo did not point out, but what is clear from his biography, is that Mr. Lehman never got close to the White House; he ended his political career in the United States Senate.

GRAPHIC: Photos: "It is true that in any state of this Union of States the complete solving of those economic problems which are national in scope is an impossibility without leadership and a plan and action by our national government. Perhaps that will come, but in the meantime we in this state have a very positive duty to do what we can to help ourselves." - Gov. Franklin D. Roosevelt: Jan. 6, 1932
 "While only the national government can influence significantly the national economic tide that carries the 50 state boats, we in the state cannot afford to wait for Washington's help, or to use their failure as an excuse for not doing all we can for ourselves." - Gov. Mario M. Cuomo: Jan. 9, 1991 (UPI/Bettmann, 1932; Joe Traver for The New York Times)
