HEADLINE: Consumers' Confidence Dips Again

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Reflecting worry over rising unemployment and the Persian Gulf war, consumer confidence fell again in January, the Conference Board reported yesterday. Not since the early 1980's has the board's monthly survey turned up such pessimism.
Consumer confidence, as measured by the Conference Board and the University of Michigan's Survey Research Center, more or less tracks the ups and downs of the nation's economy by suggesting how willing Americans are to spend. January's low reading indicates that a spending spree is not yet on the horizon to lift the nation out of recession. 
 The Conference Board, a business research organization, produces two indexes from a nationwide poll of 5,000 households. These indexes had fallen steadily but gradually from March until August, when they plunged sharply in the wake of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, reaching recessionary levels in the fall.
 
Pessimism on the Future
 One index, measuring how consumers feel about current business conditions and job availability, dropped in January to 53.6 from 63.3 in December. That was the lowest level since September 1983. The other, measuring what people feel might happen to jobs, income and business activity over the next six months, fell to 54.3 in January from 59.8 in December. That was the lowest level since May 1980.
Less than one person in five expected their incomes to rise over the next six months, and one in three complained that jobs were hard to find. Plans to buy a car or a home also fell in January from December's level.
The big question is whether confidence will rebound if the war ends soon and successfully. Fabian Linden, who runs the Conference Board's survey, and many other economists say the gulf crisis explains why consumers are feeling so low, while rising unemployment and a weak economy play a lesser role.
"The readings we are getting are far too stark to be explained by the economy alone," Mr. Linden said. "If the war ended tomorrow, we would get a spurt in confidence and a psychological thrust toward ending the recession. But ending the war might not end the recession."
 
Separate War Responses
 In support of this view, the Conference Board poll, conducted from Jan. 1 through Jan. 24, broke out responses after the war started on Jan. 17. "They were a bit more positive; not pushing the indexes up to the December level, but more positive than the responses earlier in the month," said Jesse Bram, a Conference Board official.
Edward Yardeni, chief economist at Prudential-Bache, noted that personal consumption data released by the Government this week showed a rise in December. "Consumers don't seem to be acting as badly as they seem to feel," he said.
Richard T. Curtin, director of the University of Michigan's consumer survey, is more pessimistic. "The problems in the Middle East helped to cause the fall in consumer confidence and the recession," he said. "But once the economy was in recession, then the problems usually associated with recession came center stage: unemployment and lagging incomes."
The university's January survey has not yet been published.
The Conference Board's survey is conducted for the organization by National Family Inc., Toledo, Ohio. It noted that confidence fell in January in seven of the nation's nine regions.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Saudi Arabia;
War Transforms a Bypassed Desert Community Into a Boom Town

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ZULFI, Saudi Arabia, Jan. 27

 BODY:
George Bush is a local hero here. America is Number One. And some Bedouins here have been calling their hunting falcons Patriot, a name that residents predict Bedouin children will soon bear.
The war has been good for Zulfi. Egyptian, French and Syrian troops have recently passed through this sprawling community of hamlets set in valleys of sand. As a result, Zulfi, which most traffic bypassed once a major freeway was completed in the early 1980's, is booming. 
 But merchants throughout the area expressed ambivalence about their sudden prosperity. "The war is good for business," said Mohammed Abdul Samad, an Indian who manages an electronics store. "But I wish it were over."
 
An Influx of Kuwaitis
 Mr. Samad's success began soon after Aug. 2, when thousands of Kuwaitis fled to Zulfi, many to the villas and farms they had purchased long before Iraq's invasion, others to more modest shelter, even tents. Sales of shortwave radios and television sets promptly increased by 40 to 50 percent after their arrival, Mr. Samad said.
Al-Nakeel Bakery, which used to sell 20 cartons of round, flat Arabic bread a day, now moves 50 to 70 cartons a day. And the owner of a rice and spice shop in the vegetable market reported that his business had increased by 40 to 50 percent.
Agriculture in this region, which is heavily subsidized, is also doing well. Abdullah Barjas, an owner of the National Fertilizer Company, said demand for his chemical-based products was particularly strong. "We sold about 45,000 metric tons in 1989, and nearly 60,000 metric tons last year during the crisis," Mr. Barjas said. A metric ton is about 2,200 pounds.
The results of the Government's intensive nurturing of the kingdom's agricultural sector are surreal. Lush green fields irrigated by giant water cannons are framed on one side by a towering rocky escarpment and on the other by an ocean of red-tinged sand dunes hundreds of feet high.
 
Camping Atop the Sand
 Bedouins and residents still take to the dunes at dusk in their four-wheel-drive Land Cruisers to camp atop the sand, sip tea and swap gossip over campfires. Some come just to gaze at the moon and the Milky Way and retell ancient myths about battles between the constellations. On a clear, cold desert night, with a full moon, there are many shooting stars, and these, unlike the Scuds and Patriots over Riyadh, do not explode.
Zulfi is part of the Nejd, the conservative central Arabian heartland, in which almost everything is "haram" -- forbidden. "We call it Haramstan," complained one young resident.
One sunny market day, a Western reporter, dressed in a headscarf covering every strand of her hair and a black floor-length cloak, was approached by two young members of the religious police. Scowling, they commanded a man who was with her to "cover her face."
"We are Americans, and American women do not wear veils," the woman protested. Studiously ignoring her, they turned once more to the man. "Aren't you ashamed?" they chided him, throwing up their arms to the heavens in disgust. "How can you let her walk around like that?"
 
Roads Paved in the 1970's
 Zulfi is only about 15 years old. Before that, it was two small villages connected by a dirt road. There were no paved roads here until the 1970's. Villagers from Belad and Aqdah, which became Zulfi, used to hurl stones at one another, such was the emnity between them. Now, the physical, social and psychological lines that separated them have blurred.
Beyond this merged town lie remnants of the poverty that all too recently was the hallmark of central Arabia. The tiny hamlets, set like emeralds in the rolling dunes, betray the secrets of the past. Most have a squat mud-brick tower, in which these settlers protected themselves against marauding Bedouins, one of this country's most enduring struggles -- that between the settled farmers and the nomadic peoples.
Several of the hamlets languish in their isolation. These places, built by the country's poorest, not by Government subsidy or decree, are slowly collapsing in the winter rains and blasting desert windstorms.
 
Steadfast Backwardness
 These hamlets fought to preserve their backwardness: Athuwayr, for example, rejected mandatory education for boys until 1974; for girls, education did not come until 1981. Both were resisted, along with other forms of "westernization," as contrary to Islam, and the Government did not impose them.
"The Government knew that connecting these virtually deserted outposts with paved roads, running water and electricty was a waste of money, that it did not make economic sense to permit these people to engage in nostalgic farming," said one cosmopolitan young resident of Riyadh, who was raised in such a village. "But the people wanted it, so, of course, the Government complied."
"It looks romantic now, doesn't it?" he said, pointing to the eroding mud hut that once was his home. The reality was harsher, he said. When it rained, his family huddled by a fire on the dirt floor in the only section of the palm-leaf thatched roof that did not leak. There was unrelenting heat in summer, numbing cold in winter, no lights or running water and omnipresent lizards, spiders and flies. Ants the size of a fingernail used to creep inside his ears and bite.
"This is the poverty we came from," he said. "This is what most of us remember. And this is why we hate Saddam. This is what he wants us to return to."

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Germany;
GERMANS TO GIVE $5.5 BILLION MORE

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, Jan. 29

 BODY:
German leaders, under quiet but sustained criticism for not contributing enough to the anti-Iraq coalition, announced today that their Government would provide an additional $5.5 billion.
They also said Germany would send new air defense systems to Turkey, together with about 580 soldiers to operate and maintain them. 
 The Defense Ministry says that 1,600 to 1,700 German soldiers are already aboard minesweepers and frigates in the eastern Mediterranean and at an air base in Turkey. It is the first military force Germany has sent to a war zone since the end of World War II.
"This contribution is a clear sign of German solidarity with the United States, whose soldiers bear the main burden of implementing the United Nations resolutions on the liberation of Kuwait," the chief Government spokesman, Dieter Vogel, said in a statement announcing the new aid today.
 
Help for the Israelis
 Mr. Vogel said Germany would soon supply air defense systems and perhaps other military equipment to Israel. Officials said later that the Government was also considering making a direct contribution to Britain to help defray its war costs.
Leaders of the allied countries, anxious to preserve the anti-Iraq coalition, have refrained from publicly criticizing Germany for the level of its contribution to the war effort. But allied unhappiness with Germany has begun to spill into public view. It has been especially sharp in Britain, where some politicians and news commentators have in recent days been accusing the Germans of cowardice.
Otto Lambsdorff, head of Germany's Free Democratic Party and a senior political partner of Chancellor Helmut Kohl, said on returning from Washington on Monday that he had found Americans "indignant and disappointed" about Germany's uncertain role in the Persian Gulf conflict. He reportedly pressed his colleagues in Bonn to announce new aid commitments.
"Germany's position in the United States has never been as difficult as it is now," Mr. Lambsdorff said.
According to Government figures, Germany had already contributed or pledged more than $2.2 billion to the allied war effort, in addition to $1.3 billion in aid for Turkey, Egypt and Jordan. But it is unclear how much of that money had already been committed when hostilities in the gulf began.
 
A Constitutional Issue
 The total amount Germany has now pledged to the war effort, slightly more than $9 billion, roughly equals the sum pledged by Japan, which has also been criticized for failing to aid the anti-Iraq effort generously enough. The Government spokesman, Mr. Vogel, said at a briefing today that the similarity was coincidental.
"Japan's gross national product is twice as big as ours," Mr. Vogel said. "We also have obligations in southeastern and eastern Europe that must be taken into account. In our negotiations with the Americans, we ask them to take that into account. And they do."
The German Constitution, in clauses that have been much debated in recent weeks, bans the dispatch of troops to foreign combat zones. The 18 Alpha jets and 270 pilots and maintenance workers that Germany sent to Turkey this month, and the additional military aid pledged today, are symbols of Germany's commitment to the defense of a NATO ally against possible Iraqi attack, but they are not deployed as part of the anti-Iraq effort.
Recent public opinion surveys suggest that Germans are evenly divided over whether the Alpha jets should be sent into action if Turkey is attacked by Iraq. Chancellor Kohl has taken no firm stand on the question, much to the consternation of Turkey's President, Turgut Ozal.
"The signal should go out that if Turkey is attacked, let NATO be with Turkey," Mr. Ozal said in an interview broadcast on German television last week. "We would like to see that wrong messages should not be given to President Saddam Hussein, because in that case he may make wrong decisions."
 
'Count-Me-Out Attitude'
 Former Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, writing in the liberal weekly Die Zeit, warned that Germany's nonparticipation in the military offensive against Saddam Hussein was being viewed as "an egotistical count-me-out attitude."
Resentment toward Germany in other allied countries stems not only from its perceived low level of commitment to the gulf force, but also to the role of German companies in arming Saddam Hussein. Public demand to curb such exports has risen sharply, and officials are moving to give the police greater investigatory powers, but some Germans remain skeptical of the Government's seriousness.
"All German governments, no matter from what party, as well as a silent majority in the Bundestag, are responsible for the fact that Israel has not been able to sleep the past few nights," concludes the weekly magazine Stern in its current issue. "German governments, officials, and companies could have prevented Saddam's arms buildup if they had chosen to do so. The shame of having built up Saddam's military is a burden on Germans, and it is understandable if other countries find this deplorable."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
A Club Med Vocation For a New Executive

BYLINE: By Kim Foltz

 BODY:
Tod Seisser said he had little difficulty adjusting to his new position as senior vice president and associate creative director at Ammirati & Puris, the New York agency he joined this month.
It helped that one of the first responsibilities he inherited was the Club Med account, which involves a bit of tropical travel. Ammirati, which has billings of more than $245 million, also handles accounts for BMW, Schweppes and U.P.S., though Mr. Seisser would not specify his other clients.
Mr. Seisser is perhaps best known for his work at Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver on the Maidenform campaign, which featured the actors Corbin Bernsen and Omar Sharif discussing their feelings about lingerie.
He left the agency to become vice chairman at Keye/Donna/Pearlstein, New York, but he found himself unemployed when the agency closed last year. He did freelance work for nine months before joining Ammirati.
In his new job, Mr. Seisser has already traveled on business to Club Med resorts in St. Lucia, Martinique and Guadeloupe.
"It beats touring a garbage bag factory in Alabama, which I've done, too," Mr. Seisser said.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Public Opinion;
A Slight Decline Is Found In U.S. Backing for War

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. KAGAY

 BODY:
Support by the American public for the war against Iraq continues to be strong, but there are further signs of reduced expectations, according to a new poll conducted by CBS News.
Seventy percent of the 1,173 adults nationwide interviewed by telephone Sunday and Monday agreed that "the United States did the right thing in starting military actions against Iraq." That was down slightly from the 76 percent who agreed with the same view a week earlier in a New York Times/CBS News Poll. 
 In another indication of a more sober outlook, 34 percent of those interviewed said their impression was that the war was going "very well" for the United States, down from 50 percent a week earlier. Most of the rest in each poll said the war was going "somewhat well."
The proportion of Americans who expected a war of just a few weeks duration continued to fall, to 7 percent in the latest poll from 18 percent a week ago and from 40 percent the day after the war began.
The new CBS News Poll and the earlier Times/CBS News Polls had margins of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
On a question intended to measure personal distress caused by the war, 39 percent of the Americans interviewed said they have felt "edgy or short-tempered or are having trouble sleeping" because of the war.
But the percent saying they "feel proud about what the U.S. is doing in the Persian Gulf" remained essentially unchanged at 78 percent.
 
Slight Drop for President
 President Bush's job approval rating stood at 79 percent, down slightly from 84 percent a week earlier.
But Americans were evenly divided on Mr. Bush's handling of the economy: 43 percent approved while 44 percent disapproved. Their view had been even more negative in December when 34 percent approved and 55 percent disapproved.
The image of Congress also seemed improved from the level before the war; 49 percent said they approved of the way Congress was handling its job, up from 23 percent last October during the battle over the budget.
Although the question has been asked only intermittently in national polls since 1974, this is one of the highest rating ever given Congress.
In the latest poll, 67 percent said they thought "the United States military is holding back information about the war in the Persian Gulf." But more people said the purpose was to avoid giving help to Iraq than said the purpose was to avoid giving bad news to Americans.
Looking ahead, 42 percent of the Americans interviewed said they expected the war in the Persian Gulf would hurt the nation's economy.

HEADLINE: Tax Rebate in New Hampshire Town Poses a Test for School-Choice Issue

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EPSOM, N.H.

 BODY:
A new program granting $1,000 tax breaks to families that send their children anywhere but the local public high school may turn this small town into a national testing ground for plans that offer parents a choice as to where their offspring will go to school.
The plan was enacted in December in this town of 2,800 people in south-central New Hampshire as part of an effort to reduce local property taxes, which are among the highest in the nation. Epsom has no high school of its own; instead, it pays a fee to a regional high school for each student it sends there. 
 Sponsors of the measure contend that for every family that chooses to enroll its children in other schools, including parochial schools, Epsom will save money.
But opponents of the program, including some parents, school officials and the state's largest teachers' union, say it would violate the constitutional separation of church and state and is really a disguised attempt to undermine public education. They also say it would discriminate against those who do not own property.
 
Bush Administration's Views
 The concept of parental choice plans is favored by the Bush Administration, which recently set up the Center for Choice in Education as part of the Department of Education. The Administration has strongly supported a new Wisconsin program that allows up to 1,000 low-income families in Milwaukee to use state funds to send their children to private nonsectarian schools.
Clint Bolick, the director of the Landmark Center for Civil Rights in Washington, a conservative group that has offered legal and financial aid to defend the Epsom program if it is challenged in court, said, "I think Epsom has tremendous potential significance for New Hampshire and the United States."
The center is also providing legal help for the school-choice program in Milwaukee. A lawsuit challenging the Wisconsin law is scheduled to be argued before the State Supreme Court this spring.
Mr. Bolick said the Epsom program might be an even more important "breakthrough for choice" than Milwaukee's because it was enacted by the town itself, without going through a state legislature. "That makes it highly transportable and ripe for copying by other municipalities around the country," he said.
 
'Frightening Implications'
 But Barbara Barksdale, who has three children in Epsom's public schools, said, "I see this program as the first step in abolishing public education in this country."
Dr. Paul DeMinico, the superintendent of schools for Epsom and four neighboring towns that share Pembroke Academy, the regional high school, said: "In my opinion this has frightening implications. It creates a new class of citizens who are less responsible for supporting public education, and it could mean that public schools will only be for the poor, ethnic minorities and the handicapped."
He added, "I don't think this is fair or legal."
The new plan may bring more attention to Epsom than the landmark for which the town has been best known until now -- a 10-foot-tall roadside replica of a Trojan horse, designed to mock the United Nations as the handmaiden of Communism.
Under the plan, any Epsom property owner can get a rebate of up to $1,000 on his property taxes if he sends his children to a high school other than Pembroke Academy. This could be a private school, a religious school or another public high school.
Jack Kelleher, a former town selectman who devised the ordinance, said the program would save the town $3,600 for every student who chooses not to go to the local public high school. Epsom must pay $4,600 per pupil to the high school now, but would have to give back only the $1,000 in tax abatements to parents who sign up for the program, a savings of $3,600.
 
'Choice and Competition' Cited
 Mr. Kelleher, a member of the Libertarian Party, said, "This is the only program I know of where the more people participate the more the government saves."
The program also fosters "choice and competition," said Mr. Kelleher, who is single and has no children. "Essentially, what we have now is a government monopoly over schools. As in any monopoly, quality deteriorates and costs go up."
In addition, Mr. Kelleher said, the plan would help the local public high school because it would reduce crowding in classrooms and lighten teachers' classroom work.
Dr. DeMinico challenged Mr. Kelleher's arguments. "It doesn't work out as neatly as he claims," the superintendent said, because "the bulk of our costs are fixed costs, for items like bond debt service, utilities, transportation and the salaries of teachers and maintenance people."
"So if we get fewer students from Epsom, it doesn't mean that we can cut our costs the $4,600 we charge per pupil," Dr. DeMinico continued. Instead, he said, the school will have to raise the tuition it charges Epsom to compensate for its loss of revenue.
 
'User-Fee System' for Schools
 Dr. DeMinico said he also thinks the new plan creates "a user-fee system for public schools," adding, "This goes against what public education in America has meant."
So far, the parents of 12 Epsom students of high school age have signed up for rebates. But their children are already attending other schools, most of them parochial schools. Of the 800 students enrolled at Pembroke Academy, 180 are from Epsom.
Epsom's adoption of the rebate program is part of a spreading tax revolt in New Hampshire, the only state in the country except Alaska that has neither a state income tax nor a sales tax. This has meant a heavy reliance on local property taxes.
In New Hampshire, local property taxes account for 91 percent of the revenue for public schools, by far the highest percentage in the nation, according to the United States Department of Education. The second highest is Oregon, with 68 percent. The national average is 46 percent.
 
'A Convenient Whipping Boy'
 In small residential towns like Epsom, with no industry or commercial development to broaden the tax base, the heavy reliance on property taxes has made homeowners keenly attuned to any increase in school budgets. Epsom's property tax rate has doubled in the past decade, and many residents have taken out their anger on the public schools.
"The schools are a convenient whipping boy," said Mrs. Barksdale.
Mr. Kelleher, who wrote the rebate program, said that when he first proposed the plan in 1982 he was regarded as "so radical and crazy" that no one would sit near him. But he persisted.
Mrs. Barksdale said Mr. Kelleher once showed up at a school board election with a sign saying, "Cut your property taxes by 75 percent -- abolish public education."
Mrs. Barksdale, who is organizing a group of parents opposing the program, said there were several different groups of people who supported it: Libertarians like Mr. Kelleher, who advocate a sharply reduced role for government, especially on the Federal level; old-line New Englanders, who see the program simply as a way to save money; parents who want the best education for their children and think the $1,000 will help get them a private school education, and Roman Catholics who send their children to parochial schools.
One parent who has signed up for the plan is Ken Preve, a college administrator with a 15-year-old son in Bishop Brady High School in Concord, 12 miles west if Epsom. "It's a matter of pure economics for the town; it saves the town money," said Mr. Preve. "The issue of church and state has nothing to do with it."
 
Legal Challenge Weighed
 Mr. Kelleher is confident the ordinance will withstand legal challenge because he copied much of its language from a landmark 1983 Supreme Court decision, Mueller v. Allen, involving a Minnesota law that allows taxpayers to deduct school costs, including those for parochial schools.
But Ted Comstock, a staff lawyer for the New Hampshire School Boards Association, said he thinks the Epsom plan violates the First Amendment, as well as the New Hampshire Constitution's prohibition against using public money for church schools. Mr. Comstock said the association is considering a plan to join a lawsuit against the program.
A similar move is being considered by the New Hampshire branch of the American Civil Liberties Union and the National Education Association of New Hampshire, the local branch of the teachers' union.
But the first challenge may come from the neighboring town of Pembroke, which is examining whether Epsom failed to live up to the terms of its contract with the district school system.
Dr. DeMinico said he thinks Epsom is in violation, and therefore Pembroke could refuse to accept high school students from Epsom.

HEADLINE: In New York State, That Question Again: How Much to Tax, and Who Should Pay?

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM with EDWARD B. FISKE

 BODY:
As New York State's budget crisis slides from the painful to the excruciating, the state is being forced to confront anew one of its least favorite questions: how much tax revenue should be squeezed from its citizens and companies?
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, with an eye on his national reputation, has for months stressed his desire to balance the budget mainly by spending less. But administration officials have already said that in his budget plan for next year, which the Governor will unveil tomorrow, he will propose a 10-cents-a-gallon increase in the gasoline tax, a delay in scheduled reductions in the personal income tax and other tax increases. 
 Those new taxes, however, would offset only about one-fourth of the projected shortfall for the 1992 fiscal year, now estimated at $6 billion.
Virtually everyone agrees that state government is laden with fat and low-priority programs that should be lopped off. Some will be cut; but spending cuts have political and practical limits of their own, and deep reductions could be especially painful for a state that prides itself as a generous pioneer in social spending.
 
Long-Term Increases?
 Some experts believe that the deficits looming in the years ahead are likely to be so great that the state will be forced to consider major long-term tax increases as well as major reductions in its programs.
Among the questions posed by those who believe taxes will have to rise substantially are these:
*Did a 1987 cut in personal income-tax rates go too far, letting high-income New Yorkers off too easy?
*Should a decline in business-tax revenues be reversed by curbing the investment credits and other incentives that let many companies slash their taxes?
*Should the growing share of the economy devoted to services, like consulting, accounting and computer programming, continue to escape the sales tax, which was growing sluggishly even before the recession?
The Governor said last week that he wants to "avoid increases in broad-based taxes that would impair our economic competitiveness." But while elected officials tend to shy away from talk of tax increases, among private groups a debate has already been joined.
 
The Debate Begins
 Not surprisingly, public-employee unions and human service groups that depend on public funds call for casting a wider tax net.
Expected cuts in funds for essentials like schools and roads as well as for supporting the poor "will cause a real public outcry," predicted Russell Sykes, a policy analyst with the State Communities Aid Association, which represents social-service groups.
"The State Legislature will be forced to look seriously at the revenue side," Mr. Sykes predicted.
But Daniel Walsh, president of the Business Council of New York State, asserted that major tax increases could drive companies from the state. "The problem isn't on the revenue side, it's on the spending side," he said. "How do you get more revenues pumped out of an economy that's flat?"
While the recession has intensified the crisis, the state's budget has in fact been seriously out of balance for several years, according to experts ranging from the State Comptroller to community organizations. Borrowing that built up $5 billion in debt and the frequent resort to one-time revenue measures, these experts say, indicate a chronic imbalance that could outlast the recession.
And many economists warn that in the decade ahead the state's economy is not likely to repeat the boom of the 1980's. That would mean slower growth in revenues in an era when pressures to spend -- on health care, on the elderly, on crime, on a decaying infrastructure -- are greater than ever.
And since two-thirds of state spending supports city and county budgets, what happens to state revenues will directly influence the fiscal prospects for troubled New York City.
 
The Burden
High Taxes And High Spending
New York has long been a relatively high-tax, high-spend state, an approach perhaps epitomized by the reign of Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller from 1959 to 1973. Those policies have been extended under Governor Cuomo during a decade of booming economic growth that, until this year, allowed government to grow even as tax rates were cut and Federal aid, apart from welfare and Medicaid, declined.
New Yorkers complain that they pay the country's highest taxes, and they are essentially right.
If only state taxes are considered, New York would appear to bear an average burden: in percentage of personal income collected as state taxes -- 8 percent in 1989 -- New York ranks 21st among the states. But when state and local taxes together are considered, New York is number two, trailing only Alaska, where oil companies pay most of the bill, according to data compiled by Steven D. Gold of the Center for the Study of the States at the State University of New York.
This does not necessarily mean that urban extravagance is the problem. New York, unlike other states, requires local governments to share the huge costs of Medicaid and welfare. But the numbers do show that the economic and political impact of state taxes are linked to trends in local taxes, some of which are rising this year too.
 
Low Business Taxes
 After the 1987 cuts, the percentage of personal income collected by state and local taxes in New York declined slightly, from 16.6 percent in 1987 to 15.6 percent in 1989, but this was still well above the national average of 11.5 percent, according to Mr. Gold.
Unlike most other taxes, corporate taxes in New York are relatively low. Faced with a loss of manufacturing jobs, the state has offered a range of investment credits and other attractive features. A 1989 study, by the accounting firm Price Waterhouse, of tax burdens for companies investing in manufacturing in nine states -- five northeastern states plus Ohio, North Carolina and California -- found that New York had the lowest effective corporate income tax. Comparing total tax burdens on companies, including corporate, property, sales and other taxes, New York was below average, with a burden equal to those in North Carolina and Massachusetts.
 
The Outlook
Slow Growth, Increasing Pressure
Pressure for higher taxes will hinge in part on the performance of the state's economy; slow economic growth means less revenue from personal, business and sales taxes. Long-term forecasts are notoriously unreliable, but many economists believe that New York will not experience booming growth for many years, well after the current recession ends. "It will be a sober recovery," said Rosemary Scanlon, chief economist of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
"The 90's will be a payback time, a period of restructuring and consolidating," said Rae D. Rosen, vice president of the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York. The finance industry, the engine of growth in the 1980's, appears to be in for a long period of reorganization. Banks are also retrenching. With exceptions upstate, manufacturing continues to dwindle.
New York City's economic performance is the biggest single factor in state revenue prospects. In the 1990 fiscal year, the city alone provided 36 percent of the state's personal income tax revenues, and 41 percent of its sales taxes.
 
Personal Income Tax
Most Visible, Least Popular
Providing close to half of tax revenues, the personal income tax plays a more prominent role in New York than in almost any other state. The rate has been cut substantially since the 1970's, when it was 15 percent, but with business and sales taxes lagging the personal income tax is more dominant than ever.
The most recent cut, in 1987, was to be phased in over five years, cutting the maximum marginal rate to 7 percent for a married couple. Last year, as the deficit loomed, the state delayed the decline, freezing taxes at the 1989 rate of 7.875 percent.
The State Communities Aid Association, in a recent report, called the 1987 changes "too generous," and said they let higher-income taxpayers off too lightly. It proposes creating new top brackets for those with high incomes, a temporary surcharge and other changes.
Many experts say the personal income tax is often the fairest, most efficient way to raise revenues. Simply placing a surcharge of 10 percent on the existing tax, for example, would bring in an extra $1.5 billion. It is also, however, one of the most politically visible taxes, and one of the least popular.
 
Corporate Taxes
How to Handle Declining Revenues
To the chagrin of state officials, revenues from key business taxes declined from 1987 to 1990, even before the recession. The revenues rose in the current fiscal year only because the state imposed a temporary surcharge.
The 1987 changes in the corporate franchise tax -- the main income tax for manufacturing, trade and financial service firms -- reduced the top rate from 10 percent to 9 percent of taxable income, but at the same time sought to tax income that had previously been excluded. The combination of the two changes was supposed to leave the level of revenue unchanged, said James W. Wetzler, Commissioner of Taxation and Finance.
"It appears in hindsight that the tax reduction was too large to fulfill that goal," Mr. Wetzler said. Payments for the franchise tax instead declined by hundreds of millions of dollars during years of rising company profits. Several factors contributed, a state study found, including unexpected effects of Federal tax changes, reduced profits in financial services, increased deductible interest payments and increased use of investment tax credits. Another factor was a shift by many smaller companies to a tax status that allows owners to treat profits as personal rather than corporate income.
Mr. Wetzler described the problem with corporate taxes more as one of volatility and unpredictability than of declining revenues. But he added, "New York doesn't raise that much from corporations compared to other states, and we do it unevenly, with some companies paying higher rates and some paying lower rates."
 
Investment Credits
 Revenues jumped back up last year when the legislature placed a surcharge on corporate taxes of 15 percent of payable taxes for two years, then 10 percent for a third year.
Many critics have faulted the state's investment credit, which permits companies, mainly manufacturers, to write off a share of their investment costs. The credit became a lightning rod in the mid-1980's when it was discovered that the bulk of the benefits was received by a handful of giant companies.
Several changes have reduced the worth of the investment credit and related credits, but they still cut state revenues by about $300 million a year, Mr. Sykes estimates. And the benefits are still highly concentrated: more than half go to 10 large companies, he said.
Adding to the controversy was the revelation in the mid-1980's that thousands of companies, including some of the world's largest, had amassed enough credits to wipe out all tax liability except the token minimum of $250. In 1987, an alternative minimum tax was passed that now, with the surcharge, amounts to 5.875 percent. A majority of the state's manufacturing firms earn enough credits to require their use of this alternative.
Critics have also questioned the basis for calculating taxable corporate income. New York makes it relatively easy for interstate or international companies to allocate their income to other jurisdictions, tax experts say.
 
Fear of Losing Businesses
 Called loopholes by critics, most of the corporate tax breaks were adopted to counter a perceived threat of corporate flight, and to help lure new companies to the state.
"Do you want to risk losing an I.B.M. or a Kodak?" asked Abraham Lackman, director of fiscal studies with the Finance Committee of the Republican-controlled State Senate. "It's critical to our state to have these kinds of industries."
But Richard D. Pomp, a tax specialist at the University of Connecticut Law School who directed a major study for the New York Legislature that helped bring about the 1987 changes, said: "Corporate taxes are a low percentage of the cost of doing business in New York. It's hard to show that this affects anyone's decision."
 
Sales Taxes
Should Services Also Be Taxed?
Even before the recession, revenues from sales, excise and other consumption taxes had grown sluggishly. The big item is the sales tax, which has long been set at 4 percent; local governments charge another 3 to 4.25 percent.
One reason for poor growth in sales tax revenues, many experts believe, is the exclusion of the fastest-growing part of the economy: services. Special attention has focused on services often used by businesses, ranging from computer programming, advertising and consulting to accounting, legal and engineering services.
Extending the sales tax to many of these services could raise several hundred million dollars a year. But the lesson in Albany last year, when affected industries successfully beat back such proposals, was that the political obstacles are enormous.
So too would be the practical problems. One concern, even among proponents of such a tax, is that larger firms that have their own legal departments, accountants and other professional employees would escape the tax, while smaller businesses that must hire outsiders to provide such services would suffer. And in fields where the "products" are largely intangible and are delivered electronically, companies could easily move such "production" to branches out of state, noted Mr. Lackman, the State Senate aide.
But proponents of service taxes say such problems can be solved. "We have a service economy and we're not taxing services," Mr. Sykes said. "That's fundamentally wrong."
Mr. Wetzler, the State Tax Commissioner, urged great caution in entering the area of service taxes. "In looking at the tax system," he said, "it's important to be mindful that, just as manufacturing firms have the option of leaving, it's just as possible that service firms might leave."

HEADLINE: Borrowing By F.D.I.C. Suggested

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29

 BODY:
Congress's chief economist proposed today that to head off insolvency, the Federal bank insurance program borrow from the Treasury and pay taxpayers back later.
Robert D. Reischauer, the director of the Congressional Budget Office, told lawmakers that without such a step, the fund that insures bank deposits could have a deficit by the end of this year. Even if the banks increase their contributions and the recession is mild and short-lived, he said, the fund will run a deficit of about $2.8 billion next year. 
 In the budget request President Bush will send to Congress on Monday, the White House is forecasting that the fund will be insolvent as early as next year and that its deficit could be as large as $23 billion by 1995.
 
On Congressional Agenda
 The proposal by Mr. Reischauer, a highly regarded figure on Capitol Hill who has a strong reputation for not being ideological and not overstating budgetary problems, puts taxpayer assistance to the bank insurance fund on the Congressional agenda.
The budget office recommendation that the borrowing limit for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation be increased above its current $5 billion cap by $5 billion to $10 billion is the latest of several repair proposals under discussion in Washington among regulators, lawmakers, Administration officials and industry leaders.
All the proposals, which involve some form of borrowing or increased contribution from the industry, seek to avoid the taxpayer bailout that the more pessimistic forecasters call a virtual certainty. At the end of 1990 fund balances had sunk to about $9 billion from about $13 billion at the beginning of the year.
 
Proposal From Bush
 President Bush said in his State of the Union address this evening that the Administration's plans to revamp banking laws would "bring America's financial system into the 21st century so that our banks remain safe and secure, and can continue to make job-creating loans for our factories, businesses and home buyers."
He did not provide any specifics of the plan that Treasury is expected to disclose as early as next week. Treasury officials have said that they will call for the repeal of Depression-era laws that have prevented the merger of investment banks and commercial banks, sharply limited interstate banking, and prohibited industrial companies from owning banks.
Mr. Bush also did not address the problems of the bank insurance fund in his speech. Administration officials and industry executives have yet to agree on a solution in private meetings that have been under way since last week.
Administration officials have maintained that a reorganization of the Depression-era laws will ultimately make banks more profitable and attract badly needed investment, which could then be used as a cushion against losses.
 
One Official's Prescription
 But in his appearance before the Senate Banking Committee, Mr. Reischauer discounted the effect of such changes on the short-term health of the fund.
The insurance fund's liquidity needs "cannot be remedied by long-term regulatory reforms," Mr. Reischauer said. "To avoid delaying necessary bank closures because of a cash shortage, the F.D.I.C. must have the resources to undertake those closures."
He estimated that in the current economic climate, the F.D.I.C. would probably have to borrow $11 billion through 1994 to make up for shortfalls, even if banks pay premiums of more than 50 percent above the current annual payments of 19 cents for every $100 in deposits. If the recession became severe, he said, the F.D.I.C. might be required to borrow as much as $38 billion.
Mr. Reischauer also predicted that between July of last year and the end of 1993, 596 banks would fail, 48 of which have assets of more than $500 million.
The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, Donald W. Riegle Jr., called the suggestion of borrowing money to bail out the F.D.I.C. "a rather stunning development." Mr. Riegle, Democrat of Michigan, said the budget office recommendation could be adopted as a part of the effort to reorganize the fund, but questioned whether the projections were too optimistic.
 
Depression-Era Idea Revived
 The staggering difficulties of both the insurance fund and the industry are apparent just by the nature of the proposals being explored. A new fund that would invest in weak banking companies, a kind of plan not used since the establishment of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation during the Depression, is being discussed.
Treasury officials and banking regulators are scheduled to meet privately with bankers on Thursday to explore how to reorganize the insurance fund.
One approach being considered is for the F.D.I.C. to borrow from the banking industry instead of taxpayers, with interest to be paid by the premium payments. One problem with such an approach is that it would further limit the amount of money that banks would be able to lend to their customers.

HEADLINE: Canada Is Expected to Join U.S.-Mexico Trade Talks

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 29

 BODY:
After months of high-level talks, the United States, Mexico and Canada have reached agreement to include Canada in negotiations toward a continentwide North American free-trade zone, diplomats and trade officials said today.
The agreement, which could be announced as early as this week, would make Canada a direct participant in talks that have been under discussion by the United States and Mexico since the middle of last year. 
 The negotiations envisioned in the agreement would seek to bind the three countries' economies in a common market that would include more than 350 million people and would be larger than the European Community. Such a huge unhindered market would encompass interests as diverse as the machine shops of northern Mexico, the financial district of New York and the farmlands of western Canada.
"Everything is ready," one diplomat said, describing preparations for the three-way talks. "It's just a matter of making the formal announcement."
Administration officials in Washington said that any inclusion of Canada, which signed a bilateral free-trade agreement with the United States in 1988, would probably oblige President Bush to notify Congress that new trade negotiations were planned. A notification of the United States-Mexican trade talks was sent to Capitol Hill on Sept. 25. After receiving notification, Congress can disapprove of the proposed talks within 60 legislative days.
Diplomats said the inclusion of Canada would probably not delay the start of the talks with Mexico, which are expected to begin this spring. They said the talks could take account of Canada while awaiting the direct participation of Canadian negotiators after the 60-day Congressional period has passed.
In Mexico City today, business leaders who have been involved in the trade talks expressed support for broadening the negotiations.
"This could be the birth of a commercially united America, equal to the united Europe that is expected in 1992," said Francisco del Cueto, a spokesman for the Foreign Trade Coordinator for Business Organizations, a council of 500 Mexican business executives that is advising the Mexican Government on free-trade issues. "If it includes more countries, it gives more alternatives to Mexican producers and consumers."
 
Effort Begun Last Year
 Speculation about the possibility of continentwide free-trade negotiations has been strong since last year, when President Carlos Salinas de Gortari formally requested free-trade talks with the United States.
Canada quickly expressed interest in having a role in the new talks, but its status was left unclear amid uncertainty about how its inclusion might affect the United States-Mexican talks, which were considered a high priority by both countries.
President Salinas has sought to conclude a free-trade pact quickly to accelerate the economic growth that has become a hallmark and a crucial test of his administration. President Bush has also made an accord a central economic objective and has sought to complete it before it could become embroiled in the politics of the 1992 Presidential election year.
As discussion about broadening the talks has grown, Mexican politicians and commentators have expressed concern that Canada's participation could slow the process and reduce Mexico to the status of a latecomer to the 1988 United States-Canada accord.
But American officials have appeared increasingly receptive to the idea of a three-way negotiation. In his letter to Congress in September requesting permission to negotiate a United States-Mexican agreement, President Bush said Canada would be consulted. Since then, the three countries have held a series of meetings to work out the details of Canada's participation, including a high-level conference at the Mexican resort of Cancun earlier this month.
Administration officials in Washington today would not directly confirm that an agreement had been reached to include Canada. But a spokesman for Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, said Mrs. Hills had made clear her receptiveness to such an arrangement.
 
No Obstacles Seen
 "She has said in the past that she sees no technical or substantial obstacles to Canada's participation," said the spokesman, Timothy O'Leary.
In seeking a direct role in the negotiations, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada has argued that any United States-Mexican agreement would inevitably affect Canada.
Canada and the United States exchange more than $150 billion of goods and services each year and each is the other's most important trading partner.
Mexico's two-way trade with the United States is more than $60 billion, making Mexico the United States' third-largest trading partner, after Canada and Japan. Mexican trade with Canada amounts to only $2.5 billion annually, but has grown rapidly in recent years.

HEADLINE: Durables Orders Up In Month

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29

 BODY:
Buoyed in part by new military orders related to the Persian Gulf buildup, orders to factories for long-lasting goods climbed 4.4 percent in December, the Commerce Department reported today.
The increase was somewhat more than expected, but analysts said they found little in the latest figures to support hopes of an economic rebound. Even the rise in military orders, they noted, was from a severely depressed level the month before and was not large enough to provide any more than a nudge to business activity in coming months. 
 "It's only a marginal recovery," commented Robert H. Chandross, chief economist for Lloyds ank North America. He added that the best that could be said of today's report on durable goods, which are those that last at least three years, is that "in the aggregate, the economy is not in free fall."
A survey released today by the Conference Board, however, showed that consumers' confidence in the economy continues to erode, Pessimism is deepening, the survey showed, as worries mount about the Persian Gulf war and rising unemployment. [Page D2.]
 
No Military Breakdown
 A Commerce Department official said last month's orders for durables were clearly higher than they would have been in the absence of the Persian Gulf confrontation. But he said he could provide no breakdown, for example, of orders for ships compared with those for tanks.
Excluding military orders and those for commercial aircraft -- segments of the economy not closely linked to the business cycle -- December durables orders fell 3.4 percent from November levels.
Excluding only military goods, orders rose 1.9 percent, to $113.3 billion, after tumbling 9.1 percent without military goods in November, the department reported.
December's 4.4 percent overall rise from the month before, to $121.6 billion in orders, followed a 10.1 percent plunge in November from October, only slightly better than the 10.5 percent plunge initially reported for that month.
November's order total was so poor because of the later-than-usual adoption of the Federal budget, which delayed military and other Government purchases. Orders for military capital goods in November were the lowest in more than eight years, at $5.3 billion, and they rose last month to only $8.3 billion, or about 10 percent more than the monthly average for 1990 and below the average for 1989.
For all of 1990, durable goods orders sank 1.6 percent, the first decline since a 6.4 percent drop in the recession year of 1982, according to department officials.
Orders for durables are closely watched because they signal future levels of economic activity. But analysts are careful to allow for wild gyrations caused, in part, because durable goods tend to be costly items, like airplanes, that are ordered sporadically and in large quantities.
Analysts also take into consideration that some of the biggest items ordered may not actually be built for years, although the economy gets some immediate stimulus from design and other preliminary work.
Other parts of today's report showed that shipments of durable goods in December fell 2.8 percent, to $118.1 billion, hurt by a decline in shippings of motor vehicles and parts.
 
Higher Backlogs
 Backlogs of unfilled orders edged up seven-tenths of 1 percent, to $501.6 billion, almost entirely related to aircraft and shipbuilding, the department said.
The 13.6 percent increase, to $32 billion, in transportation equipment was helped by large increases in military shipbuilding and commercial aircraft and parts, which more than offset a decline in motor vehicles and parts. Orders for electrical machinery rose 11.5 percent, to $20.6 billion, mostly reflecting communications equipment.
However, new orders for non-electrical machinery slumped 5.1 percent, to $21 billion. And orders for primary metals slumped 6.1 percent, to $10.1 billion.
 
Year-to-Year Decline
 Before adjustment for seasonal variation, durable goods orders last month were $123.7 billion, up from $115.6 billion in November but 7.3 percent below the level of December 1989.
New orders for nonmilitary capital goods advanced 16.9 percent last month, to $41.9 billion, the report also showed, reflecting increases in orders for machine tools, computers and office equipment.
The economy could get "a significant countercyclical" lift in coming months from investment spending, said Gordon Richards of the National Association of Manufacturers, particularly from spending on computers.

HEADLINE: Intel to Spend Up to a Billion This Year

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PALO ALTO, Calif., Jan. 29

 BODY:
In a bold move to stay ahead of its competitors, the Intel Corporation plans to spend as much as $1 billion on new plants and equipment this year. If it does, that would make it the leader in capital spending among semiconductor companies, American or Japanese.
Gordon Moore, Intel's chairman, told securities analysts at a meeting here today that Intel's capital spending would be $800 million to $1 billion this year, and he said that the company expected to maintain that level for several years. That amount would be up sharply from about $670 million last year and would double the less than $450 million spent the year before that.
 
'Definitely a First'
 "This is definitely a first for a company to spend $1 billion," said Rajiv Chaudhri, semiconductor analyst with Goldman, Sachs & Company. Japanese chip makers, he said, are being more conservative in capital spending because they already make too many dynamic random access memory, or D-RAM, chips, their main product. The leading Japanese semiconductor producers are expected to spend $600 million to $800 million this year, he said. 
 The ability to outspend American companies on development and production has been a big reason Japanese companies have made gains in the semiconductor business. Now Intel plans to borrow a page from the Japanese by spending heavily through a recession to gain ground on weaker competitors. Other American companies might not be able to match that tactic because Intel has an unusually strong product line.
Intel is the only supplier of the 386 and 486 microprocessors, which serve as the "brains" of the most advanced personal computers compatible with the standard set by the International Business Machines Corporation.
 
Facing End of Monopoly
 But Intel, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., now faces the end of its monopoly. Advanced Micro Devices Inc. is beginning to sell a chip that duplicates the 386. And powerful microprocessors using technology known as reduced instruction set computing, or RISC, are moving strongly into the marketplace.
Intel's apparent response will be to use accumulated wealth to outspend the competition. It will add advanced new capacity at existing plants and at new plants in Ireland and Oregon.
The advanced technology will allow the company to produce vastly more complex chips, containing millions of transistors. That will essentially allow more of the parts of a computer to be placed on a single chip, giving Intel greater revenue from each computer sold. Dr. Moore said Intel should be able to keep a positive cash flow despite the heavy expenditures.
But Michael Gumport of Shearson Lehman Brothers, said the high spending could hurt Intel's earnings if demand softened or competition proved tougher than expected.
"I would be a lot happier if they had won those lawsuits before deciding to spend so much money," he said, referring to legal attempts by Intel to block Advanced Micro Devices and other competitors.
Intel's stock, traded over the counter, closed today at $44.50, up 50 cents.
Andrew Grove, Intel's president and chief executive, said in an interview that the company wanted to move "not when the competition becomes palpable, but well before it does." He added, "For us to have the opportunities that we have today and not bet on them, I don't want to lose that way."
Intel also plans to be a moving target for competitors. While Advanced Micro begins selling its 386, Intel will try to move computer makers toward the more powerful 486 chip.
Intel will introduce three scaled-down versions of the 486 this year that will be less expensive than the full 486 and should appeal more to computer makers. The first of those chips, expected to be called the 486SX, will lack the high-speed arithmetic capability of the full 486.
Thomas Kurlak, semiconductor analyst at Merrill Lynch, said that given Intel's plans, the potential competition from Advanced Micro and the RISC chips seems far less worrisome than it did a few months ago. Wall Street "has learned they don't need a monopoly as a crutch to do well," he said.

HEADLINE: Auto Slump Hits Honda And Production Is Cut

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 29

 BODY:
One of Japan's most successful auto makers is experiencing one of the most important rites of passage since it became a United States manufacturer: slumping sales and production cuts.
The Honda Motor Company, maker of the best-selling model in the United States for the last two years, the Honda Accord, said it would trim production at three assembly plants, including its factory in Marysville, Ohio. The cuts reflect consumer jitters over the war in the Persian Gulf and a deepening recession in the American automotive industry. 
 But Honda will not take its cue from larger Detroit rivals, which customarily idle workers for a week or more. Honda production will be cut back, but workers in Ohio will stay on the job, assembling sedans, coupes and station wagons at a slower pace.
Besides the Marysville plant, two of the Honda plants are in Japan. But the Ohio factory, the Japanese industry's first assembly plant in the United States, has become a symbol of the auto maker's widely praised approaches to manufacturing, labor relations and product design.
Honda and the other Japanese auto makers with United States plants have not yet had to adjust to serious sales declines, so American labor experts will be closely watching how they cope as the industry slumps.
 
'Nobody Is Unaffected'
 Honda, which has never before had to slow American production because of faltering demand, said it would build 25,000 fewer cars in the first quarter, equal to about 3 percent of its United States sales in 1990. Production cuts at Honda's Sayama and Suzuka plants in Japan will account for about 20,000 cars, assorted models that would have been earmarked for export to the United States. About 5,000 cars will be cut from production schedules at Marysville.
"This shows that nobody is unaffected by the weaker demand picture," said Harvey Heinbach, automotive analyst for Merrill Lynch & Company in New York. "Honda has been one of the very few auto makers who was able to sell everything" it could produce.
He added, "Even Honda is no longer in that position."
While the company's reaction to slow sales is relatively mild so far, its approach could change if the recession is longer and deeper than economists are predicting, a Honda spokesman acknowledged.
Since the early 1980's, in the face of restraints on their exports, seven Japanese auto makers have opened their own North American assembly plants or joint-venture plants with American partners.
Honda was the first Japanese auto maker to open an assembly plant in the United States, when it began making motorcycles at Marysville in 1979. It added cars in 1982.
The plant has become a prime example of how well American workers can adapt to Japanese-style management: productivity and quality standards at the factory have consistently outpaced those at most Big Three auto plants. That is due in part to relatively young and enthusiastic workers who have been assured they will always have a job.
For years, Honda's sales have risen spectacularly. But skeptics, who include American union leaders, have wondered how Honda might fare in a time of adversity. They may now have a chance to find out.
 
U.S. Sales Down 16%
 In the last two months, Honda's United States sales have dropped almost 16 percent from a year earlier, and inventories of unsold cars have been swelling. Honda has been the only auto maker -- American or Japanese -- to refuse steadfastly to pay cash rebates directly to customers to stimulate sales. Instead, Honda prefers to give discounts to dealers, allowing them to negotiate prices with customers.
Shigeaki Kato, a Honda spokesman, said the production cut would be accomplished by slowing the Marysville assembly line; many workers will simply do their usual jobs more slowly. All overtime work is being canceled.
The line speed at the plant, which normally averages about 96 cars an hour on a two-shift operation, will be reduced by about three cars an hour. The Marysville factory is the single biggest and most productive auto plant in North America, producing about 50 percent more cars than the typical American plant. It employs 6,200 workers and assembles about 60,000 cars a year.
Japanese auto makers have long avoided layoffs in Japan by keeping their work forces lean. During slowdowns, they gave workers other projects, taught them additional skills or sent them out to sell cars until business improved.
During union organizing drives in the United States, like those that failed at Marysville in 1986 and at the Nissan Motor Company's plant in Smyrna, Tenn., in 1989, the United Automobile Workers insisted that nonunion workers in Japanese plants in the United States were in danger of being laid off in a recession without unemployment benefits.
Some of these Japanese "transplant" operations have hired temporary workers who are subject to layoffs. But so far, layoffs have not been a big issue at the American plants run by Japanese companies, because the sales of Japan's auto makers, as a group, have continued to grow.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Honda Motor Company plant at Marysville, Ohio, where Honda plans to cut auto production without laying off workers. The work force will be kept at its current level but the assembly line will be slowed. (Kevin Fitzsimons for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Cash Draining, T.W.A. Asks U.S. to Act on Deal

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Trans World Airlines, its coffers brimming with cash as it entered the winter, is now pleading hardship to the Federal Government.
Sharply higher fuel prices, a drop in travel because of the recession and now a huge decline in bookings on its international routes since the Persian Gulf war increased fears of terrorism have begun to deplete the airline's financial reserves. So in a filing on Monday seeking swift approval from the Transportation Department for the sale of its London routes and other assets to American Airlines, T.W.A. argued that it critically needed the $445 million it would get from the deal. 
 At the end of September, the most recent date for which the airline has disclosed its cash position, T.W.A. had about $383 million in cash and $500 million in investments, some of which could easily be converted to cash.
In normal times such a position would enable T.W.A. to offset its losses during the winter, when overseas travel drops. But these are not normal times.
"Prompt approval of the proposed transfer of route authority to American is essential if T.W.A. is to avoid Pan Am's fate," said the filing, which is required by the Transportation Department in considering route sales.
 
Loan for Pan Am
 Pan American World Airways filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code this month because it was running out of cash. It was also able to get a $150 million loan from Bankers Trust and United Airlines to tide it over until the sale of its London routes to United for $290 million.
Because T.W.A. has been in a better financial position than Pan Am, some analysts said the dire warning in the filing was intended to put pressure on the Transportation Department to approve the sale.
"Part of this could be posturing," said Raymond Neidl, an airline analyst with Dillon, Read. But he added that "if traffic in February and March continues to fall as it has, then the cash can disappear pretty quickly."
Carl C. Icahn, the chairman of T.W.A., sought during the fall to strengthen the carrier by trying to combine it with Pan Am, by considering the purchase of Eastern Airlines' assets like the hub at Atlanta, and by putting pressure on T.W.A.'s unions for concessions. These efforts have not succeeded so far.
Mr. Icahn has also not hesitated to make big cuts to reduce operating costs.
T.W.A. cut its international service by half and put smaller Boeing 767's on some of its flights to replace 747's. The carrier also cut its work force by 2,500 employees, or 8 percent.
 
Bookings Decline
 Mark A. Buckstein, a senior vice president and general counsel for T.W.A., said the decision to cut back was made when bookings for the next 30 to 60 days began to fall, with many cancellations.
He said Mr. Icahn and T.W.A. management were no longer trying to find a carrier to merge with or to pick up some of the assets on the market.
During the last period when terrorist attacks sent bookings plunging, in 1985 and 1986, T.W.A. also moved quickly to cut back on flights to Europe and diverted much of its fleet to destinations in Florida and other parts of the United States. Mr. Buckstein said a similar strategy was being followed now, with the airline having added capacity to Florida.
Some of T.W.A.'s unions, including the Air Line Pilots Association, have asked the Transportation Department to require management to submit a plan on the use of the proceeds of the route transfer or dictate that the money be spent on such things as new equipment.

HEADLINE: Wait for a Bed at Public Hospital Can Be Days

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29

 BODY:
The average emergency room wait for a bed in the nation's public hospitals is now more than five and a half hours and in the worst cases 3 to 10 days, the National Association of Public Hospitals said today.
It is the first time that public hospitals around the country have been surveyed on this and other data that describe their rapidly deteriorating condition. Public hospitals, which are those operated by cities and other government bodies, are where most of the unininsured and the poor receive care. Private not-for-profit hospitals are run by churches, charitable organizations and universities while profit-seeking hospitals are owned by private corporations.
 
Average Loss of $40 Million
 Using data from a survey of 60 public hospitals completed in 1988, the study found that in that year: 
 The hospitals lost an average of $40 million to care that was not reimbursed by private insurance, Medicaid or Medicare. The hospitals receive subsidies from local governments, but even after these, their revenue fell an average of $9 million short of operating costs.
*An average of 104 cocaine-addicted babies were born in the hospitals, and the numbers were increasing.
*An average of 19,000 emergency room visits at the hospitals were drug-related, accounting for almost 30 percent of the emergency department visits.
The researchers found that the average wait for admission to a public hospital from the emergency department was 5.6 hours. The average of the longest wait at all the hospitals was 31.6 hours. While the longest wait was 10 days, waits of 3 to 4 days were not uncommon, said Virginia B. Weslowski, director of research for the public hospitals' association.
The survey for the emergency room waits was conducted over a one-month period while other parts of the study continued over the year.
 
Crisis for Many Hospitals
 Public hospitals, which historically are what the association called "the nation's safety net," have never been very healthy economically, said Larry S. Gage, president of the association. But now, the situation is reaching a crisis for many more hospitals.
"No one epidemic is sufficient to bring us to this point," Mr. Gage said. "But put together AIDS and crack and teen-age pregnancy and high infant mortality and inner-city violence and you see a large systematic increase in demand on these hospitals and a tremendous increase in mostly uninsured patients presenting themselves for care."
The report said, "In spite of long waiting times, overcrowding, staff shortages and lack of adequate equipment, the number of patients using public hospital clinics continues to grow."
The survey showed that more than 50 percent of all the visits to the hospitals by patients not admitted overnight were by people without insurance, confirming the idea that public hospitals are the "family doctor" for people who have no insurance.
 
Other Hospitals Affected
 Dr. Arthur Kellermann, medical director of the Emergency Department of the Regional Medical Center at Memphis, said the figures in the report described the first wave of a problem that is present in a large number of private and nonprofit hospitals.
Doctors have reported anecdotally for some time that public hospitals have been hit hard by a combination of epidemics and what Dr. Kellermann called a health care "system that just doesn't work well." The data released today provide evidence to back up the anecdotes that conditions are worsening, said Dr. Kellermann, who took part in the study,
The current crisis was noted in 1988 in New York City, he said, but the latest data show that the problems seen there are now occurring in hospitals around the country. "Many hospitals now are literally functioning daily and nightly as if there were a disaster or combat in the cities," Dr. Kellermann said.
The waits in the emergency departments, he said, are only the more visible parts of what is happening to hospitals in general. He said there are often long waits from the time a patient comes into the hospital and the time he first sees a doctor. "That is the least important wait, and this report doesn't measure that," Dr. Kellermann said. "These numbers are much more serious."
 
Waits for Intensive Care
 For example, he cited a wait of many hours for a patient who had suffered a stroke and had received emergency treatment but needed to be put in a bed where he could be watched.
The study showed the average wait for a bed in the intensive care wards was about 3.2 hours. The maximum wait at all the hospitals averaged 18.7 hours.
When the emergency rooms fill up with patients on stretchers, the survey showed that emergency departments take one or more of several measures: They refuse to accept new transfers from other hospitals, they close the emergency room to incoming ambulances and they begin to transfer patients to other hospitals.

HEADLINE: Weyerhaeuser Posts a Profit

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TACOMA, Wash., Jan. 29

 BODY:
The Weyerhaeuser Company, the wood products concern, today reported a profit for the fourth quarter but said its operating results were down in all but one of its business segments.
Weyerhaeuser had net income of $58.8 million, or 30 cents a share, compared with a loss of $128.7 million in the comparable period of 1989. Revenue for the quarter was $2.09 billion, nearly 19 percent less than the $2.57 billion for last year's quarter.
For the year, Weyerhaeuser had profits of $393.7 million, or $1.87 a share, 15.4 percent more than 1989's earnings of $341.1 million, or $1.56 a share. Revenue for 1990 was $9.02 billion, 10.8 percent below 1989's $10.11 billion.
The 1989 figures inlcuded a loss of $270.4 million for special items related to a restructuring. Without that expense, profits would have been $141.7 million, or 67 cents, for the period.
Setting aside special items in 1989, Weyerhaeuser's 1990 operating results for forest products were down 22 percent, while pulp and paper products were down 29 percent and real estate was down 70 percent. Operating results for financial services were seven times higher.
The company's shares were up 50 cents today, to $23.375 on the New York Stock Exchange.
George H. Weyerhaeuser, chairman and chief executive, said his company was among the first to be hurt by the recession. Mortgage and construction loans were harder to come by, housing starts hit a 10-year low and demand for new commercial space fell, all of which affected the building-materials markets, he said.
The company's financial service subsidiaries were a bright spot. The GNA insurance subsidiary set an earnings record, and the Weyerhaeuser Mortgage Company posted near-record results.

THE ECONOMY
The Federal bank insurance program should borrow from the Treasury and pay taxpayers back later to head off insolvency, the director of the Congressional Budget Office proposed. [Page D1.]
Orders to factories for durable goods climbed 4.4 percent in December, the Commerce Department reported. [D1.]
Consumer confidence fell again in January, the Conference Board reported. [D2.]
Among Bush's comments on the economy in his State of the Union address, he said interest rates should be lower and called for a commission to study a cut in the capital gains tax. [A1.]
Real estate taxes in New York City could rise far more than is clear from what has been outlined. [A1.]
The White House has waived the legal requirement that Federal projects be assessed for their environmental impact. [A14.]
The U.S. has halted a big part of a grain reserve program started in the 1970's to help stabilize prices. [A16.]

Honda said it would trim production at three assembly plants, including its Marysville, Ohio, factory. [D1.]
