HEADLINE: Eating Well

BYLINE: By Marian Burros

 BODY:
SINCE 1977 one branch or other of the Federal Government has been telling everyone in the country to eat less fat, cholesterol and salt. Everyone, that is, except the children who participate in the federally financed school-lunch program.
 The United States Dietary Guidelines, published by the Department of Agriculture and the Department of Health and Human Services, do not apply to school lunches, which come under the jurisdiction of the U.S.D.A. As a result, many of the meals served to schoolchildren are high in fat, cholesterol and sodium. 
Although there have been no national studies measuring the average amount of fat in school lunches, it is not unusual to find meals in which as much as 42 percent of the calories come from fat, according to calculations by the Center for Science in the Public Interest and the Marriott Corporation. The commonly accepted maximum is 30 percent.
 The meals, often that greasy kid stuff like high-fat hamburgers, french fries and hot dogs, are high in sodium as well, as much as 1,800 milligrams, which is the maximum amount recommended by the National Academy of Sciences for an entire day.
 Politics, inertia and ignorance are among the reasons many school lunches are such nutritional laggards. And the Agriculture Department has contended over the years that the dietary guidelines simply were not specific enough.
 But the latest version of the guidelines, published last fall, provides numbers that are difficult to ignore: people should get no more than 30 percent of their calories from fat, with less than 10 percent from saturated fat. The recommendations apply to everyone over the age of 2.
To motivate the Agriculture Department, the Citizens' Commission on School Nutrition recently published a "White Paper on School-Lunch Nutrition."
 The commission recommended, among other things, that the percentage of fat in school lunches be reduced to 35 percent of all calories over the next four years, and to 30 percent by 2000.
 The commission, brought together by the Center for Science in the Public Interest, a Washington advocacy group, included cardiologists, pediatricians, educators, nutritionists and school-food workers.
 The U.S.D.A. said it was willing to go along with most of the recommendations. "We don't want to turn the world upside down all at one time," said Ann Chadwick, the department's adviser for food and consumer services. "Changes have to be gradual."
 This is not the first attempt to improve the nutritional quality of school lunches. Officials of many school districts around the country, aware of the relationship between diet and health, have made their own changes. The U.S.D.A. itself tried, too.
 "We started out trying to do this in 1978," said Carol Foreman, former Assistant Secretary of Agriculture for food and consumer services.
 "And then it got to be controversial because the food producers -- the egg, milk and meat folks -- thought it was an attack on their products," she said.
 In nutrition circles the Reagan Administration is best remembered for trying to cut costs by having ketchup counted as a vegetable in school lunches.In 1981 the budget for the Government's Child Nutrition Program, including the National School Lunch Program, was cut by a third.
 "For 10 years that began with Reagan's inauguration the school-lunch program didn't go forward and it didn't even stand still," said Ms. Foreman, now a public-policy consultant in Washington. "It went backward and it is just regaining momentum now."
 Vivian Pilant, chairwoman of the American School Food Service Association's public policy and legislative committee, agreed. "My main concern is that the U.S.D.A. has not had funds," she said. "The Reagan Administration cut so much money."
 But the Federal bureaucracy has not been the only barrier to more nutritious school lunches:
 * Government commodities like ground beef and butter, many of which are high in fat, cost the schools less than what they would pay on the open market for more healthful foods. Most school systems do not have enough money to refuse the lower-cost items.
 * Untrained food-service workers do not know what constitutes a healthful meal or, for that matter, how to make food appetizing enough that children will eat it.
 * Junk food is easily available from vending machines in schools.
 * Some schools allow older children to buy lunch away from school.
 The biggest roadblocks to better nutrition may be the children themselves. "Because of television advertising, kids expect to eat a diet of foods that are fun," said Marion Nestle, a commission member and chairman of the department of nutrition at New York University.
 Victoria Leonard, director of the Children's Nutrition Project for the Center for Science in the Public Interest, said: "Kids and industry are an unholy alliance. Kids are choosing to eat junk."
 And Ms. Chadwick of the U.S.D.A. said: "The biggest problem is keeping kids in the program. If schools don't give children what they want to eat, they buy it elsewhere."
 Ms. Foreman, however, is not buying the blame-the-victim excuse. Much of the food served in school lunches is, to put it politely, tasteless.
 "Some of the stuff in school lunches does not have to be radically different from fast food," Ms. Foreman said. "Minor changes can be made to reduce the fat and cholesterol and salt so that the food still looks the same and costs the same. But you have to be creative enough to do it."
 There are schools that are trying. Joy Miltenberger, director of food service for the Palm Beach (Fla.) School District, brought about one of the success stories. When the Surgeon General's Report on Nutrition and Health was issued in 1988, Ms. Miltenberger decided that the 130 schools in her district ought to follow the recommendations.
 Salt has been reduced by half; dishes are made of half ground beef and half ground turkey; hot dogs, fried chicken nuggets and cold cuts like bologna and salami have been eliminated. French fries are served only two days a week.
 In 1989, California became the first state to limit the amount of fat and cholesterol in the school-lunch program. In Massachusetts, those who sell food to the schools are required to provide information on the levels of fat and calories per serving.
 In the Huntington and Harborfield Long Island School District, the menus arelower in fat, cholesterol and sodium two days a week. Tacos are made with turkey instead of beef, corn bread is made with egg whites rather than whole eggs, and skim milk has replaced whole milk.
 Praiseworthy as all of this sounds, there may be a downside to lowering the fat in school lunches. Lunch is supposed to provide a third of a child's daily nutritional and caloric needs. But for poor children, it may be the only square meal they get all day.
 Even though the commission's report called for the elimination of whole milk in school lunches, some health advocates believe it should remain as an alternative so that these children get the maximum number of calories.
 Everyone agrees that parental involvement can make a big difference in the quality of school lunches. To Dr. Nestle, lunch is part of a much larger problem.
 "It's part of our decline in caring about children," she said. "That's the reason school lunches are worth making a stink about, why they are worth fighting for."
 
LESSON NO. 1: REDUCE FAT; NO. 2: ELIMINATE JUNK FOOD
 THE Citizen's Commission on School Nutrition, made up of cardiologists, pediatricians, educators, nutritionists and school-food workers, has issued an 11-point program for improving school lunches. Because it is difficult to change children's taste preferences, the commission suggested making some changes in two stages, the first to be accomplished in four years; the second by 2000. NUTRITIONAL REQUIREMENTS: Adopt regulations to make school nutritional standards consistent with Government dietary recommendations.
 FAT: Stage 1: Reduce total fat to 35 percent of calories, with no more than a third from saturated fat. Stage 2: Reduce fat to 30 percent of calories.
 FIBER: Stage 1: Increase consumption of high-fiber foods, providing at least 8 servings a month. Stage 2: 15 high-fiber servings a month. Half of all bread and grain servings should be 100 percent whole grains.
SODIUM: Average sodium content of lunch, 1,000 milligrams. Stage 2: Average sodium content, 800 milligrams.
 NON-NUTRITIOUS FOODS: Ban sale of non-nutritious foods at school.
 CHOLESTEROL: Reduce average cholesterol content of meals to 100 milligrams or less.
 SUGAR: There should be no more than 20 percent sugar by weight in school breakfast cereals. Avoid sugary, high-fat desserts. ADDITIVES: Eliminate or reduce acesulfame-K, asparatame, BHA, BHT, caffeine, monosodium glutamate, saccharin, sodium nitrite, sulfite, yellow dye No. 5.
 MILK: Stage 1: Standard beverage should be milk with 2 percent fat; whole milk should not be required. Stage 2: Standard beverage should be milk with 1 percent fat or less.
 MONEY: Increase funds for lunches. Stage 1: Increase financing for Nutrition Education and Training program to $25 million by 1993. Stage 2: Financing beyond 1994 should be tied to inflation.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: GERMANY;
GERMANS ARE TOLD OF GULF-WAR ROLE

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, Jan. 30

 BODY:
Chancellor Helmut Kohl warned Germans today that they would not be able to avoid playing a role in the war against Iraq.
In a speech to Parliament, Mr. Kohl pledged that Germany would pay a fair share of war costs and would provide increased military aid to Israel. 
 The Government interprets Germany's Constitution as banning the dispatch of German troops to combat zones outside the NATO theater, but Mr. Kohl said he would seek to amend the Constitution to allow German soldiers to take part in United Nations peacekeeping missions.
"There can be no safe little corner in world politics for us Germans," Mr. Kohl said. "We have to face up to our responsibility, whether we like it or not. Until now, we have worked actively and successfully for the world's economic stability. This will no longer be enough."
 
Willingness to Aid Israel
 On Tuesday, responding to assertions that his Government had not contributed enough to the anti-Iraq effort, Mr. Kohl announced that Germany would send an additional $5.5 billion to the allied coalition. According to official figures, that raises the German contribution to slightly more than $9 billion.
Mr. Kohl warned today that tax increases would be needed to finance Germany's future contributions.
As he has in several other statements in recent days, Mr. Kohl stressed Germany's willingness to aid Israel. Relations between the two countries have been strained in recent weeks, and there have been protests in Israeli cities against Germany's role in arming Saddam Hussein.
"In these difficult days, Israel should know that it has our solidarity," Mr. Kohl told the Parliament.
A German television program reported Tuesday night that German companies had helped improve Iraq's Soviet-made Scud rockets, which have been used for attacks on Israel. The program also asserted that the German Government had given the companies financial guarantees for their work in Iraq. A Government spokesman said today that the guarantees were obtained under false pretenses.
In an interview to be published Thursday in Die Welt, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel described Bonn's efforts to control arms exports as "simply too weak."
An Israeli delegation is in Germany discussing details of a coming German military aid package. Newspaper reports published today said the Israelis had asked for $670 million in aid, including 2 submarines, 10 helicopters, batteries of Patriot and Hawk missiles, hand-held Stinger antiaircraft weapons, and serums for victims of anthrax and other poisons, as well as 100,000 gas masks.
